That's an issue.)For the tital role, Ezra Miller is actually a capable actor, but he choice to play Barry Allen as a kind of a jittery young nerd is a big step away from the source material of the comics (or the CW TV series). That approach didn't really appeal to me in Justice League (2017) where Flash was introduced, and ultimately it' s not much better here. On the plus side, the best part of Miller's work is that the two Barry Allens from the two timelines are side by side for almost the whole thing, and it's surprisingly convincing. You forget that they are the same person. The CGI team came up with a depiction of the 'Speed Force' realm that looks different from anything on screen before, though it doesn't make sense that Flash can sort of stop and look around at different alternate timelines seen all around him while time-travelling. I see this effect is now called the 'chronobowl'. OK, whatever.I think though there are two basic problems with the whole movie. One is just that it's coming late to the party. It's a kind of addendum to the Justice League world, but that was 6 years ago already and is now old news. By contrast, Aquaman (2018) followed JL almost immediately and benefitted from it. The second issue is just that Miller is really a character actor, not a lead-role actor. I constantly had the feeling that this was a misfit.I've rarely felt this conflicted about a movie. For Sasha Calle's sake alone I'd like to rate this whole thing higher than I did, but the rest of it -- the details have a kind of patchwork feel which I'd guess may be the result of too many years in development and being passed around through too many hands. The bits of humor often fall flat, and the details of the plot weave their way into kind of a mess. And I have to say that I thought Kara's fate was was ugly and disturbing, suggesting that we weren't supposed to view these alternate-timeline characters as anything more than paper dolls to be thrown away whenever they liked. I felt like we'd been sucker-punched. They gave her a strong introduction, built her up into a character of real stature who we care about, then just tossed her away. That's a kind of betrayal of trust with the audience. Finally there's a riot of cameo overload and callbacks from previous DC players that puts it so far into the meta realm that there's no recovery. But that's the essential problem with the multiverse: if anything can happen, who cares what happens? (to quote Gene Siskel.) It puts emotional distance between the viewer and the characters that feels a bit unsatisfying.Bottom line for me is, go to this to see Supergirl! Calle is the only one who comes out of this production with a well earned boost in profile, and I hope we get to see more of her, but I'm worried that we won't, unfortunately. DC has already walked away from Henry Cavill, maybe the best Superman ever. Now it feels like they're going to walk away from someone else who's also made a hit and would gladly continue if given the chance. I read that three different versions of the ending were filmed, with one of them where Kara and Keaton/Batman are alive and well back in Barry's 'original' timeline. That's the version I want to see.

title: Best DC film hands down
text: Took me forever to watch this because of bad reviews. Cannot believe I listened to anyone. If you've ever been a fan of DC films whether in this film universe or previous movies from the early 2000s, 90s and before, you're going to love this. Storyline is very intriguing and there's a fine balance of heartwarming story with comedy. Comedy is not overdone like the Marvel films. If DC can continue pumping out films like this, it'll easily beat marvel since that's obviously been saturated by lackluster films. People should just watch the movie and see for themselves. The cameos alone make the film amazing but the story, action scenes and characters really does make this one of the best comic films in the last decade.

title: Loved you first
text: Barry Allen(Miller, delivering what is required) realizes that if he travels back in time he might be able to save his mother's life.This movie has been in some stage of production for a very long time by now and it does show. It's impressive that it isn't way more of a mess. One thing that does come out looking bad though is the unfinished special effects. When this really hits the exact right tone, it is a tender, sweet examination of heroism and selflessness. There are times when even the fanservice and comic relief serve this end. I would say about half of the comedy does not land, but the strengths in the rest of it outweigh that. There is some truly amazing acting in this.I recommend this to big fans of DC Comic Book films. 7/10.

title: How does this garbage become one of the "best" movies, I don't get it!
text: How can such a garbage third-rate production, which hasn't even completed its special effects, dare to call itself a "masterpiece" or the "best"? I don't get it. I was deceived by the inflated ratings and ended up watching this film in the cinema. I was furious when I saw the poorly executed scenes of the super-speed force field. They had nothing, so they resorted to nostalgia by clumsily assembling CGI faces of actors from old movies. It's so vulgar and crude that it doesn't even bother to disguise itself. Setting aside the visuals, the character development and storyline lack any depth; it's all clichéd and formulaic. How can it be called the "best"? This movie is simply an insult to the words "film" and "cinema." How much money did they pay Tom Cruise for promotion? After all, it's a commercial world now, and the most important thing is to grab money. Once they've made their profit, what does it matter how it looks?

title: Finally DC hit the mark
text: Everyone is a critic. Especially Marvel fans super jealous that a DC movie is actually good. Do not listen to the Marvel fans throwing hate around and trying to squash this great movie.Flash is fun, supergirl rocks!, and the colliding worlds with awesome throwbacks are fantastic.If you are a true comic fan and understand the significance of this move, then just enjoy it! Love it and be super happy that we finally get some great DC action and great DC characters to watch.Bottom line, if you are a true comic fan this a great movie. Don't let the marvel fans that are sad that the franchise is in the toilet discourage you from seeing this fun movie.

title: Much Better than I Had Been Led to Believe
text: I wanted to write a lengthy review of the movie, but given there's already so much out there, here are my random thoughts on The Flash:The movie was legitimately funny, I laughed out loud multiple times.Michael Keaton's return as Batman was great. He wasn't playing another broken down, bitter old man, he was a recluse who made peace with his past and was happy to live in a world that no longer needed Batman.Supergirl was underutilized, but Calle's performance was good and the character was unique, not just Caville's Superman but a woman.The nostalgia was utilized well if a bit too much at times, but it never beats you over the head the way the latest Star Wars movies did.Miller as a person is very problematic, however their performance here, especially against "himself" as two different versions of Barry was really good.The special effects were really bad at times. They should have been more subtle and used their human actors where they could.The time travel/multiverse concept here was handled well and I loved the zoetrope time bubble concept, but this is where humans, not CGI, would have been better.The movie added layers to obvious story beats such as the reference to Back to the Future that also showed that things were different. This made telling the origin story not just a rote retelling of events.I read complaints that they overused the time travel aspect in the final battle to go back a few minutes and correct mistakes. They did it twice.The ending was hilarious, as was the post credit scene that didn't feel the need to set up another movie.John Francis Daley and Jonathan Goldstein have got a wild resume of big hits and misses. I've enjoyed all of their work and hope this doesn't hurt them.It's a real shame that this movie was a failure. For everything it doesn't do well, there's a lot to like and I was entertained the whole way through. I read the reviews and honestly feel like a lot of the criticism was overblown. It's well worth checking out even if it marks the end of the current DCEU.

title: A Flash of Brilliance Marred by Mediocre CGI
text: The Flash (2023)" is a film that brings together an interesting mix of old and new, with Ezra Miller and Michael Keaton delivering commendable performances. Miller, reprising his role as the Flash, brings a certain charm to the character, while Keaton's return as Batman is a nostalgic treat for fans of the older Batman films.The plot is engaging enough, revolving around Barry Allen using his super speed to change the past in an attempt to save his family. However, this creates a world without superheroes, forcing him to race for his life to save the future. While the storyline is intriguing, the script could have been tightened up to provide a more cohesive narrative.Unfortunately, the film is let down by the performance of the actress who played Supergirl. Her lack of facial expressions and robotic demeanor made her performance feel more akin to an AI NPC rather than a dynamic superhero.The biggest letdown, however, was the CGI. For a film that relies heavily on special effects, the quality of the CGI was surprisingly poor. The facial quality of the special guest stars was particularly disappointing, and the overall quality of the CGI was subpar, to say the least.Despite these drawbacks, "The Flash (2023)" manages to be a better film than it has any right to be. The performances of Miller and Keaton, coupled with an engaging plot, make it a worthwhile watch for fans of the superhero genre. However, the poor CGI and lackluster performance from Supergirl prevent it from reaching its full potential.Overall, I would give "The Flash (2023)" a 7 out of 10. It's a film that has its moments of brilliance, but is ultimately let down by subpar CGI and inconsistent performances.

title: Great story great film!
text: What a wonderful film I just watched! Every second of this film is very important and awesome. Ezra Miller is a perfect actor for this film. The Flash's costume is also cool. Sasha Calle, Michael Shannon, Ron Livingston, Maribel Verdú, Kiersey Clemons, Antje Traue and the legend Michael Keaton did the greatest job in this film. Ben Affleck's DCEU Batman's fighting and chasing with the Batcycle was the coolest scene I've ever seen on film. I have played Arkham Knight, so that's why I feel like it's a DLC for Arkham Knight. The multiverse concept of Flash was so realistic. The Flash is now my favourite film! Great job, Andy Muschietti!

title: Why is no one raving about Supergirl?
text: Yes, I understand why: because of Micheal Keaton (who was, of course, awesome), Ezra Miller (for many reasons), the CGI, and the fact that she didn't have that much screen time.I, however, would just like to take a moment to say that Sasha Calle did a PHENOMENAL job as Supergirl, and I sincerely hope that we'll get to see her take up the role again.Micheal Keaton did steal the show as Batman, and I could rave about him as well (he's my favorite Batman), but everyone else I think has already done that.I personally enjoy Ezra as The Flash, but can understand why others do not. There is one thing I would like to point out, though, about Barry being annoying: it was on purpose, and is even addressed in the movie. Older Barry blatantly yells at younger Barry for it.As for the CGI, it never even occurred to me that it was bad until someone else pointed it out to me. Some of the best movies ever made have bad CGI by today's standards (ie. The Terminator, and Ghostbusters), so I never really pay attention to it. I understand that because we do have the technology to make it better now, many are upset by it, but I also understand that it was done that way on purpose. I know for most viewers it didn't work out, but for me I guess it did.The movie was very thick on fan-service (which can be a negative for some people), but I am a huge DC fan, so I enjoyed that.The story wasn't spectacular by any means, but was still well-written and well-executed, although the ending was a bit up-in-the-air, leaving the viewer with questions. I suppose, though, that we all have questions about where DC is going (and maybe, if you're a DC fan like me, worries, too), so the ending leaves it open for those questions to be answered in future movies. I just hope the answers are good ones.

title: No speedster here, just a bad jokester
text: The Flash is such a disappointment.Someone at the top of DC and WB had all the resources available, a great story already written in the comics of Flashpoint Paradox and a great character developed already and instead of using them, using at least just a part of it at least they chose to went the "comedic" way and filled this film with SO MANY STUPID JOKES.SO. FREAKING. MANY.They probably saw a couple of marvel movies and thought "oh boy, it's obviously the jokes!!! They get more money because of them!!".The movie is longer than 2 hours and I bet you could cut at least 40 min of idiotic, cringy humor designed for 8 year old kids.As for the special effects, well they are SpEcIaL all right. They made the Flash look as if he was skating instead of running in the other 15min of useless scenes in which the characters floats above concrete in slow-mo instead of just running but at the same time he's going supper fast. It just feels and looks terrible. And the babies...Ugh!!! The freaking babies!....Anyway. I could rant a lot more but to be brief this movie is a solid 6. You can watch it to kill a few hours or entertaining your kids but that's it. No one will watch it twice and you won't miss anything by skipping it.

title: F YES
text: Ezra is essential here. Even if he doesn't look like Barry from comicbooks, he played as him in 120%. Yeah I know bad cgi, but who cares?! It's MF Flash after years of waiting. I love Barry, even have tatoo on my neck. Don't complain, just enjoy. About Ben as Batman he does his work well. This is very entertaimant movie. The only ones is Iris, dull character, and Barry mother, Nora is latino? The FFFF? Please stay with source material sometimes. It's not about racism, but true about material. That's why I gave 9 not 10. Don't push people to love other races. Just keep some original traces. Love U guys all :*

title: The End Of The Road
text: It's a fitting end to the DCEU, in the sense that it's an absolute mess (like most of the DCEU)! The script is just hands-down bad, and the only really redeeming qualities are Michael Keaton's Batman and Sasha Calle's Supergirl (both in terms of the performances, and the way the characters were written)Its got some pretty cool scenes, and there were some times that I got genuine chills, but it is lightyears from being a good movie. Like, when the use of the legendary theme from the 1989 Batman film was one of the best parts of it... That's not exactly greatI didn't even go in with high expectations, either. I was expecting something just alright (maybe like a 5/10), and the fact that it didn't even meet those relatively low expectations is just shockingHonestly, I just don't want to waste more time talking about it. I would say the only reasons to watch it would be Batman, Supergirl and just because it's the end of the DCEU. Other than that, it's not worth the time or money.

title: Well, there's Batman
text: Keaton is the only good thing about this movie. The Batcave looks fantastic. Then comes Ezra Miller and in the opening sequence he's even funny. Then he goes on and on with stupid jokes and after 20 minutes you have 2 of them. He's the main character of the movie and you just hate him for being so annoying. If only they could have cast Grant Gustin to give this movie a more serious note. It looks like they convinced Keaton to put the cape ( you know the real cape ) back on and then desperately looked for a plot. Also, they weren't able to cast Cavill, but they could have at least ask Brandon Routh or Tom Welling or even Dean Cain. Instead they cast some Girl as Kara. She's not as bad as Miller but she is just no Superman replacement. So the movie goes on and on and it seems to never end. A chaotic mess. They should have asked Tim Burton for advice. I love DC but they should stop trying to compete with Marvel. Of course you compare The Flash with No Way Home and it does not stand a chance at all. Huge Disappointment.

title: VFX might be bad. But, the movie was great.
text: Entertaining movie. Not a single second, when I felt bored. Better than most of the recent Marvel movies. Michael Keaton steals the show. Supergirl looked cool. Seems like a very good script which could not get enough budget. These days, no one wants to work hard on VFX. But, the action choreogrpahy was still very good.Entertaining movie. Not a single second, when I felt bored. Better than most of the recent Marvel movies. Michael Keaton steals the show. Supergirl looked cool. Seems like a very good script which could not get enough budget. These days, no one wants to work hard on VFX. But, the action choreogrpahy was still very good.

title: "You wanna get nuts? Let's get nuts"
text: Barry Allan uses the speed force to travel back in time and save his Mum. But on his return to the present timeline he gets knocked off course and finds himself stuck in an alternate timeline where Superman is not around to stop Zod's invasion of earth.I was not expecting much when I went in to watch The Flash, so I was pleasantly surprised when I walked out having enjoyed this so much! The Flash is sort of like the DCU's version of Avengers Endgame in that it references and rewrites various events from movies past... and not just recent movies either but ALL DC related films or shows going back to the 50s. The humour can be a bit on the nose at times, but there's also some genuine comedic observations about the other Justice League characters. Although the overall plot is quite emotionally heavy and deals with loss, grief and the role pain plays in our development as people, the story is told in a light and breezy way making it very easy to watch. Generally time travel storylines get very confusing, but the explanations given in this film are quite different to how other films deal with time travel and I found it slightly refreshing. It did start to get a little confusing right near the end with what was happening inside the time bubble thing and worlds were crashing into one another but outside of that small sequence, everything else made perfect sense to me. It was great to see Michael Keaton return to his role as Batman. There are a few other interesting faces that show up and events refrenced from movies past and I don't want to spoil it for others but it was fun pointing them all out. That was also the movies biggest let down. The CGI was generally alright I thought but the faces on the de-aged characters and the ones with actors whom have passed away looked noticeably fake. Not horrible, just not great either. I get they were trying to do a heartfelt homage to Reeves but the poor CGI made it look almost embarrassing. I also think the return of Zod was... underwhelming. I get Zod was not really that big of a part of the overall story anyway as it wasn't about him, but if you bring the original actor back then at least give him more to say and do!Final Verdict: Action packed, funny, emotional when it counts and just an all round easy watch. It does start to get a bit self-indulgent right towards the end, the CGI at times was iffy and the humour didn't always land but its one of the better DCU films in a long time! DC fans should love it.

title: Way better than expected!!
text:
I went to see Flash with a big fear that it would destroy my love for DC forever (The Batman almost succeeded).I was happily surprised that I actually liked it. Based on The Flashpoint (with a lot of changes), which I love as a comic album. Even tho they changed a lot I felt the tune of the comic in it.Ezra was not as bad as I thought, and I believe that a lot of hate towards his acting, is more about him as a person of camera, which I chose to not think of.Keaton was very good and I found myself sitting with a nostalgic smile a lot.The only actor I really didn't like in the casting was Iris. I found her very boring and not very engaging.In difference of many others, I actually liked the CGI in the running part too.Script wise:
I have to give it a little minus, since it felt that you should already know some of Barry's backstory. It's presented a bit rushed in the movie, and that can definitely create a feeling of being messy.But I liked it.It captures my emotions in different directions and I like that every DC movie doesn't have to be pitch black, just because The Dark Knight -trilogy became such a success.I like it, and I wish this universe would have got more movies!

title: An Insult to Your Eyes but Better than Expected
text: The last remnant of Zack Snyders comicbook debauchery, no way I'd have any expectation from it. Won't say I was pleasantly surprised but its better than I thought it'd be. The entire movie looks like it was made by little kids lemonade shop earning, an absolutely insult to people with eyes. Adding that to the bold and dimwitted excuse by the director for the story state of visuals, this could easily be the worst looking superhero movie of the 2000s. Because it really is just an excuse cooked up by a thirdrate hack with zero filmmaking knowledge who shouldnt be anywhere near the directors chair.The good surprise all came from Ezra Felon Miller, who I wasnt a fan of as Flash. But in some weird way he makes it work, which is astounding since there are two of them and the other one is an even more insufferable version of him. But both version work, their contrast and perspective and role reversals work. The additional treat was Michael Keaton back as Batman, not in all his glory but in the most Michael Keaton way as possible. The easter eggs from the '89 movie was peppered throughout, nostalgia bait or not it worked on me. The fight scenes were appalling and I swear this is the final time but the whole big battle in an empty field fight is the worst thing Ive seen in a superhero movie. Honestly I imagine the Morbius theatre looked more packed than this. Sasha Calle as Supergirl was decent enough but Ben Affleck and Gal Gadot just keeps getting worse as times go on. Ben Affleck is a terrible Batman and Bruce Wayne, he was only ever good in half of BVS, people need to wake up and see for what he is. The twist at the end was very neat and dare I say as a concept was better than the actual Flashpoint comics for me. Wont spoil but you'll understand when its revealed. And be sure that is high enough praise for me, when I say its better conceptwise than the actual comic that everyone loves.Ezra Miller carries the film, the nightmare opening act aside he was really solid. Esp in the more nuanced scenes injected with just enough emotion. Its a shame that both he and the concept was stuck inside a movie made by a D-grade moviemaker pretending to be a C-grade moviemaker. I literally have no respect for the director of this film, couldve really been quite good if made by someone with half a vision.RATING: 6/10(Was expecting a 2/10 movie)

title: Barry Allen Is: The Nutty Professor
text: The Good: Michael Keaton is an amazing actor, and after 30 years, all true fans got to see their Batman return. Every second of Kenton's screen time was well worth the wait. The time-travel-Butterfly Effect plot line is endearing, and the gravity of the situation was at times palpable.The Bad: Ezra Miller's Barry Allen is a Stooge - like the 4th, less funny of the Stooges. The goofy schtick was painful, and played out by 20 minutes into the 2+ hour film. For a character that is purported to be super smart, all of his screen time was spent showing us how dumb he really could be. Enter the multi-verse, and now viewers have to endure multiple Nutty Barry Allen's. It overshadows the Good.If I could dissect the elements into entirely separate films, I would say Michael Kenton's Batman / General Zod: B+ - Barry Allen / The Nutty Professor: D-. Mash the two together, it's an almost-watchable film, but really not worth the pain and suffering.

title: It's very hard to emphasize with characters when we clearly see that they are computer generated renditions of the actors.
text: Long before the premiere of 'THE FLASH' apparently there were rumors that DC producers were not happy with visual effects (CGI) on this rather mildly anticipated coming book adaptation. The audiences however heard that 71 years old Michael Keaton might be rephrasing his role as Batman, which made older generation very excited.Both rumors came true to fruition.Keaton indeed is a supporting character and CGI is as awful as early rumors anticipated.It's very hard to emphasize with characters when we clearly see that they are computer generated renditions of the actors. At this moment in development of filmmaking art there is clear distinction between video gaming and genuine film experience.This is why first 'MATRIX' is still considered one of the best movie of the genre, not only because of great concept and performances, but because visual fx created for the film (epecially "bullet time") are still being used to this day by other filmmakers. Then again we don't go to the cinema to see special fx. We normally want to escape in to the world of make believe and switch off our awareness of our own daily struggles and experience characters through medium of silver screen.But want if the lead actor isn't very convincing and although he has to perform two roles in the movie, should we be hard on him, or more understanding that perhaps having dual performance might simply be too difficult task for him/her. I feel Ezra Miller who reprised his role as Flash, tried to do his best, but simply behind the lines he speaks, there needs to be clear inner objectives, which actor attaches real inner emotions to, which in turn audience will feel on the emotional level.Sadly Ezra's dual performance (he also played a younger version of himself) lacks in this department.To be a 'Method' actor you don't have to be Daniel Day-Lewis and live for 6 months in the forest hunting, to be able to portray an Indian with conviction. It is about attaching some real inner objectives behind the dialog which actor is saying. And there are different approaches to internal method acting, some like Lee Strasberg will use emotional intelligence, other acting teachers like Stellar Adler will opt for imaginary stimulus, which triggers real emotional responses from the actor. Some external actors due to their thespian stage technique, might come very close to believability, however should we be hard on Ezra that the dual performances he given as the Flash feel forced and simply not real? I would say no...the technical task of performing two characters is simply very difficult technically and so even truly exceptional actors would have difficulty with this task.Perhaps the strongest aspect of this otherwise forgetful visual extravaganza is Sasha Calle who plays the SUPER-GIRL.With the background in her character she displays wonderful mixture of suppressed emotions, which are joy to observe. And of course having wonderful Micheal Keaton as supportive character brings depth and nostalgia to some who remember him in his prime.He still got it though in every sense of the word. THE FLASH' isn't awful, but specifically by the end it becomes very narratively messy indeed. And considering that the main plot evolves around son trying to safe his deceased mother, as someone with experience in this matter I was hoping to connect with material, sadly I felt like Ezra instead of feeling the actual emotions of grief, only pretended and technically let the tears follow on cue...and trust me, we know as the audience when you as the actor are honest in your emotions and when you technically force it, as it is in this case.I would love to recommend this one, but make sure you don't expect too much, especially by the end it resembles video game, which makes us switch of from drama which unfoldsf.

title: So Much Potential But Overall A Disappointment
text: They pulled out all the stops for this movie which should have led to global box office success-30 years worth of DC actor cameos and a lifetime of DC digital Actor cameos. But it couldn't overcome the negatives-the lead actor being average at best with enough baggage to sink the Titanic and EXTREMELY POOR CGI-possibly the worst ever in a big studio movie. The public criticism of the CGI was not overblown-action sequences resembled a video game and superb actors from recent DC movies seemed computer generated.Should you watch it? Absolutely for the decades of IP nostalgia. Should you pay for it? Absolutely not. Like most Warner Bros DC movies its flaws are too great. Action sequences resemble video games, it has a below average main actor plus a side cast with computer generated mouths or faces. Around 5ish Stars is pretty accurate.

title: Took a great storyline and made it average
text: I was really excited about the flash because flashpoint paradox was one of my favourite movies and obviously michael keaton reappearing as the batman was a cherry on too.However, i was bored throughout the movie. A couple of one liners here and there did make me laugh but overall it was executed so poorly. The overdid the whole nostalgia thing (felt like a desperate attempt to achieve what Spiderman no way home did).Also an unpopular opinion maybe, I don't really like this comedic theme in DC movies. DC's characters have so much depth which i feel like is overlooked in this DCEU. That's why i personally appreciated Matt Reeve's Batman more than any of the DCEU movies thus far.

title: So much nostalgia!
text: Overall-very entertaining movie! Our house enjoyed & loved all of the spot on previous Batman references among other nostalgic DC films, cheers to certain quotes made. Personally a little disappointed to not see Basinger or other leading ladies from the past. Looking forward to more. Disclaimer here-we don't judge on the personal lives of anyone in spotlight, there are places for that in judicial system & not arts or media hyperbole. We support MH/BH and/or victims. This is a failing of our system that, if anything actors highlight, but "the rest of us" have always dealt with & is sorely ignored, yet prominent more than ever. Hopeful solutions come out of this vs, dismissing bc there's A LOT of wor to do in this arena.

title: A missed opportunity for a good film, and a bad homage to Keaton
text:
What is good in this film?+ Michael Keaton
+ Michael Keaton !+ Michael Keaton !!!!+ a hommage to the 89' Batmobile
+ a hommage to Bat stuffes, the Batcave, some antagonists from the earlier DC movies
+ there are some good jokes ( 2-3 throughout the whole film)
+ there are references to unrealised DC film projects
+ the personal tragedy of Flash in his young age is represented well.(have You noticed that only the last one is connected to Flash in a movie called "Flash" ?)The negatives:
The plot goes nowhere. It builds up something, than let it go, without solution.Ezra Miller is not good enough lead.The plot is so bad, that it even cannot provide opportunity to Keaton to show, why we liked him soo much as Batman back in '89-'92. He simply cannt show why this character is interesting.And the whole thing looks like a mess, waisting the opportunity for the introduction of a proper multiverse.

title: Fun movie
text: "The Flash," starring Ezra Miller, delivers a captivating performance that breathes life into the iconic character. Miller's acting prowess shines, seamlessly blending humor with depth. The film's comedic elements are a delightful touch, providing moments of genuine laughter that enhance the overall viewing experience. The inclusion of surprise cameos adds an extra layer of excitement, creating a sense of nostalgia for fans. With its well-executed blend of humor, stellar performances, and unexpected twists, "The Flash" comes highly recommended for both comic book enthusiasts and casual moviegoers alike.

title: Had Potential to be great...but!
text: Almost based on the Flashpoint story line, this movie had the potential of being great. Characters were good, especially Keatons Batman (Should have played the Thomas Wayne Batman as per Flashpoint) and Supergirl was not long enough in the Movie. The distracting parts was Ezra Millers portrayal of a very obnoxious Barry Allen (both of them). But the ultimate killer of a movie that had great potential was the poor CGI. I can't stress how bad it was. Without exaggerating, it was on the same quality like the Scorpion King. It's shocking that a studio would have agreed to releasing it like that!!!

title: The Scarlet Speedster is dealing with his past
text: Oh, the poor DC cinematic Universe. She has already turned 10 years old, and probably only the lazy one did not scold her. A great start for Zack Snyder's "Man of Steel", a promising sequel and a team action movie "Justice League". A fan's dream that went awry. As a result, in 2023, the viewer has the long-awaited (actually not very) finale of the Snyder Universe and the subsequent restart after Andres Musketti's film "Flash". It is known that the film was redone several times, something was added, something was removed. It is not surprising that by the time of release, the picture approached with caution and a lot of potential problems. On top of everything else, attempts to somehow attract an audience after the announcement that the superhero team franchise would be relaunched seemed doomed to failure, as the fees showed. With a budget of $200 million, the film collected a little more than two hundred, turning out to be a failure. It seems hopeless, but everyone decides for himself.For me personally, this is a one-time movie. Yes, for one, but he still remembered positively in some moments. And the most important of them is the central theme of Barry Allen, the main character of the picture, a man who is trying to turn back time and bring back his mother who died many years ago. This is one of the central plots of the Flash hero in principle. And it's not bad that this theme was chosen for the solo album. And even though the implementation looks quite controversial, the film can't take away a good line of Flash's longing for the deceased mother. This grief became decisive for the young man, made him insecure, a little twitchy, funny and creepy, but still a kind person who, having received his superpowers, decides to fix everything at all costs. Longing and feelings of guilt are perfectly conveyed in the picture. Ezra Miller's performance is impressive in some moments, and meeting his mother in the finale is worth a lot. The creators approached the topic of son and mother with all responsibility, in my opinion, they conveyed the relationship of two very touchingly.The rest of the picture is trying to stand on a par with other blockbusters about DC superheroes, but it does not leave the feeling that everything that is happening is somehow local and does not have the scale that we saw in Snyder's films, Wonder Woman or Aquaman. Despite the great timing, in which there seems to have been enough time to reveal the characters, this does not happen. You do not get into the story of Supergirl, you are not impressed even by Michael Keaton's Batman, who was an excellent embodiment in Tim Burton's films. Yes, the fan service has been delivered, there are a lot of comic book stories here for fans, you will get to see a lot of cameos. But for a non-immersed viewer, this only breeds a bunch of questions, and the film is obliged, in my opinion, to avoid such by explaining and telling who is who in this story.The visual component leaves a lot of questions. Especially closer to the final. I have heard the creators' statements that a lot has been done as an attempt to show how Flash sees everything at super speed and so on, but I am inclined to believe that the guys simply did not master high-quality computer graphics. And of course it's a shame in 2023.Feelings are contradictory after viewing the picture. There is good humor, there is frankly bad. Plot moves do not cause strong emotions. As a separate picture, the film is probably not bad, but you will hardly want to watch it again. His main decoration for me personally, I repeat, was the theme of his son and mother, attempts to save the world of young Barry, who lost his family, and at the moment of an important choice, this guy becomes a responsible person who is ready to make an adult decision, understanding what it threatens him with.7 out of 10.

title: Difficult to watch
text: This movie was incredibly difficult to finish. Ezra Miller wasn't believable as Flash at all. The plot was okay. I mean copy and paste story they always tell for the flash but Ezra just makes it hard to even watch. That's before we get into the CGI looking like 2008 cut scene on an Xbox 360. You would have thought they learned their lesson with the terrible Green Lantern uniform CGI but I guess they didn't. Maybe one day we will get a Flash movie with a decent cast and story but not today. I honestly wouldn't waste your time watching this if you haven't seen it yet. Do yourself a favor and just watch the animated Flashpoint movie.

title: Different than expected still good.
text: Yeah, everybody mentions bad effects, but it's only half true, effects actually are good apart animated faces, but for me it wasn't jarring or impacting negatively the whole movie. Some people expect ultrarealistic animated face in every movie it seems, but i have to agree babies in one scene looked odd, but maybe it was for a better.So yeah i expected some epic story, but it was much more focused story on flash personally and his character development and it was a good thing.One of the best DC's movies i've seen and i actually liked, not just consumed it for fun.Have to add Supergirl was cool would love to see her in more DC movies.

title: Decent enough Film but far from what it should've been.
text: For a very long time now I've been very excited to watch the flash movie. The movie has gone through countless changes over the years and not all of them for the better.This production is interesting, at some points very impressive but at others absolutely horrifying.Despite Andres Muschiettis words that the flash is a Tribute to Zack Snyder and Ezra Miller saying that "No power or force in any known megaverse would or could ever erase Zack Snyder's mighty wrkz. You can take that quote. Take that to the bank, to the press, to the schools, to the military, to the other pillar of capitalism I'm forgetting cause of that thing where if you try to think of a group of things you always forget one of them" this still feels like a watered down version of what Snyder had in mind.That being said movie is decent enough "the performances are excellent Ezra Miller is the perfect choice to play the flash, Batfleck is the ultimate Batman but Keaton's performance oozes nostalgia and is very good, young Sasha Calle is brilliant easily becoming the perfect Supergirl (I must admit though that I'd rather have seen Henry Cavill as Kal El in this movie) and even Nicholas Cage in his 15 seconds on screen gave us goosebumps imagining what Superman Lives would have been like had Warner Bros not been so short sighted.The plot is the typical Flashpoint storyline with a few alterations. Once again one can't help but feel Snyder would have insisted on a more fleshed out story, this felt kinda paper thin at times. The CGI is definitely sub standard and no movie in the Zack Snyder era of the DCEU now the DCU was ever passed with such poor CGI. There are some very good emotional moments, lots of Nostalgia and performances Par-Excellence.It's a good movie but isn't everything it should've been. Perhaps I'm being overly judgemental here but I feel the constant changes in management and direction messed this movie up badly.Still it's worth a watch.Unfortunately I don't agree with Andres Muschietti Zack Snyder should definitely not watch this movie. Being the man he is im certain hel be polite enough and encouraging but deep down inside I'm absolutely certain he'd be disappointed in the end result.

title: A disgrace to the great character that is Barry Allen and a disgrace to superhero movies.
text: This is by far the worst installment in the DCEU as the script is too forced, the graphics are laughable and they missed out on a great opportunity by changing too much of the plot from the Flashpoint Paradox. Barry Allen is a fun, happy, sometimes awkward character... like a puppy! However, Ezra Miller and this script just make him uncomfortably awkward. The biggest issue with this movie is the graphics. His awkward running style is the least problematic of the CGI issues. The largest by far is that all the other characters in scenes where Flash is running or going back in time look like they were replaced with department store mannequins. This is laughable in all aspects. It makes sense that the DCEU is doing yet another reboot (scrapping all the actors) with all the bad PR surrounding DCEU actors and the monster flop that is Flash.

title: Brilliant and epic! Let's go fast and let's get nuts! 👍
text: We've now entered the DC multiverse. The story wasn't that bad. I noticed that there were a lot of negative reviews about this film. There was one scene in the film that everyone laughed at. There were funny moments in the film that I liked. There were also some sad moments but the action sequences were the ones that I enjoyed. The CGI and special effects were all right to see.It's great to see Michael Keaton return as Batman. He nearly stole the entire movie. It was just like watching a third and new installment to Tim Burton's film series but only with the Flash. The best of all was hearing Danny Elfman's theme song. There were references in the movie that the fans and I know about. Of course there were easter eggs and cameos that I saw so I won't spoil those in this review. The ending took me by surprise as well.I know that this film didn't make it to the top 10 box office success but there were a lot of positive reviews who liked this movie. I don't know why there are negative reviews hating this film. It was two hours long but that's what superhero films are for. I don't know what to expect for the next upcoming DCEU films in the future. So this is just a brilliant and entertaining superhero film to watch and I give a thumbs up.

title: This movie was actually really good!
text: Because of the hate this movie received, I decided not to watch it in theaters, but today after I knew tonight will be its last night, I bought a ticket, and Im really happy I did.The only thing that makes anyone hate it, is either Ezra Miller real life, or for some reason the hardcore comics fans who adore the animated movie "Flashpoint".Other than that the film is better than everything came out from Marvel after Endgame. Ezra Miller is a great actor, he delivered two different characters that after a while you will not believe they are the same person, he gave an amazing dramatic scene at the end of the movie. He can be whoever he wants in real life, but im not at court to judge him, as both Barrys and Flash he delivered good movie.Batman is giving me goosebumps every time he appears, specially his introduction kitchen scene. The movie is long but I wasn't bored.I really feel sad that this movie flopped on theatersAlthough CGI was bad, but this doesn't kill a movie if everything else was good.

title: It's not that bad nor is it that good--but it's a fun one!
text: "Not every problem has a solution. Sometimes, we just have to let go."The Flash is actually a pretty decent movie if you just wanna watch something that could entertain you with its laughable CGI, a fascinating story with depth, Sasha Calle as Supergirl, and the Batman cameos...and Nic Cage.It is a movie that I can sit through without ever being bored, so that's a plus for Andy Muschietti's massive directing. I loved the storyline of Flash/Barry Allen and his dynamic with his past self (and Bruce!). Truly what captivated me the most was Supergirl's introduction. Sasha Calle immediately hypnotizes you on-screen that every scene she has pulls you on the edge of your seat. She is entertaining and perhaps one of the most promising young actresses in the industry. I'm immediately hooked and cannot wait to see her in future projects.I loved the characters' dynamics and how Barry would sacrifice everything just to feel his mother's love again. A bittersweet story about the loss of a parent, the failed justice system, and a story about love.

title: IT'S A VERY GOOD CBM MOVIE
text: I didn't want to watch the movie at first because ifykyk, but it grasped my attention anyways. And I didn't regret watching this movie. It is action-packed, funny and emotional. Very colorful and the speed-force scene is very interesting and beautiful. Ezra Miller is actually good at portraying Barry Allen and the Flash. My only criticism is the CGI. There is some moments where I get too distracted by the obvious CGI. In summary, I recommend everyone to watch this movie because it's actually good, not the best but good. Stop boycotting the film and watch it before you give your opinion just because of the what Ezra Miller did in the past.

title: A Time-Traveling Adventure That Falls Short of Its Potential
text: The Flash (2023) is the 13th installment in the DC Extended Universe (DCEU) and stars Ezra Miller as Barry Allen, a young man who can move at superhuman speeds. The film is loosely based on the comic book storyline Flashpoint, in which Barry travels back in time to prevent his mother's death, but alters the timeline and creates a world without super heroes. He then has to team up with an older Bruce Wayne (Michael Keaton), a female version of Superman (Sasha Calle), and his alternate self (also Miller) to stop General Zod (Michael Shannon) from destroying the planet.The film has some positive aspects, such as the humor, the action sequences, and the performances of Miller, Keaton, and Calle. Miller brings a lot of charm and energy to his role, and his interactions with Keaton's grumpy Batman are fun to watch. Calle is also impressive as Supergirl, who has a tragic backstory and a fierce personality. The film also has some impressive visual effects, especially in the scenes where Barry uses his speed force powers.However, the film also has many flaws that prevent it from being a great superhero movie. The plot is convoluted and confusing, with too many characters and subplots that are not well-developed or explained. The film tries to cram in too much fan service and references to other DC properties, but they feel forced and unnecessary. The third act is especially disappointing, as it devolves into a generic CGI-fest with a bland villain and a predictable outcome. The film also suffers from some poor editing, pacing, and dialogue issues.Overall, The Flash (2023) is a mixed bag that will appeal to some fans of the character and the DCEU, but will also frustrate and disappoint others who expect more from a superhero movie. It is not a terrible film, but it is not a great one either. It is a mediocre film that could have been much better with a tighter script, a clearer vision, and more focus on its main character.

title: I had low expectations for this movie and it was worse than I imagined!!
text: I just don't know how DC could give us such a catastrophe of a movie. Visual Effects are the ties that bind us to superhero cinema and what we have here is so goofy that you cannot even look past it and enjoy yourself.Michael Keaton is the only reason I watch this film and his role did not disappoint. However, everything else should be thrown in the scrap heap and set on fire.Do not believe the hype train nor the inflated high ratings here. This movie sucks balls and I would like to have my time back DC.I recommend a cease and desist by DC on any future superhero endeavors if this will be the quality we can expect. If I could give a negative rating this movie would get -10.

title: Quite Possibly The Eyesore Of The Year
text: The 13th instalment in the DC Extended Universe also happens to be the one that's expected to wipe the slate clean by resetting the timeline & rebooting the stories so it can have a fresh start in the upcoming DC Universe. As forgettable as most entries have been in the DCEU so far, The Flash raises the bar on how visually hideous a blockbuster with $200 million production budget can look.Directed by Andy Muschietti (Mama & It), there are times when the story hits the right emotional beats but everything around it is so chaotic from the start that those moments never manage to strike the chord. Many of the callbacks & references to past films & characters are unnecessary to its own plot and all the superheroes reprising their roles appear much worse in this story than they ever did in their own films.The action has no build-up, excitement or escalation whatsoever, humour is often awfully timed, and the visual effects are all over the place, ranging from serviceable to inexcusably cartoonish whether it is rendering the backgrounds or focusing on the action unfolding in the forefront. The performances are mediocre at best and editing puts more emphasis on fan service than getting the basic storytelling fundamentals right.Overall, The Flash is visually abhorrent, emotionally vapid & creatively bankrupt from beginning to end and doesn't feature one memorable set piece worth investing into. The film had potential in its premise but it required a tightly-knitted narrative that's devoid of deviations & distractions instead of prioritising cameos & appearances that neither add to the film nor enrich the viewing experience by much. Quite possibly the eyesore of the year.

title: Dumb fun with bad cgi, but decent story.
text: Don't get me wrong, there were some pretty epic and cool things in the flash, but there was also some highly questionable stuff. I certainly didn't expect it to be quite so farcical, it was almost like a comedy caper, but it didn't step over the line like thor love and thunder did. The special effects were noticeably bad in a lot of places too. I'd say more bad cgi than good effects, but there were some good effects and the general vibe of the movie meant I didn't get offended by the bad cgi, I just sort of let it go. There was one particular bit that was so awesome I just.... I mean not awesome cool, but awesome that they did it. I don't want to say what it is, but people who follow rumours and memes will know. Its a throwback nod to something really old school.I definitely enjoyed it but I can't really rate it highly. I would recommend it for sure, it was a really fun movie, but be prepared some some annoying over the top humour thrown in there and try to be patient with that 😁

title: GO BIG or go home
text: For a first live-action Flash Movie, Andy Muschietti and his team really said, go big or go home. That exactly what this movie is, it doesn't follow the trend of the usual superhero origin story, but instead offered something spectacular. The opening scene got me hooked instantly with its bombastic sequence, the time travel fiasco and the emotional scene between Barry and his mother were also major highlights. I love that it felt comic-booky, lots of showcase of powers from the two Barry's and other super characters. And of course, Michael Keaton's Batman was the everything.Worth. The. Wait.

title: A fun interpretation of the Flash's main story
text: A fun interpretation of the Flash's main story complete with emotional heft and drama, but by focusing on it heavily, it relies on some knowledge of the wider DC universe to make the other elements gel. It starts off very silly but has some great scenes and action sequences, especially once the other superheroes have been introduced. The multiverse humour is good, although nowhere near as special as the Marvel offerings and Miller is good in his dual roles, as are his supporting cast. The pacing could have been better and some of the cast, especially the villain, don't get the depth they deserve, but as a Flash story, it serves its purpose and looked good.

title: It's a fully entertaining ride by DC
text:
Really it's been a while since I watched a great superhero movieThe Flash mixed the entertainment with a moral messagesA stunning visuals really you must watch on a huge screen to get the full entertainment rideAlso as usual The film got a lot of laughs, as well as dramatic scenesThis movie worth the watch, really i have to say that DC is more moral than MarvelDC world more wiser than Marvel
More mature than MarvelIf you love DC and The Flash character then definitely this movie is for you
If you don't love DC or The Flash character then this movie also for youIt's a real great entertainment ride whether you are a superhero movies fan or not.

title: Terrible
text: I'm a big DC fan, and so wanted this to be good, but it wasn't. If you want to see it wait till it's out on Redbox or HBO Max. The actings terrible, story predictable, and was so wishing they would have gone with a Christopher Nolan character development instead of what they went with.If you're a fan of Christian Bales Batman then you already know. So much cheese in this film you would think that you are in Wisconsin. Save your money and time and watch something you enjoy and already have seen, and if you do want to see this just because, wait for it to be released on DVD or on a streaming platform.

title: Very good movie
text: Very good movie it has it all! It's funny, it has great character action, memorable childhood actors, and it's a tribute to almost every actor that worked on DC movies, Superman, Batman and The Flash before 2000.The only thing that Grant Gustin's flash was missing but it had a superb villain General Zod and his companions from the movie Iron Man Superman (2013) and for Latin America they respected their original dubbing and that was a great detail!A great movie if you are DC fans you will enjoy it like never before! And if you are not a fan but you like good movies, I also recommend it! One of the best superhero movies of the year!

title: Smart, respectable, awesome.
text: It's rare for me to want to see a movie a 2nd time. It has everything you may want to see, from comedy, to drama, to high stakes. It has 2 Batmen and 2 Flash! And at least 2 Supermen! And it's an origin story for Flash, so that people who don't know how he got his powers, won't be left wondering! The origin is shown in an interesting and engaging way too. It has everything except dinosaurs!I think it's a genius detail how the story revolves around a can of tomatoes, and around spaghetti. Barry needs to eat to keep his speed, and this is shown. And that there are key points in time that can't be changed. And that Batman is more emotionally mature that Ironman since Batman realizes how bad time-traveling can get, and he wants to avoid it. And that Super Girl is weak compared to Superman and she can't defeat a soldier like Zod. (This was actually a complain in Man of Steel - how can a normal superman defeat a soldier superman? Well, this is addressed here)Something else I respect, is that nothing happens the first time they try it. Flash tests the time-travel before he embraces it. SuperGirl loses to Zod before she gets a second chance. Barry tries and retries on many occasions to get things right, like when he tries to regain his powers. This happened many times and I love it! (This is the movie's message. That sometimes, no matter how many times you can save and load your progress, the damage is done. Food for thought for those who blame themselves, thinking "what if I could have done this and that?")Even the cameos are well thought and respectable. We get to see that somewhere in the DC multiverse there's a Nick Cage Superman, that finally fights giant spiders! (For those who don't know, that movie project was abandoned and the producer wanted giant spiders so bad, that he added them in his next movie, Wild Wild West!). For those wanted to see more cameos.. come on, think of the pacing of the movie! Right now every cameo matters. Everything else would be shoehorned and badly received by the majority of the viewers.People complain about bad CGI. To me, it was fine. There are CGI for 90% of the movie and they don't use night-shots as an excuse to cover any flaws. Everything is shows during the day in a colorful and mostly cheerful manner. Also when Barry talks to his younger self, played by the same actor, while the camera moves in a dynamic way... that's seamless. The story is so gripping, it will make you forget about the CGI. (Most "bad" CGI is when Barry uses the speed-force, so in my head-canon, it's the speed-force that makes everything look a bit weird.)Even though I have seen many multiverse stories (Xmen, Avengers, Dr. Strange, CW Flash, even the animated Flashpoint), the story here feels fresh. I could say that this is the best multiverse movie I have ever seen, as I couldn't find any plot-holes. (Even the beloved Into The Spiderverse had a massive hole: the Kingpin wanted to change universes, but that doesn't make sense, since it is explained that you will degrade if you go to another universe!)Essentially, this DC multiverse has a smart fail-safe. They can't reuse timetravel often, because every time they do it, the universe is reset for good. The explanation is even better than Rick and Morty! And they even showed it in action since Flash tried over and over to fix something and fails. Very clever!For those who think that DC copied Marvel regarding the multiverse story. DC did it first in the comics, Marvel did it first in the movies. These 2 companies copy each other for over 50 years, but DC did most things first, as it had a 20 year head start. The Flash #123 from 1961and Justice League of America #21 from 1963, "Crisis on Earth One!" were the pioneers of this concept. Marvel Comics began in 1961 and their first multiverse story was "What If? #1" in 1977.I originally went to see the Flash with my biased glasses on. I don't like most DC movies but I love the DC animated universe (The only DC movies I really enjoyed were Batman '89, Shazam 1 and 2, and Aquaman). I didn't like the Snyderverse and I didn't like Ezra Miller as the Flash. All that said, Ezra Miller did well in this movie and as THEY play 2 roles... it helps getting behind the pronouns thingie!Some people may hate the movie because they hate Ezra Miller. The actions of one, should not be a punishment for everyone else who worked hard on a project. It is unfair to sacrifice the jobs and the future potential of hundreds of people involved in a production, just because of the hatred for single person. Besides, this was DC's only way to reboot their franchise.Flash is crazy awesome, go see it, go have fun!

title: Ezra Miller is the weak link along with some bad writing.
text: So Michael Keaton is great. As usual. Supergirl is good too. Even Iris is good and not annoying like the TV actress in the series. The writers were trying so hard to make a comic relief movie with some clever lines and humorous scenes and situations. Like Marvel has succeeded at with Iron Man and Guardians. They failed. I was embarrassed and uncomfortable for them. Truly bad. And that is just the surface. Ezra Miller was literally the worst thing in the movie. Trying so hard to be cute and funny. Not working. Pushing hard l, too hard, to be quirky and likeable. Was it him or the director? Maybe both. Just not happening. What was happening was a really annoying character getting more and more annoying as the film went on. DC has done some terrible casting in some of its movies. Like Affleck for Batman amidst literal petitions not to do it from fans.they should have seen from a screen test or first scene he needed to be replaced. The writing from DC has also been really bad and this movie is no exception. The opening sequence just starts the ball rolling with an unbelievably annoying scenario. BTW this review is irrespective of Ezra Miller's personal problems. He was just bad on his own merits as an actor in this film. As a main character it's enough to destroy a potentially salvageable story. I got through it merely due to laughing, not at the places laughs were intended, but in places where they weren't. If you want to laugh at a B movie level effort with TERRIBLE cgi (compared to what should be available at this budget) check it out but don't expect anything good from the lead.

title: Gone In A Flash
text: It is one of the better DC movies, which is not some groundreaking statement by itself. It's good, but it's not the "greatest comic book movie ever" like it was promoted for a few months and you gonna see it by yourself soon.Everyone is good in their roles, Ezra Miller, Sasha Calle, Michael Keaton....especially Keaton. I mean he got the scene stealers moments, alongside with Sasha Calle. Ben Affleck probably got the best few minutes as Batman and I mean better than everything he did in the past few of the movies, which is kinda shameful, because he deserved solo movie.The story as you can expect is much inspired by the Flashpoint comics, but there are some big changes of course. Most of the story progression feels fine. Everything with Barry and his mother and the scenes where Affleck's Batman is talking with Barry is great, the humor for me it's hit and miss, the same goes for the VFX.Props to Ezra Miller for portraying two irritating characters, making the younger Barry more irritating and the one we know kinda wiser. There are scenes when you can clearly see that one of the Flash characters it's not Ezra. It's the stunt double with blurred face or just VFX, but it's much noticeable. As a whole the desert scene it's kinda messy in my opinion talking about the effects.Good to see Michael Shannon back. Great actor in great character. Michael Keaton as I said bring the smile to your face every time if you're from the kids grown with his Batman. Sasha Calle is really good addition to the movie. In some scenes her eyes and facial expression just talk by themselves. Speaking about characters, there are some cameos, some of which I guess you already know, some not, I'm not gonna spoil anything, but will say that some feels earned, others just throw there. In the end it's fun, don't get me wrong.It is up there with "Man of Steel" and "The Suicide Squad" for the best DCEU movie. Like I said it's far from masterpiece, given that we watched "Across the Spider-Verse" so soon, it's like watching "Dungeons & Dragons" after "Inception", both enjoyable, but on a whole different level.Kudos to Andy Muschietti, the man who delivered this movie, after the project got a few other directors, was in works for decades, been in production, halted, rewritten and finally see the light of sun, or maybe I should say was hit by the bold of lightning.And yeah...there is a post credit scene, make of it what you want knowing the recent DC changes.

title: Good to see Ezra Miller have his own standalone movie as The Flash and a big welcome back to Michael Keaton as Batman/Bruce Wayne.
text: The Flash finally hits cinemas with Ezra Miller returning in the titular role after numerous delays with covid, change of directors, and post production problems. Despite being plagued with controversy after a number of run ins with the law, Ezra Miller makes a welcome return although I'm more used to Grant Gustin as The Flash on TV. Still Ezra Miller was good. If anything, I was more excited to see Michael Keaton return as an older Bruce Wayne/Batman having last appeared in Batman Returns (1992) before Val Kilmer took over the role for Batman Forever (1995).Barry Allen/The Flash (Ezra Miller) takes off where he left after Justice League (2017) working with Batman/Bruce Wayne (Ben Affleck) and Alfred (Jeremy Irons) to save the day by rescuing people and stopping the bad guys. Barry Allen is haunted by the murder of his mother (Maribel Verdu) and the false imprisonment of his father (Ron Livingston) from many years ago. Wanting to correct the past, Barry Allen as The Flash wants to reverse the timeline to save his mother from being killed. Though successful, events are altered with devastating consequences. Barry Allen somehow finds himself thrust into an alternate 2013 in which his parents are alive and through fate Barry runs into his younger self. Both Barry's end up having to team up after General Zod (Michael Shannon) declares war on earth. Trying to recreate the Justice League to stop the invasion, Barry seeks the help of a now reclusive Bruce Wayne (Michael Keaton) who has retired as Batman. Though in his 70's, Bruce Wayne returns to don the Batsuit to help Barry Allen/The Flash prevent General Zod's invasion. Along the way, they enlist the help of Supergirl (Sasha Calle).I never expected Ezra Miller to make a successful return as Barry Allen/The Flash. I do think this may be has last outing though, given that Warner Bros will be taking DC in another direction.I was very excited to see Michael Keaton return as Batman/Bruce Wayne and he certainly lived up to the hype. I grew up watching Michael Keaton as Batman in Batman (1989) and Batman Returns (1992). It was a shame Michael Keaton couldn't make another appearance given that he was meant to appear in the now cancelled Batgirl movie.Sasha Calle did well as Supergirl. I'm unsure that she was going to have her own standalone movie or make any other appearances but it doesn't appear likely.It was fantastic to see Michael Shannon reprise his role as General Zod from Man of Steel (2013). He just picked up where he left off and didn't miss a beat.Director Andy Muschetti did a fine job with The Flash and having the multiverse being brought to the big screen.I thought The Flash was a bit slow to start off but once it got going I enjoyed it. Though it doesn't rank as one of my favourites, The Flash was well worth watching and worth the wait.7/10.

title: A fantastic movie 10/10
text: Oh my God, what have I just watched? It was so enjoyable, thrilling, and dramatic. The movie had an excellent pace throughout, from the beginning, the middle, and all the way to the end. I was literally glued to the screen and mesmerized by the amazing visual effects. The movie had an excellent storyline, and I did not expect it to be this great. It's a fantastic movie that you and your family will love to watch repeatedly. This is one of those movies that you will want to watch over and over again. It's a wonderful film that deserves all the praise and accolades. It's my favorite movie of the year, and I would definitely give it a 10 out of 10 rating.

title: Mediocre Movie.
text: The Flash (2023) is a superhero movie based on the DC character of the same name, starring Ezra Miller as Barry Allen, a forensic scientist who gains super speed after being struck by lightning. In this movie, Barry uses his power to travel back in time and save his mother from being murdered, but this creates a world where General Zod has returned and there is no other hero to help him. He must team up with a retired Batman (Michael Keaton) and Supergirl (Sasha Calle), his alternate self from another dimension, to restore the timeline and stop Zod.The movie's strongest point is its cast, especially Miller and Keaton, who have great chemistry. Miller brings a lot of charm and humor to Barry, making him a likable and relatable character. Keaton steals every scene he is in as the grizzled and cynical Batman, who still has a spark of heroism in him. He also provides a link to the 1989 Batman film, which is one of the many references and Easter eggs that the movie offers to DC fans. Calle also gives an impressive performance as Supergirl, who has a tragic backstory and a fierce personality. She adds some diversity and female empowerment to the movie, which is otherwise dominated by male characters.The Flash is a mixed bag as a movie, with some strengths and some weaknesses. On the positive side, the movie is funny, fast-paced, and entertaining, with some impressive action sequences and visual effects. The movie also explores some interesting themes, such as the consequences of changing the past, the importance of family, and the concept of multiverse.The movie's weakest point is its plot, which is overly complicated and convoluted. It results in a lack of focus and coherence. The movie also suffers from some inconsistencies and plot holes that are hard to ignore.The movie also has some issues with its tone and style, which varies from scene to scene. The movie also has some uneven visual effects, which range from stunning and realistic to cartoonish and fake.The Flash is a decent but flawed superhero movie that offers some fun and excitement but also some confusion and disappointment. It is not the best or the worst DC movie in recent years, but somewhere in between. It may appeal to fans of the character or the genre, but it may also frustrate or bore others.

title: Can I get my time back please!!!
text: Thank god I did not waste money on this movie. Why make such a dumb movie? The best part was Micheal Keaton the rest was just sad. It was like watching a train wreck on the side of the road. I sat in the sidelines praying it would be over. Why was it so disjointed? Let's just stop the madness now and let DC die already like Marvel. Coffin slowly closes and get lowered into the ground with a slow progression of all the characters putting dirt on the coffin. Fade to a music montage as in screen reads the end. Please please don't make anymore of these movies. Next time I won't even bother to watch it on HBO.

title: Frankenstein.
text: Way better than I expected. Action sequences and visuals are good in general. Funny, both in action and dialogue which made the whole movie fun. Ben Affleck Batman was amazing, loved that he was rugged and not smooth in action. Old Bruce Wayne was good, Batman better than expected because I didn't like him from the trailers. Micheal seemed like a good blend of the two(Batman and bruce wayne), just old. The actors who played the role in my lifetime usually play one side notably better than the other. I didn't expect to like him, I thought he'd just be for those who grew up watching him but he was actually great.Loved super girl, I think she was a scene stealer and she's just as cool as I thought she was gonna be, it was great casting. I liked ezra miller too but she's the highlight for me. Idk how but I'd love to see more of her in the future.I think the first half of the movie was the better just because it's when the movie felt most put together and thought out. After that it's a bit touch and go, yet it still erred on the right side of the line but just about, just enough to be more than tolerable. On a side note I just want to say they were a lot of back camera shots of Flash were his butt stuck out for some reason. It feels unheeding to not mention it because it was notable.I loved each of the cameos, individually, done right but they were one too many especially in the third act. Love interest felt like an extra and didn't really do add much, I didn't think it was explored enough so this was one of the rare occasions I wished they just scrapped her off, at least as a love story.I think the story was decent enough, if you'd never seen a time travel movie before I'd say it's amazing but unfortunately it's a formulaic hence predictable story. I still enjoyed it though and loved that the movie seems to make it a point to let the inspirations to be known. The story also reminds me of Frankenstein monster, but is not horror in any way, it's fun and charming and it's unfortunate it comes out in somewhat no man's land, during the period after Snyder and before Gunn. I feel like it'll garner some hate because of it and split fans. It's hard not to make comparisons with mcu's Dr strange as they have very similar story arcs, Batman warning flash and dr strange warning Spider-Man; exploring the multiverse and changing realities.The pacing changes; it made sense to slow the plot down were instead of moving from one scene to the next, we get to see a little more of who the characters are and come to grips with the story which despite some complexity, I think was well told for the most part; but I wish the thrill went on and on. However I did love the dialogues, didn't feel lazily or hastily written.In the end I wouldn't dare to call The Flash a great superhero movie; it's very messy but it all somehow gels together and works (to me). It's a surprisingly fun because despite evidently being held together by a thread I still enjoyed the movie as a whole. It's always funny because I expect this to get a lot of hate, but everybody in the cinema, albeit in china, seemed to have a blast watching this. I think it's better if you go in wanting to enjoy it and not critic it.

title: What it takes
text: Call Marvel unchecked and shallow but what #ErzaMiller delivers as The Flash is remarkable.I find no dull minutes in this Hollywood blockbuster. The thrills and twists are in place thanks to #AndyMuschietti directions.The auditorium had been full we were all awe what happens next. But most of all it is those quieter moments that hold the picture together.I do not agree with the critics what more you can expect from movie summer tent pole.Special effects are state of the art. Supports are there to help the protagonist and it whoas. #MichaelKeaton does a magnificent job to reprise #Batman of 1989.In the end The Flash is the audience choice. You hate it or you love it.07/10.

title: A decent enough superhero film
text: Due to the events of Zack Snyder's Justice League, superhero and JL member Barry Allen is convinced he may have the ability to manipulate his Speed Force to travel back in time and prevent his mother's death and father's frame for it. When his attempt to save his family go awry and inadvertently changes the future, Barry becomes trapped in a timeline where Man of Steel's General Zod is on the precipice of conquering Earth. Utilizing the help of the Barry Allen from this dimension, as well that universe's Batman and Kryptonian, Barry is determined to set straight the tears in the fabric of reality that he himself has created.As far as superhero adaptations go, The Flash is a decent addition. After years of delays with the filming of the movie, saddled with the further baggage of the ill advised actions of its main actor, its end result is a great story hidden within a messy product. After the back-to-back box office failures of Black Adam and Shazam: Fury of the Gods, Warner Brothers looked to The Flash to be the big win that help end the Zack Snyder era while beginning to pave the way for a new regime in storytelling for DC Comics. Sadly, due to a bloated runtime and cripplingly bad visual effects, what could've been a resounding victory for the company ends up being a mid tier movie that fails to cash in on its potential. An interesting premise, a meditation on the fact that even with the greatest power people can't control everything in their lives, is often undercut by late 90s/early 2000s era GCI and oddly placed jokes. With cavalcade of cameos ranging from instantly recognizable to morsels for the fans, The Flash is a serviceable feather in the cap of franchise in the midst of a reorganization but nowhere near the successful product they'd hoped for.The Flash co-stars Michael Keaton and Sasha Calle as Batman and Supergirl, respectively. While seeing Keaton on screen suited up as The Bat again initially thrills, Keaton himself seems to be rarely present in the scene, delivering his lines without any real conviction or sense of purpose. The thrills mostly come from the recreation of the world Tim Burton and his crew directed (along with composer Benjamin Wallfisch's nods to Danny Elfman's score), with Wayne Manor's exterior shots draped in fog and its interior immediately reminiscent of the mansion's expansive room inside viewers came to love from the set design of the first two live action movies. Keaton's presence, while welcoming, is lethargic and lackluster, getting through his lines in order to collect his paycheck.Sasha Calle is the breakout star of the film. As Kara Zor-El, cousin of Superman's Kal-El, her entrance into the film gives the audience a much different look at her arrival on Earth. Harkening back to a well received comic book story of the early 2000s, once Superwoman is able to break out and let loose she dominates the screen with her quiet brooding nature that changes as the story unfolds. A delight to watch, Calle would be a worthy addition to James Gunn and Peter Safrin's upcoming DC reboot.Directed by Andy Muschietti, The Flash was a tall order from the beginning. After a veritably endless carousel of directors walking in and out of the chair, the It and It Chapter 2 helmsman was tasked with picking up the pieces of a number of different ideas and forging them into one unified vision. The end result is a flawed, yet entertaining movie that does a good job at balancing the action with the the character work. While the character work takes a bit of a back seat in the second act, the first and especially the third shows the viewer exactly who Barry Allen is, and the impact of his family on him. Pacing wise, the film wastes little time establishing his whereabouts since last seen in Zack Snyder's Justice League and the titular character attempting to justify to Bruce Wayne his intent to time travel. The story's second act, easily the weakest in the narrative, as well as being interminably long, loses the momentum gathered in the first before having to ramp back up to a fairly strong narrative conclusion. With General Zod being more of a side story than an actual plot device used to propel Barry's story forward, the confrontation between Flash, Zod, and Zod's troops serves as nothing more than a desperate clinging to what came before with Man of Steel.Overall, The Flash is a decent enough superhero film. While there's justifiable frustration at the fact that inside the over convoluted kitchen sink of a story lies a possibly great film waiting to be unearthed, the result the audience is left with is a passable one. It's main star, while being overshadowed by Michael Keaton and Sasha Calle, takes the best of what worked with the character in previous movies and finds ways to continue fleshing him out. A fun enough adventure that pales greatly in comparison to the other multiverse film released a mere two weeks ago, The Flash will likely be remembered more for its controversial lead actor than for the movie itself.

title: An absolute blast!
text: Outstanding Flash and DC movie.Great music, solid acting especially from Ezra playing 2 versions of the same person. Main Flash costume is great, looks amazing in action. Plenty of action scenes keeping you engaged and the humour lands for the most part. If you're a fan of The Flash character, the use of his speed and VFX are jaw dropping and the costume looks beautiful.
