Plenty of cool cameos to surprise the audience.CGI is wonky in some places and the pacing of the final act is a bit rushed, drops you straight into it unexpectedly unless you're a comic reader. Stakes don't feel high until right at the very end of the third act.Batfleck was not in this enough and the cameos are fully CGI which looks kinda weird.Shame Ezra is shrouded in controversy as they do such a good job here and it's an excellent movie it makes you want them to come back for more.It's an ode to Flash fans and comic readers, definitely going to watch this a second time in theatres!

title: UNIQUE AMBITIONOUS EPIC STORY DC IS BACK
text: Now the superhero movies are not good whether it's marval or dceu but DC is always at risk with their movies. We all know dceu is not successful as a universe . But wb make unique movies which are different from any other superhero movies like the Batman and rated r movies like joker and the suicide squad. The flash is a great multiverse movies it's accomplished things that NWH did not. Ezra Miller is great at playing Barry Allen Micheal keaten is MVP and Sasha calle is star. It is a great adaptation of flashpoint story and we'll executed . Cgi is bit issue but didn't take me out of the movie.

title: Not As Fast As the Speed of Light, But It's Still Damn Fast
text: Verdict: Vibrantly beautiful, this doppelganger-superhero showcases a compelling first act, enjoyable action sequences, a terrific performance by the fastest man alive and a powerful message about family, fate and consequences. However, The Flash gets progressively worse halfway through, becoming a muddled mess at the end.

title: James Gunn: The Flash is F'n Amazing!" - WTF?!?!?
text: James Gunn, the head of the DCU, was quoted before the release of this film:"Can I say one more thing? The Flash is F'n amazing. Like it's one of the best superhero movies I've ever seen. Andy Muschietti (Director) did an amazing job."Now I'm terrified for the future of the DCU. What was he watching. How low are his standards? Was he ordered by lawyers or his bosses to say that?If Gunn truly thinks this is one of the best superhero movies ever, then I have no faith that he can deliver on an entire franchise, much less one movie.The opening sequence was one of the most ridiculous, convoluted, poorly acted, terrible CGI, jumbled messes I've seen since, well, since the most recent Marvel movies.I thought Keaton's run again as Batman was fantastic. His acting, the Batplane and his story arc were all well done. But I took points away for Affleck's Batgirl, a soap opera Supergirl and Barry's stupid laugh. Keaton was the only redeeming thing about this movie.So bland acting, poor writing and storytelling, lathered in terrible CGI gives this a one star. Keaton, by himself, adds a second. And the future of the DCU in Gunn's hands makes me incredibly nervous.

title: One of the best superhero movies of all time!!
text: Aw this movie was phenomenal its a really touching heart wrenching story of letting things happen the way they should.....if you think this movie is a batman movie you're wrong!! Its a barry allen story at heart...very comedy very sensible and a very compelling story all together with a great execution made me say this is 'one of the best superhero movies of all time' the action scenes were wonderful and what a visual treat this movie was! Acting was blummin'incredible and straight out a comic book panel.......super girl was great the stakes were high and the main villian was menacing and well written.

title: Will DCU find its saving grace?"
text: Amidst tepid expectations and mixed opinions I had heard, I must say, I thoroughly enjoyed this film. It was a fun experience! While not an incredible masterpiece, the two-and-a-half hours flew by, thanks to a simple yet effective storyline. Surprisingly, amidst the Marvel competition, they managed to carve their own path in the Multiverse narrative.Reluctantly, I admit that Ezra Miller delivered a discreetly brilliant performance, and the chemistry between the two Barrys worked wonders. Kara's presence added an extra spark, but undoubtedly, Keaton's Batman stole the spotlight from everyone.The best outcome of this film would be the return of Keaton as Bruce in a Batman Beyond adaptation. However, let's address the mammoth in the room, the CGI. It's an ENORMOUS problem! It's genuinely terrifying! The initial sequence showcasing Flash's first mission gave me nightmares, and Barry's suit with its flashy lights resembled Reynolds' Green Lantern costume, albeit with a bit more conviction.Honestly, I have no idea where the Gunn universe will go from here. There's a single post-credit scene that was concealed from the press and early screenings, and unfortunately, it's horrendous! It might be the worst aspect of the entire film, and it would have been better if it hadn't been included!All in all, it exceeded my expectations, but it falls short of being the savior of the DC universe.

title: Not Bad
text: I enjoyed this movie more than I thought I would. Loved Michael Keaton's return as Batman. He actually was in a light mood with a bit of a sense of humor. Izra Miller was good in his role as The Flash, legal troubles aside, he played both dual roles of himself very well. I don't know about the girl who played Supergirl though, it just wasn't as strong. Maybe because it was little more than a cameo, and she didn't get to do much except tussle with some guards and Zod. The special effects weren't that great, but the story was well done, even though many people may have multi verse fatique. It was a lot of info to take in with cameos galore, but still fun. A solid 7. Above average in my book.

title: Best so far
text: For me DC have always been on the back foot because the films they have made up to this point have been pretty awful on the whole. It feels like they're trying to turn a tanker round but with this film they have got the ship at least going in the right direction. It's not perfect at all and it's too long by at least 30 minutes (they all seem to be too long) but this is a good, if not a great film. Bringing back Michael Keaton's Batman is a real master stroke, his addition adds gravitas and heart to the film. It doesn't feel rushed and rewritten a billion times like the others. Supergirl is a real revelation. I was left wanting to see way more of her. Tbh I'm not sold on Ezra Miller as Flash. He is fun and puts his all into it but as a main character he's too light and throw away so having the extra characters really helps. A big success with this film I felt was that they've finally got the flying right. It's more graceful than powerful and doesn't feel like you're watching a computer game. I was so excited to see this as I'm a huge Burton Batman fan and on the whole I found it entertaining and it also goes all out to please the fans (maybe a little too far) If you're a fan of DC and fed up with the mess of the 'Snyderverse' this should have something for you. Now it's time to get Superman right!

title: Speed. I am speed.
text: This is a really fun film - not a perfect one, but a very enjoyable watch. 'The flash' is packed full of colour, heart and of course speed. This guy is fast, like really fast and it's a joy to watch Barry Allen zip around in a storm of fiery lightning.As mentioned, this is not a perfect film - it's true that the CGI is poor in parts, and this can take you out of the experience, however in the vast majority of this film the visual effects are slick and clean. The big boss battle against general Zod's army was particularly striking and wonderfully backed by a rendition of 'salute your solutions' by The Raconteurs.I'd also like to praise the films tackling of 'time travel' and it's consequences. I won't go into detail but I thought it was note worthy to mention that this take on 'time travel' felt a lot more grounded than other films like Avengers Endgame (whose time travel appears to only have minor consequences and so lowers the stakes of the movie).Overall 'The Flash' is a great film to go and see with your friends, it has a little bit of everything (including Michael Keaton's Batman!!) and I was pleasantly surprised with how it all panned out.

title: Delivers a Fresh Take with Some Unfinished Flashes !!
text: After numerous delays and changes in direction, we finally witness one of our favorite superheroes taking the center stage in his own standalone film. However, it is important to note that a significant amount of the character's journey has occurred off-screen, making this perhaps not the ideal starting point for his saga. The narrative could benefit from further development to fully flesh out this character, making it a potential entry for movie 3 or 4 in his overall arc.Pros: While I won't delve too much into the story itself, I must say that the portrayal of Flash as a character remains true to his essence. The alterations attempted within the comic realm offer a fresh and intriguing retelling of the flashpoint storyline.Cons: The CGI falls short of completion, leaving certain visual elements feeling unfinished. Additionally, despite the heightened anticipation surrounding the cameos, I found them to be underwhelming and not worth the hype.I strongly recommend that viewers watch the Flashpoint animated movie alongside this film. It provides essential context and enhances the overall viewing experience.

title: Heart broken
text: I haven't been this excited to see a movie in a long time. I cried when I saw Michael Keaton in the suit again in the trailer. Sitting in the theater as The Flash started I got this terrible feeling in my gut. The sfx are god awful in this movie. Ezra Miller is an unwatchable cringe factory. He is a horrible flash. A terrible actor. He plays Ezra Miller, not The Flash. The worst depiction of a comic book character I think I've ever seen. I heard this movie had a ridiculous budget, 250 million or something. For that money you would think the cgi would be jaw dropping. It looked like a PS3 cut scene. The time travel effects are cartoonishly terrible. I was in shock. Super girl was ok. Zod was wasted. Keaton was ok but horribly written. Keaton's fight scenes were cool. Over all this movie was horrible. I'm absolutely crushed and demoralized. Don't think I'll return to the theater this summer.

title: Worth it for Keaton and affleck alone.
text: I saw a preview screening of this film and mostly enjoyed it. Call it nostalgia but I saw it for affleck and Keaton. If you think about the controversy surrounding Miller, he IS a good actor because he acts totally normal in this film. The movie ventures off course in the middle of the second act and early third act. It's like they forgot their original point/purpose. The movie did feel long that way. I hate to say it but one of the characters felt unnecessary. It's a good enough film but you feel its length for sure. It's too long. But it was funny. For someone not really into superhero movies it wasn't bad.

title: A cinematographic catastrophe
text:
In my opinion "The Flash" is a very very bad movie for many reasons:
There's something that I would save? Probably Micheal Keaton. He's a very good actor and he emanates charisma every time he's on the screen. But the character itself is a bit meh, mainly because he's a side character and so do not expect this big and deep character arc. But his Batman was good.To wrap up I report my initial thoughts right after coming out from the theater: "if someone asks me if I would prefer to re-watch The Flash or watch any other random movie, I'd probably roll the dices of the random choice". The Flash was very bad and surely all the production chaos was a big reason why it came out like this. However for those that are able to turn off the brain and enjoy some superhero action with very low expectations, it may be an enjoyable time. But if you don't fall in this category, please do yourself a favor, spare 2 hours of your life to do something more interesting. It will be worth it.

title: Inconstant in Pace, But A Flash Worth Catching
text:
LIKES:Comedy
-Very diverse, filled with a variety of styles for many to enjoy
-Much of It comes from Miller's selves and the interactions he has often with himself
-Keaton's delivery is spot on and adds elements that are very dry, but fun, feeling like the 90s
-An end credit scene that serves as one of my particular favorite funny moments, alongside some laughs in the fightingThe Sound Editing
-Made for theater quality, it feels like a live action comic book story.-Great blends of actions sounds make the world come to life, the scenes pop, and made me dance with delight at just how immersive it is.-Loved the fact music and sounds mixed well and were edited to stand out.-I could hear everyone talking, no low tone mumbling to require captions or blowing out my ear drums.The Emotional Aspect of The Story
-There are moments where the movie hits hard and helps really give character development.-Barry's story has a lot of emotional connections and I loved the hero's reflection through his eyes.-Those connections, that moral exploration, all was relevant to me and I appreciated the emotional moments that came especially at the end.-Several members in my theater were crying in my showing.The Visuals To Some Degree
-They created a world that is hard to make come to life outside of drawings, but they did some things very well.-I liked the new style of Flash running, part speed, spart slow motion, and part reference to cartoons as they went along.-I liked several of the action moments feeling legitimate and looking real, giving you that D. C. comic feel.-The lightning effects and vehicle moments excellently designed and still showing the details they can make when they put everything together.-Costumes and looks of the villains were impressive to me and do enjoy the details they paid attention to.-Animation mostly flow smoothly, impressive work for this bunch.The Action To Some Degree
-Primarily the opening and midpoint of the movie is my favorite section of action. Here, it's coordinated, creative, and good use of talents that make for exciting moments.-My favorite moments had a bit of edge with stakes, a fantastic fight that has theatrical flair, but mostly choreographed moments.-Loved the blending of comic book with the dark edge of DC in those moments, and in some cases adding an emotional finish that worked for me.The Acting Is Pretty Decent
-Calle did a great job as the edgy Supergirl. She has looks, the feel, and play an emotionally torn edge quite well to go with the dark edge of the movie. Sure, not your typical portrayal, but for the theme of this movie works.-Affleck is fine for when he shows up, but in the brief time, he's the same role he has played with a little more comedic presentation like Whedon had him do.-Miller is much of the film, but impressed with his acting skills still flourishing well. He plays the double role well, and he acts extraordinarily well with the others. Those emotional moments really bringing out his best, while his comedy shows his delivery talents for one-liners that made him famous.The Cinematography
-Brings about the various tones they want and gives you the real life comic edge
-Liked the dynamic movements and shots to give you a maximized outlook that D. C. does well to bring to life.-Enjoyed the unique shots to establish the world, but not lose focus of the moment.-Adds a bit of nostalgia factor in some of the ways when it came to the movie's references, action, and the mind bending concept of the multiverse in this series.Michael Keaton
-My favorite aspect, Keaton returns to the role of Batman with the grace and vibe we love to see in a movie.-I absolutely loved him reprising the role, felt like I returned to the 90s, but with a modern look, as he jumped back into the sarcasm he wielded well.-He takes the character and goes with it, acts so well with just about everyone, and gives me one of my favorite Batmen in the longest time. Absolutely the most balanced and best use of the character for me.DISLIKES:The Story Transitions
--Kind of weak, rushed, and trying to stuff a lot into one story, The Flash struggles to handle the non-emotional moments.-The concept of interacting with oneself becomes more comedic than impactful for me, and really only thrives at the end.-While the Supergirl component is mediocre and feels last minute, sort of thrown a bit extra to include the villain they chose.-Even the big bad thing at the beginning is a tad mediocre and almost forgotten, leading to weaker story elements for me.-Why not more references to some of the other story components given several of the other hints they dropped.-Felt very much like taking shortcuts at various points, perhaps a tad too much editing to fit the time limit, and it was still a bloated film.The Cameos To A Degree
-Most of the cameos are meh in my opinion. I can't say much for some of them, but they almost did nothing for me outside of a few laughs here and there.-Some of the cameos seemed forced and again some sort of calling card or overdone gimmick that I find little need for the story. Thus, I wasn't impressed and would have liked a few others to come into play.-Some of the nostalgia moments managed to help some of the factors, but I just wished I could have had better cameo inclusion.The Action To Another Extent
-Near the end, the fighting got more theatrical and less of the balance I like, leading to very stiff, overdramatic fighting.-It got lost in slow motion fighting sometimes, losing the elements I liked and the coordination, again, very shortcut feeling and boring.-And especially the big finish... it was okay, very bloated, mundane, and cheesy in my opinion, but helped by the emotional aspect of the story.Double Ezra Sometimes Annoying
-The double dynamic became a big focus of the movie, and it only worked for me at times.-The comedy got a bit too much for me, getting annoying, stale, and constantly bantering to bloat the film.-It's not that these growth weren't necessary, but just went too long and I would have liked a little more curbing to help use the time better in my opinion.-Ezra's quirks are fun at times, but again, others needed more moments to shine in order to maximize their inclusion.The Visuals Go Fake At Times/Ridiculous
-The movie's biggest meh for me, is some of the visuals and just what they can't still accomplish that other studios do better.-An opening scene shows one of these, going a tad too far for me to be impressed with the visuals, lost in the ridiculous nature of the scene.-In the time moments, these are fake and rough, needing a little more finesse to polish things up.-This happens several times and thus, WB still has some work to do to blow my mind with the consistent visuals that I've seen.The VERDICT:
The Flash is one of the better movies of this universe that I have enjoyed in a long time. It's fun, funny, collected, and does a lot of things in the 150 minute run-time. I think the emotional moments are touching, I think the character journey makes sense and is deeper than a lot of movies, and I think the movie has some better balance than I expected. Action wise it works on levels, with the hero for me being Keaton's who steals almost every scene with the direction they took and him making it come to life. But, the movie is very inconsistent, dropping quality and balance at times to fit something off for me. Near the end, the things I liked mostly burned away, and the speed of the movie rushed through things and dropped the action to more theatrical finishes. Not the worst thing, but, also not the best, alongside animation and character inclusion that still needed more finish and touch-ups. I guess a director's cut will come soon enough to rectify this, but... for now, my scores are:Action/Adventure/Fantasy: 7.5
Movie Overall: 7.0.

title: One of my favorite movies ever
text: This movie made me cry three times and laugh a number of times. I mean really cry. And it was very satisfying on so many levels. It is one of my favorite movies of all time. I really love it. I love the acting, the plot. The dialogue, the character development. Everything about this movie was perfect. I heard negative reviews about why this movie is bad and I just don't understand how. The thing that I don't like about DC comic movies is this gritty, dark atmosphere. Which this movie had too. I like the bright and glossy feel of the marvel movies. That's the only thing I wish that was different. The character development and extras were also amazing.

title: Enjoyed this way more than I was expecting
text: Just finished watching this and I can safely say that it's a thoroughly entertaining watch. Ezra Miller is great playing the two different Flash characters, the plot has a lot of heart and Warner Bros threw everything at this one in terms of their DC properties. Seeing Michael Keaton as Batman again gave me goosebumps and the nostalgia factor is dialled up to 11, but done right. I often find that action sequences can become quite repetitive and boring, but in The Flash they manage to pull them off without the film getting too bogged down with smashy crashy nonsense. An excellent entry in to the DCEU, more like this please.

title: Come On Barbie Let's Go Party
text: I feel conflicted about this film. On one hand I absolutely loved the barrage of surprise cameos, on the other I'm unsure if such expanded universe would survive. In all honesty I'm thoroughly entertained by the catastrophic battles, but was that the best glass-shattering effect a 3-billion-dollar production could depict? For one I absolutely loved the ground-breaking presence of Supergirl, yet should we pass on the red cape this soon after Henry's dismissal?Out of all superheroes whose dedications sprout from childhood trauma, Flash is the only one competent of trimming it, which poses him a much harder choice. Miller's portrayal of the "Barry"s is phenomenal, let along the controversy, at times a careless urchin while the next scene the poorest child forced to bereave himself. The story is good - after all it's based on one of the most evocative DC comic - and the ending is actually quite enticing. As an entertainment, The Flash is beyond decent, yet in terms of "changing the course of DCU", it just isn't enough.DC, you have renounced Snyder's Superman, you may do so with Batman, but can you please not take away his Wonder Woman? I seriously can't think of an actress capable of replacing Gal Gadot.

title: This was enough poor excuse by DC
text: Where the begin? The only good acting was Michael Keaton the forever true live physical Batman. Just look at his 89 & 91 portrayals. I will also say that the work for George Reeves and Christopher Reeve as well as as Helen Slater were incredibly realistic. If DC was trying to duplicate Dr Stranger's Multiverse. They failed spectacularly simply by not including any number the Arrowverse or Smallville shows. Then there's this pathetic excuse for a Barry Allen. No acting skills and well as a crappy looking suit. He was more suited for Impulse. To call him Barry wasn't just wrong but insane. Barry Allen the most powerful honorable super-speedster. Now I never claim to be a fan of DC Comics other than for the GLantern-Family Hawk-Family Bat-Family and of course the Flash-Family. To see this film made me die alittle inside. Barry Allen has always been my all time favorite DC character.

title: Don't support abusers
text: Ezra Miller is a known abuser! The fact that this movie was still allowed to happen after all that they have done is crazy. Shame on everyone that still pays to see this. Hopefully ezra will not be allowed to continue to be in dc films. Please look up what ezra has done and do not continue to support them in any of their past or future acting roles. The double standard of how they've been treated vs amber heard is whack. Honestly having this many issues with your cast should be a sign that you need to scrap your plans and start over. Again, please do not support anything that exra miller has been in.

title: They never left the studio
text: For a 200M USD production, you'd expect to watch great CGI and show pieces like the ones shown in the trailer, but this movie only stands out by its terrible effects that take you out of the immersion.The script is not very good either, filled with jokes every 5 min by the super annoying young Barry Allen. It feels like a montage of several reshoots that didn't quite fulfill a complete story. I was hoping to like this film, I was excited as I watched the trailer for the first time but it ultimately failed give a new beginning to the DCEU and it feels like it could have been so much better. I'm very disappointed.

title: Pathetic
text:
I left the cinema as he lost his tooth transferring his powers to his older self and leaving himself stuck in the past..
What a pathetic storyline and a lacklustre addition to the comic/movie world.. to be fair ... just as bad as the last marvel guardians of the galaxy.. if you can cone up with anything worth while, wait until you can.. I won't watch another flash or guardians of the galaxy film, they just lost a fan.The only reason I'm bothering with a review is because it was simply That Bad.Have they all just simply run out of ideas and just respin all the old stuff hoping we just gobble it up and smile.. do your job and invent something impressive, sure you get paid enoughFor it to get a 7.4 on here is BS
Save your money.

title: Good Fun Superhero Action
text: It's a real shame this movie isn't performing better at the Box Office. It's a lot of fun and I was never bored once in it's long run time. Ironically, if this movie was released in another timeline it would have been a smash hit.But we live in this timeline where Ezra's real life antics and a glut of Super Hero movies ( Good and mostly Bad lately ) has probably really hurt this fun film.After watching extremely negative reviews on Youtube, I was not expecting much, but being a life long Super Hero fan I thought I would give it a chance and I'm glad I did. Some of the FX don't look photo real and the young dude bro Barry Allen was a tad annoying but there are also moments of humour that had me smiling and laughing.Give it a chance, you might be pleasantly surprised.

title: There is nothing that could be much better than The Flash and that is the movie that we were not expecting.
text: Best comic book adaptation film ever.Dealing with changing the wrongs of the past and encountering problems, troubles that could haunt them for the rest of their lives.Going back and fixing the scars that made the characters who they are. Not only what they are.Dealing with and going back to their... pain, hurt, dread, love, and loss made the characters who they are. Not only what they are.Barry Allen transversing the timeline to alter the fate of the world, reversing the actions of the villains, restoring balance, liberating unforeseen allies, reshaping his own world of metahumans, and bringing back his family whatever it takes.

title: enjoyable movie despite flaws
text: Ezra Miller was good as the flash. I liked the chemistry between him and his younger self. It was an interesting concept to explore, what would it be like if you met a younger version of yourself? You would probably find yourself annoying. The humor for the most part was done well. The action scenes were enjoyable too.Michael Keaton was good as Batman. Seeing him kick ass was fun but I felt like there was no real reason to bring him back besides nostalgia bait. His character already had a story arc and it wasn't like the Andrew Garfield spiderman where he redeemed himself. At this point I am kind of bored of seeing Batman. It's a flash movie but they need batman to attract viewers.Supergirl was alright, she didn't really do much but she had some cool fight scenes. I would've liked to see her character have more development.The biggest problem with the movie is the CGI. I was expecting a multiple million dollar blockbuster would have better CGI. Some of the effects looked like PS5 graphics. Some scenes looked cartoonish. I'm not a big fan of how much CG they put on the Flash's suit. The whole multiverse/different timeline thing was a bit confusing and seemed like the writers didn't really defined clear rules of how it works but rather just used it as plot convenience so they don't have to explain much.

title: Fun, but needs better CGI
text: I was very excited to see The Flash as a massive Keaton/Batman fan. Lately, being excited to see a movie has usually left me disappointed and have to say the opening sequence left me worried. I like the 'fun' side of The Flash but it was borderline silly and the CGI was not good. I stuck with it and have to say it did bring me back in.Miller, setting aside all their off-screen issues, does a great job. In fact the whole cast, without exception give superb performances. Keaton's performance and his story were the highlight for me.Some multi super hero movies have felt like they're cramming in too much complex plot and end up being messy and confusing with a feeling of being overly long. But I felt The Flash did a great job of keeping it simple, considering it tackles time travel and multiverse.I like the dark stuff in DC, so I had to accept this was going to be more tongue in cheek and fun, just accept it don't think too much about technicalities or plot holes. It's supposed to be fun and it's multi-verse time travel - let's not get overly bogged down in 'well that wouldn't happen'Some of the CGI seemed unnecessary, so when it was bad I wonder why they bothered. Just keep it practical. My biggest criticism is the CGI - it risks taking you out of the film when it doesn't look good. But stay for the plot and the performances.

title: Good but not mind blowing
text: According to some this was supposed to be the best superhero movie ever made, I enjoyed it but I wouldn't class it as the GOAT, or anywhere near that status.I enjoyed seeing Michael Keaton as Batman again, it brought some childhood nostalgia along for the ride.Some of the action was good, but overall it was typical superhero action scenes nothing new.Now I have to keep writing, so I can post this comment. I had a hamburger for lunch today, but I start my diet this week. Michael Keaton is not the greatest Batman, but I'm sure he'd like my hamburgers. 39 characters to go, now 14, fourteen.

title: Dreadful
text: I don't know if this is Disney's influence, or just that the script writers are running out of idea, but this just feels like a poor rehash on the TV show. Some of the CGI, especially in the opening scenes with batman were so poor it looked like a game. The lead actor just doesn't carry the role well. I just could get past the first hour of this woeful film before giving up on it. I do not think anyone past the age of 40 could enjoy this movie as as it is simply so poor compared to so many movies that have gone before. It really feels like both DC and Marvel have past their best. I could not recommend this film to anyone.

title: A Perfect 10/10 Masterpiece in the DCEU
text: "The Flash" is an absolute masterpiece that surpasses all expectations and sets the bar high for superhero movies. This cinematic gem deserves nothing less than a perfect 10/10 rating or a full 5 stars. From start to finish, it flawlessly executes every aspect, leaving viewers in awe of its brilliance.Every scene in "The Flash" is a work of art. The visionary director's attention to detail and his ability to create breathtaking visuals is unparalleled. The movie immerses audiences in a stunningly realized world, where each frame is a visual feast for the eyes. From the electrifying action sequences to the mesmerizing use of slow-motion, every shot is meticulously crafted to perfection, creating an exhilarating and visually stunning experience.The actors in "The Flash" deliver performances that are nothing short of extraordinary. The casting team deserves applause for assembling a group of talented individuals who embody their characters with sheer perfection. The portrayal of Barry Allen by the lead actor is a revelation. He effortlessly captures the essence of the Scarlet Speedster, bringing depth, humor, and emotional resonance to the role. The supporting cast, including the portrayal of Iris West and the formidable antagonist, are equally remarkable, elevating the film to new heights.The story of "The Flash" is a triumph of storytelling. It weaves together elements of science fiction, action, and heartfelt moments seamlessly, creating a narrative that grips the audience from the very beginning. The plot is filled with twists, turns, and unexpected surprises that keep viewers on the edge of their seats. It's a testament to the screenwriter's skill that the film successfully balances thrilling superhero action with genuine emotional depth, resulting in a truly captivating experience.While "The Flash" excels in numerous aspects, it's worth noting that the CGI quality could be seen as its sole weakness. However, the film skillfully utilizes CGI as an essential tool for storytelling. The visual effects, despite their minor flaws, are a testament to the power of cutting-edge technology. They successfully blend with the live-action elements, contributing to the creation of a world that balances realism with a touch of fantasy. The visual effects team should be commended for their dedication and talent in executing even the most intricate and complex scenes with remarkable proficiency. Though the CGI may not be flawless throughout, its overall impact on the movie's narrative is commendable."The Flash" is a triumph in every sense of the word. It represents the pinnacle of superhero filmmaking, setting a new standard for excellence in the genre. From the superb direction to the exceptional performances, every aspect of this movie shines brightly. It is a cinematic experience that leaves an indelible mark on the viewer's soul, igniting a sense of wonder and joy.In conclusion, "The Flash" is an absolute masterpiece that deserves the highest praise. With its breathtaking visuals, stellar performances, and a captivating storyline, it stands as a shining example of what a superhero movie can achieve. It is a flawless piece of art that will be remembered for years to come. "The Flash" is not just a film-it's a cinematic triumph that deserves nothing less than a perfect 10/10 rating or a full 5 stars. Prepare to be blown away by its perfection.In addition, "The Flash" serves as a fitting transition from the previous era of the DCEU to the anticipated James Gunn era. While the tone of the film leans more towards a cheerful and light-hearted atmosphere compared to the visionary Zack Snyder's previous works, it does not undermine the significance and impact of the Snyderverse. Instead, "The Flash" embraces a refreshing approach that aligns with the evolving creative direction of the DCEU. It marks a promising new chapter for the franchise, injecting a sense of optimism and excitement for what lies ahead under James Gunn's stewardship.

title: Disappointed
text: As a long-time fan of both the Scarlet Speedster and superhero films in general, my excitement was palpable when I heard about the upcoming "Flash" movie. Anticipation was high, and expectations even higher, considering the potential of the character and the rich source material available. However, upon finally watching the movie, I was met with a sinking feeling of disappointment that echoed long after the credits rolled.One of the most glaring issues that plagued the film was its lackluster pacing. The narrative seemed to rush through crucial plot points without allowing the audience to fully grasp their significance. Scenes that required emotional depth were glossed over in favor of flashy action sequences, leaving character development hanging by a thread. The movie's breakneck speed was ironically fitting for a film centered around a speedster, but it ultimately detracted from the story's impact.Speaking of characters, the ensemble cast that had so much potential was squandered. Ezra Miller's portrayal of Barry Allen was endearing, but the script failed to explore the depths of his character. The emotional turmoil and personal struggles that make the Flash such a relatable and intriguing hero were brushed aside in favor of witty one-liners. Even the supporting characters like Iris West and Cyborg were given disappointingly little screen time, robbing them of the chance to truly shine.The villains, a crucial aspect of any superhero film, were equally lackluster. The film's decision to incorporate multiple antagonists seemed like a recipe for disaster from the start. Instead of allowing one villain to take center stage and truly challenge the Flash, the audience was bombarded with a confusing mishmash of motives and backstories. The potential complexity of these villains was sacrificed for convenience, resulting in a forgettable rogues' gallery that failed to leave a lasting impression.Visual effects and action sequences, while visually appealing, couldn't save the film from its narrative shortcomings. The relentless barrage of CGI-laden scenes often overshadowed the story's emotional beats, leaving me feeling detached from the characters' struggles. The movie seemed more concerned with showcasing its impressive visuals than with delivering a coherent and engaging plot.Another point of disappointment was the missed opportunity to explore the multiverse concept in depth. The film's title promised a journey through time and alternate realities, yet the execution felt superficial at best. The multiverse should have been a narrative playground, but instead, it became a convoluted mess that left me scratching my head rather than marveling at the possibilities.Perhaps the most disheartening aspect of the "Flash" movie was the squandering of potential. The character of Barry Allen is a fascinating one, with decades of comic book history to draw upon. The film could have delved into his personal struggles, his relationships, and his evolution as a hero. Instead, it settled for a shallow portrayal that failed to capture the essence of the Scarlet Speedster.In conclusion, the "Flash" movie left much to be desired. With its rushed pacing, underdeveloped characters, forgettable villains, and missed opportunities for narrative depth, it fell far short of what it could have been. As a fan of the source material and the superhero genre as a whole, it pains me to say that this film was a disappointment. Here's hoping that future adaptations will learn from these mistakes and give the Scarlet Speedster the treatment he truly deserves.

title: Coming from the Silver Age D.C. world this was a revelation.
text: I was a huge Flash comic fan during the Silver Age of D. C. comics. Also all the other D. C. comics. After I grew out of that juvenile age I lost it interest in comics. I've seen a few of the movies and TV revisions over the years. Some have been good, some not so much purely as self contained stories.I still am bemused that so many older people take comics (and their film representations) so seriously. The genre is escapism, fantasy, imaginative story telling. Not heavy, deep mythos with existential meaning or depth psychology archetypal symbology. Taken as such is a facile shortcut to a deeper philosophical understanding of the patient subject matter.Of course, comic and script writers have posed as mythologist, but the results are often shallow and superficial. And treating these comic and film writers as more than financially motivated story tellers is simplistic. No doubt they do their best and have pride in their work. But the intent is to sell.The comic derived films are best as pure entertainment. As much as the Indiana Jones type franchises. Reading reviews here, so many are obsessed with connecting the dots between all the other comic and film iterations of these characters and their previous stories. A pure linear, analytical approach. And nit picking at the technical minutiae of the presentation rather than focus on the evolving action as it embodies the story arc. If a visual glitch or blurred image detracts too much then you have lost focus on the story.A captivating story should be enjoyable as it is shown not in how it does or doesn't relate to other stories and characters of the same franchise 'multiverse.'I think that the movie taken as such in isolation was good. Not great. It got bogged down too much with quasi scientific babble intended to connect the dots with other iterations of the franchise. Meant purely to satisfy the hard core comic fans of the franchise.There were some interesting twists and unexpected plot turns. The comedy element was ok but maybe overdone. Having two Flash characters at the same time interacting and with opposite personalities was a clever premise, and the transition from slacker Barry to responsible Flash was a solid plot point.The Batman story and the rationale for the team up was set up solidly. But the Lebowski-esque Bruce Wayne suddenly reverting back into the grim crime fighter was overdoing the credibility of the idea.Maybe I'm way out of the loop. But what happened to Kryptonite? How was the imprisoned Kryptonian girl kept enslaved? That vulnerability had always been a critical element in the Superman/Kryptonian stories. .The family dynamics storyline grounded the movie, but seemed a little too soap opera-ish.I was entertained enough watching the movie on it's own without having to check off how it did or didn't conform to franchise criteria. Obviously the multiple Batman actors and clips of previous Superman and other franchise actors was intended to close the multiverse loop. I think it did so adequately enough, though possibly it could have been done a bit longer.I still have hundreds of vintage D. C. Silver Age comics. I would love to see an authentic recreation of that part of the multi verse. Not as retroactively re-envisioned, with a ton of revisionist political correctness. Just the pure imaginative stories and characters living authentically in their own era. Without the compelling urgency to make them 'relevant' to whatever demographic is chosen to be the target audience.To me, these comic adaptations are taken way too seriously. Too much emotional investment and commitment to the comic genre, looking for purity and conformity and evaluating the movie based on those criteria.

title: It was Surprisingly good
text: I actually enjoyed it the acting was good the cameos are amazing and the cgi wasn't at the level required for such a film but the story bring me back to Snyder justice league world and it was amazing watching all of that.I actually enjoyed it the acting was good the cameos are amazing and the cgi wasn't at the level required for such a film but the story bring me back to Snyder justice league world and it was amazing watching all of that.I actually enjoyed it the acting was good the cameos are amazing and the cgi wasn't at the level required for such a film but the story bring me back to Snyder justice league world and it was amazing watching all of that.

title: Fun, refreshing but with some refinement pending
text: I definitely think it's one of, if not the best work in the DCU right now. The story is entertaining and while the base of everything is not something you've never seen before, or aren't at all familiar with, it works very well to tell a very compelling story in a fun and slightly refreshing way. The characters are likable on their own and even more together. I do have to add some of the visual work could be better for a film of that rank and specially competing with some other recent films in the same genre, but where the visuals may lack in some areas, they are jaw dropping in others. Overall a good experience and a definite recommend for any fan of old, recent and new DC films and series.

title: Ezra got annoying, Keaton made it watchable
text: Whatever you think of his trans issues, two Ezra Millers for the price of one really does grate after awhile; not enough vocal variation between him and his past self, way too many 'wide eyed, wide mouth' expressions. The CGI was dodgy, though I did like the circular proscenium way of presenting the multi verse. Only the return of Michael Keaton as the Batman of my lost teen years (and a few minutes of Gal Gadot as WW) made it worthwhile, and even he couldn't do much with the needed another draft script. Even Ben Affleck seemed tired as the regular universe Batman. Saw it twice, that's enough.

title: A DC fan's dream!
text: I say this as fan, this movie is a love letter to us. Andy Muschietti knows what he is doing.The movie is technically an adaption of Flashpoint but the DC film equivalent with lots of callbacks to not just the DCEU but the entire history of DC on film! Also the movie finally makes it clear which JL is canon, it's ZSJL!The cast are all phenomenal, Ezra Miller despite their allegations carries this film and delivers a career best performance that is not only engaging but also emotional. Michael Keaton is as great as ever here and arguably even better than in the original Burton films. Sasha Calle's role is small but she is good in the role and I can see her playing the character in future if given the chance.Overall as a DC and a Flash fan the movie really satisfied me!I recommend seeing it on the biggest screen possible!

title: What movie did you see???
text: I'm very confused. I saw Flash Thursday night. Horrible CGI, bad attempts at jokes, dialogue that shows a shocking lack of self awareness, "plot" & tone all over the place. Where is this masterpiece you all saw? It was great to see Keaton as Batman again, Supergirl was awesome (for the little she was there), and Barry's moments with his mom were good. Those positives are why it has a 5/10. The cameo montage was hit & miss, though the best one was spoiled by the director. Unfortunately it ends on a head scratching cameo. Who the hell asked for that??? The "twist" was obvious if you know anything about Flash. Especially since the TV show did that particular villain.

title: May be the greatest (2nd) "comic book" movie of all time..
text: PLEASE NO SPOILERS! Do not destroy your experience by reading spoilers.. simply put: This ranks up there with THE DARK KNIGHT. It's a masterpiece and if this is DC with Gunn at the helm then by god the future will be amazing. Go see it. Don't spoil yourself. Go in and let yourself be moved and captured and have yourself a "magic" moment only possible in the movies :) Don't you owe yourself that much at least? The Flash delivers on everything on my mama and is as good as the greatest movie of all time (imo) The Dark Knight! We've been spoiled by having the animated spidey and the flash released side by side and both are a treat for sure. Go and enjoy it folks! It is worth it. Simply, wow.

title: Worst superhero movie I've ever seen.
text: The Flash has to be the worst superhero movie that I've ever seen, and I've seen them all. It's worse than anything Marvel has put out in the last few years and even worse than that horrible Fantastic Four reboot that came out a few years ago. Ezra Miller has got to be one of the most annoying people on screen, I don't know how he gets any acting gigs. He runs like a gimp and his voice is one of the most squeaky annoying voices I've ever heard. All the secondary characters are just as annoying. Effects aren't great storys not great and bad casting. The Batmans' bring a little bit to the movie but not enough to save this thing, it should have been canceled just like Batgirl was. Save your money, do not pay to watch this movie. Don't even watch it for free, you can do anything else with two and a half hours of your time.

title: Highly recommended! I will watch again next weekend!
text: I have just finished watching the movie with my family. The movie is amazing, emotional, and full of action.What impressed me the most is the storyline. I don't want to give spoilers here, so I can just say that the storyline truly made me laugh at first, and then it made me cry in the end. It's about family love, the torment of loss in the past, and the need for appreciation of what we have at present. It truly touched my heart.The action scenes are very cool. I love the fast-moving scenes of Flash the most.In summary, I highly recommend watching this movie. I will watch again next weekend.

title: Entertaining
text: After some long delays and many obstacles finally The Flash released on big screen , but wrong time . Relatable that most of us would've thought changing our past , same here Barry Allen aka Flash trying to change his past and what are the consequences he faced . After some great multiverse stuff from hollywood like No way home , Everything Everywhere All At Once and recently Across the Spiderverse really made this film bit less exciting despite good plot and decent narration . Major drawback here was horrible VFX and CGI work literally delivered a poor experience . Return of Michael Keaton's Batman were really exciting . Expected more from Supergirl but they underused her . Ezra Miller as The Flash delivered a good performance .Overall , movie had potential to be great but falls under good and worth watchable . If you can digest the poor VFX and CGI work then give it a try .

title: One of the better DC movies
text: The Flash is a DC movie not the series on the CW with Erza Miller who played Barry Allen as the Flash. Barry uses his powers to travel back in time to try to save his family but ends up in a timeline that has no super heroes. General Zod (Michael Shannon) returns to face Flash, Batman (Michael Keaton), and Supergirl (Sasha Calle). In the current timeline the Flash is told by Ben Affleck's Batman not to mess with the timeline but he immaturely does not listen. Henry Cavill, Jeremy Irons and Gal Gadot have brief cameos one last time since James Gunn is taking over the DC Universe. I believe he is one of the reasons why the movie failed at the box office, besides that it took too long since it was released from production costing the studio way more than anticipated to the point that they had to put the attention on Keaton because of Miller's bad public relations. Ron Livingston and Maribel Verdu played Barry's parents in both timelines. I personally liked the movie, I could care less about Miller, but seeing Keaton as Batman was well worth it. The movie didn't have the best CGI but having to see George Reeves, Helen Slater, Adam West, and Christopher Reeve along with Nicholas Cage at the Flashpoint was well worth the price of admission. I would say this was one of the better DC movies released lately. Loved the twist at the end but don't bother sitting through the credits, the end scene was pointless.

title: One of the best DC movies (even better than some of the Marvel ones).
text: The movie was great, I don't usually enjoy DC movies, but this one must be one of the best ( even better than some of the Marvel ones). I understand that the Ezra Miller off screen controversy, and people boycotting the movie for those reason and the Snyder, Gunn issues (recasting of Superman blah blah) and then you have the fans of the Flash series wanting Grant Gustin as the Flash (tbh so did I, as I have seen all the seasons and was not going to watch it if Gustin was not in it). I did go and watch it with my son with the view that I won't like it but boy was I wrong, it's a great movie with top performances all around, and the icing on the cake was Michael Keaton's batman. I highly recommend trying to put all issues off screen to the side and watching the movie, as it would be a real shame it does not get the credit I'd deserves due to outside influences, don't listen to the noise go experience for yourselves!

title: Fun enough
text:
Fun and entertaining enough for spending 2hrs + in cinema,
batman is stunning like always, he gave big credit to movie but unfortunately superwoman is boring and stupid.Flash has comic character so if we have two flashes which we do, the comedy must be double then before, in this case also, movie let me down too, i smiled sometimes but nothing so funny happened.This movie can be end of justice circle ( i know some still left ) but dc and warner have to get chill and write great scripts for upcoming superheroes movies otherwise we can see more disasters like wonder women 1984 .Go watch it in cinemas while you can :)

title: Better than Black Adam and Shazam 2
text: The Flash is an entertaining movie with some notable pros and cons. Michael Keaton's return as Batman is a highlight of the film, bringing a mature and experienced take on the iconic hero. Ezra Miller is another standout as the grown-up Flash, effectively conveying the character's geeky charm and quick-wittedness. The music is also commendable, adding to the film's overall tone.The pacing of The Flash is well done, ensuring that the story moves along at an engaging speed without feeling too rushed or bogged down. That said, there are some negatives worth noting. The Other Barry Allen character can be frustratingly annoying, detracting from the overall experience. Not all of the humor works either, though it's not a major focus of the film.The action scenes revolving around Batman are mostly created using CGI, which can sometimes feel less impactful than practical effects. However, given Michael Keaton's age, it's understandable why this choice was made.Overall, The Flash earns a 6.5/10 score. Despite its flaws, it remains an enjoyable film that fans of the superhero genre may appreciate. If nothing else, it's worth seeing Michael Keaton's return as Batman.

title: We're not meant to fix them.
text: The Flash is a lighthearted popcorn fest of feet up reclining relaxation which is far from the serious world we live in. A big chuck of the audience will probably like it and there will be others who will probably just see another average forgettable film. I'm with the later on this, although it isn't totally void from the memory box due to the nostalgia of Michael Keaton returning as the dark knight. I'd say it's more colourful and kid friendly type of superhero film in comparison to the recent film 'The Batman'. Weirdly this film excels best bang in the middle where Barry Allen (Ezra Miller) must locate The Batman of a different time line, a Batman of age from Tim Burtons 89 Batman film. It opens with outstanding cinematography where the Flash is contacted by Bruce Wayne (Ben Affleck) asking for Barry's assistance on a mission. Using slow motion to clarify the speed of The flash as if time stood still, some effective shots are displayed although they are of course very far fetched for humorous purposes . Juxtaposed we have Ben Affleck's Batman on a bat pod similar to what we saw in Nolan's movies chasing down some goons with again immaculate shots of the highest level.Ezra Miller despite having much controversy surrounding his personal life evokes the role showing his potential conveying two different personas. It's the Ezra Miller show alongside (Michael Keaton) that keeps the viewer fully engaged. Later on we get (Sasha Calle) and (Michael Shannon) returning as General Zod (Man of Steel) however neither seem to get the amount of screen time they need to make any real impact on the picture. The opportunity to explore alternate DC universe films is an interesting concept with the highly recognised Christopher Reeves having acknowledgement, as well as Superman projects that never got past development stages such as Tim Burtons version of what would've been a Nicolas Cage Superman. Ultimately this is a film about Barry Allen though and focuses on his journey to go back in time and save his mother. The main villain is never really the obstacle Barry has to overcome, instead his biggest enemy is himself.The script has moments of heartfelt emotion although many of the jokes feel awkward at times to me and rather forced; yes comedy is the most difficult genre when trying to please a wide range of audience members. Like most comic book movies as of late the end feels rather dragged out bringing an epic battle that outstayed its welcome. With endless video game like lives The Flash is able to go back again and again leaving a rather messy script carrying very little weight, meaning or even point to it! All in all the point of it all is in the tagline to an extent, "some things aren't meant to be fixed!" Yet this feature is far from flawless leaving me thinking if only Andy Muschietti had a little more time to work on the ending and finally fix what he started.

title: Had a great time watching this movie
text: I won't give any spoilers away, will just say I greatly enjoyed this movie. Its a shame it didnt do better at the box office as it was a very solid movie. I guess its a better watch if your a fan of the superhero movies.On the positives Ezra Miller is really good as the Flash. I've heard he has some baggage and outside issues, but he is very likable in this role and a fine young actor. It is a treat seeing the cameos, and I was really happy seeing Michael Keaton returning as Batman.The only negative I have is that this whole Metaverse thing was done already in Spiderman no way home. There is no escaping the fact that this seems very much like the Marvel version of that. I greatly enjoyed No way home so for me thats not a bad thing, but in terms of originality this isn't a first. Well in truth most all Superhero movies kind of play off others. Spiderman wasn't the most original concept either.So all in all I felt it was a highly entertaining watch. I enjoyed it a lot. It is definitely worth a watch.

title: A good flash debut
text:
_watched_: It is a good one with a decent story. Do not why people disliked it (referring to the early box-office-bomb reviews). There are some loopholes when coming towards the end of the movie, but despite that it is a good entertainer.The point for which the villian sacrifices himself for the greater good did not look very convincing, in the climax. The action sequences are awesome. Suddenly once batfflek stopped being batflflek, he started looking good & is being missed. This also happened when Christian
bale hanged the cape. And also liked the cameo of Superman they put in. Overall it felt like a good movie.

title: Great movie.
text: It was a fantastic movie. The best from DC so far. I wish there would have been more Affleck. Keaton was absolutely amazing and I wish there were someway for him to appear as Batman again. My son loved it and hasn't stopped digging into into the mythology of The Flash since the movie ended. I'm really looking forward to what DC has up their sleeve with future projects especially if they are this entertaining. Without a doubt the best part of the movie was Michael Keaton. I haven't been a huge fan of Miller's Barry but this was the most likeable I've seen him yet. The pacing was great. May have to go see it again.

title: Expected to hate it but had a great time instead
text: I'd heard all the bad things about this movie. I went into it expecting the worst. What I got was one of the funniest, fun superhero films I've ever seen.Now I won't lie. The film does have issues. The special effects are kind of weird. The story was a little messy. Some parts are unintentionally hilarious. Though what surprised me is I was laughing with the movie far more than I was laughing at it. A lot of the comedy was intentionally hilarious. They should have advertised the comedy more. It's by far the best element. I'm so used to the comedy in superhero films being lame and distracting.The movie is a lot of fun too. All the actors look like they're having a ball (except Michael Shannon who looks almost disappointed to be there). It's clear this was meant to be a fun fan service movie first and foremost. If you think about it too much, you're going to have a bad time. Now I'm not saying you need to turn your brain off. Just know that you can nitpick any part of this movie if you really want to lessen your enjoyment of it. But the movie does a fairly good job of making some of the more fantastical elements sound plausible if you're willing to suspend your disbelief a little. I honestly expected far more stuff to be handwaved by the film, like why Michael Keaton is suddenly Batman.I'd recommend it if you want a fun superhero movie that focuses heavily on the comedy. If you want something more serious, this isn't it.

title: One of the worst movies of the Millennium
text: One of the worst movies of the Millennium. This is what we are forced to watch by the greedy spoiled millionaire stars churning out film after film to "star" in?With a cast of so many supposed "A/B/C-list actors", more than any of the Marvel movies even ever had, I cannot fathom how this is so abysmal.The script is like something from a sixth grader.The lighting looks like it was made by a blind person.The cinematography is a placement nightmare.The pacing is slow when it should be fast and fast when it should be slow.The special effects look cheesy and rushed, why did they not use more practical/real special effects? The computer generated visuals are like something from the 90's.

title: Solid movie
text: CGI is iffy but I don't think that destroys the movie as a total. Solid watch. Also people need to separate art from the the artist. Ezra was amazing and all I see are these reviews complaining about Ezra as the flash because of what he has done. Like just watch the movie and see Ezra as Barry and not Ezra. A lot of fun action scenes in the movie. In those action scenes I will say that Batman is very fun to watch and is fluid to watch and is iffy in cgi. If you are looking for a pretty good comic movie I would recommend the flash. Am I saying it's the best comic book movie of all time no but I will say that it is a good movie by itself.

title: Why the hate?
text: Ok so I've been reading a lot about CGI, what do you expect? Is a super héroe movie! I'm honestly not a big fan of the flash but I think this movie was great, the whole story, the unexpected ending, the Batman! That was the best part, no offense to the other Batmans like Christian Bale is one of my favorites, but Michael Keaton is still the best Batman of all of them! Also I don't know if the super girl was the first time that came out on this movie but I'll tell you this, she will be perfect for a super girl movie in the future! The costume is awesome and it looks great on her, her hair, her body, face, everything about her is great! Enjoy the movie!

title: Don't waste your time / money
text: In all honesty, I must express my profound disappointment with this ridiculous movie. It can only be described as truly dreadful. The plot is incredibly awkward, leaving viewers feeling perplexed and unsatisfied. What truly stings is that it tarnishes the cherished memories of those who held the original Flashpoint story in high regard. The CGI effects are horrible, the acting is subpar, and the twist in the narrative is outright ludicrous. It pains me to say that watching this film was an incredibly disheartening experience. I am left pondering a single, simple question: What compelled the filmmakers to deviate so badly from the brilliance of the original animated Flashpoint story? It is truly disconcerting to witness such a misguided adaptation.

title: It had ups and downs
text: The flash dillevers a more funnier movie then expected but story wise is a bit dissapointed. It is great to see a big mix of huge actors on the screen but this going back in time idea gets a lettle bit boring on a point of two. There is a lot of GCI in this film and that makes the movie a bit cheesy. I mean, special effects can be cool but they are kinda overdoing it. When your only seeing GCI and not even one human asspect or ''normal'' world sights for a big amount of time... i just dont see the bonus in it. Maybe it is cheaper for the movie companies? It could be better. On the plus side; some funny jokes, fast pacing story, great acting and good actors.

title: Enough with the multiverse!
text: Marvel clearly wants to beat this topic to a bloody pulp, but what does DC have to do this now? When you have a plot centering on the multiverse, that basically means that you have no plot. Disappointing! The lead character has his charms. This movie had potential. But it just got stuck in the multiverse. By the end, it was just so ridiculous. I also don't understand why you have one actor playing Batman in the latest movie, and you have Affleck playing Batman in the Justice League movies. I also don't understand why the Justice League even has to be in this movie. They could have had a movie just with the Flash and a good plot line, but that is asking for too much clearly.

title: ignore the effects and enjoy the ride
text: After being totally disappointed with Warners attempt at the recent DC movies, I have to say my expectations were low. My only draw was that Keaton was my Batman and I wanted some nostalgia.That being said, this is by far the best DC movie since Wonder Woman. The effects are typically appalling (why Warners do spend more on effects I don't know!!) but if you can get past the uncanny valley, bedroom driven graphics and some Snyder colour grading it's great.The character arcs are great, the story is fun, not too serious and hits nostalgia hard. Without spoiling it for yourself if you know what may have been in the DC universe of movies. This will make you smile like a kid at ChristmasWell done Warner just sort your CGI.

title: Funniest DC movie ever!
text: There was nothing about The Flash I didn't like. The best thing about this movie was the story. Whoever wrote it has an extremely creative mind. There's not a DC movie I didn't and it's nice to watch a super hero movie that not predictable and can make you laugh at the same time.Anytime you see bad reviews on a good movie a movie that you totally enjoyed its obvious that the reviewers had an agenda and wasn't a real fan review or everyone knows theres a small percentage of people you just can't make happy no matter what. Even if the movie spit of twenty dollar bills they would find something to complain about.

title: An Absolute Mess
text: The Flashpoint Paradox is one of my favorite comic books, and is the only comic to make me cry. The relationship between Barry and his powers, the maturity of his final decision to undo the time manipulation he undertakes, and the alternate versions of classic characters all make that story an epic tale and one that would translate so well to the big screen.The Flash has none of that in any good capacity. The writing in this film is infantile, trying to be funny constantly and delivering on none of it. The incessant CGI looks horrible. The movie seems to be a pasting together of meme content from around the internet in a hope to arouse interest.Let's start with the writing. To give a good look at how they wrote this film, let's concern ourselves with the pivotal line: "Not every problem has a solution. Sometimes you just need to let go." This is spoken by Barry's mother to him as he tries to complete MATH HOMEWORK. How dumb can it get? That's horrible advice for a child doing math homework, it's unnatural to talk like that, and it's so obvious what the writers are actually getting at with the line, including their intention of bringing the line back later. To add to it, Barry has the audacity to accuse another character's entry line as being rehearsed. The other problem with the writing is that it is obsessed with shoehorning jokes and leaving spaces for audience laughter. My theater was silent throughout. The gags are borderline slapstick, and Barry Allen, a supposedly smart, witty scientist superhero, seems to be living with Roger Rabbit and taking speech cues from him.Next, the CGI. Avatar: The Way of Water just wowed us with how fantastic a movie can look. The Flash seems to believe that immersive visuals are an option. Every other shot had at least one actor fully replaced with CGI, and seeing as there are two characters played by the same actor in most of this movie, that's a SERIOUS PROBLEM. The first scene with the two of them looked really good; I don't know why the quality took a nosedive from then on. Every bit of CG face looked like it was constructed from clay, and I couldn't help but think about how Red Dead Redemption 2 looked more lifelike than this motion picture.The writers and producers of this film seemed to think that what the world needed, as a response to such multiversal entries into popular culture as the Spiderverse movies and Godzilla, was Nicholas Cage as Superman. Of course, Nicholas Cage doesn't really make an appearance in the movie, but a CGI version of his likeness based on the decades-old rumors of him donning the red cape disgraces the screen in a cringe-inducing cap to the climax of the film. Memes everywhere, as if that's how you should write a movie.I was really hoping for a bit of greatness here. I have been disappointed for years with Snyder's terrible butchering of solid characters, and I was even willing to look past the few minutes we have with the fake Batman we've had from the DCEU. Unfortunately, Affleck was one of the better parts of The Flash. He managed to not go murdering everybody like he's done in the past (not Batman), and his acting and action were pretty solid. Another hero that kept me in my seat was Cara-El, written and acted rather competently, especially compared to our protagonists.5 out of 10. Go see it if you LOVE Michael Keaton in the suit, but don't expect to see him doing any karate chopping. They leave all that difficult stuff to the computers.

title: Absolutely awesome
text: A wonderful film , very heartfelt and done so well. The best dc film since man of steel. So many great moments and the chi is great unlike with a marvel movie. Keaton is amazing back as batman and miller shines as the flash, he captures the character so well. Timeline films can be so difficult to manage but Andy does that very well, specially with why Barry wants to do it. No spoilers here but definitely go see it and make your own minds up about it but I recommend it for sure. It's got some really nice surprises that I was never expecting and it's super fun as well. A dc film that finally delivers.

title: Harkens back to the days of Schumacher's silly Batman.
text: This film is silly, campy, has a few genuinely cool moments, has a few genuinely cringey moments, and is ultimately a goofy mess of a film. It certainly has a Schumacher vibe to it, and I would rank it between Batman Forever and Batman & Robin. It's probably closer to B&R.The only recent comic book film I could compare this to would be Wonder Woman 1984. Both films had bad directing, bad effects, and bad CGI. In fact The Flash's CGI is even worse that WW84, it's downright shockingly bad.I don't understand WB. I trash talk Black Adam and Shazam 2, but both of those films are better than this cheese ball of a movie. It's like the studio look at how poor Marvel's Phase 4 was and said "hold my beer."

title: Go for the Flash stay for Keaton!
text: While The flash is a hot mess, Michael Keaton shines as Batman once again. This movie would be a great collection to add to Batman 1989 and Batman returns. Loved Keaton both as Bruce Wayne and Batman. The scene in the Russian prison is wonderful. He had the best bat car and the best costume and he played a great Bruce Wayne! If you don't like Ezra Miller stay out of the theater until about halfway through the movie.Ben Affleck as Batman. What can I say but please shave because you're looking pretty grungy. He does a pretty good job though.I like the twist at the end with his dad's trial. All together it's not a bad movie but could have been great with more Michael Keaton!

title: Another bloated, painfully average superhero film....
text: The Flash had a pretty hard road for years before it finally was released. The marketing on the film made it look like it was going to be the end all be all of superhero films. It is far from it. I am not a fan of The Flash but I do think that Ezra Miller was a good fit as Barry Allen/ Flash as part of a ensemble cast as in Justice League. Ezra Miller is not bad in this film but his character is so jokey and and annoying that it gets tiring. The premise of this film is that The Flash goes back in time to fix an event in the past but causes an alternative reality without metahumans. That's it. If course the selling point if this film is the appearance of both Ben Affleck and Michal Keaton as Batman/Bruce Wayne. This really isn't a spoiler because all of the trailers showed them. I was not a fan of Ben Aleck's Batman, but here he is pretty good but it's really just a cameo. Michal Keaton dies get more screen time and his performance is probably the best element in the film. The truth is that it is pure nostalgia and Keaton does a good job with what he's given. The problem is that it works only as nostalgia, nothing more. The film is called The Flash, you would think that the secondary character wouldn't overshadow the main character but Batman dies overshadow The Flash. The character is too annoying to care very much for him. Another problem is that with the whole multiverse tripe the story isn't as compelling as it should be. Michael Shannon returns as General Zod and is a completely weak villain this time. Not menacing at all.There are so many callbacks and nostalgia moments that the story takes a backseat. I have no problem with nostalgia and fan service, but when it's the best part of a film,The problem with this film and so many films in comic book hero films these days is that they are big, loud but completely forgettable. Its incredible that a film with such a large budget could be so averageNot horrible, but painfully average.Grade: C.

title: An Entertaining Movie That Exceeded My Expectations
text: Let me start by saying that I never cared for Ezra Miller being cast as Barry Allen/Flash. My Silver Age memories of the character as a stalwart but brainy, clean-cut All-American were dashed by the current re-imagining as a clumsy, insecure geek. That being said, Miller's acting in this movie was impressive, playing two versions of Barry Allen in scenes ranging from slapstick humor to sensitively emotional. He turned in a very good performance.Michael Keaton's portrayal as an alternate universe Batman was a brilliant piece of casting and solidified his oft-referenced claim "I'm Batman ". He truly embodies the role.Much has been made of the CGI being poor quality. Honestly, it looked okay to me but I generally rate movies on plot and acting and don't pay close attention to visual gimmicks. The action scenes looked good and I could at least tell what was going on. I've seen other comic book movies where that wasn't the case.Near the end of the movie there are nostalgic references to other iterations of DC characters over the decades. It attempts to explain how these various versions of the same characters exist in different parts of the multiverse. It's a fun and logical device that sets the groundwork for the coming DC Cinematic Universe.In conclusion, this movie may not be high art or faithful to the Flashpoint storyline, but it has action, a coherent story, humor and pathos. A good movie-going experience.

title: A solid superhero entertainer that could've been better
text: A solid superhero entertainer that may look lame compared to the recent animated multiverse movie or the animated Flashpoint movie. Apart from making an aspect of the multiverse clearly defined with spaghetti, which worked fantastically, there's not much that can be considered new ideas that haven't been already explored in recent years. Even so, the fulcrum aspect of the multiverse they tried to show ends up just a setup for world-building and not properly utilized at all, considering how the movie ends up and how it dealt with paradoxes. Ezra Miller is the heart of the movie and now I do see why some critics criticized that aspect because of his real-life persona. There's an automatic apprehension to root for the character because his face reminds you of real life. But still, when the movie really engages you, that doesn't become too much of a problem.The action set pieces are conceived wonderfully, as the use of the environment with the action looks quite novel but the CG work is very inconsistent. It did give some amazing action setpieces with a couple of characters and actors that were amazing to watch even though it kind of gave a feeling that there's something unrefined about it as a whole. A lot of the action in the movie looks kind of like video-game cutscenes but they have designed the visual keeping that in mind and tried to integrate that into a visual style which is not too bad and made it enjoyable but there were still some scenes that were a little bit too shoddy.The cameos could have been done in a better way or at least the choice of usage of some of it in the way it was presented could've been better. It also made it feel like some other cameos should've been there which could've been easier and more appropriate.There are also a couple of absolutely mad cameos that like most cameos didn't have much to do with the film but leave the audience dumbfounded with the audacity with which they brought them and I'm all for it.Supergirl didn't really have much to do here but Michael Keaton's Batman shined even within his limited scope in the movie. Even with all the cast of characters the film firmly belongs to Ezra Miller and he has done a great job of it. At the end of it, The Flash is a very entertaining movie but could have been way better if they would've taken a little bit more risks and had better CG work.

title: come on barbie let's go party 💅💕
text: This was perfectooo!!Having these cameos while keeping a close eye to the individual storyline is not an easy thing to do, so I appreciate that so much.Muschietti has done a bold job as this is his first non-horror movie. Pulling this movie off must have been some challenge but he's done it! So proud of him!Color grading and sound design were absolutely made for home cinema! I know this movie will look EPIC on physical copy.I love the suits, the dialogues and the handsome piece Affleck 💕And of course especially the Supergirl was portrayed in such a strong way. I would love to see her again in future projects.

title: Bravo DC!
text: The absolute BEST DC movie so far - hands down. Finally is DC nailing the ironic and humorous take on their heroes. Perfect balance of action, drama and be ready - tons of humor spread throughout the story. I caught my self laughing with tears in my eyes till the end. Don't listen to the naysayers on this one, trust me you'll have a blast with both new and "old" DC characters. And hats off to the Flash. Bravo DC for hiring the right director and writers. Keep it up!The story is actually moving on a deeper level regarding appreciating your parents, and that's a story that never gets old. Supergirl is stoic and well cast - and bringing Batman-89 back on the screen gave me the really good chills. Wanted the movie to last for one more hour, and that's a rarity with superhero-movies these days. I'd say Marvel watch out, if this fresh take on the DC Universe continues... Finally you got it right DC.Even though the CGI is lacking in places, the fun, moving and creative story makes it a 10/10. Go watch it on the big screen tonight!

title: Michael Keaton saves it
