I think they should reboot the dc verse but before doing that they should hire a good CGI team if they want their movies to do good.

title: Was it the casting or the acting or maybe it was the writer?
text: Ezra Miller flashed onto the screen a few years ago and I asked myself "what was that?" Here I am years later asking "what was that"? He has always been a terrible choice and this movie proved it. Did he do a good Ferris Buhler? Sort of, but that was not the Flash! That was not Super Girl. That was not Iris. It felt a lot like the most recent FF movie. The cameos were cheesy.The CGI was way too noticeable and often way over the top. At least Afleck and Shannon were great and the characters spent time in costume but that was not the Flash!!!So to summarize my review... Ezra Miller can't act.

title: Not worth watching or streaming
text: I didn't have high expectations from the movie but I thought I'd give it a chance, well... I should've just stayed home cause this movie is not even worth streaming for free.The acting: Ezra Millers performance impressed me with how cringe it is, awkward annoying teen who is just unlikeable and nothing like the actual flash from the comics btw. The performance of his friends felt like a CW show. I guess the only thing decent was Michael Keaton.VFX: not only was the green screen super obvious in some of the scenes, some of the cgi people in the movie looked like ps2 characters. Some of the explosion vfxs looked like they were put with a Snapchat filter.The plot: it's just a mess, had potential but nah.I guess the only good thing that I liked in this movie was his suit and Kara's suit. That's about it. The suits were well designed and looked good.

title: Not as bad as I expected
text: That's the best thing I can say about the film. It's not as bad as I was expecting. It's just all a bit underwhelming and is tonally all over the place.I felt there was a decent story bubbling away, but it all got gobbled up by DC's need to avoid a PR disaster by focusing too much on Ezra Miller, who is surprisingly good in his dual roles and, if it wasn't for the off-screen baggage, is good enough here to carry a Flashpoint/BTTF type film about time travel, dealing with grief and going up against evil Flash.But I got the sense all that was lost in the reshoots and handing the DC reigns to James Gunn. The opening act feels like it was tacked on - possibly they went to James Gunn and said "We need a wacky, outlandish opening" - because it doesn't sit tonally with the rest of the film.The last act feels like the last act of a different story, maybe the one they set out to make. And isn't helped because the special effects clearly aren't finished and it all feels rushed.Overall, not a disaster - it made me laugh, I liked the Batman nostalgia and some action scenes are really well done - but it all feels like a superhero movie made by a committee. Despite the big explosions and big action, there's not much to get excited about. Just a bunch of scenes from 3 different films in search of a story.

title: They finally fixed it
text: They fixed it.Whats it you may ask??? Everything, the whole god damn dc universe.If this is the beginning of new leadership at this studio and they dont go and drive it off a cliff again we could be in for a bright future.The movies a solid 7 and is definitely worth a watch. It could have jumped to different timelines a bit more to fix other timelines that just need to be permanently erased but who knows what the future holds. All we can do is hope that the studio doesnt go back to its old ways of spewing out yearly garbage that waters down what can be a great franchise. Hopefully we lose aqua and wonder along the way....

title: Unjustly a box office bomb
text: This is an excellent, well-acted version of the "Flashpoint" story. I read the comic books and saw the animated movie and the TV series' version. Ezra Miller is a great actor and I hope their personal problems are really a thing of the past. I should have recognized Sasha Calle from the 100 episodes I saw her on "The Young and the Restless." I loved her then. Michael Keaton was better than ever as Batman, I went into the movie wondering how that would be possible. The cameos range from clever to funny to heartbreaking. I hope time vindicates this movie. I have seen 'em all and I loved this one.

title: DC popcorn superhero silliness
text:
As my headline says - It's a lighthearted, silly but entertaining, superhero, popcorn flick. Ultimately could of been what all the 'critics' said - "one of the best comic book movies ever" but alas some dubious writing, gapping plot holes, the worse CGI I've seen in a superhero film since green lantern (yes Ezra's suit for the most part is CGI and moves at odds with his face)...Kids will love the humour and action. Adults will take it or leave it - I needed to pee half way through and I had no issues heading out the door for 5mins - where as I would of happily sat in groin aching pain till the end of Dark Knight or Civil War etcWithout spoilers...The Good:
The Bad:

title: Very much comic in true essence!
text: This is a very good movie, I am not sure why it flopped and why people are not going to watch it! Thought the show today was almost full house!Anyways, the characters are great in their roles. There is action, good costumes and definitely a lot of humor. There is humor and a very good feel of multi-verse comic book coming alive feel! Anyone who follows comics regardless to it being Marvel or this, will enjoy and appreciate the acting and cinematic scenes!Ezra Miller did an excellent job with his role! I would definitely watch this one again and recommend people to watch it also. The only minus was the after credit!

title: 16 minutes and I don't know why I am still watching this..
text: I have NEVER liked Ezra in anything. Why is he still cast? Never liked that awful actress they installed as Blunder Woman. The jokes so far are for 10 year old children. Oh gee, guess what...seems you needed to watch the tv series to understand what is what...I gave up on that after the first season. I only lasted through that because Danielle Panabaker was in it. 16 minutes, and I am confused who is playing Batman. This may be the ONLY reason I may still watch a bit more of this disaster. Oh, all the commenters complaining about bad CGI? So far well based. They are terrible. They must have slashed that budget to the bare minimum. There are plenty more things wrong so far in this movie..but it seems DC is set on making awful movies. What really puzzles me is that there are people actually going to see this carp. Why? Who are these people? I don't know anybody who went. That includes my two sons and their friends. And that is a pretty big crowd!

title: Umm all you bad review folks are haters- great movie
text: Watch this movie- its amazing I grew up on marvel and dc. I grew up around comics and met alot of written and artist. This is an amazing movie dealing with dc multi universe. Do not listen to anyone who says this movie is bad. This was awesome movie.The movie is really action filled and brings alot of characters old and new into it. Not sure why people hated it. I was a comic nerd , this was one of the best dc movies made. Its funny, unique I love the Orginal batman back. It had an Interesting plot line that would align w the comics. Barry character is complex and I feel this was brought into this movie. If you dont know the comics and the different version of them you simple wont get it.

title: Rush
text: Full of surprises that are pleasing to the genuine fans of the DC universe. Altough, it could've been more impactful and exciting if the creators didn't rush it. Overall, there were good parts also bad parts in this movie. The visual effects here and there seemed "cheap" if I describe my visual experience. Some relationship and storylines felt "rushed and pushed" and was very unnesessary."What's with the rush?"However, the background music experience throughout the film was one of the best things one could enjoy. Cheers to the ones who created and made such choices, it really satified my crave for a good choice of music.

title: What an absolute Mess
text: DC simply can't get any of their movies right. This is by far the worst. They took one of the best comic book stories of all times and turned it into an absolute farce. Referring to the Flashpoint saga. Incredible that DC has the best roster of superheroes in the world and to date they have literally produced Turkey after Turkey. Not to mention the lead actor here is absolutely awful to the point of actually being utterly unwatchable.big surprise that DC have added another massive flop to their perfect record of dismal failures. DC needs completely new management. The team that produced this and the Zack Snyder series of duds really needs to be nowhere near any movie production.

title: i almost walked out
text:
Halfway through...too much adolescent type humor for me. But i'm glad i DIDn't because i enjoyed the second half...and what's with all the criticisms about the CGI? I just sat back and whatever they decided to do with that layer of the film, they did...it wasn't distracting, as some said, in any way. Maybe the people for whom it WAS should put together their OWN films, complete with their concept/s of what the CGI should be like...
i agree with those that said the film was 'uneven'. And i'd care to throw in that it was maybe, unnecessarily, longer than it could've been and a bit of editing might have made it feel like a tighter picture. I DID enjoy the second half, for what that's worth.

title: I didn't hate it like I expected to
text: So I thought I would go into this movie hyped to see keaton as batman again etc and to finally see DC move on from the awful snyderverse we had to suffer, but in the end I enjoyed it but not quite the batmans sections most of which felt really off and out of place for his character, the story was fun and it felt like a good old 90s kids movie I'm sure younger me would have given it a better rating but still this wasn't the mess everyone seems to be making out, I saw it didn't do well in cinemas but honestly I haven't been the cinema to see a superhero movie since batman vs superman that was kind of my cut off point where I grew tired of paying for movies I wasn't enjoying.Judging this movie on it's own merits rather than jumping down the twitter cancel culture rabbithole of finding ezra guilty without an judicial outcome, I enjoyed it for what it was but I'm hoping now that DC really start building their universe bigger and better than it's seemingly been since the nolan batman movies, DC hasn't really seemed to top those films since which is a real shame because us the fans keep on giving them chances, stop chasing marvel and start fresh.

title: I love this movie!
text: I admit, I was skeptical about the director of the project, but he actually surprised me very pleasantly. The Flash is the perfect comic book movie to have a good time, and it falls just short of being perfect. Regardless of the problems that Ezra has created for himself in society, of course, without condoning his behavior, the actor does a brilliant job in the role of Barry Allen. Thumbs up from me, the movie is good enough and Michael Keaton is wonderful as always! I would happily watch another Flash movie! Thank you DC and Warner Bros. For entertaining us with such enjoyable films. As I wrote earlier - I love this movie!

title: Not as bad people make out
text: I enjoyed the movie. For all of E. M personal issues he is a very good Flash. I really enjoyed the storyline, the cameos and of course Keaton stealing the show!Seeing Michael Keaton back as Batman is a real sense of nostalgia and how great he was as the caped crusader.Moving onto the movie, I was hoping to see the reverse flash. The CGI though, the amount of money and budget they had they could of done better. Very obviously computer generated compared to other superhero movies you can see the work that was out in. It feels like they had no time left and just made it work which is a shame, as this movie could of been a 10 with better CGI and some tweeks.Overall enjoyed it. I hope Gunn's vision keeps EM as Flash.

title: Entertaining! Don't Rely On Others Opinions
text: Movies are meant to entertain, i enjoyed this movie.When i see a movie, its to escape reality for a bit and relax.Otherwise I would watch a documentary.See the Flash movie and judge for yourself!This Supergirl was cool and hope to see more!Batman was also cool to see , and how he looks with today's CGI technology!The SnyderVerse Batman was also cool to see him in action in a daytime setting!The CGI was obviously meant to be the way it was, im sure they had they reasons for this.Again its entertainment, like watching a live action cartoon or comic book!I'm glad I live in this age to see these characters come to life with the all the special effects and CGI!Don't be spoiled, there was a time where we only dreamed of seeing this type of fantasy in a movie!

title: I'm torn, but still give it a 7/10.
text: I am very conflicted about this movie. First of all I've always been a Marvel comics fan and never cared much for DC comics, and this has carried on with the movies. This is one of my favorite DC movies to date, but it could have been so much better. At this point, they have so much lore and history to play with in a movie like The Flash. Sure enough, they are using plenty of it and even a non-fan like me got all giddy a several Easter eggs and references, but there is so much more they could have pushed for. And the horrendous CGI doesn't help; why is it so bad compared to other current movies, especially MCU ones? Still, I very much recommend it if you're into entertaining super hero flicks.

title: What did I just watch?!?!?!
text: In the immortal words of Samuel E Wright - 'There's Something Funny Going On'. I honestly didn't think DC could get any worse than the Rock's 'Black Adam', but "oh boy" does it!Right off the bat I'll have to mention the animation. Why does DC continue to waste time, talent and money on cheap CGI instead of investing in a ILM equivalent type studio? Can't ask this enough...As far as 'The Flash' as a cinematic experience, prior to watching I had an expectation of what we saw with Marvel's Quicksilver in films like 'X-Men: Days of Future Past' and 'X-Men: Apocalypse', films that came out in 2014 and 2016 respectively. I'll just say my expectations were not met.The only meaningful substance that came out of this film, from my perspective, is obviously Michael Keaton reprising his role of Batman. Keaton, though, isn't enough for me to give this film even a mid-rage rating.

title: Better and funnier than expected, Deserves an opportunity
text: I definitely think that someone really planned a boycott to make this movie fail. I agree that the CGI is kind of poor and the plot could have been better, But this movie is really entertaining, funny and has a lot of awesome fandom service. I never got bored and it was surprisingly enjoyable. I can assure that this movie is better than Justice League and most movies from Marvel's Phase 4 such as Thor Love of Thunder, Ant-man Quantumania, Shang-Shi, Black Widow or Eternals. Too bad that we did not get to see Henry Cavil as Superman or Melissa Benoist as Supergirl due the stupid diversity quote that Super Heroes movies need to meet nowadays, but If you want to disconnect your brain and enjoy a Super Hero movie please give an opportunity to this one UNTIL THE END!

title: How not to reboot a franchise
text:
Tl:Dr Gunn- a one hit wonder with zero business heading a cinematic franchise.Ezra - a n undeserving scumbag multiple felon whose crimes include child grooming, multiple occasions ( which have video evidence) of beating women, trespassing and burglary
These 2 morons are responsible for one of the worst movies ever released and easily the worst piece of DC media ever created. Ezra was involved in the flash ( obviously), Gunn was given control and decided to have the flash edited to suit his vision for DC. That vision meant editing the flash to include cameos and throwbacks to storylines, characters and plots that Gunn is responsible for cancelling, yet in his complete lack of brain activiity and out of touch with reality bubble he thought that putting throwbacks in the flash would blind the audience with nostalgia and they would overlook the steaming pile that the flash is. If you want to be reminded of storylines, plot points and characters that Gunn has already killed off, while a the same time watching an ego tripping child groomer deliver utter mediocrity while poorly delivering a story that DC has already told countless times over and which was handled infinitely better in the animated movie "flashpoint" then maybe you'll like this movie.If you have working brain cells, if you want a movie to tell a story, if you want to have some escapism aided by compotent acting, if you want to be entertained then this is not the movie for you.Main***
First things first lets address the elephant in the room, this movie deserves to fail, before it even hit cinema some people had a negative, albeit justified perception of it. Gunn, a one note hack who in 30+ years in the business has only had 1 success which was guardians of the galaxy, which was impossible to be anything other than a success since marvel fans are so rabid its effectively a cult, marvel could sell bags of feaces, if the bags had a marvel logo printed on them they would be guaranteed to sell. Point is Gunn is not a good director and objectively is one of the least qualified people on the planet to be given the reigns to all of DC's property, yet inexplicably that is what happened. Gunns first acts as CEO of DC were to round up all the popular, successfull, fan favourite actors like Henry Cavill and Gal Gadot and fire them on the spot, but for reasons defying any semblance of brain activity he cleared house of all the good and profitable actors he decided make Ezra the sole focus of his attention so all of the press, all of the media and the future he envisioned for DC all revolve around and/or heavily include a child grooming, woman beating, assault prone, thief. This movie, Gunn and Ezra deserve to fail, that is not a matter of opinion, that is not even up for debate, that is an immutable fact. So all that said, it was set in stone that this movie was never going to have an impressive showing once released.Now onto the reviewing the actual movie footage. It's bad, plain and simple bad, a boring, predictable movie that tries to use a nostalgia factor to mask it's many shortcomings but since those moments of nostalgia are all looking back on different stages of live action DC, none of which exist anymore and thanks to Gunn will not be continued or revisited instead of making us smile or having fond throwbacks to the past they come across as exactly what they are, cheap poorly thought out manipulation tactics. You will not watch this movie and have a little smirk when certain cameos come up or when certain things are mentioned, instead you will just be reminded "oh yeah, we were going to have X storyline or Y was going to get more screentime". I know this movie was not headed by Gunn but changing aspects of it to suit his terrible marvel-lite, zero storyline, zero effort, sloppy phase system BS vision for what DC should be were among the first actions he took once put in the position of power and those changes are further proof of the reality of what I said above, Gunn is not fit to head DC.Instead of this being a movie that serves as a bridge of sorts, one that serves as a fair well to the established DC we have seen while also setting a clean slate to revisit those characters what it actually is is an insult, it insults DC's existing movies with how it handled it's cheap cameos and throwback moments using them as atom thin veils to mask it's own arrogance and it also both insults possible fans of future movies and establishes those movies are going in the wrong direction because Gunn is actively doing everything in his power to do the exact opposite of what people want. Rebooting DC is easy1: fire the child grooming, multiple felon who would be and should be in jail, the only reason he isnt is because it would be bad PR so the 1% in control of WB are pulling strings to avoid him facing the
consequences of his actions.2: Keep the actors who have proven financially successful as well as being well recieved by fans and critics alike. I am not saying that Henry Cavill should be superman for the rest of his life, Gunn could still turn out his guaranteed atrocious unneeded, unwanted, superman origin story number 9000, doesn't mean there is no room in any DC content for Cavill to play a slightly older, established superman.3:Release batwoman movie. This movie was 100% guaranteed to be profitable, a movie focusing on a member of the bat family who has not had a lot of attention in live action media and that stars Brenand Fraser, one of the most beloved actors of the past 4 decades playing a villian, there is 0% chance this movie would not have generated a profit.4: Do *NOT* turn DC into marvel lite. The phase system is the worst thing ever to happen to cinema. Storylines are gone, scripts are gone, plot are gone, quality is gone. Phase systems are not about telling stories, they are about re-treading the same footsteps over and over again while leaving enough "ambiguity" ( it isnt ambigious, it is so one dimensional you cant miss it coming, but ambiguity is the most fitting word for what marvel *think* they are doing) so that they can then tell those same stories again on smaller screens with predictable spin offs and adaptions. Instead of looking at a franchise and thinking " in 30 years time we can create a good story about superman if first we spend 29 years releasing and re-relasing his origin story in cinema and home media every single year until we are officialy in phase 15" Instead of that zero synapse perspective focus on making current movies good, give them compelling stories that work, don't think " how can I avoid developing this story for the next 3 decades to milk every penny out of this characters name"

title: By Geroge Its Pretty Good
text: Barry Allen is determined to the right the wrongs of the past by protecting his family from a horrid past. Using his powers to turn back time, he realises hes created a world without superheroes. Barry has to fight his demons and his life to correct the damage.DC has provided a fitting end to The Flash universe, as Gustin has decided to pull the plug and Ezra Miller took over. Performances were above standard with Michael Keaton a leading standout reprising his role as Bruce Wayne. Granted the cheese level may have gone up a notch, and the CGI was very hit and miss. That aside, there is no reason not to enjoy the ride. Great cameos by George Clooney and Jason Momoa for a good laugh.

title: A Victim of Expectation
text: So this was my most anticipated comic book movie of the year, of the last few years really, I love The Flash character and after the TV show kind off disappointed me I was just desperate to see another version of the character at the forefront of his own story. It's definitely a bit of a double edged sword to go into a film with those kind of expectations because of if it doesn't 100% live up to them it's gonna feel disappointing even if the film's still solid overall. And that's very much how I feel walking out this movie; a bit conflicted maybe even underwhelmed having still had a good time for the most part.Obviously Ezra Miller has brought a whole load of controversies to this film that couldn't have been foreseen and it's made the build up to it more difficult but I'm not gonna deny I think they're great in the movie. I think the best compliment I can give the performance is that I did start to see both versions of Barry as 2 separate characters pretty quickly, they're funny and bring the emotional weight that's needed for the films more poignant moments. Sasha Calle isn't in the film as much as I was expecting but I really gravitated towards her version of Supergirl and I would really like to see James Gunn keep her on in the new DCU. I loved Michael Keaton in this movie, I thought his Batman was used with a good amount of restraint and I thought he fit right in to the story. He's still totally believable physically and I just thought he excelled in the mentor role the script sets him up to be. It may be controversial to say but I think this could be his best Batman performance.I think Andy Muschetti elevated a lot of sequences with his really slick and visually creative directing. Just like with both the IT movies he always seem to find the most visually appealing way to shoot the types of the scenes the script calls for. I liked his interpretation of the speed force and it's as bright and colourful visually as I'd what a film about this character to be. I will say the tone was a bit hit and miss for me, I understand the Flash by nature is a quirky character but not all of the jokes landed for me and my biggest issues come when Muschetti tries to apply that same quirky tone to the character's that aren't Barry.While is directing it very creative what bogs down his visuals is the CGI. There's no way around it; the visual effects here are pretty horrendous to a baffling degree. And it's not just that they're not great, they are so poor that it actually took me out of certain moments where you're clearly supposed to feel awe inspired by what's on screen but instead it makes what's happening feel a bit empty. But the CGI isn't what I'd classify as my biggest problem with this movie.I just didn't think the story was that strong. There are a lot (and I do mean a lot) of great moments but the overall narrative feels really messy. I think this is partially a victim of the fact that the DCEU has never really felt like a fully fleshed out universe so the first act has to do a lot of heavy lifting to set up the character dynamics just so that the time travel the whole plot is based around can take place. Despite that I still found myself enjoying the first 2 acts but the actual climax in the 3rd act fell a bit flat for me. The awful visual effects are on full display and it essentially re creates Man of Steel's climax to a much lesser degree. There's a moment that's meant to feel awe inspiring but instead it just came across as hollow because there was nothing that felt real or tangible going on. The actual end to the story I actually thought was pretty perfect the pace getting to the conclusion though is clunky.So I'm pretty conflicted on The Flash overall, there are so many great individual moments but they're built on a story that didn't feel fully realised to me. I definitely think it's a victim of its expectations because Warner Bros did themselves no favours by building this up as one of the best comic book films of all time because it's absolutely not but I certainly wouldn't believe any of the hyperbolic negative reactions I've also been seeing online. It's a very enjoyable but imperfect superhero movie with a script that definitely needed a bit of an overhaul. I would be curious to see how my opinion evolves after a second viewing but as of now that about sums how I felt about The Flash in a nutshell.

title: Much better than the hate.
text: I saw the film on 6/31 because of all the negative buzz around it. I decided to take a chance based on a words from someone I know.I do not usually do reviews but I had to on this one because this is much better than what the hates given to it, much better. This is on of DC's better movies since Wonder Woman and it's a shame how it was treated only based on Ezra Miller which of course is a dummy. But, you have to tell it like it is, it's a good story and well made.Not only are we judging the movie based on Miller but, the director made good, Keaton was awesome as always s in that suit (the best Batman suit ever), so again go ahead open minded and see it.

title: A Fun DC Multiverse Tale
text: The Flash is DC's version of the Multiverse having already seen takes on the concept in Doctor Strange and the Multiverse of Madness, Everything Everywhere All at Once and Spider-man Across the Spider-verse. It also serves as a way to softly reboot the DCEU and help to rework the upcoming Aquaman 2 and Blue Beetle into James Gunn's new DCU.Overall I had fun with this film and found it to be enjoyable throughout. Ezra Miller was impressive in his role as Barry Allen/The Flash and was largely responsible for the film working as it did. The story has mature themes and an emotional foundation. The time mechanics felt realistic even if a little complicated. Seeing a returning Michael Keaton as Batman will be a huge draw for many as will the introduction of Supergirl to the DCEU. The script was generally fun and littered with cameos and Easter Eggs.My main issue was the noticeably bad CGI. The filmmakers have responded to audiences saying that it was done on purpose but it was genuinely off putting at times. I wasn't sure how I felt about Supergirl at times but I think that was due to a mixture of her being an Alien and the CGI. Therefore the awkwardness of her character works. This is miles better than this year's Shazam 2.

title: Go big or go home!
text: I have been wanting to see a huge blockbuster FLASH film since I was a little boy. I went on the journey with Barry Allen through the eyes of Carmine Infantino. I witnessed his death in Crisis. I saw the rise of Wally West in his own series. The Flash was a comic I loved the most.Why the Flash? Because he was a normal guy got chosen with that lightning strike to make the world a better place. He wasn't a millionaire, amazon, alien or god. He was just a guy racing to catch up. He wasn't perfect either. Wally West the character was deeply flawed.Flash forward past the 1990s TV series and the Grant Gustin series to the Snyderverse and the insanity that was Zack Snyder being unleashed onto the DCU.This version of the FLASH kind of reminds me of what Ben Affleck's Daredevil tried to do with that character. It jumped right into the hero's biggest story without warning. Since the Gustin series had been going strong for 9 years, the film relied on that public knowledge to go big or go home.Put aside Ezra Miller's controversial public life, he does a great job here playing his version of Barry stuck in two different times in their life. The effects on The Flash, the suit and humor were all great. The now controversial "ChronoBowl" was an interesting choice but also seemed doom for failure. (To be honest, The Arrowverse did a better job of explaining the multiverse and including legacies) In this cut of the film, Sasha Calle and Michael Keaton are completely wasted. Ezra Miller's performance is the best part of the film. This is by far THE FLASH film I dreamed of but they did their best with the insanely crowded and oversaturated superhero world we are now in.

title: Let's get nuts
text: I saw it in a theater, and it was better than I thought it was. The bad reviews are very wrong, and this movie was so great. I don't think this movie deserved to bomb.I loved the superheroes and the battle scenes but the 2 Flashes, Batman and Supergirl is a real good Justice League team. Black Adam and Shazam Fury of The Gods were kind of bad and I thought that The Flash might be bad because DCEU have so much bad films and some good ones, but I was wrong. I love that this movie also teaches us to love our parents and it's just sad that Barry lost his mom, and he still fights to change the past so he can live with her.I didn't like that CGI was actually pretty bad and that's mostly it.Honestly this is my number 1 favorite DCEU film.

title: A movie to get nuts about.
text: The Flash takes us on a journey back in time where Barry attempts to change the past, but this brings unintended consequences for our speedster. An emotional storyline awaits, with quite a few unexpected twists and turns.Ezra Miller, Michael Keaton and Sasha Calle deliver a great performance as the super-hero team comprising of Flash, Batman and Supergirl respectively. Sasha brought Supergirl to life with her stellar performance. As a Keaton-fan of the Batman movies in 1989 and 1992, it was memorable seeing him in action and hearing his famous one-liner.The action sequences and sound effects is a must-see for the big screen. Lots of humor and touchpoints with the exiting DC universe.I feel the trailer reveals quite a lot about the movie but still leaves enough surprises for the avid DC Comics fans.There is a post-credits scene. Wait till the end!

title: Disappointing
text: I was so disappointed by the CGI, in many scenes it looked worse than a video game. And it was all the way through the movie.The story was fun, and It was cool to see the other Batmans. The cast was great especially Michael Keaton and Sahsa Calle, but the movie was flawed with having Ezra Miller as the lead. I think they could have a found a much better lead actor, he really ruined it for me. I think some of the script was poorly written, like Barry always reminding people of what happened or should have happened in his reality. At this point did it really matter? It felt like a lot of filler lines, to just fill the moment. There wasn't a lot of heart to the movie, it just felt empty, like something was missing. Lot's of great action but with poor CGI. Was not impressed.

title: great superhero film
text: The Flash has finally arrived, a film I've been looking forward to since it came to fruition back in 2019 after many years in development of different directors/writers. Flashpoint would be the inspiration behind the film and that got me excited as I love the graphic novel, this isn't a direct adaption, its inspired and has Barry Allen traveling back in time to save his mother as the plot point but after that, everything is different and honestly it works quite well in how you'll be in for a ride that you'll be unprepared for like The Flash in the film. Ezra Miller has been a topic of controversy for two years and I understand why someone would choose not to watch it for him but his performance is great in this and he's better than ever as The Flash. Then came the marketing, making Michael Keaton the main Batman with him reappearing as his character from Tim Burton's two Batman films, Sasha Calle as Supergirl and the first trailer brought back Michael Shannon as General Zod and Antje Traue as Faora-Ul which was the villains for "Man of Steel" which was the start of the DCEU, it feels fitting that they're back for the ending (Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom will be the true conclusion). It also stars Ron Livingston, Maribel Verdú and Kiersey Clemons. With Ben Affleck along with other actors from the DCEU making cameos.The Flash is directed by Andy Muschietti from a screenplay by Christina Hodson, she wrote Birds of Prey prior to this so she has knowledge of the universe. Henry Braham served as a cinematographer for the film and shot The Suicide Squad prior to this aswell for the last two volumes of Guardians of the Galaxy. Benjamin Wallfisch did the musical score for the film and it's a good soundtrack, music fitting each scene both light hearted and darker, also the more suspenseful scenes. I think it was nicely edited. Andy Muschietti's direction was great, I really liked his vision for the project and how he wanted to make the project his own and fitting to the DCEU. I don't have any criticism towards him, great visual storytelling and it felt like he gave great direction to the actors.The Flash met my expectations, it was a great superhero film which brought plenty of satisfying and joyful moments. I love the characters and DCEU, I think they did a good job at putting an ending to it. With the speed force and time traveling, we got the multiverse in film format (after seeing it in Arrowverse and Titans before), and I don't want to spoil anything but you'll surely find it worth sitting through. The Flash offers a lot of things to like, the visual effects could and should have been better though, the final battle sequence against General Zod deserved ten times better effects and a more detailed location. I also understand why Michael Shannon didn't quite like it in this film just because of how one-dimensional Zod is and how there are almost no deep themes, I wouldn't say there are no themes though as there's one strong theme that's executed perfectly on screen and in writing, the theme of loss. There was emotional depth in the film through the loss of Nora, Barry's mother, it was executed perfectly and performed perfectly by Ezra Miller. The writing offered some great comedy, plenty of laughs from me and the others in the audience on the premiere, Ezra Miller had that comedic timing. Overall, I think the writing was great, much better than her work on Birds of Prey. The dialogue was great and so was the characterization. I really enjoyed the first and second act, they were golden. The third was fine but could have been better. The action sequences were great, all of them! Again, here the visual effects could have been better, but the action sequences were well thought out. It was also nice to see Michael Keaton back as Batman, he was great! I also liked Sasha Calle as Supergirl, good performance. This is a film I'll rewatch, without a doubt. Great superhero film!

title: A Rocky Send Off For The Former DCEU
text: Watched The Flash with Ezra Miller(Fantastic Beasts : The Secret of Dumbledore) as Barry Allen/The Flash, Ben Affleck(Air) as Bruce Wayne/Batman, as Victor Stone/Cyborg, Michael Keaton(Batman, Spider-Man:Homecoming) as Bruce Wayne/Batman,Sasha Calle(Final Stop) as Kara Zor-El/Supergirl, Maribel Verdu(Pans Labriynth) as Nora Allen, Ron Livingston(A Million Little Things) as Henry Allen, Jeremy Irons(The Lion King, Die Hard With A Vengeance) as Alfred Pennyworth, Antje Traue(The Seventh Son) as Sub Commander Faora-Ul ,Michael Shannon(Man Of Steel) as General Zod.This marks the final hurrah of the DCEU this is Flashpoint for the DCEU as James Gunn stated it will reset some things for the forthcoming DCU while not as solid as its comic or film adaptation it did reset the board much like Flashpoint and the New 52. Keaton, Miller and Calle had the best performances.Great Score By Benjamin Wallfisch(Shazam!) , Cinematography by Henry Braham(Guardians Of The Galaxy Vol.2) , and Direction By Andy Muschietti(It, It Chapter 2) A Rocky Send Off For The Former DCEU 7/10.

title: A beautiful Flash movie
text: This movie celebrates DC Cinema and provides so much character development for Barry Allen. I freaking love it.There is some CGI funkiness tho.This movie basically asks if one is truly ready to move on from one's own trauma. And Barry is essentially trying to reconcile his past while facing his insecurities and flaws, which take the form of Young Barry.Keaton gets some love and he plays a major supporting role.Kara is a great new addition.This may be a multiverse movie, but it is such a heartfelt Flash-centric film that we've been waiting for. It puts a neat twist to the Flashpoint storyline.

title: By no means a bad movie like most Marvel these days but not a great one either.
text: The Flash actually stands out in some aspects such as performances, particularly of Ezra (even though I don't encourage his off-screen activities), story and the message conveyance. But I think this could have been much better if they had put more thought into the pacing of events. Like, some characters, quickly turn in favour of Flash with no real depth. I hate that given this movie has a substantial run time touching 2 and half hours. Then, the most controversial aspect of CGI. I can't argue with that, really. I watched this on 4k at home so all the imagery were very clean and the CGI was noticable in times where it should've have been. I'm not talking about the "chronobowl"/Speed force CGI but other ones like Barry's face when he's in Flash-time. The budget is 220 million so I wish they had done much more given the time for production were much longer than most superhero movies nowadays. The cinematography was fantastic and I shed some tears because this one actually had an emotional impact. Then, Michael Keaton's Batman was fantastic and so was Sasha Calle. Zod's scenes felt very rushed though I can see he was not the point of interest in this movie which is driven by plot and character, literally!!! Get it? Anyways, I think this movie is not really underrated as of now and if it were to fall from its rating, it deserves justice because the vision was well-received for Flash fans such as myself who've seen the CW Flash and saw this familiar storyline of Flashpoint. I hope Andy Muschietti do well with his Attack on Titan project which at this point is not even sure of being made. I wish they make a good live-action adaptation of it if they do make one.

title: Everything already seen, a film full of non-original things. A repetitive DC universe. Partially disappointing.
text: I just saw the film today at the cinema where I entered with great interest and the film partially disappointed me. I found a part of the film interesting another part of the film I didn't like, too many things already seen in other films, too many concepts used in other works, too many ideas copied from other films and animated works (there are animated DC products who have already shown similar things for years).The CGI is good but not always, there are some points where it's not good. The story entertains but did not convince me at all. In short, a partially disappointing and partially promoted film, half half. I honestly expected more. The DC universe is now at the end, let's see if the new DC universe will be better or worse than this. Partially disappointing. My rating is low due to the lack of originality of the film.

title: The Flash
text: Barry / The Flash's life is subsumed with the fact that his father is in jail for the murder of his mother. When he discovers that he can run faster than the speed of light, he decides, against the advice of Bruce Wayne, to go back in time to put things right. As we all know though, such plans are always fraught with danger, time line wise and this is no different.Whilst Barry and his past self played by Ezra Miller are largely good fun in this, there are significant sections where they are both deeply irritating which is somewhat distracting. In addition the film includes a contribution by Supergirl played by Sasha Calle giving, at odds with the rest of the film's tone, one of the most miserable performances seen since The Grapes of Wrath hit the screen.That said this is one of the more enjoyable DC superhero movies of the last few years featuring an entertaining story, fun set pieces and strong FX throughout. The big draw here though is the introduction of shots and cameos of past beloved superheroes (and some who nearly were) and a starring role for Michael Keaton returning as Batman. The man provides much kudos here as does the accompanying suit, quite beautifully realised bat cave, bat mobile and plane, even Danny Elfman's glorious music. These factors add to a fun tale that should appeal to most people, but which may not include ardent young fans into DC lore.

title: Perhaps I should break up
text: My gf doesn't like to go to movies so I couldn't see this movie during its theatrical run and that was a mistake. The Flash is visually appealing and has a nice soundtrack. Story builds up slowly but never gets boring. Sasha Calle, oh my, she was awesome as Supergirl. She added so much nuance to the character that I wish there was more of her like a solo movie or something. Mind you, I never liked Supergirl until this movie. I thought seeing Michael Keaton as Batman would be cringe but it wasn't. The fight choreographies for his Batman were pretty good, and the audience finds Bruce Wayne in an interesting place in his life. Very much like the Supergirl, I wanted to see more of this Batman/Wayne. If the movie is still on theatres where you live, I think it deserves to be watched on silver screen. The theme, some problems don't have a solution, your past makes you who you are and you can't change it is a relevant and timeless one. Although it maybe hard to relate. Trying to change to past leads to destruction is a quite nuanced theme that not everyone may not be able to connect to. Regardless, the movie was an enjoyable experience.Now, to address the elephant in the room because everyone is doing it; I don't care much about Ezra Miller. They did this they did that, well who knows what celebrities got away with before the age of social media. I actually never liked their Flash until this movie but they did a good job in this one as well. I'd recommend this movie.

title: The flash mash
text: So I've become a bit despondent with super hero movies of late so I went to the cinema with less than average hopes for the flash especially with Mr miller's shenanigans of late, but oh I was pleasantly surprised and very happy when I left the cinema some two hours twenty minutes later.OK so there's some stuff in this movie that I just thought really? But for the majority I was well pleased how it all played out! The comedy elements are occasionally hit and miss but mostly they are a hit. There are a few lovely surprises where I found myself beaming with delight!All in all a solid effort well worth 9 out of 10 hopefully you won't be disappointed either! Zoom zoom!

title: Michael Keaton is the reason you made money
text: I went to this because I'm a huge DC fan, I am a nerd and I love Comic book movies. Your story was great. Having Michael Keaton come back as the Batman was amazing, it brought me back to my childhood.Cons you have a man that is a terrible person playing a hero. He is not someone I want my kids looking up to you should have replaced Ezra Miller with someone like Grant Gustin that fans and kids can look up to as a hero. We don't see these issues as much with Disney's Marvel. You hired someone that everyone hates and that is why you didn't make the money you wanted from this movie. Ezra miller needs to be fired and in jail.

title: This film deserves a better rating
text: This film deserves a much better rating than it has, I went to see it and really enjoyed it even if I'm not a big comics fan, it has a good story and some great cameos like Michael Keaton. I'm not saying it is a perfect film but I believe is pretty decent, you can even see Christopher Reeve make an appearance in the movie and also Nicholas Cage both as Superman from other dimensions! Don't be so hard on this film, go see it on the theater and enjoy a good old superhero movie. I think Ezra Miller does a great job playing the Flash and leading the cast; you also get a really fun cameo whit Gal Gadot as Wonder Women. So again I suggest you give it a chance, go see it, and have some fun with this film.

title: Fits the Bill but I Expected More
text: The Flash distinguishes himself from the crowded pack of DC heroes with his unique brand of action and his sarcastic sense of humour (at least this version of the character in this universe). Hearing The Flash was going to get his own solo movie, my mind leapt to the things they could do with the action scenes. While there's some obviously shared notes between Barry and Quicksilver (his comparable X-Men Universe counterpart) in how they use his abilities, hats off to the creative team for giving us some fun action scenes and some funny moments when Barry's dealing with his powers. One of the pleasant surprises I had watching The Flash is that I laughed a fair amount and it didn't feel forced or too manipulative. The writers and the creative team were able to find some unique ways to present how dealing with these powers would affect Barry and how the average person would perceive them. I wouldn't describe the action as fantastic but all the characters have their moments and I didn't leave disappointed with those scenes being too cliche or just average.Ezra Miller's been in the headlines a lot for his behaviour off-camera so let's set that aside. He's play dual roles here as both present Barry and younger teenage Barry. I liked Ezra better as current/older Barry, he's able to wring some funny moments out of Barry's awkward behaviour and maybe it's because he's the sobering presence next to his goof of a partner but I found him more believable in that role. Conversely, he's not as good as the more aloof member of the duo. The young adult Barry is designed to be more selfish, less aware and dumber overall but even if you make that concession, I found him mostly grating other than a few one off lines. It's a decent overall performance when put together but I'm not sure if it will save this iteration of the character. Michael Keaton is fun returning as the alternate Bruce Wayne from the Tim Burton timeline, he's still got the style and the presence the character requires and he's the steadying veteran the movie needs. The Burton movies were before my time but we all love Keaton and he seems comfortable being a supporting character next to Miller. My favourite performance was Sasha Calle as Supergirl, she's got the steely demeanour and the other-worldly vibe down pat, she fit the part like a glove from moment one and with all the questions about re-integrating the returning characters, go figure it's a new cast member that outshines them all. Maribel Verdu and Ron Livingston are both fine as Nora and Henry Allen respectively, they're having to work hard due to the cloying nature of their arcs but they get the job done. Largely the same for Kiersey Clemons, she's decent with what she's given but her inclusion seems more to setup the character for future movies than to give her something to do in this one. We get most of the Snyder/Wheedon Justice League appearing in cameos and they're all fine, I don't have many notes one way or another on them individually other than I wish we got more Jeremy Irons as Alfred before DC hit the reset button.Getting into what I didn't like about the movie, I'm surprised that I agree with the critics. The Flash is a perfectly acceptable entry in the DC Universe but it's oddly placed in the larger order. It's filled with little in-jokes and references which you may or may not know depending on how attached the the Snyderverse you are. The Flash also expects you to already have some warm and fuzzy feelings for the characters (both the main players and the supporting) that I just didn't have. They really want you to invest in Barry saving his parents but it's played like you're already attached to Barry as a character. He's been in a couple other movies as a supporting member of the Justice League, I haven't spent enough time with him to overlook that his plan is selfish and likely to fail. So when it comes time for the emotional payoff and we're supposed to be crying for Barry's selfless sacrifice, I just shrugged my shoulders. I also think The Flash suffers from tough competition in the multiverse superhero movies. Marvel's already taken a run at this a couple of times and because we've spent more time with those characters and there's been more buildup, we feel when they make those tough choices. It's earned vs unearned pathos. The Flash stands on it's own but it's not the first one to arrive to the party and it may not have all the fresh appeal it thinks it has for that reason.Whether this movie was even going to get released at all became a controversial subject with all the drama surrounding Ezra Miller. But the potential of it was too much to ignore and after having viewed the finished product, The Flash accomplishes what's required. With the crowded superhero landscape, the film had a tough fight to separate itself from the crowd and it unfortunately doesn't quite get there. I'm interested in seeing where DC goes from here as this movie seems to be a point of diversion (as described in the movie). I think this movie will give the die-hard fans what they want but I don't know if it will be the game-changer some were expecting. I think it's worth seeing if you're interested but it's not a must-watch experience and you could wait for this on streaming on need be.

title: Horribly cheesy film - AGAIN.
text: This movie for me, was unwatchable. Everything DC has done since the Christopher Nolan trilogy has been a mess. With, for me, the exception of Man Of Steel. That was an interesting take on Superman and I enjoyed it greatly.This Flash movie was HORRIBLY CHEESY. I still cannot understand why DC executives continue to RUIN these great characters. Bad script, bad dialogue, bad acting.Keaton was the ONLY thing good about this movie.Ezra Miller's performance, along with the rest of the cast did NOT come through at all. He has no range, no layers and was simply not believable as the Flash.I hate having write reviews like this, but I what is worse is that DC makes movies this bad at this point.

title: DC's ray of hope amidst uncertain times
text: Things have been very murky around DC's universe plan in the last few years. Almost like they go one step forward and two steps backwards. We are hoping to see some creative approach to storytelling with James Gunn leading the charge in days to come. The Flash however was the last of the previous management product and has been years in the making. This movie is definitely one of a kind and surprises you out of nowhere (in a good way).The Flash has a lot going on, the film explores the 'flashpoint' concept which gets briefly introduced at the end of justice league. There isn't much of a surprise around it as they have revealed quite a bit about the timeline and characters which The Flash is traveling to. The movie is a journey between timelines where The Flash battles internal and external conflicts. What sets the movie apart is the creative visual representation of time travel, the humour and the final flurry of surprises with easter eggs in the end. There are indeed some outrageous action sequences, especially the introduction scene of flash saving the babies from the hospital. However these add a different charm to the movie almost equivalent to the cheekiness of deadpool. The time travel concept isn't new and so the multiverse concept considering how this is being explored in recent movies. The movie does remind you of Dr Strange Multiverse of Madness in some scenes and also Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2. For some creative choices which have been made. However this doesn't negatively impact the movie. The movie kind of tends to go haywire at times but somehow manages to bring itself back on track. The climax definitely has one of the best emotional moments in a superhero film and portrayed in the most beautiful way possible.Keeping public and personal controversies aside Ezra Miller has played one of the best dual roles which I have seen in a film. The two different versions of Barry Allen present such variety not only in terms of looks but also in terms of demeanour. One can almost feel as if there are two different actors playing in the movie. Ben Afflect, Michael Keaton play the apt supporting Batman characters. I cannot speak much about the performance and impact of other actors because that could lead to potential spoilers. They all have been written and portrayed in a deceivingly brilliant way.The Flash is fun, engaging, visually compelling, at times outrageous and deeply emotional. If only DC had standalone introduction movies for these superhero movies before Justice League and then continued the universe, maybe this movie would have had a much bigger impact. The movie does end with some exciting potential ahead but nobody knows whether DC is going to pursue the same.

title: Meh.
text: My overall thoughts on this are just meh.... I thought it was just ok but nothing really special about it. With all of the hype around it from different celebrities and the studio heads, etc, I was expecting more to be frank. I didn't hate it but also didn't love it either. Also, I was never a fan of the casting from the beginning when I first saw Miller in Justice League in 2017. His portrayal just never worked or grabbed me compared to the others. And his portrayal here didn't change my mind. This just wasn't what the studio and lots of others hyped it up to be at the end of the day. Definitely NOT one of the best superhero films to date but just an ok entry.

title: A Taste of Gunn's Era
text: They said it was adapted from the story of Flashpoint, but they only used at least 1% from the source material. This could have been a Justice League 1.5 if they used every league members in the movie and follow the real story. It could've happened if Zack Snyder was the director. They focused more on comedy and lazily told the story why it flopped. 7.1 doesn't do justice to this movie. The animated movie was way better and closer to the comics. Prepare to be disappointed more as Gunn's ideas are all over DCEU now. One good movie and you chose Gunn to handle your movies? OVERRATED. RIP DC!!!!!

title: Flashy Fun: The Flash Review - Superhero Surprises and Nostalgic Nods!
text: Blasting out of The Flash, I gotta spill the beans-it didn't exactly rocket its way into the superhero hall of fame. Nope, not even close to snagging a spot among DC's heavy hitters. But hey, don't write it off just yet-I had a downright riot!Now, your mileage may vary on Ezra Miller's Barry Allen. Some folks found him a tad grating, but hey, maybe that's part of the whole Flash package, am I right? Personally, I didn't mind him at all.Let's talk about the true scene-stealer: Michael Keaton! When that Batman theme kicks in and Keaton's back in the cape, it's like a shot of pure nostalgia straight to the veins. But hey, just a heads-up-it's The Flash's show, not Batman 3. Gotta love those sneaky cameos!And Supergirl? She's a hoot! If she gets her own flick, count me in for round two! Oh, and the surprises? I'm still reeling from 'em! Can't believe they managed to keep those under wraps!Sure, it drags a bit in places, and some of the CGI's about as dodgy as a back-alley deal. Seriously, what were they thinking? But hey, they sure pushed the PG-13 envelope, didn't they? Nudity and f-bombs? This ain't your grandma's superhero flick, that's for sure!So, will I be hitting the play button again? Who knows, but one thing's for sure-I had a blast on this wild ride.

title: Incredibly Fun and Enjoyable Movie
text: This movie is absolutely one of the best superhero movies of the decade. The Flash succeeds not only in making a good story, but they subvert expectations constantly. I did not notice any contradictions of previously established story points. The story itself was gigantic, yet easy to follow. All the actors did an amazing job playing their characters, especially Ezra and Sasha. My only gripe with the movie was the fact that the CGI was not the greatest, especially when they had faces on their character models. They were quite obviously CGI, but this didn't detract from the story at all. Tons of cameos and easter eggs for fans of DC too. Overall a very good movie, and the only (kinda) bad part about it was the CGI.

title: Another DC attempt at copying Marvel
text: Controversies aside, this movie works pretty well for those who don't have anything to do or any other better alternative to watch. CGI is most of the time pretty PS3-like and only 3-4 jokes land well for me, among hundreds of jokes that remind you again of that abominable Whedon's cut. What Muschietti basically did in this movie is erasing almost entirely whatever remains of the Snyderverse to pave the way for the new overlord Gunn-verse though the latter still remains to be seen until perhaps the end of Aquaman 2 which gave birth to the despicable power creep. Some of the logic and decision making process by the main character need to met with heavy criticism or even scrutiny. The moral of the story being conveyed here isn't bad all, in fact, it's almost tear-inducing, at least that's a plus from me for this movie. Had it not for my cousin(s), I would never have left the idea of not seeing this or any other comicbook film since No Way Home, especially on the theaters.7.5/10.

title: One of the best DCEU Movies!
text: This was a movie that I had some interest in watching & after watching it, I can say that this movie was phenomenal!Despite the controversy surrounding the lead actor, I found Miller's portrayal of both Barry Allens to be great. It was great to see Michael Keaton as Batman again & I was especially impressed with Sasha Calle as Supergirl. The one issue that I definitely noticed in the movie was the CGI, but to be fair, that's an issue with all of Andi Muschietti's movies, so that didn't really bother me.Overall, I had a absolute blast with The Flash (2023), & if you're able to put your issues with Ezra Miller aside then you'll definitely enjoy the movie.

title: Thoroughly enjoyed it
text: I thoroughly enjoyed this from start to finish (even it is was a tiny bit long).The story is interesting and engaging. Lots of humour and laugh out loud moments. Likeable characters.The CGI is a little hit and miss in places - then again it always is - so nothing new there.There lots of action - as one would expect. Its fairly easy to follow with only a couple of moments that made no sense to me - theres also something that needs that extra fan knowledge.I'd recommend it. Its fun. Miller is great. Keaton is brilliant.Some nice cameo appearances. It has a satisfying conclusion. Great fun.

title: Seems to suffer from the same things as most DC characters.
text: DC comics seems to have some of the most interesting comic book characters but most of their movies come off a bit campy when compared to their Marvel counterparts. Flash was no different. Many points early on feel forced and overly campy and definitely smells very much like a rip off of the Spider-man Multiverse movie. That is not to say the movie doesn't have some really good moments, it most definitely does but they come on late and I nearly lost interest at several points. Ultimately if you like the Flash stories then it is a must see but if don't expect a unique experience. They are trying very hard to garner Marvel successes and DC always seems to be playing second fiddle even though in my opinion they have some of the most interesting super heroes.As the CGI goes some of it felt very faked. The AI is getting there but it's not quite polished yet. I won't state which characters to which I am referring as I don't want give any spoilers but you will recognize them when you see them.Michael Keaton stole the show but that came as no surprise. Michael is one of the finest actors out there is definitely under utilized. His moments are screen are well done and he pulls the role as Batman off so well it's a wonder they just don't recast him in the role even though he is getting on the older side for an action hero role.Juxtaposed Ezra Miller's character feels like he is stumbling through much of the movie but does have his moments coming across as a solid action figure. But you would think he should have the character well figured out by now. All of the actors that portrayed spider-man pretty much nailed their vision of the character down pretty solidly pretty quickly. Still, there is something I like about the character and it is probably more a problem with the writing than the actor. I think they should let the actor ad-lib a bit and see where he takes the character. Right now he feels a bit too restrained.Overall the movie isn't horrible I just would like to see DC comics pull it together and put down some solid 8 or above movies that really show off some of their outstanding comic book super heroes. If you like DC stories you should see this one. It's better than most. If so far the DC stuff just hasn't done it for you, you might want to skip this one. It's probably not going to change your opinion much.

title: Cringe humor
text: What is with every blockbuster feeling like they have to have so much cringe humor? I left the theater halfway through the film because I just couldn't take it anymore. Every scene with the younger flash was absolutely cringe inducing to watch. Also, we are supposed to believe Ezra Miller as an 18 year old? Please.. And Michael Keaton is able to have the fighting skills of a ninja at 71 years old? I don't even remember his batman being able to fight like that.. Nobody cares about Michael Keaton as batman anymore. His time has passed so can we please move on? Just like Harrison Ford returning as indiana jones... Who wants to watch a senile man playing his same signature character... and we all are supposed to believe that they "still got it." These older actors just can't let go of their huge egos and let someone new and hot take over. Please bring back serious and well written movies again.

title: Awesome movie but the problems stick out
text: Setting aside one's animosity towards Ezra Miller, this movie worked in the ways we've been hearing it was, but there's some heavy asterisks to that.Let's start with the good. This movie is really exciting and very well paced. Ezra does a wonderful job working off his younger self, and interacting with the rest of the ensemble. I was worried he would be shadowed in his own movie by everyone else brought in for fan service, but I'm pleased to say everything fit together like a well oiled machine. Don't like the man, but credit where it's dueSpeaking of the rest of the cast, everyone works well where they're placed even if they may be a little under utilized at times. It was wonderful to see Affleck return as Batman, Michael Shannon brought his perfect villainy back to Zod, and Sasha Calle was a great supergirl I hope to see lots more of. But of course, we all knew who the big gun was gonna be...Michael Keaton never lost his touch with Batman. Stole every scene he was in, and seeing him mop the floor with baddies never gets old. I'm very excited to watch his scenes over and over again when they're available on streamingWorth noting as well, the movie's humor definitely landed for me. Everyone's comedic timing is right on, the callbacks and references are utilized well with the jokes, and it was good to see it never compromised any of the dramatic moments as we've seen so many times before. There's some stragglers here and there, but I knew it was gonna be good with one of the first visual gags in the movieOk, so what was bad about the movie? Well as it's been said many times before, the CGI really falls short at times. To be fair, it worked well for the majority of the film in my opinion, but when it was bad it was BAD. It was distracting, and definitely pulls you out of the immersion. I can forgive bits and pieces since I know one day all CGI will look dated, but the filmmakers have come out defending it as a creative decision to show how the flash views the world in the speed force. Fair enough, but it probably should've either been polished up or just straight up scrappedThis movie also is clearly reliant on fan service and nostalgia, which isn't inherently a bad thing if you know how to walk the line. I would argue they do it well for about 80-95% of the movie, but when they overplay their hand, it definitely shows. For those that saw SpiderMan: No way home, imagine if that's where the line should be drawn on fan service reliance, now take two big steps over that line and you've got this movieBut here's my biggest problem in the movie, which does get into minor spoilers so be warned. I'm of the mindset that revival of old characters through people who have since passed is not a bad thing, if you're willing to put in the work to be respectful to their portrayal. This movie does feature some of that, and it's that with that atrocious CGI I talked about. It's in bad taste to try and pay homage to someone but make them look like a melting Barbie doll. This movie could've had an extra star from me without that, but this is what they chose at the end of the daySo overall, the movie was a fun DC movie I would easily say is some of the best we've had in a while I'd be happy to watch again, flawed though it is. If this is where worlds collide, I'm happy to say this is where some of the greats came together.

title: Best DCEU film since the first WONDER WOMAN
text: At this point in time, the average movie-going public is suffering from "Super-Hero" fatigue, and (more than likely) "multi-verse" fatigue because the latest entries in this genre all are tapping the same type of experience (in order to pull in properties/characters from other films). It's a smart strategy from a Movie Executive point-of-view as they can bring in other, generally liked/loved characters from previous films/entities.Sometimes it works Excellently (SPIDER-MAN ACROSS THE SPIDER-VERSE), sometimes it works "Well Enough" (DR. STRANGE IN THE MULTI-VERSE OF MADNESS) and sometimes it is just plain boring (the latest ANT-MAN movie), so expectation is that the DCEU will find a way to screw this up and make dull and boring a premise (and characters) that should be exciting and fun.And...with THE FLASH, the DCEU got it right (for once) and it is the most fun DCEU film since the first WONDER WOMAN film.Based on the FLASHPOINT comics series and Directed by Andy Muschietti (IT and IT, Part II), THE FLASH Isn't (really) a "multi-verse" story, it's a time travel tale (that causes multi-verses). An important distinction for the Fanboy - but rather unimportant to the regular movie-going person. This tale brings a bunch of fun (and humor!) to the DCEU as well as touching on the fondness nerve for by-gone characters (and the actors who portrayed them).Central to this film is, of course, THE FLASH, played by Ezra Miller. Your enjoyment of this film will swing on whether you find Miller's performance "fun" or "annoying" for it strides that line between the two. For the BankofMarquis, Miller's performance was a ton of fun - which added to the enjoyment rather than taking away from it.He is joined by a bevy of cameo appearances - to name any would be to spoil them - but (since it is in the trailer), Miller does spend much of this film interacting with his younger self and he succeeds (more than he fails) during this part of the film. The 2 Millers are also joined by Michael Keaton, reprising his role as Batman from the 1980's (again...not a spoiler - he's in the trailer). Keaton brings starpower - and star energy - to this film and he lifts the middle portion of this movie.Muschietti conducts this orchestra of multiple-cameos, multiple versions of the same character and multiple special effects professionally and cleanly, never letting the audience get lost and (most certainly) never letting the camera (or the film) linger too long on any plot device (which hides the holes that, inevitably, show up).A fun, enough, installment in the DCEU - with some heart and a large portion of nostalgia - THE FLASH is a positive way to say goodbye to the DCEU.Letter Grade: B+7 1/2 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

title: A highly uneven movie with hits and lows
text: Greetings from Lithuania."The Flash" (2023) is a hit and miss movie - and at the end of the day its somewere in between descent and average. Majority of this film i enjoyed and was about to give it 7/10, but then 3rd act kicked in and its your typical boring superhero movies stuff with lots of CGI and big battle and it kinda lost me there. Talking about CGI - they were pretty bad in this movie to be honest. How did they even managed to do Batman's cape CGI and it looked 100 times worse then in any Batman movie i've ever seen. And i don't want to even mention the faces of some of the cameo characters we see in 3rd act - they looked pretty horrible and ruined the fun factor.Overall, the only reasson i watched "The Flash" was due to Michael Keaton's Batman - and it was fine / good. There are surprising cameos but overall this is a very uneven movie and i found Barry character very annoying until act 3 when he finally shut up.

title: Amazing!!!!
text:
The Flash(2023) is amazing. This is one of the most beautiful film that i have ever watched.The content is suitable for everyone and every age. This film gave me so much emotional. I love the content of this film because it discuss about many different aspects like family, friend,....
Thank to this film, i recognize some beautiful things. Sometimes we think that a simple activity won't influence so much to the others but in fact without thinking deeply to the consequence, we can make a bad result and even we can't imagine.I believe that no one feel of wasting of money when you decide to watch this film at cinema.

title: Decent time-travel caper
text: 'The Flash' has been a long time coming, when you consider that Miller first played the character in 'Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice' in 2016 and this version of the film starring Miller was announced in 2014! It's interesting that they still try to make him the "funny one" of the Justice League team, when DC have kind of done that with the two 'Shazam' films already, and at it's core, this film asks the serious question - if you could go back in time, would you save a loved one who died?Due to the time-travel & parallel universe aspect of the film, we get to see many multiples - Barry/Flash (Miller), Batman (Keaton & Affleck) and Superman (no spoilers!). I'd say Keaton actually gets more screentime than Affleck and does really well, especially considering he's 71 and hasn't played Batman for over 30 years! The main plot is basically 'Back to the Future', which gets plenty of nods, with Batman and Kara (Calle) helping Barry to get back and overcome the changes of where he's ended up.Some of the "speed-force" CGI is pretty bad and the main problem the film has is trying to tie together a decade of DC films that haven't had the same interconnectedness/planning as the Marvel films. This film uses Zod (Shannon) as the villain again, taking it back to 2013's 'Man of Steel'. While there's not a crazy amount that's new, there's some funny/nice/good moments, but probably not enough to elevate this to something special, and it's not quite as good as 'Wonder Woman' or 'Man of Steel'.

title: honest review
text: If there was a 0 i would have chosen it.This was a waste of 02:24:04 of my funkin life.Title: A Disastrous Attempt at Filmmaking: "The Abyss of Shadows" Deserves Its 1 out of 10 Rating"The Abyss of Shadows" is a film that aims high but falls painfully short in every aspect of its execution. From its convoluted plot to its abysmal performances and lackluster production quality, this movie is an absolute disaster. It is rare to come across a film that fails on so many levels, but "The Abyss of Shadows" manages to achieve this dubious distinction.The film opens with a promising premise-a group of explorers embarks on a perilous journey into an uncharted underworld. However, the plot quickly devolves into a convoluted mess. The narrative lacks coherence, leaving the audience confused and disconnected from the story. The dialogue is filled with clichés and lacks any meaningful depth or emotional resonance. Character development is virtually nonexistent, with the audience being introduced to one-dimensional, unrelatable figures who are impossible to invest in.The performances in "The Abyss of Shadows" are uniformly atrocious. The cast appears to be devoid of any acting talent, delivering wooden, emotionless performances that make the film feel like a high school drama production. The lack of chemistry among the actors further exacerbates the film's already unbearable shortcomings. It is clear that the director failed to extract any meaningful performances from the cast, leaving the audience wondering how such talentless performances made it onto the big screen.In addition to its poor storytelling and performances, "The Abyss of Shadows" suffers from a noticeable lack of production quality. The cinematography is amateurish, with shaky camera work and poorly framed shots. The visual effects, if they can even be called that, are laughable, reminiscent of low-budget B-movies from decades ago. The audio design is equally subpar, with poor sound mixing that often renders important dialogue unintelligible.The film's pacing is another significant flaw. The narrative drags on without purpose or direction, leading to a torturous viewing experience. The few action sequences present in the movie are poorly choreographed and lack any tension or excitement. Even the attempts at suspense fall flat due to the predictable and poorly executed plot twists. It becomes increasingly challenging to stay engaged as the film stumbles from one incoherent scene to another.Moreover, the production design and set decoration in "The Abyss of Shadows" are uninspired and uninspiring. The locations lack any sense of authenticity or visual appeal, further contributing to the film's overall lackluster atmosphere. The costume design and makeup are equally disappointing, failing to create a believable world for the characters to inhabit."The Abyss of Shadows" attempts to tackle complex themes but does so in a clumsy and heavy-handed manner. The film's feeble attempts at social commentary and philosophical musings come across as trite and pretentious, adding insult to injury. It is evident that the filmmakers bit off more than they could chew, resulting in a film that feels disjointed and out of touch with its own intentions.In conclusion, "The Abyss of Shadows" is an excruciating cinematic experience that fails to deliver on any level. From its baffling narrative choices to its abysmal performances and lackluster production quality, this film is a prime example of how not to make a movie. It is not often that a film deserves a rating of 1 out of 10, but "The Abyss of Shadows" earns that distinction with its incompetence and lack of redeeming qualities. Save yourself the agony and steer clear of this cinematic disaster.

title: What in the fresh mediocrity is this flaming garbage? Jay and Silent Ezra
text: It literally astounds me how obnoxiously ignorant DC are, to keep making the same Hack Snyder-esque stuff over, and over, and over.What is with the constant mummy issue storylines? The forced humour? The overthetop and horrendously bad CGI. This is a 250 million dollar movie, that feels like a Saturday morning cartoon in Live Action.In what world or universe would anyone think that this would fly, let alone be a good idea, let alone an actual production, let alone entertainment that they could charge money for?I don't care for Ezra Miller, though the guy can act. He is however, terribly miscast as the femboy, inflection-voiced tween awkward adolescent trying to outdo Tom Holland's effortless nerd kid charm with an overthetop irritation that is unparalled - only until you meet his more overthetop, jarringly grating alter ego.Why are the female superhero characters always average-faced, androgynysed with male haircuts, scowls, and absolutely dripping with zero visual feminine appeal and loads of masculine energy. Why are they always latino? Would it kill them to make an actual gorgeous, femininely perfected version akin to Chris Reeve? Super characters are meant to be the epitome of human perfection. Not average kids you see at the supermarket.
