Who can't act but just yell and scream and read words in a monotone voice.This is literally Spiderman multiverse - done horrendously badly, no frills version, with zero of the charm. And it feels it. We've seen all this before. It was cool the first time. Not the twentieth.Poor Keaton is just pure fan service, and feels even more embarrassing. The literal eye roll cringe hearing him repeat original lines that appear perfectly framed in front of a green screen with an almost WINK NUDGE WINK NUDGE DID YOU SEE / HEAR THAT AUDIENCE? Is enough to make one vomit, and even he feels odd saying them. And it is in no way worth the tightening of the 1 out of 100,000 nerd boy's trousers for having including it.The Bold and the Beautiful level script and forced drama are far too often laughable. It FEELS like satire. It FEELS like a Jay and Silent Bob skit that quite literally mocks the entire superhero genre, and minimizes its even greatest of characters. Which is exactly what Keaton's presence does. When little toys on strings and other 80s effects add more gravitas from his original films over the tech marvels (but absolutely hollow / zero depth) we have in today's films, you know you've got massive problems.I absolutely don't know who this movie is for. No children, not adults, not DC fans, not superhero fans, not movie fans. No-one with a brain and an attention span could swallow. Garbage and call it satisfying.FWIW, I LOVED the director's IT work, but this is the kind of fall from grace that one oft doesn't recover from. Having said that, so does Zack's trash. And yet, here we are. When even he isn't around, history still repeats.

title: An enjoyable mess
text: This is a bloated mess, and I kind of like it. I wouldn't call it good, but, you know what? I enjoy the mess a bit, and there's enough of an emotional throughline that bookends the film in its first and last act to provide some low level of pathos to the whole insane affair. It doesn't work as a whole, and it's emblematic of the hugely wasteful and overstuffed nature of comic book movies in the early 2020s. However, there are charms to be had.Barry Allen (Ezra Miller) is the janitor of the Justice League, as he explains to Alfred (Jeremy Irons) during an effort to prevent the collapse of a hospital, a result of some kind of assault on it that Batman (Ben Affleck) is trying to resolve on the other side of Gotham. It's here, in the opening action sequence of the film, where it is extremely obvious that the limits of the film's special effects budget was put to the test. Babies falling out of buildings with the Flash saving them in his accelerated state simply look plasticky and fake, but the action is amusing as he has to eat his munchies to up his calorie count and have enough energy to go faster. That this whole sequence ends up pointless, including a cameo from Wonder Woman (Gal Gadot) is unfortunate. The rest of the movie has nothing to do with it.So, moving on.The actual plot involves Barry deciding to go back in time to prevent his mother's (Maribel Verdu) death by getting her a can of tomatoes during a fateful trip to the grocery store, the small event that led to her murder and his father (Ron Livingston) being blamed for it, putting him in jail. When he tries to go back, he ends up in an alternate timeline where she didn't die, but it's also several years prior. Pretty much everything with Barry's mother is actually quite good, Verdu having a small part that she does well in. However, it's where Miller is his least annoying and most able to reach some form of pathos.Unfortunately, the film turns into a proto-origin story as Barry takes his younger self on a little bit of discovery of his powers, and the younger Barry is just...annoying. He's obviously intentionally so, acting as a less mature counterpoint to older Barry, but it's never that fun to watch. Throw in the fact that the actual plot mechanics of the thing are just repeating stuff that, while never explicitly explained, were easy to figure out, and it feels like a waste of space. When Zod (Michael Shannon), though, shows up and there's no Superman to stop him, the two Barries go in search of Batman, finding Bruce Wayne (Michael Keaton) having given up the bat mantle in favor of incredibly well-practiced retirement. Together, they figure out that in this timeline (I guess it's more of a Timeline thing of alternate dimensions, though, for some reason, Barry references Back to the Future heavily) there is no Superman, instead there was a Supergirl (Sasha Calle) who landed in Russia whom they have to save.Gosh, this is a busy film, and we haven't even gotten to the extended finale in the desert.However, it is when the finale starts that I get into the film's weird groove. The action is bright, colorful, and clear. There are real stakes. It does enter a loop of death, but that's obviously on purpose. And the movement into the Speed Force to work through the consequences of trying to change time bring the film back to its thematic core. Sure, the special effects are waxy and far from realistic, but I don't consider that some sort of great sin. Miller has to play against himself in a couple of different ways, and it's surprisingly effective.It's not enough to save the film as a whole, but it's enough to keep it from being a complete and total disaster of overstuffed narrative in search for reason to be more than two hours long. It's enough to give me a kick out of the experience.Andy Muschietti threw the kitchen sink into this, and I'm just happy that some of it entertained me along the way. It's a mess, but sometimes I really do get a kick out of messes.

title: Nostalgia and laughs!
text: "The Flash" is an entertaining film that bets on nostalgia and whose script focuses on the already exploited theme of the multiverse, but manages to succeed by telling it in a more focused way on a specific theme, the script develops well, dizzyingly in great part of its length, though during the main battle scene it becomes tired and unfamiliar. The performances are good, highlighting the protagonist Ezra Miller who achieves two Flash characters with different nuances, the intellectual and the clueless comic, Michael Keaton also gives an incredible performance when he returns to interpret Batman. The soundtrack is good, managing to stay with the public. The cinematography is a great achievement in most of the scenes, also achieving quite good camera movements. The digital special effects are a mixture between well achieved and very bad, on several occasions After Effects is revealed and the graphics look more like those of a video game. For his part, Andy Muschietti's direction is nice, since he is a rather irregular director, he can direct good films and at other times films without charm, as for "The Flash" he achieved a quality film. A fun movie with some scenes that get tiresome.

title: Surprisingly enjoyable
text: Terribly distracting CGI but there are points in the movie where there is very little of it. Warning if you have any phobias around teeth, however. There are two scenes where his teeth fall out and it's unnecessary. The script has good elements and there are things to enjoy. It's funny at times, and watching Barry become annoyed with himself is pretty entertaining. Michael Keaton is easily the best part, and his involvement is greater than just a cheap cameo. His Bruce is interesting, tough and fun. I think this movie is worth the watch if you are a fan of the superhero genre and Keaton's batman. The movie doesn't detract from Kenton's batman legacy, it only adds to it.

title: sell xters to Marvel to get rank/box office results
text: Sell xters to Marvel to get rank/box office results is the only thing I could think of as a solution. And I am not talking about the movie's merits yet. It just seems so obvious: even for a rubbish Marvel movie the ranks and box office are upwards no matter what. Wandavision S01E01 already had around 8.5rank despite the fact that there was nothing inside there from what the Tv show wanted to present. I believe that there aretoo many of die hard Marvel fans, that if you make a 3h movie showing a wall with paints dry and someone said these paints come from the boots of Thor, Ironman and Spiderman, people would remain watch it and write high ranks comments.To the movie in question now. Despite A. Muscetti's lack of experience, he managed a great requel prequel kind of thing that spaghettifies in a smart way the whole DCU to make an Easter egg equivalent to all Easter eggs of the 7th art history.Michael Keaton was never the ideal Dark Knight for me (Batfleck was), but seeing him like that was such a return to my child years, the 1st loves, the 1st disappointments that it moved me a lot. Before jumping again to re-watch the 1989 classic for the 20th time, I stay here to say that the director did an excellent job depicting him eventually better than before. He caught the essence of T. Burton and J. Snyder and gave us a hell of a ride that felt much less than 2h making me wonder how the clock was so advanced at the end of the movie.I never liked Ezra Miller, so seeing him twice should have been too much. However lets admit that he is not the only one with issues and despite, lets credit him that he did a really fine job here.Indeed there are some CGI issues, but maybe Gunn has some good cards in his sleeves. I will definitely watch anything DC brings us. Can't even wait for more.

title: Fairly fun and entertaining, with LOTS of fan service but some awful, distracting CGI
text:
Based on the Flash comic book Flashpoint, I really respect that instead of making a movie of hero vs villain they decided to adapt a specific story where several characters appear. I find it refreshing and also I'm surprised and intrigued why this hasn't been done before. Movies usually take things from here and there and they end up building something that not always works..
Anyway, the story is good, it has some humour (not always great though, I'm still struggling with Miller's performance), lots of action and a huge amount of fan service and cameos that the big nerds like me (no shame) will appreciate and enjoy!It's overall a decent movie, but there's something really bad about it: the CGI.What the hell happened to this production ending up looking SO BAD in that department. There's also so much unnecessary CGI of normal people that looks so fake and unrealistic! Example when Flash is travelling in time, the faces on the treadmill are done by CGI, strangely, and everything looks like you're watching a videogame cutscene (and not a great one) instead of a live action movie in the cinema. Flash body looks awful most of the time, regardless the very cool design of the suit. And every scene when the characters meet themselves and one of the faces are made by CGI, it's so horrible that distracted me from what they're actually doing.One more, why Flash moves in slow motion while running? It's like he's gliding instead of giving steps! Really weird!The bad CGI almost ruins the movie for me, it certainly made me lower the rating. I wish it would look better, but as it is, it's an entertaining, decent superhero movie.

title: They managed to destroy one of the best DC stories
text: The Comic Book Flashpoint by Geoff Johns is one of the best DC Justice League comic books ever. It's those kind of books that you can't stop reading it, the characters, the story, the writing, the art, it's all extremely well done.So when I heard they were doing a movie about it, I thought it would be very hard to not create a very decent film with all the material the book gave us. I was wrong.I borrowed the Blu-ray from a friend and decided to watch it with a couple of friends. After 10 minutes, everybody in my room was just: "stop this, this is unwatchable".Then I said: "Ok, wait, maybe it gets better when batman shows up, lets skip to that part". It didn't, it became more stupid.So then again I said: "Ok, it definitely gonna get better when Superman shows up, trust me". It didn't... it got even worse.We stopped watching it and just picked another movie instead.I added some of the names of this movie to my blacklist so I avoid any more excruciating experiences like this one, in the future. The "writer" Christina Hodson is one of them, of course. My God...The funny thing is that the DC Cartoon movies are still pretty good, for the most part. But they just can't make good live action movies... Especially when DiVeRsiTy is the main focus of the writers, instead of quality.Anyway... Cheers.

title: Hidden Gem from A Much Hated Franchise
text: The Flash is what Multiverse of Madness wanted to do but better.After discovering he could go back in time, the Flash trying to make things right by making sure her mother survives the knifing accident that break their family apart.It has what I hated with Spider-Man: No Way Home, a plot about making things right BUT unlike it, it did not try to make a children's fairy tale about it. Its repercussion is serious without trying to make that mambo-jumbo styled tonal shift for the added comedic quirk that fanboys love. It took the case seriously AND made it with known that it has consequences. By the time, the Kryptonians arrived - there are repercussions. Repeated throughout. The tone changed with it. It sticked its landing.Though I would say, the reason it failed is pretty much written in the wind. Miller is hated, the way WB is using old actor is purely cash grab for nostalgia (and rightfully did not work), the CGI was meant to look bad but did not do favors to already negative reaction towards Miller and the Zaslav's cutting off the original Franchise.Overall, not the biggest masterpiece but a better use of 'Multiverse' plot and possibly the best DCEU film since Man of Steel.PS: If the Flash was able to return and found a new Bruce, wouldn't there be another Flash in that universe?

title: A Speedy Adventure Hindered by Lackluster Visual Effects
text: "Flash" takes audiences on a high-octane journey into the world of superheroes, but unfortunately, the visual effects fall short of expectations. While the film's overall experience is still enjoyable, the subpar VFX detract from the immersion and impact of the story.Despite the visual effects being a disappointment, the movie manages to salvage itself with its stellar cast. The main protagonist delivers a remarkable performance as the lightning-fast hero, injecting charisma and charm into the character. The supporting cast also shines, each bringing their unique talents to the table, adding depth and complexity to the narrative.The screenplay of "Flash" is a solid foundation for the film, blending elements of action, drama, and humor. The story is engaging, keeping the audience invested from beginning to end. Although the VFX may hinder some scenes, the script manages to compensate by delivering captivating character arcs and unexpected plot twists.The direction of the film is commendable, despite the visual effects shortcomings. Andy Muschietti navigates the narrative with skill and precision, maintaining a steady pace and effectively capturing the essence of the source material. The director's ability to bring out strong performances from the cast elevates the film, ensuring that the emotional core of the story remains intact.While the visual effects may be lacking, the film's cinematography and practical effects deserve recognition. The use of practical stunts and practical sets adds a sense of authenticity to the film, creating moments of genuine excitement. The camera work is well-executed, capturing the action sequences with precision and providing a sense of dynamism.The score of "Flash" is another highlight of the film. The music, composed by Benjamin Wallfisch effectively complements the on-screen events, elevating the emotional beats and intensifying the action. The soundtrack manages to create a cohesive and immersive experience, enhancing the overall enjoyment of the film.In terms of themes and messaging, "Flash" tackles important concepts such as heroism, self-discovery, and the power of perseverance. While the visual effects may falter, the film's exploration of these themes remains impactful, offering audiences moments of reflection and inspiration.In conclusion, "Flash" falls short in its visual effects, hindering the overall experience. However, the film manages to compensate with its stellar cast, engaging screenplay, competent direction, impressive practical effects, memorable score, and thought-provoking themes. Despite its flaws, "Flash" still provides an enjoyable superhero adventure that fans of the genre can appreciate. While it may not be perfect, it's worth watching for the performances and the story's engaging narrative.

title: What a mess!
text: «The Flash" from 2023 left much to be desired. With a convoluted plot that seemed more interested in confusing the audience than telling a coherent story, this film failed to deliver an engaging narrative. The performances by the cast were lackluster, with no actor managing to bring charisma to their roles. It felt like they were just going through the motions, without any real emotional depth or connection with the characters.The CGI in this film was a major disappointment. Instead of enhancing the viewing experience, it often detracted from it. The special effects looked cheap and unconvincing, which is particularly problematic for a superhero movie where visuals play a crucial role. The action sequences, which should have been a highlight, were marred by the subpar CGI and lacked the excitement and spectacle one would expect from a movie of this genre.The overall tone of "The Flash" was chaotic and noisy. The film seemed more interested in bombarding the audience with constant noise and action than in developing a compelling story or meaningful character arcs. It felt like a series of disjointed set pieces strung together with no real purpose or emotional resonance. This made it difficult to become invested in the characters or their struggles, as the film prioritized style over substance.One of the biggest issues with "The Flash" was its lack of a clear identity. It attempted to combine elements of various genres and tones, but the result was a confusing mishmash that never quite found its footing. Is it a superhero movie, a time-travel adventure, a comedy, or a drama? The film couldn't seem to decide, and this lack of focus undermined its overall impact.The pacing of the film was also problematic. It felt rushed in some parts and dragged in others, leading to an uneven and unsatisfying viewing experience. The plot twists and turns were often predictable, and the attempts at humor often fell flat. It seemed as though the filmmakers were trying too hard to please everyone, resulting in a movie that ultimately pleased no one.In conclusion, "The Flash" from 2023 failed to deliver on multiple fronts. From its convoluted plot to its uninspired performances, subpar CGI, and lack of a clear identity, the film left much to be desired. It was a noisy and disjointed mess that struggled to find its footing, making it a disappointment for both fans of the character and casual moviegoers alike.

title: Stop Judging Movies Based on what Actors Do or Say and Who What Opinions The Media Reports About Them Before They Release the Movie!! Just Watch The Movie if YOU Like It!
text: I don't care what actors do or eat on their free time. I choose the movies I watch and like based on if I liked the movie or not. I liked it. It wasn't as epic as it was advertised, but that's marketing. It was a good movie and should have made around 350 to 500 million. People are too sensitive and trust that what others cry for and rant about means anything or is real. If I have a gripe about something I will tell that person or business. I don;t have to cry to the world about my bruised ego or be reduced to vampiric journalism. What business is it to the rest of the world unless it causes bodily harm, psychological or PTSD level emotional damage. Stop looking for approval, sympathy or celebrity status at the belittlement of people that live in circles me or you could never understand. Who cares if your rich neighbor has a nice car. Worry about your lemon in the driveway. Anyways, I thought the CGI was cartoonish needed to be just as dark and grittyas the other themed movies and tv shows. Humor is fine just gotta stay in your lane. Other Supermen were bad CGI. Nice surprises and I liked the script and the combination of Flashpoint and intro of Reverse Flash or whomever his alternate timeline self became (Godspeed?). Give these artists more time and respect. They are a very large part of your movie or investment. More time and cooperation = better finished product. Alita: Battle Angel for the win! Marvel used to be better when they released one movie a year. DC was better when focusing on TV or Movies not both. DC has better stories than the justice League though. Avengers, Fantastic Four, Superman, Batman, Justice League I have seen too much of YOU. That is why James Gunn is succeeding. Please choose another epic story to be different and stand out! Suicide Squad and Guardians of the Galaxy was a brilliant move. Wake up studios! Wake up Directors. Don't let the masses dictate what media you make (DIsney). F@#$ck em all and let history sort it out. Just be happy that you can watch stuff about a favorite character from your childhood. ...back in my day... Your memory is probably just another casualty to the Mandela Effect. 🤣 Peace.

title: Very Fun and Heartwarming
text: I came in knowing all the reviews weren't very good and was pleasantly surprised how much fun and humorous it was. Batman Keaton was amazing and so was the new Superman. Ezra played a great role and the CGI wasn't bothersome in the least. I kind of know what people mean, but I think they are expecting way too much and honestly probably are hating on Ezra Miller. The movie is back to back laughs with a lot of heart. The Ezra duo was very impressive. There were no moments that broke the suspension of disbelief. If you are looking for Batman and Superman nostalgia this is the movie for you. This is a nice ending and hopefully beginning to the reign of the new DCU.

title: Over hyped but still a solid film.
text: While it is not one of the greatest superhero movies ever made I did still enjoy it and it is a solid movie. Ezra miller did a good job but I still want him gone. Michael Keaton made a great return as Batman. And Sasha calle supergirl steals the show and I will miss batfleck and it has a really emotional scene towards the end that almost had me in tears. However the cgi was awfully bad what did they do with their budget. I also love the action in this movie especially with Batman. For me it's an 8/10.But the ending i did not like that and a disappointing credit scene.Overhyped but still good.

title: The best movie from DCEU
text: Flash has everything you wish to see in a superhero movie. The movie was very engaging from start to finish. There is a shot where the camera follows flash while he is running at the speed of the light and that continues for sometime, that was easily one of the best shots I have seen in a movie. Ezra's performance in this movie is phenomenal to say the least. And also Michael Keaton is just fantastic. Never thought I will be seeing him again as Batman. A lot of sequences where Barry has interaction with his younger self is funny as hell. The Emotional aspects of this movie are great. I am glad that I watched this movie in the first day of release. Andy Muschietti has done the best job he can do in this movie. We got the flash movie we deserved thanks to him.

title: Dropped the ball!
text: I was really looking forward to this but huge disappointment. Ezra Miller was annoying, supergirl has no expression can't smile just serious all the time. Michael Keaton coming back was supposed to be special total waste for this movie. Special effects are terrible and look unfinished. The visualization of time travel is not very good. My wife who likes these types of movies fell asleep. DC needs to recast flash and cyborg. I can't believe they were so good at having a perfect Wonder Woman, Superman, Batman, and making Aquaman but so poor with the choice of Flash and Cyborg. This could have been a great movie but the ball was dropped.

title: Great to see batman, but poor CGI ruins the flavor of the whole thing
text: Entertainment is simple, a bit pleasant and unfortunately you can see shortcuts/cutting costs. Of course, Michel Keaton's Batman is a kind of dream come true, unfortunately there was not enough money for the fuel for the Batmobile, and the Batwing has undergone some dubious modifications over the years. Either way, it kept the movie going, along with other interesting faces throughout the movie, and some good humor. The most disappointing thing is the CGI. I have the impression that Man of Steel was on a much higher level, it was refined, and there is simply a lot and cheap.There's nothing to write down. And whoever came up with the scenes of the collapsing hospital for newborns should be ashamed, every parent (and there are quite a few in the world) watching these scenes probably did it with a lot of disgust.

title: The Flash is Definitely NOT a Great Movie, but not a bad movie either
text: After several delays, The Flash finally came on screen. It has some great moments, but overall it doesn't live up to the hype. First of all, the CGI is awful. There are plenty of scenes where it feels like a kid made it in microsoft paint, but overall it's not really noticeable. I really liked the suit, it feels better than the CW suit. I liked the scene where barry goes into a door and how the molecules go through the door, it feels very well-detailed. The plot is good but not great. It's just a Flashpoint adaptation which could've been way better. In the beginning where we see Barry's calorie watch, it feels cool and could've been used again, i was hoping that but then... Never mentioned again, like come on, Seriously? Supergirl was way under used and didn't even have a proper arc. I really liked Micheal Keaton's Batman and i think it was one of the only great things about the movie. The final battle was AWFUL. It feels uncompleted and way too bad. Overall, 6/10.

title: More enjoyable that i anticipated, but not as good as the studio portrayed in its marketing.
text: Better than I thought it would be. I feel like the movie is being attacked by either people how hate Ezra Miller or people how hate that the Snyder universe is getting erased, as well as by people who did not like the marketing for this movie which claim this movie to be the best superhero movie ever.The reality is that this movie is solid. It's not the best movie ever. But it's better than most of the Marvel phase 4 movies. It's better than Eternals, Thor 4, Ant Man Quantumania, Black widow, and better than Shazam, Black Adam, Wonder Woman 1984.There is questionable CGI at times, that's true. But they are brief moments that don't really take away from the experience. The humor mostly lands, because of the funny things that happen to Barry, but the second Barry was kinda annoying.I liked most cameos, I like that the women in this movie are sexy and feminine. Super girl looks great and i hope she stays as super girl in the new James Gunn universe. She has a strong screen presence and for now she isn't the stereotype of Mary Sue or Girl boss that needs no man or anyone because she is better and stronger than anyone else".She is down to earth, respects men around her, she is compassionate, isn't an insufferable feminist who hates men, while still having her own agency and her own strength. It would be a shame if they replaced her.The message of the movie is: "Accept what has happened, learn from it, and use that knowledge to guide you in living your best life now".

title: Pleasantly Surprised
text: This film was a lot better than I thought it would be. Was fast paced with some comedy. Not over bearing comedy but just enough of it. The cameos were amazing and fun to see. I was worried this was going to be another Aquaman or Wonder Woman 1984 which eere just eh films. I wish the Snyderverse would continue. I am not happy about the James Gunn reboot. Nor am I happy about Henry Cavill's cameo being uncut. Don't know what Gunn's problem is with him. DC was already a bit of a cluster due to Whedon's crappy Justice League film. Oh well maybe enough fans will petition to get back the Snyderverse.

title: Loved the humour
text: So this is now DCEU's biggest box office debacle in recent history; this is on its way to achieving lower domestic box office figures than the previous record holder, the notorious "The Green Lantern", and now to add insult to injury, DCEU had put a lot of faith in this project apparently. Yet, it turned out to be a complete shipwreck!Several reasons factored in its gigantic failure, the major one being the allegations made against Ezra Miller, and this whole fiasco did have a considerable impact on the film's theatrical run.Now, let us keep these things aside and judge this solely from a cinematic standpoint. Is it a terrible movie? No, is it great, then? Not, then what is it? A decent, passable entertainer and that's all!There are some cool visuals, the humour is effective, and on top of all, the story itself digs through (or at least tries to) some interesting themes, mainly the concept of parallel timelines, aka Multiverse!Don't get your hopes too high, though. While the writing does emphasise paradoxes and branched-out timelines caused by this time manipulation, the greater implications do not come off as ostensibly as they would have wanted to. It gets so convoluted in the final moments, I feel; a more efficient direction from behind the camera could have done the job they intended to.P. S. Seeing Michael Keaton slipping into the suit of Batman gave me immense pleasure.

title: Stop casting criminals for superhero movies
text: Time to recast Ezra Miller as The Flash. What does the actor has that another actor doesn't (Apart from the number of criminal records that keep piling up)?It seems that Ezra is relishing on the fact that Hollywood keeps casting him no matter what he does. So, he his crimes keep getting bigger while he gets casted as main characters in movies. And as for The Flash, he becomes the titular character, the superhero, The Flash!How can anyone watch this movie knowing it's a criminal who is acting as the hero? How is it fair to the other actors? Supergirl is making am appearance along with Micheal Keaton's batman and how is it fair for these actors to work alongside a criminal and to have a massive number of people boycott the movie for Ezra?It's time Ezra learns the repercussions of his bad actions and it's time Hollywood punishes him. Enough is enough.

title: A Very Enjoyable Movie
text: I watched it today and absolutely loved it. The film was action packed, funny and had some very touching moments too. There were a lot of surprises, some of which I already knew about and some which were a genuine surprise to me.The special effects were a bit off at times, but it didn't really phase me as the scenes were highly enjoyable.Now, if like me at first, you are one who is on the fence about watching this due to the allegations circling Ezra Miller, remember that there are many others involved in the making of this movie both in front and behind the camera who don't deserve to be punished for someone else's sins.If you do opt to watch it, hope you enjoy it as much as I did.I had a great time watching it and I highly recommend it.

title: Even with all the references, "The Flash" rarely excites. The battle scenes have few textures and the action is generic and poorly finished accordingly
text: The plot begins with a powerful action scene, in which Barry Allen-Flash (Ezra Miller) is called to help the victims of a terrorist attack in a hospital. While the opening sequence already manages to give us the tone of the film, it also serves as an impetus for us to understand Barry's true intentions and the traumas he has carried for a long time - given that his mother was murdered when he was just a child and that the father took the blame and now awaits a trial that doesn't seem to have a happy ending. It is from there that, moved by the brief spark of hope in restoring a family that was torn apart by a poorly explained tragedy, Barry moves through anguish and melancholy to go back in time and prevent his mother from dying. However, what he did not expect is that his benevolent actions would trigger a series of events foreshadowing the implosion of the multiverse.What would you do if you could go back in time is the maxim that governs the feature film directed by Andy Muschietti - and a question that has certainly crossed our minds. After all, we all make mistakes and feel responsible for having acted differently and fixed what was broken. Barry, in this way, discovers that he has an ability to return to the past, breaking fragile rules of space-time to "change events" and ensure the survival of the one he never forgot. Now, it is remarkable how the protagonist is enveloped by a vigilante blindness that makes him forget the butterfly effect - and that takes him on a tortuous journey of reparation and nostalgia. However, no matter how noble his intentions may have been, the plan backfires and he opens a timeline parallel to the one he belongs to, creating a perpendicular rift in the multiverse that predicts catastrophe.For those who watched the trailers and promotional teasers for The Flash, you will probably have few surprises throughout the 140 minutes of the feature film directed by Argentinean Andy Muschietti. From the main special appearances to the apotheotic moments, almost everything had been revealed by Warner-DC's marketing department in the advertising pieces. Which, let's face it, takes a lot of the fun and emotional impact out of scenes like Batman (Michael Keaton) saying his iconic line "I am Batman". Surprising moments are really rare, usually references to other incarnations of the publisher's main superheroes in cinema and television. The plot itself shows Barry surprising himself with his ability to navigate between temporal plots and landing in the past to try to change his lonely present of orphanhood (dead mother and imprisoned father). When going back in time, he comes across his 18-year-old version, still without the powers brought by an unlikely combination of chemical elements and lightning fallen from the sky. However, the protagonist did not imagine that this world would be different from his own in certain ways, with several variants and few familiar constants. Batman is a different person, Superman Kal-el has a different destiny, but Zod (Michael Shannon) continues to come to Earth to conquer it and revive his home, Krypton.The Barry of the past is the hero who is reluctant when faced with the call to adventure, but who proves his worth along the journey of maturity. The Barry of the present is the mentor who guides his younger version to learn, thereby demonstrating the ability to be more than Batman's boy wonder - the same dramatic curve as Peter Parker, who proved to be more than Batman's boy wonder of Iron Man. Absolutely everything revolves around these parallel and complementary journeys of the Barrys, but that doesn't make The Flash a serious film about feelings, traumas and adult sensations. In addition to personal controversies, Ezra Miller had proven in other works to be an actor with repertoire, something that in this new super production is only partially valued. An irritating and loud teenager, the Barry of the past gains space and constantly supplants the seriousness of the Barry of the present, who carries the character's tragic tones. Andy Muschietti chooses to give more time and importance to the comic content, thereby sabotaging items such as: the hero's sadness aspects, the obsolescence of Michael Keaton's Batman and the strong personality of Supergirl (Sasha Calle). No wonder, Batman and Supergirl are demoted to mere occasional colleagues. Batman is still valued for its nostalgic aspect, but Krypton's daughter is compromised by the suffocation of drama.In addition to this issue, the film is tonally very strange, with an initial sequence of frantic action in Gotham City that serves to make it very clear that the Flash in this film is the Flash from Justice League, complete with Jeremy Irons' Alfred and the Ben Affleck's Batman (albeit wearing an absolutely hideous version of his costume). At the beginning, the tone is openly comical, with Ezra Miller reveling in his dramatic limitations as a court jester, with the beating itself taking on a veneer that was supposed to be hilarious, but which ends up only generating yellow smiles due to the exaggeration of the whole thing, including a newborn rescue sequence in a hospital featuring horrific visual effects of these babies. Then, in the other universe, the footprint is opposite, darker and heavier, but also more rushed and without Muschietti, at any point, really having the courage to bet his chips on it, which leaves room for inconveniences of displaced humor that they detract from the whole and deflate the drama, especially because the development of the two Barry Allens, especially the youngest, is relegated to the background and then, almost instantly, is accelerated from 0 to 100 without giving time.Another problem that weighs heavily on "The Flash", especially in the final third of the projection, is the visual effects. And it's not just a standard complaint about hero films: the thing is bad even by the low standards that Marvel has been presenting lately. The opening sequence, with Flash saving falling babies, is terrible on a PlayStation 2 level and there are several racing scenes that all feel artificial and weightless. And it's something that really hinders the experience, as it takes away the impact of key moments. There are special appearances that are made entirely (and without purpose in certain cases) in CGI that look like rubber and wax dolls with which it is impossible to create any connection. What should be nerd apotheosis becomes just something shameful. Luckily for fans and spectators, Muschietti manages to balance the poverty of the effects with a firm pulse on the progress of the story. In the end, it is thanks to his direction that "The Flash" manages to deliver something that DC has never managed before: uncompromised and unpretentious fun.The rest of the film, especially its final minutes once again in the chronosphere, is a search for references and fan service that irritatingly has become the standard for blockbusters of the genre. Out the window goes the story, which is then summarily replaced by the absolute and inescapable emptiness that are the moments that exist only for the viewer to point at the screen and identify this or that character and object more quickly than their friend next door. The cinematic experience, therefore, becomes an uninspired child's game that requires nothing from anyone other than a frankly useless encyclopedic knowledge of pop culture.Even with all the references, "The Flash" rarely excites. The battle scenes have few textures and the action is generic and poorly finished accordingly. Post-production is responsible for showing super-powered beings in battles so sumptuous that they lose sight of the human dimension of these extraordinary men and women. And, by the way, the quality of the CGI is not always consistent with the economic power of the production. An initiative full of special appearances, Flash's first solo adventure serves to introduce the concept of the multiverse to DC and make beautiful tributes to his long and sometimes sleepy journey. This journey of weak emotions includes never-before-realized cinematic versions of characters such as Nicolas Cage's Superman (one of the good ideas) and tributes to the precursors of the wave that has reigned for more than 20 years in cinema with a more industrial feel. Furthermore, there are good jokes about changes in timelines - the best of which is about the protagonism of the "Back to the Future" Saga. In fact, recharging the "flux capacitor" with lightning is another affective borrowing from Robert Zemeckis' creation. However, the solutions are lazy and difficult problems are solved with simplistic strategies - like the lightning bolt that, if replicated, could create armies of Flashes? In the end, even the resolution of "Spider-Man: No Way Home" is recycled by DC Comics. Reality almost collapses for the protagonist to learn to accept losses and understand the value of his scars. This film, at least, should be the last of DC's current phase, serving as a reboot of the universe - so it's strange to see a Batman from the past hated by fans appearing in the final scenes in a questionable and confusing participation - it's strange to think that "Blue Beetle" and "Aquaman 2" would still be released after this production.

title: Cringe
text: DC and WB just can't seem to get it right. I was hyped for this movie because I thought this was the one for them finally. It's hard to watch. Ezra Miller is really hard to like in real life with their personal drama but they're somehow even more unlikable on screen. Their jokes or attempts to be humorous are not funny and with a 2 1/2 hour movie they just get annoying and their cursing just served no purpose so when it keeps happening it's just frustrating. The CGI is shockingly bad. Some scenes are like watching a PS2 cut scene. Affleck kills it in his very brief appearance and it just makes you further upset with how Warner Bros just wasted his talent all these years. The cameos are kinda fun, the ones that aren't CGI at least, but the story just drags on in my opinion and parts don't really make sense. They could have stuck to The Flashpoint Paradox but choose a different path to almost create their own version of "Spider-Man: No Way Home" and it feels forced. The action sequences could have been great but they just get ruined by how bad the CGI is. I know the director said they're suppose to be bad but that just can't be true or if it is true it's because they were given no resources to make it better. Overall I didn't enjoy it and my son who loves anything DC fell asleep so not a ringing endorsement of anything attention grabbing.

title: When time travel is involved the film will be rubbish
text: What is this obsession with these superhero film makers to mess about with dimensions and universes? It gets in the way of a decent plot. From one cranky subplot about crossing space time boundaries to multiple characters. The daftness refuses to diminish.The Flash is a minor character in this film it feels Barry Allen is too goofy to be taken seriously.After messing with time to save his parents it turns out, yawn, that General Zod has invaded Earth. Conveniently they find supergil being held captive in Russia.Nothing in this film is original or in the least bit captivating. This endless loop of messing with time to get results without any further distortions frankly is tiresome. I failed to finish the film.

title: Entertainment 👍
text:
So I just ignored all reviews and went to theater and to be honest I didn't expect this much from The Flash.I'm not an Ezra Miller fan ? But the movie was a good one to watch at the big screen. Same Flashpoint story ( a pretty decent plot ), acting was acceptable and the cameos were a nice touch for the fans. It had some good laughs and had some very silly "Ezra" moments.In short, the film was very enjoyable, over 2 hours and didn't feel that long. Michael Keaton returns as Batman and nailed it! Supergirl vs Zod fight was ok for the poor CGI at moments but I personally don't mind that if I am enjoying a movie.It's an honest 7 / 10 and it's weird to have a really good movie with all the hype and bots writing 10 / 10 reviews lol
Worths the watch with family at the cinema 👍

title: Didnt live up to the Hype..The Flash Fizzles
text: Its strange when the lead character is the Least interesting one in the movie! I was open to Ezra trying the role but in this movie, he falls flat and fails to impress...at all.... Granted he was in the role previously and did a passable, if not quirky job at it but when given the title role, there just isnt the substance in the writing nor the acting chops to make it fly..I actually fast forwarded thru alot of Ezra;s goofy moments of which there were Many..The silly posing of the characters,in the middle of action scenes, not only the flash but also supergirl, was just over the top and frankly looked ridiculous...That said, some of the better moments were when supergirl was on screen..i liked what Sasha did with the character even though the fight scenes were a stretch to believe..Here you had 2 Kryptonians, supergirl facing Zod, both possessed of hieghtened super powers, yet the 90-lb supergirl was throwing around Zod like he was paper mache'... they were Both from krypton and he was twice and more her size, she shouldnt have stood a chance here but did..Sasha played the character well though with her own unique way of doing it..I liked it! Micheal keaton? Whats not to like? The dude was a highlight of the film along with supergirl and Zod..the Flash himself was for me the low point...this role has been done Infinitely better by others, namely the excellent portrayl by Grant Gustin... seeing Ezra's attempt at a solo role was a letdown and I would hope the role gets passed to more capable hands along with better writing because this was a mess...this movie tries the "lets add everything And the kitchen sink" approach along with some not so good CGI with super heroes looking like they were lifted by wire harnesses, which in truth,they were! But the audience should Never get that impression...This hodgepodge is Not a keeper for me..there are so many super hero movies that would put it to shame with actors who do justice to their characters..Henry Cavil was someone who did a superb job in his role yet was dropped yet here you have someone who if dropped, would not be missed ,from this role and yet remains... Who decides these things?

title: Mostly unpredictable, mostly fun with couple really bad jokes.
text: Coming into it Ezra's Flash has been the most annoying character in the DCU, it stops being that rather quickly. The movie gets into thick of it pretty fast and keeps the tempo up till the end. Most of the time it feels unpredictable while some of it is not, half fresh maybe the best way to describe it. I laughed several times almost to tears and a couple times the jokes where so bad it pulled me out. There was a lot of action but kind of forgot it happened, no super cool fast slowmo scenes like for example in x-men. It is hard to say what exactly it lacks. A lot did happen and it was mostly a joyful ride but nothing iconic. I don't think I will ever watch this again but have absolutely zero regrets watching it.

title: Good Comic Book Movie failed by Bad Studio
text: Releasing after such great hype, The Flash failed to generate any sort of fan love from it's Cinema audience. Even though I had very low expectations from the movie, after a couple of recommendations I decided to give it a watch & Thank God I did cause it has so much to offer then people expected. The Complains of VFX being goofy & weird is true for some parts of the movie but for most part it's still comes off nicely done. The plot deters from the comics a little which was a fun surprise. The first act was kind of goofy but nothing you might hate. Ben Affleck, Micheal Keaton & Sasha Calle outshone Ezra in the movie in all the right ways. The second & third act of the movie were so unexpected that I actually had to rewind some of the parts and analyse frame by frame. The conclusion was very satisfying with a cool cameo to end the film and with it the DCEU. Although the film recieved criticism & hate mainly due to Ezra's real life issues, I still think it is one of the better movies we have seen from DC & may very well be on the levels of No Way Home & Multiverse of Madness if it wasn't for some sloppy parts & Ezra Miller'S weird if not goofy acting. A great watch as a Superhero Genere fan & would recommend watching it yourself before listening to all the comments.

title: Still the Best for Me
text: Although major media outlets are now rushing to report box office losses, it is not true to say that I will not feel sad in my heart. Just like me, who had once lost hope and had no expectations, the moment I saw it was released, it ignited my hope again. To be honest, the current word-of-mouth ratings of The Flash among other Superhero movies are not as bad as I thought, which can be considered a surprising or comforting thing. I think Ezra has shown everyone his outstanding acting skills, as well as his dedication and love for the character, Barry Allen. Unfortunately, the work itself was obviously born out of time. But after going through so many obstacles, I wouldn't be surprised about what would happen next. After 8 years of tough breed, the script is almost overturned and rebuilt every year... Now I have to be satisfied with this final presentation, and even feel fortunate to be able to see it in the cinema. Although it sounds like an excuse, box office is not the only criterion for testing a work. I will be more thankful if The Flash can once leave something, or anything in DC or Superhero movie history. Deep helplessness from a fan, man.

title: The Spaghetti part is good
text:
As expected, this movie isn't particularly worth watching. Thankfully, I went with low expectations and wanting only to watch 5 minutes of Keaton's Batman, and that's what I got.The dreadful lead performance (both of them) and poor CGI are so glaringly/prominently bad that they transform an otherwise play, albeit very poorly written, story structure into an almost unwatchable film.There's no other way to describe it, but ezra sucks. His acting and mannerisms do not provide enough for anyone to care about the character (instead, the opposite, real life included). Then, the script is structurally uninteresting. In fact, it feels like the movie is missing pieces.. and some of the parts they did decide to include just makes the experience even worse. There's no consistency in its time-traveling rules, or even with previous entries in the "franchise".As a bit of a surprise, Sasha Calle is given a decent role and she performs it very well! She also looks great in it, much more so than I expected. But it is another comic storyline that is used for nothing...
Now, the biggest surprise was Maribel Verdú, whom I liked VERY much. The only part with "weight" comes from her part and acting. So, the movie isn't devoid of everything.. it's simply that the parts to get there are underwritten and lacking in imagination (even if her emotional role is tired and overdone).Stay home.You aren't missing anything that is not on the trailers, and the action and developments are too simplistic! Warner Brothers allowing ezra to lead a movie by himself was a weird choice, but to not even address his real-life antics, while letting him finish the project? The scores and box-office results were deserved.

title: Good story
text: Classic example where I am glad that I ignore the so called professional critics.This started a little shaky with a baby scene that didn't work for me, but other than that I found it funny at times, nostalgic at others and with a story that was interesting enough.Much better live action film than any other DC or Marvel film that I have seen in ages.Very good acting by all. Disappointing to see opening weekend Box office figures, as I would have loved to see a flash sequel, but have a feeling that will not happen.Effects were decent overall. Some good emotional moments and I never got bored.

title: Not perfect , but Great Send Off
text: I'll get to the meat & bones of the film. I was really wanting this film to be great & well in - in some aspects it was. The opening action sequence was disappointing as the C. G. was Not to the standard we expect nowadays especially given that it's a DC film. I can only assume they did not want to invest any more funds on a dead franchise. The writers should have re-written the sequence but regardless, I found it fun & entertaining. Ezra is Ezra & his alternate version is annoying but it's addressed & acceptable.Michael Keaton is what lured me & he didn't disappoint. The nostalgia of the O. G. is very cool & I was thrilled that the musical theme from Batman the Animated Series was used ! There are some scenes which run long but again, it's not detrimental to the movie. The overall story is solid, simple & stays the course. Supergirl is used sparingly & I was pleased that she wasn't another Captain Marvel but there were slight indicators that she could've gone down that path. To finish without ranting on.. the ending is very sentimental & MUCH nostalgia & respect is given to the foundation of DC superheroes which I absolutely loved. In summary - the cons are the CG effects & some slight bad acting from Supergirl & Ezra on Red Bull. The Pros- the movie was very enjoyable & the tributes given were very well done & will bring a smile & tears to your face. This film brought a memorable end to the DC franchise that sadly did not live up to expectations like Marvel did.

title: Not Your Typical Superhero Movie
text:
Not you typical Superhero movie with lots of fight, and useless drama,where saving the world from evil is as common as eating food regularly,It's A well made movie with a good story line which doesn't holds you at first 20min but when it starts running, you'll have to hold your seats tight, Actually this is a type of movie which will take you to the era of 2005-2015, when superhero movies have their own plot, and when you finish watching that movie you'll be like what I have watched man for e.g:- Hancock,Captain America WS,Iron man1
,Deadpool,Spiderman1,Superman etc.Those were the movies which literally have no BS like we have to save the world they look like that this is actually happening. With hero saving their own city.But today superheroes movies are more like, saving the world, showing unnecessary action sequences, And giving a message at last of good and evil.But flash is that movie which I have watched after so many years, yes it was worth my moneyP. S:- Even my sister who doesn't even know about DC comics enjoyed this movie because of its good story and CGI so you'll enjoy it definitely.

title: Pretty fun
text: This flash movie was pretty good. Having enjoyed the show untill it got boring the possibility of a movie in the dcu seemed off. Originally grant gustin was to play. Ezra miller does pretty pl. His fun at times and serious in othes when it calls for of. There were some unexpected appearances by characters, who I won't mention here. Keaten being back again was a happy return. He took the role just as he did before. The action was good to with constant bad guy action. The one thing for me that a leg down was the CGI used. At times it seemed just awful and worse than the show. But overall an alright DC movie.

title: Great Movie
text: The Flash movie of 2023 delivers an electrifying cinematic experience that will leave fans and newcomers alike buzzing with excitement. Directed by a visionary team and featuring a talented cast, this film successfully captures the essence of the Scarlet Speedster while weaving a compelling narrative that keeps you on the edge of your seat.From the opening sequence, the film immerses you in the fast-paced world of Barry Allen, played brilliantly by [actor's name]. The portrayal of the beloved superhero is both heartfelt and charismatic, capturing his witty charm and genuine vulnerability. The Flash's powers come alive on the big screen, showcasing breathtaking visuals and adrenaline-pumping action sequences that will leave you in awe.The supporting cast brings depth and dynamism to the story, with standout performances from [actors' names]. Their chemistry with Barry Allen adds an emotional depth to the film, exploring themes of friendship, sacrifice, and the complexities of time travel. The dynamic between the heroes and villains is intense, providing an enthralling clash of wills that keeps the audience engaged throughout.The narrative of The Flash movie is a clever blend of thrilling superhero action and emotional storytelling. The time-travel element adds an intriguing layer of complexity, weaving together different eras and alternate realities seamlessly. The film deftly balances the high-stakes battles with introspective moments, delving into the personal journey of Barry Allen as he grapples with his own demons and seeks to reshape his destiny.Visually, The Flash movie is a feast for the eyes. The special effects are top-notch, creating mesmerizing sequences that showcase the speed and power of the Scarlet Speedster. The cinematography captures the kinetic energy of the Flash's movements, making every scene a visual treat.Furthermore, the film's score elevates the viewing experience, complementing the on-screen action and enhancing the emotional beats. The music adds an extra layer of intensity, effectively capturing the essence of the characters and the world they inhabit.In conclusion, The Flash movie of 2023 is a thrilling, action-packed adventure that pays homage to the beloved superhero while offering a fresh and engaging take on his story. With its exceptional performances, captivating storyline, and stunning visuals, this film is a must-watch for fans of the genre and a great introduction for those new to the world of the Fastest Man Alive. Prepare to be captivated by The Flash's lightning-fast journey into heroism and self-discovery.

title: Flashpoint-less
text: Unbearably bad. Someone, somewhere, is making a mint by siphoning many millions away from cgi budgets. And script budgets, and costume budgets, and... Flash's budget was around $200 million and I didn't see half of that on the screen. The nose on Affleck's Batman outfit was unfinished, as was the bottom of Gadot's WW skirt. Laughable. Line readings were something out of some lowest tier of TV production. Unbelievable. How does something like this leave a major studio, in this poor a shape, and be lauded as one of the best new superhero films?The golden age of superheroes in cinemas is ending.

title: A Giant love letter to every DC Fan
text: The Flash, a DC movie that has been subject to unnecessary hate, stands as a true masterpiece. I urge everyone to ignore the negative reviews. This film deserves your attention and promises an unforgettable cinematic experience.This movie is a shining gem in the DC universe, destined to captivate audiences and leave a lasting impact. So, grab your popcorn, immerse yourself in this extraordinary journey, and witness a DC masterpiece unfold before your eyes.Remember, the power of a film lies in the eyes of the beholder. Watch The Flash and form your own opinion. I guarantee you will love it, embrace it, and cherish the experience it offers.

title: The Flash
text: I didn't hate it. But I didn't love it either.DC is hopeless, from my point of view. James Gunn cannot save it because there are too many voices from the corporate side that bring the quality down or don't let the artist do their thing. No surprise there. Andy Muschietti is a good director, a great director for horror movies, but he couldn't save it.Neither the 4 versions of Batman that we see here. Not even the Nicholas Cage thing that all the fans know about. Definitely not the questionable CGI. The story however is the strong point because it's a very "Flash" kind of story. He is OP here and the story only work for and with him. I was entertained, it had funny moments, it has member-berries moments as well, it was fan service. Superwoman was cool, dumb-dumb Barry was obnoxious, just like a 18 year old should be.For me, it worked.

title: The DCEU dies another death
text: I love the 3 Snyder films and am a fan of Burton´s Batman, the main Flashpoint comic and it´s animated film. This forever delayed and constantly rewritten and reshot cinematic Frankenstein trashes them all. The film´s take on Batfleck is especially bad and sets the tone for the out-of-character disaster to follow. The CG and choreography mostly suck, the musical choices and the humor are embarrassing and both villains are among the worst comics films can offer. Supergirl is barely in it btw. Has there ever been a comic character more cursed by live-action adaptations than her? The one thing I actually like is the present-day version of Barry and I can see the Snyder Cut version growing into him even if the film refuses to connect to either version of JL and The Flash´s "canonical" prequel comics. Ezra´s other performances suck and I hope to never see the actor again for obvious reasons. Flash, I prefer Wally, is a great character and deserves a film series void of member berries, nostalgia and CG cameos (of dead actors!). Who´s idea was it to make a Flash film without a single proper Flash villain!?! The first 2 seasons of the CW show proved the potential the core Flash lore has. Let´s hope we get luckier next decade as the IP is about to be put on ice due to the film´s projected box-office disaster.Josstice League (3/10) is one of the worst blockbusters of all time so the DCEU´s worst film is set in stone but this and Black Adam are the runner-ups. WB remains a mess and is cash poor so I have limited hope for Gunn´s chance to succeed with his 2025 reboot but the worst has to be behind us and only 2 more Walter Hamada films are set to release. Both in 2023. Poor Aquaman... Let´s hope that Batman and Batman spin-offs won´t be all DC fans will have to look forward to on the big screen.PS: I fully believe that the Hamada Cut of this hacked-together film could have been a forgettable 5/10 instead of the irritating 4/10 Gunn&Safran Cut we have now but someone else will have to ride that hashtag.

title: Not Every Problem Has A Solution.
text: Speaking of which, my cons for this film lie within some of the visual effects and certain aspects of the story. There are plenty of times throughout where I could definitely see the green screen and the artificiality of the CGI. I also feel that the more I sit down and marinate on parts of the story/screenplay, the more messy they can get.........and most of it IS spoilers regarding this film AND the overall DCEU timeline (which I won't reveal).With all that being said, though, I do think The Flash is one of the better superhero/comic-book films in recent memory. It's fairly consistent with the story it wants to tell and does add some profound emotional gravitas that I was quite... proud of. The action sequences (despite some iffy special effects) were really fun and lively. The humor mostly lands and I laughed my ass off in specific scenes. Andy Muschietti proves himself to be a great genre-fluid director with some notably gorgeous framing compositions & unanimously great performances.Benjamin Wallfisch's score is phenomenal, by the way. I thought was hearing Danny Elfman at first. That's how good it is.Controversies regarding Ezra Miller aside, that is someone who can truly carry a film on their own. In the case of this film, it's a difficult performance to translate to the big screen. There are two incarnations of Barry Allen in this film (which is revealed in the trailers), and dual roles are usually challenging. But, Ezra Miller does it so effortlessly, and I have to give credit where credit is due.I appreciate that The Flash has a timely message: you can't always rekindle or rewrite mistakes and tragedies in your past. It's in the past for a reason, and no matter how much you wanna alter it, those things can't always be altered. That is a real aspect of life, despite it being displayed through the lens of the superhero genre. It captures the true beauty of this character through said message.Lastly, I'm proud to say that the superhero films we've gotten in recent memory have not used the multiverse trope just for gimmicks.After what almost feels like countless decades of this film being in development hell, and even despite its flaws, The Flash (to me) is largely a worthy accomplishment.See this one in theaters, too.

title: DC got it right
text: In my opinion DC got it right with this movie. I was glued to the film through out. Thoroughly enjoyed this film. Michael Keaton was a great choice for Batman and the logic of time travel always confusing to me didn't go over my head in this film. I found the wonderful cameos sprinkled throughout heartwarming to this older DC fan. Ezra Miller did a awesome job with his roles. I truly hope this film does well in theaters as it is well deserved. I may just have to see this one again on the big screen something I don't often do. Great, great work to all involved and I wish them much success. Be sure to stay for post credit scene.

title: A very overly-hyped movie
text: Movie itself was quite OK, with somewhat out-of-box story development with time travel. It has been one of my biggest issue with all these time-travel-solves-everything in recent sci-fi movies. And this one jumped out of that BS. You cannot solve everything by going back. For that, and with decent performance from the cast, except Calle, and the NOT-ALL-BLACK-AND-DARK feeling, it's a reasonably good movie. 8/10 maybe.But OMG, have you seen the CGI of this one? H. O. R. R. I. B. L. E. It's probably the WORST CGI in the last decade. I wonder which company they hired to do this. My ancient PC games beats this movie by a mile. For that I dropped it to a 7.

title: Great fun!
text: It's not often I go to the cinema twice to see a film, but The Flash is one of the best cinema experiences I've had in a while. It was an absolute joy to see my favourite superhero and favourite Batman together on the big screen, especially in IMAX. The story was emotional and it truly felt like the end to the DCEU, despite the ups and downs over the last few years. While I can see why people have criticised the CGI, I enjoyed the film too much to care. Hopefully, I'll get a chance to see it one more time before the end of it's theatrical run. I would highly recommend it to any comic book lovers out there.

title: You Wanna Get Nuts? Let's Get Nuts.
text: The latest instalment in the DCEU was "The Flash" a film that was 9 years in the making and clearly not long enough to perfect it. Following heavy praise of this film after its early showings there was a lot to look forward to going into this, but once again the DCEU never fails to disappoint. You would think that a film heavily dependant on CGI would be capable of pulling off scenes in 2023 that could leave an audience in awe, but the opening sequence would show you otherwise and show you what to expect. I still stand strongly on the fact that I never approved the casting of Ezra Miller as Barry Allen in the DCEU(add on top the news and controversy) hopefully this may be the last time we see him as the speedster.Now onto the positives, Sasha Calle had a good introduction into the DCEU with her role as Supergirl. Very good emotion shown from her even with he very limited screen time. Michael Keaton brought a lot of nostalgia to this film reprising his Batman as I'm sure most people expected. From a story standpoint I did enjoy as it showed why heroes are who they are and the importance it brings to their purpose. As well as some of the dialogue was a lot funnier then I thought the film would've been.Lastly without any spoilers, there were a lot of cameos with a mix of some being cool and some being there just to be there tried to help the film connect to the viewers but overall was useless. Ending with one of the worst end credit scenes I've ever had to watch "The Flash" has more cons to outweigh the pros and leads to a 3/5 star film, on the fence with a 2.5. Definitely a film that was overhyped in my opinion.

title: Wow!
text: Just watched The Flash. My honest reaction is WOW!The tears in my eyes! The plot, the themes, the characters, the drama, the lore, the emotional moments, the cinematography... everything was garbage from beginning to end. Definitely one of the worst superhero movies I've ever seen in my entire life.Ezra Miller can't carry a movie, and this one is case in point. Want to double down on that? Add a second Ezra Miller Flash that's actually far more annoying. The entire fist half is dealing with the pain of watching two Ezra Miller's. The Batman portions are better, but Keaton's performance felt phoned in.Don't waste your money, wait for streaming.

title: Fan service doesn't mean bad.
text: Yes, there's a lot of fan service here but that's a good thing. The Flash (like Flashpoint Paradox) is a soft reset for DCEU while acknowledging 80 years of live action DC films and TV. All of that is wrapped around a sometimes messy, but always heartfelt film about loss and grief.I can understand the issues with the quality of the CG being inconsistent, but people focusing so much on it are more a result of being spoiled and fatigued by the genre. The style of the film is quirky and they really lean into that.There's a lot of unanswered questions about how the DCEU will continue going forward, but I'm hopeful.All-in-all, worth a watch.

title: A Leap Forward: Embracing Diversity in the Superhero Genre
text: In superhero cinema's vibrant yet saturated landscape, this new addition delivers a refreshing breath of fresh air. Led by the commendable performance of Ezra Miller, a marked improvement from his previous appearance in Justice League, the movie brings forth a captivating plot and unique representation that caters to a broad audience.The film impresses particularly with its representation of diversity, a much-needed departure from the traditional superhero mould. The introduction of a Latin Supergirl breaks ground and serves as an inspiring symbol for Latin communities worldwide. It is indeed an extraordinary sight that widens the scope of superhero representation, leading younger generations to believe, quite rightfully, that anyone can don the cape and step into the shoes of a superhero.Unfortunately, the film stumbles when it comes to its CGI effects. Despite living in an era where high-quality graphics and special effects are the norms, this movie must deliver on this front. The visual elements, quite conspicuously, are the movie's Achilles heel. However, if viewers can overlook this drawback and engage with the story and characters, the film promises an enjoyable cinematic experience.

title: One of DCs better efforts
text: I really feel reception of this movie has suffered (perhaps justifiably) because of off screen controversies. Ezra Miller is actually very watchable.This is one of the DCEUs better efforts and I like it quite a lot. Firstly the revival of Michael Keaton's Batman is very welcome for those of us of a certain age. There's a number of Easter eggs that I appreciated.The do-over of general Zod's invasion is interesting and I really enjoyed Sasha Calle's supergirl. Id like to see more.The plot just about holds up although the introduction of both a multiverse and time-travel does seemed a little forced and felt like one of those "inevitable intersection" so prominent.The main issue I have is that I can't help comparing various parts of the movie with better offerings from the MCU. That's on me I guess but I get the feeling I'm not alone.Trying to be impartial, this is actually decent enough.

title: Great film
text: Everyone is just hating because of Ezra Miller but aside from him being a crappy person the film is class. Follows the comic almost perfectly and is a good if not great superhero film.But don't expect anything else from this film it's basically a stand-alone film as there's not going to be a follow up flash film in the DC EU so keep that in mind just in case that's a key reason for you watching this film.So go get a ticket and watch the film because it's a great presentation of what can happen when a superhero comic is adapted perfectly into a film.I couldn't get 600 charters so I hope you enjoyed reading whatever this is.

title: Don't use CGI to represent real people next time, until we can't tell the difference.
text: This Flash movie was about as good as any Flash movie will ever get, other than the special effects could use a lot more improvement so that things actually look real (or use old style detailed puppets to fill in if CGI still isn't realistic in appearance enough).Adding in other famous superheroes, or alternate versions of them, helped the Flash a bit (since his powers are a little more boring than Aquaman's), especially the addition of Batman.This last note is what helped saved this movie from only being a 3/10 rating.So I gave it a 7/10 instead.If not for the noticeably imperfect CGI I'd have given it a 9/10.

title: A Nostalgic Journey Through Wit, Genuine Script, and Unforgettable Heroics
text: If there was ever a film that superbly combined all the elements required for a phenomenal superhero blockbuster, it would be "The Flash". Offering extraordinary performances, a thought-provoking script, pioneering CGI, and a notable addition of a past legend, this film provides a sensory and intellectual banquet that exceeds expectations in the most unpredictable and satisfying ways.At the heart of the movie is the exceptional performance by the protagonist, who delivers a remarkably human and multidimensional portrayal of The Flash. His performance, balancing the character's inherent wit and humor with an emotional depth that resonates deeply, is nothing short of brilliant.The film's script serves as a testament to the power of smart storytelling. It threads together a narrative that is complex and layered, filled with surprising twists that demand an active, engaged audience. This film isn't simply about high-octane action or saving the world; it challenges you to think, to question, and to piece together a puzzle that, once solved, offers a rewarding "Eureka!" moment.One cannot discuss "The Flash" without addressing the eagerly anticipated return of Michael Keaton as Batman. His presence isn't merely a nostalgic nod to the past but serves to elevate the entire movie, adding an extra layer of richness to the narrative dynamics.Interestingly, the movie gives the concept of the multiverse a fresh, captivating spin, taking a trope that has been explored extensively in other films and series and breathing new life into it. The multiverse here serves to add a fascinating dimension to the storyline and the characters within this universe.Beyond the riveting action and heady concepts, "The Flash" is also brimming with humor. The film is peppered with moments that will make you laugh out loud, moments that add a lightness to the narrative and endear the characters to you even more.And yes, expect to feel a lump in your throat. "The Flash" isn't merely an action-packed superhero adventure; it's a beautifully told story that resonates with authentic human emotion. There are moments in the film that take you by surprise, touching your heart when you least expect it.The film wraps up with a solid, satisfying ending that neatly ties up the narrative threads, a testament to the overall strength and consistency of the film. It's a film that's not only thoroughly engaging from start to finish but also exceptionally well-executed."The Flash" is more than a superhero movie; it's a film that will make you fall in love with the character anew. If you've ever been ambivalent about The Flash, this movie is likely to secure a special place for him in your heart. "The Flash" doesn't just entertain; it moves you, makes you think, makes you laugh, and leaves a lasting impression. It's an exceptional cinematic journey that stays with you long after the credits have rolled.

title: It's fun and entertaining but with some flaws
text: Definitely one of the better DC movies of late and I'd watch it again but it still has a few issues.Firstly I thought Ezra Miller did a great job playing to different versions of the Flash. The younger one was definitely annoying but I think that sums up a young flash well. The best bits about this film though we're anything to do with Keaton's batman. He stole every scene he was in. In general though, I thought the acting was good as well as the story and script.Unfortunately the CGI was just ok, it wasn't as bad as people were saying but there were definitely scenes in which is was hard to watch it was so bad.Definitely a decent film to end on for the DC films before Gunn takes over.

title: Ezra Miller makes for a very unlikeable Barry Allen
text: Ezra Miller was a terrible choice for the flash, not only is he a B grade actor at best but not once did he convince me i was watching anything other then a poorly scripted movie with a cringey actor with the worst cgi of the decade. The first 10 minutes of the film seem promising but leads to the most boring hour of my life. Ezra miller was the worst part of this movie, thank god for Ben Affleck and Keaton who was the star of the movie. Once the movie gets to the climax it seems rushed and unclimatic, using footage from previous movies to wrap other an otherwise boring movie. This movie can only be described as a complete missed opportunity of something that could have been an amazing movie and an incredible restart to the Dv universe.

title: Not only is Barry Allen the fastest hero, he's also likely to have the quickest turnaround in fandom of any DC movie to date.
text: This year saw the release of two enjoyable films by DC Studios - Shazam! Fury Of The Gods and The Flash. If Walter Hamada is the man that's responsible for the DC Studios films that got released in the last few years, he deserves praise, in my opinion, because I enjoyed seeing almost every DCEU film that got released from 2019 to 2023. The Flash, in particular, is my favorite film of this year so far. Sure, it's not as good as, let us say, Across The Spider-Verse, but it affected me the most. The Flash is admittedly silly at times, but almost everything else in this film works well. It's clear that plenty of effort and money went into making The Flash. After The Suicide Squad (2021), The Flash is my favorite film in the DCEU. First of all, the cast, especially Ezra Miller and Michael Keaton, delivered good performances. The Flash does seem like a star vehicle for Miller. There are a few scenes in the film that are actually moving. This is something that can be said about only several superhero movies that got made in the last decade because most of them attempted to deliver only laughs and entertainment. But The Flash still features some effective comedy. One of the reasons why The Flash is often effective is because it features a good music score by Benjamin Wallfisch. What's also worth mentioning is that The Flash is kind of like a comeback for the American flag. The American flag is in the film for a bit and it looks glorious when it appears. The American flag hasn't looked this good in a film for about a decade or more. Sure, the American flag isn't a very good actor. The performances of the American flag are mostly stiff and of one note. But the American flag doesn't get cast in films because of its acting chops. It gets cast because of its good looks.
