There were rumors that the American flag had turned to drugs, and perhaps this is the reason why it looked bad in the films in which it appeared in the last decade. But I'm here to tell everyone that the American flag is back! Not since the 1990s has the American flag looked this good on screen. Perhaps the American flag has been spending time at the gym and consuming dietary supplements.

title: I am a Fan, lemme be serviced!
text: Based on the positive initial reactions I've decided to give this movie a chance myself and even went on the opening weekend. I thoroughly enjoyed myself pretty much from start to finish.Why did I ever consider skipping this movie? The Flash has been handled pretty poorly in previous DCEU movies. He was supposed to act as the comic relief, but just came of as the annoying one. It must have been the writing, because I was not annoyed by Ezra Miller in this movie, they even made me sympathise and feel for him by the conclusion of the third act.The story broadly follows the Flashpoint storyline. He goes back to save his mom from dying and breaks the timeline continuity. But in this movie instead of meeting Thomas Wayne-Batman, he meets Keaton Batman and Supergirl.The main reason why I went was "My Batman" i.e. Keaton. He was awesome in the movie once again. On top of that there is a bunch more fan service which I never thought I'd live to see onscreen. I will not spoil it for you, not to rob you of the surprise but some of the easter eggs in there were very satisfying to see.Supergirl is likeable in the movie. I feared she'd be handled similarly to Captain Marvell, but she is pretty sympathetic and I hope she'll return in later movies.The Humor worked. It did not outstay its welcome. Dramatic moments are left to be dramatic, funny moments are funny. The balance is done right unlike in the last 5 or so MCU movies.The CGI, well, people complain about it but honestly I thought it looked fine. The story distracted me enough not to care about the green screen scenes.To conclude, I'd just have to agree with what Chris Stuckman said in his review: I am a fan, let me be serviced :D.

title: "I completely broke the universe..."
text: FILM: 7/10.The Flash delivers an exhilarating and mostly satisfying experience, anchored by Ezra Miller's surprisingly fun and heartfelt performance as the titular speedster. They bring a unique charm to the character, capturing both the youthful exuberance and emotional depth of Barry Allen. Miller's portrayal adds a layer of relatability to the character, making it easy for audiences to invest in their journey.Michael Keaton's return as Batman after three decades is nothing short of triumphant. His presence brings a nostalgic thrill to the film, and he effortlessly slips back into the role, reminding us why he is considered one of the iconic portrayals of the Dark Knight. Similarly, Sasha Calle delivers a fine performance as Supergirl, bringing a refreshing energy and providing a strong counterpart to the Flash.Ben Affleck's extended cameo as Batman offers a compelling mix of action and meaningful drama. Despite an atrocious Batsuit design, Affleck seizes the opportunity to showcase his talent, leaving a lasting impact on the story. If this is his swan song, he leaves on a high note.The action set pieces in The Flash are a true highlight, offering exhilarating sequences that make great use of the Flash's super-speed and the visual representation of the Speed Force. The film presents inventive ways of depicting the Speed Force, providing a fresh and exciting visual experience.While most of the visual effects are impressive, there are moments where some CGI falls short of expectations. These occasional lapses detract slightly from the overall immersion but do not significantly hinder the enjoyment of the film.With numerous cameos and a steady supply of fan service, The Flash is a treat for fans invested in the history of DC Comics. To fully appreciate these appearances and avoid spoilers, it is highly recommended to see the film as soon as possible.It is worth noting that there is one brief end credits scene that takes a humorous approach, poking fun at some elements of the Snyderverse. While it adds a lighthearted touch, it may leave some fans with a slightly sour note as the film concludes.FORMAT: CinemaVIDEO: 10/10.Native 4K theatrical presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: ExcellentAUDIO: 10/10.Dolby Atmos, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: ExcellentMOOFIEMETER: 7/10.

title: Way better than I expected
text: Keep in mind, I had very low expectations for this movie. I was excited but once I saw the rating and some of the reviews and footage, I lost most interest. But still, I thought I'd check it out once it streamed mainly because Michael Keaton is in it.Let's start with the CGI. A lot of it looks insanely bad. Harry Potter's first quidditch lesson bad. PS2 bad. This is a big budget 2023 movie, it shouldn't look like this. I dunno if they just ran out of money or didn't care. Having said that, some of it also looks pretty cool, especially some of the action scenes near the end.Ezra Miller is a very talented actor. I feel torn because he seems to have a lot of issues to the point I'm surprised they even still hired him. Is he just troubled or actually dangerous? I also have to say that his insistence on "they" as a pronoun is very patronising and confusing - I can't believe Wikipedia seems to have gone along with this. He's clearly a guy, and he can have whatever sexuality he wants.But anyway, Miller is actually quite good in the lead role. In fact, he plays two characters, or at least, two versions of the same character. And that part of the VFX worked pretty well. It's easy to forget that it's the same guy and that he can never actually interact with himself.Miller is good in both the comedic and dramatic parts of the movie. To the point that I was laughing and moved many times, far more than I'd ever expected. The performance feels very sincere and the subject matter is pretty universal. As bizarre and silly as much of the movie is, some of the scenes worked quite well.Michael Keaton was great as usual, although it felt like he didn't have a huge amount to do. I liked many of the subtle nods to his movies, but not so much the obvious nods. If the movie has to grind to a halt so he can say "THE LINE", it's not worth it. But if we get little details on the screen or choices of wording which many people won't notice, and which don't slow down the momentum of this movie, then it's worth it.I tend to hate unnecessary gender/race swaps in movies, but Sasha Calle was really good as Supergirl. It was a relatively dark, sad and intense take on the character, but I really liked it. It felt sincere and that's what matters. You feel her anger and some of the action worked pretty well. Still, some of the earlier action scenes with her looked ridiculous, with absurd physics and very dodgy CGI. But her performance and brief arc were really good - I'm surprised she hasn't been in more movies.I was far less impressed by Kiersey Clemons who I could barely stand. I don't like to be mean, but personally, I didn't find her remotely attractive, believable or good at acting. She felt out of place and really uninteresting to watch. I have to wonder how she got the role. It felt awkward seeing Miller trying to act like he was head-over-heels in love with her, it just didn't make sense.Part of the reason Supergirl worked was that there's no emphasis on her being a girl, no "girl boss" moments, no unnecessary bringing down of men to prop her up, etc. No reference to her being stronger or wiser than Superman. In contrast, Wonder Woman's brief (and yet still slow-paced) appearance results in 3 men being embarrassed. That scene wasn't really funny.For example, Wayne mutters about maybe he should end poverty to fight crime rather than fight criminals. Pretty stupid, trite stuff. When welfare was expanded in the US, crime went up. There are no excuses for violent crime so Batman is doing just fine beating up criminals.An early scene involving saving babies was very absurd and was a bad note for the movie to begin on. The tone just didn't work. Endangering babies is very hard to sell as funny. And it had some of the worst CGI I've ever seen.The cameos near the end were kind of nice, but didn't really mean anything. They were just arbitrary. I'm left wishing they could have found some meaningful way to connect them to the rest of the story. I don't mind a bit of nostalgia here and there if it's done respectfully and if you've built up to it enough. It's something that could work, but the overall movie and plot just couldn't properly justify it - they did nothing with the concept.The music is okay - better than many superhero movies these days. But it's nothing compared to the work of Elfman or Williams who scored Batman (1989) and Superman (1978) respectively. The Batman theme is quoted, but the last chord is changed which ruins it. Why do that? Modern composers seem to be far less talented and disciplined than their predecessors. There are no memorable new themes here, although the music does its job well enough for some scenes to be decent.The Flash is a mess, there's no way to deny that. The DCU (or whatever you call it) has completely fallen apart. This movie barely holds together even without the time-twisting aspects. But good actors and some good ideas here and there elevate the material. Ezra Miller has huge potential as an actor - way above average in both comedy and drama, not to mention interacting with himself. Keaton and Calle are really good as well.There are parts that are actually moving, some brief moments are rousing and exciting. The ideas have potential. But a lot of the comedy is just bad. The tone is inconsistent. The plot is ultimately dumb. But I have to judge by the best strengths of the movie, I have to try my best to enjoy it, and somehow, I actually found many parts of it quite enjoyable.

title: Good film, could have been better but could have been much worse!
text: Basically a good retelling of Flashpoint with some good humor and touching story. The only real issue I had with this movie was the crappy special effects. Intentional or not they were BAD at times. At a lot of times. The main actor did a good job. I always thought he was an interesting take on the Flash. The cameos and returning characters were great! I wish it had maybe a few more of the big DC characters at least putting in an appearance but the ones who did were great. Maybe they could have been longer but you can't have it all. In general a good but not great movie. Definitely worth watching a time or two!

title: I was expecting a bad movie, and it surprised me
text: I usually don't like superhero movies (except some of the Batman world), and I heard from my SH movies fan friends this would be a bad one.Yes, it has disposable action scenes like Marvel movies; the movie format is not suitable - always trying to have funny/comedy scenes in each part, making it less funny than what it could be -, the dialogs are not that good. I didn't like the visual effects of Flash running - the lightning, he waits as an Olympic runner before he starts running, the effects of slow things around him. Scenes from X-Men Quicksilver are much better at this point.But the message the movie passes is very good; what motivates Barry in his journey, his story is good and legitimate, some dialogues make you think in your own life, and, oh, the nostalgic part is fantastic, especially if you are 40+. There is a role/character that did not even go on air then (this one was funny).Do those good parts make it worth it? That's subjective. I was unpretentiously trying to have fun on a Saturday night, and I found it.

title: Well, we seen much worse, i was entertained at least
text: First of all, the most prominent part is the CGI. The most obvious thing that can be said about this movie is the very poor quality and obvious CGI. If you are someone who cares about this very much, the movie may turn out to be a torture for you. For myself, I imagined that this was an artistic choice and was done to add a cartoonish atmosphere to the film, and it positively affected my enjoyment of the film.The movie is divided into two. In the first half of the movie, Barry Allen is a very difficult character to watch with the personality traits written for Ezra Miller. The movie is based on the very popular Flashpoint comic book story. As you progress through this story, and once the focus shifts from Barry Allen and his third-rate attempt to make the audience laugh, the movie's viewing pleasure increases a lot. The movie also borrows a lot of material from the movie 'Man of Steel'. I accept this as an admission that they failed heavily in the series except for that movie.

title: Amazing movie - lots of fun and action
text: If you've always loved the Flash in whatever form (comic, series, cartoon) and love DC movies, you will enjoy every second of this movie. Aside from action moments, it has a lot of funny moments but also some very serious ones.Me and my girlfriend have seen it at the movies and now, we can already watch it again (streaming).The CGI that some people say is bad, just isn't.It just shows the world from the Flash's point of view.It is a great movie that has been seriously badmouthed by some (early) reviewers and Ezra-haters. Ezra is a very good actor and has put everything he could into his character.I would love to see a Flash 2. Let's hope it happens.

title: A super hero flick with an identity crisis
text: I am an unabashed fan of DC comic book films..... well, I should say that I am an unabashed fan of Zack Snyder's DC comic book films. While I recognize all the flaws of both his trilogy of films and the thought-process that was responsible for rushing them to theatres, "Man of Steel," "Batman V Superman," and "Zack Snyder's Justice League" are all movies that I hold near and dear to my heart, faults and all. Even in the films not directed by Snyder, I enjoy the universe set up in the DC movies. So, I was really looking forward to "The Flash," excited to see the swan song to the DCEU before James Gunn's cinematic reboot. And how does "The Flash" stack up? Ehhhhhhh.You've probably seen the insane amount of press this movie had; with everything from Super Bowl ads to celebrity endorsements to near-constant TV spots and YouTube advertisements, "The Flash" was advertising itself to be the best comic book film of all time, rivaling Nolan's "The Dark Knight." Not an easy task, to be sure, but with Stephen King and Tom Cruise singing their praises to the heavens, I, for one, was fooled into thinking this really would be one of the great super hero movies. And it's not! But what it is, is a perfectly serviceable, even entertaining, movie, but one that suffers from tonal clashes and inconsistencies."The Flash" begins with an appropriately bombastic opening, one that serves to show off the powers of our titular hero. Akin to the Quicksilver scenes in past "X-Men" films, you'll witness Ezra Miller's Barry Allen as he races to save the lives of innocent bystanders caught in a life-threatening predicament. It's an admittedly fun sequence, one that's played for laughs, filled to the brim with visual gags and Barry's trademarked ADHD behavior. And after watching said sequence, you might find yourself thinking that you're in for a similarly wacky ride throughout the entire duration of the movie. That's where you'd be mistaken. Moving from zany comedy to stark drama to over-the-top action (rinse and repeat), "The Flash" has an identity crisis, so much so that you can almost hear the studio meddling as you watch the film. It's unclear whose vision this is - is it Andy Muschietti's, the studio's, or James Gunn's, or some sort of Frankenstein-esque combination of all three? My money's on Frankenstein.So, you'll see Ezra Miller mourn the loss of his mother in one scene, engage in silly slapstick in the next scene, and traverse the multi-verse (portrayed with shockingly noticeable CGI) in the next. The movie does not know what it wants to be; and instead of sticking to one, consistent tone, it tries to marry a myriad of different tones together in an effort to please as many people as it can. And you know what the worst part is? When "The Flash" allows itself to become the drama it seems to want to be, it's really, really good.The last 45 minutes of this movie does contain some of the best super hero drama I've seen since I can't remember when; it's emotionally resonant and engaging, it tugs at your heart strings at times, and it's appropriately intense and adrenaline pumping. It's everything I wanted this movie to be! But it's like the producers were afraid to let this movie just be a drama, because before you get to this you have to sit through two hours of out of control comedy. And in a way, I get it. The backlash against "Man of Steel" and "Batman V Superman" being "too dark" made the studio course correct every future DC film. But "The Flash" isn't a dark movie - it's a dramatic one, and it should've been allowed to be dramatic.I hope my review made sense, because I seem to be having some difficulty articulating what I want to say (must be due to the fact that I'm sober right now). In conclusion, I'll say that this isn't a bad movie. You can see this and probably have some fun with it, and I will certainly be buying this when it comes out on Blu-Ray to rewatch with my family. However, I can't help but feel disappointed as I watched this film, because I can see the greatness underneath that was not allowed to come to fruition.

title: A breath of fresh air? Eager to see what they do with this next!
text: I was surprised to learn that The Flash followed the Flashpoint storyline but didn't go exactly according to it.Flash and Barry have been shown in a very different way in The Flash, which felt a little unfamiliar but also like a breath of fresh air. Let's see how it plays out in future DC movies.I would've loved to see Reverse Flash in the movie but I still liked the plot of The Flash.The CGI sequences during Barry's time travel with the chronosphere were new and I liked them because the usual linear running sequences in slo-mo have become overused now imo.The Flash's backstory about his parents and his genesis are one of the bests in the superhero world IMO which was portrayed pretty well here. It was obvious that it's been made a little less dark and aimed at maybe a younger audience?There were parts which made the movie feel like a Superman/Krypton spinoff but I'm happy they didn't saturate the movie with Supergirl.I would've given this a 7 but +1 for Keaton's Batman and because The Flash is my fav!

title: Zap!, Bam!, Zoink!, Wham!... Holly CGI Batman!.
text: Ruined by CGI!. Now, whose fault is it?. Yes, the CGI is beyond bad, and is overused in nearly every scene and it's hard to not get distracted by how horrible and unnecessary it is. But, if you could remember the wonder when you were a child and enjoyed the Incredible Hulk, Wonder Woman, The Six Million Dollar Man or even Bewitched or I Dream of Jeannie, I don't see why you couldn't have a good time watching this movie.My Hispanic people, you idolized El Chapulín colorado, give this a break.As many pointed out about the fan service, oh well... I am a fan of Michael Keaton and his Batman, so I loved him here.RELAX!... CHILL!... I'm sure you are going to like it.It is cool.

title: "The Flash 2023: A CGI Disaster and Scriptwriting Fiasco"
text: Where do I even begin with "The Flash 2023"? This film is an absolute train wreck that leaves audiences wishing they could run as fast as the titular superhero just to escape this mess. The CGI in this movie is so horrendously bad that it's laughable - and not in a good way. It's as if they hired an intern who just learned how to use a 3D modeling software and decided to handle all the visual effects on a shoestring budget. From the poorly animated lightning bolts to the hilariously awkward slow-motion sequences, the CGI alone is enough to make your eyes bleed.But wait, it gets worse. The script for "The Flash 2023" is an insult to storytelling and character development. It's filled with clichés and cringeworthy dialogue that would make even the most ardent fan of the superhero genre cringe in embarrassment. The plot is a jumbled mess of time-travel mumbo-jumbo, poorly explained motivations, and plot holes big enough to drive a truck through. It's as if the writers were just throwing random ideas at the wall and hoping something would stick.As for the performances, the actors seem to be struggling to keep the audience entertained, and who can blame them? With such a lackluster script and nonexistent character arcs, it's a wonder they managed to get through filming without breaking down in tears of frustration. Even the usually charming and charismatic lead actor can't save this sinking ship."The Flash 2023" feels like a rushed attempt to cash in on the popularity of superhero movies without any regard for quality or coherence. The action scenes are forgettable at best and cringe-inducing at worst, with CGI so bad that you'll wish you were watching a cheap 90s cartoon instead.To top it all off, the movie suffers from severe pacing issues, dragging on for what feels like an eternity. It's like being trapped in the speed force with no way out. I found myself checking my watch every few minutes, hoping that the torture would end soon.In conclusion, "The Flash 2023" is an abysmal failure on every level. The CGI is laughably bad, the script is a disaster, and the performances are lackluster. It's a shame to see such a beloved character and franchise treated with such disrespect. Save your money and your precious time, and run away from this movie as fast as The Flash himself.

title: Pure fun
text: Yall may go to see Superhero movies for the best graphics ever seen, but I just needed to see my heroes on the big screen. Job Accomplished. Acting great l, story was fun and The Flash ran fast lol. Love time travel, OP Superheroes or else what are fantasies for? Tired of seeing movies about regular human stories. Love me some pure action fantasy. This movie delivers. Lots of jokes and surprises. Micheal Keaton as Batman never looked so good! Fun to see him battle in comic book style. Heart and humor carry this film. Witty, arrogant and flamboyantly fun. Two Barry's for the price of one. Fantastc!

title: Too bad
WORST superhero movie ever
text: When you develop characters for audiences, they should be likeable (even many villains are likeable in a negative way). No one in this movie is likeable except Barry's mom and dad. Barry is the LEAST likeable. He's a fricking idiot.When you write an action movie and it's supposed to include comedy, it should actually be funny when it's supposed to be. Shazam actually achieves that but it's the only one.I so much wanted to like this movie. There are so many wonderful, admirable superheroes to love at DC.James Gunn is DESTROYING the DC universe in film much like Greg Berlanti destroyed the DC universe on television. It's so sad to see.

title: Solid seven and nice amalgamation of previous stories
text: When seen other productions of DC which frankly speaking is getting more and more horrible in trendy "make it easier for audience" which mostly mean for very young and very poorly intelligent audience + you must integrate as many sexes and diversity as possible -> this is a very nice surprise as it has nearly none of this nonsense.Funny - in some places too much as bit forced - but in overall way quite good and with good pacing. There where moments which made me laugh and caught me surprised, that's amazing as new Shazam Godly mess for example was nothing like this.It is a synthesis of several stories from animated Justice League: The Flashpoint Paradox which is a bit darker one, to other depictions of same story I saw over the years. I like it has its own twists like Kara (which I would say is much nicer and more Supergirl at least for me than serial one blonde useless mess) and many small alterations which I would suspect were driven by money and samo make story really interesting. Showing of several different Batmen and new explanation of timelines is a nice touch.Will not spoil it, but I would say it is good time spent over a decent movie. Good action, nice pace and dialogues are not so forced, came natural in many places which should be not as idiotic explanation in some of movies.Solid 7/10 - BTW: end was funny and some guest appearances amazing, especially in their age...

title: not that bad
text: The Flash is a solid film in the DCCU. The story has a good build up with it creating character personality and emotion connection for the main characters and progressing at a steady pace for most of the film. The action took up around a third of film and was great with the addition of CGI adding a flare. The comedy was fine at some points and well done at other. Some of the CGI looked like it was from a game and some transitions were very abrupt but it didn't really affect the film. I found the ending to be a well done finish to the story. Overall it was a good addition to the Francine and would recommend to any who wants to watch a good superhero Movie 7/10.

title: Fast
text: I must say I am pleasantly impressed with the movie.The story is about Barry who runs back in time to try and change the events of his childhood where his mom died and dad went to jail, He alters the timeline which has many ripple effects, he must team up with a younger version of himself and create a justice league to stop Zod who is back on earth.There is a lot of humour but the scenes that are heartfelt are really good, the premise is sad and the further we get into the movie the more we feel that.Keaton Batman wasn't just a cameo he has some great scenes in this, he hasn't lost it.Not a fan of the Batfleck scenes, not sure why they just felt really weird.The younger Barry I wanted to choke at times, he does grow on you but the start he was a LOT.Super-girl was actually really good and I'd love more.Ezra was good playing both Barry, I don't know what will happen in the future with his personal life and his actions. Gunn said this set the timeline for the new DC but that I can't understand, there is one scene at the very end of the credits and I was expecting much more it was meh, disappointing. The end to the movie also is leaving us in open air so that bothered me some bit but overall I enjoyed it, 8/10.

title: Multiverse of a privileged public menace
text: I pity those that actually paid to see this movie - moreso those that convinced themselves it was anything other than the utmost of industrial dreck.There's no shortage of reasons this movie should've been scrapped - especially given how readily they ditched an almost complete Batgirl movie. They even had a perfect exit strategy to recast Ezra Miller, given that the plot revolves around alternate realities and different versions of DC characters. I am baffled as to why they proceeded, especially considering how entirely uncharming Miller is throughout the movie.The movie begins with Miller very hamfistedly portraying someone that is clearly meant to be on the spectrum, with all the sensitivity of Sia's musical movie catastrophe. Typical of contemporary representation modalities, autism is depicted as being primarily characterized by obnoxious, self-centered demanding behavior. I am not sure exactly what they hoped to accomplish by establishing the "hero" like this.Even more puzzling is the fact that the viewer is soon introduced to a more annoying version of Miller that seems to be channelling a mangled version of Keanu from the original Bill & Ted movie. This incarnation is so irritating that the writers broke the fourth wall and had the original version of the character having a vocal moment of realization of how annoying he, himself, is. At that point, I didn't know what to do but throw up my hands in resignation.On the more production related side, it's basically as bad as others have been saying with some consistency. The CGI is PS2 cutscene quality at a lot of points. The editing and plot pace is fumbling. The fanservice is almost completely constrained to the surface with little integration into the plot in any meaningful way. It comes across as a flimsy gimmick to add gravity to a pretty thin main plot - and achieved with some of the most half-baked conceptual visualization I can recall from recent cinematic history.On top of everything, the protagonist is hardly any sort of hero, considering the majority of the conflict was his own doing and the larger effects of temporal meddling are clearly left unresolved. I doubt it endears the character more to the audience having constant fisheye close-ups of Miller's gormless reactions. Maybe that's just me!I dunno, just thought this thing stunk essentially from top to bottom - a stench only intensified by the baggage brought by the main actor's disturbing reputation and the industry plowing ahead despite all the reasons own the loss or pivot in their approach. Instead they astroturfed early critic screenings and fed them to news outlets to try to cover up the obviously ill-advised festering greed and delusion that made this movie possible.

title: Andy Muschietti deserves praise
text: The script was ok. The visual effects pretty much sucks, but the visual style and the tone were so much fun that I have to give credit to the director who for me was the star of this movie. There are sequences that are incredibly entertaining to watch & I love how Andy can seamlessly switch up the tone when in-between the characters, Michael Keatons batman got the last hoora he deserves in an almost sequel to his film. He certainly does steal the show.The casting was not good imo, and I think another talented actor would be able to have made Barry a lot more related and hit the emotional beats. The whole "My mom died" story is old and these days too little of a motivation to drive the plot, I think Barrys plight should have been something more.

title: Make your own mind up
text: No spoilers here, there's plenty of those out in the wild. The story of the flash is a reworking of the classic story from the comics and more recently the tv show with Grant Gustin. Here's my take, I don't really like Ezra Millers character here, I found his performance annoying but it's different from the Grant Gustin flash and played as a continuation of the breathless awkward speed freak seen in previous Zack Snyder movies. When the alternate Barry is encountered, he's played as a different personality and the 'what if' seen in back to the future 2 is played out, with Barry's personality with his mothers influence is seen. After an act of let's get the band together, which is well thought and played and an alternate time travel trope is explored. I have to say Keaton steals the show, but the work of Ezra Miller was laying the two Barry's is very good, and the special effects work to bring these together on screen never looks odd (for example check out Van dammes double impact - it's horrible with overacting aplenty), we get to the final act and the 'big fight', and these is the bit where cgi takes over, and I've seen better. In fact there are sections where I thought it was on a par with the rock in the mummy returns. As far as the movie goes, it's enjoyable, just watch with an open mind.

title: Good and bad
text: The FlashThis superhero flick sees the titular superhero going back in time to prevent his mother's death, leading to disastrous implications.Drawn from the comic book, Flashpoint, this movie boasts strong performances from its cast and good action scenes. Albeit the visual effects suffer and are sometimes abhorrent, and it's even more shameful with the budget the movie had.The comedy in The Flash is hit or miss. When it's good, it's very good, and when it's bad, it's eye-rolling bad. The plot is standard, and the emotional core makes it better.The Flash is a decent movie, especially when compared to the past failures of the DCEU, but it's a shame that the controversies surrounding the lead actor overshadow the movie (although deservingly) and generally take away from the feel-good nature the movie may elicit.6.5/10.

title: Loved it!
text: Flash is an amazing movie that effortlessly combines heartfelt emotions with hilarious moments. It delivers a captivating story that explores the complexities of life while keeping the audience entertained throughout. The film's performances are exceptional, making the characters relatable and endearing. DC really geared up on graphics it was super cool to watch flash "flashing off" and so many scenes that I dont wanna spoil it for folks. With stunning visuals and a well-crafted soundtrack, Flash offers a memorable cinematic experience. It's a must-watch for anyone who enjoys a mix of laughter and heartfelt storytelling.

title: Mediocre
text: Movie was a fun popcorn flick but doesn't really have a lot of substance. The new supergirl being added in doesn't really add anything to the plot but more of a time filler as she is introduced as a solution to the problem of Zod but doesn't really do anything.For fans of the 89' Batman movie it is awesome to see Micheal Keaton make a return and really get to shine as Batman with today's technology. He still has the same cheesy dialouge from the old Era so it feels like watching a continuation of the old movie instead of just a cheap addition.Ezra miller does a good job as the flash and it's kind of a shame to see him being replaced and to have this universe ended when it seemed like this movie could have been a sort of reboot instead of total reset.

title: I liked it
text: I don't know why this movie is bombing in the theaters. I saw it opening day and really enjoyed it. Despite the long runtime, I didn't feel the need to cut the movie shorter. Miller did a great job playing both versions of himself and all the cameos certainly made this entertaining. Yes, i know some may be protesting Miller due to recent events, but a lot of stars have had issues from time to time. The story is great, acting is great, visual effects are great. This is very entertaining. If you are a fan of the Flash, Superman, Super Girl, DCEU in general then go watch this. I think you will be entertained.

title: Fast and Flawed
text: The Flash (2023) left me feeling like I just ran through the Speed Force myself - a bit dizzy, but with a smile on my face! First things first, Sasha Calle as Supergirl? She's a Kryptonian goddess, and I absolutely love strong women in superhero films. Now, onto the movie itself.Let's be honest, this film had some decent moments, but it's like trying to run a marathon in brand new shoes - you stumble a few times. The storyline with Barry messing with the timeline, multiverses, and older versions of himself got me scratching my head more than trying to figure out time travel. It felt a bit convoluted, like trying to untangle a messy ball of yarn. And speaking of messy, the CGI during the battle with Zod's forces left me longing for some cleaner action scenes.But hey, it's not all bad news in Central City. The chemistry between Barry and Supergirl was electrifying, and their teamwork brought some much-needed spark to the film. Plus, the emotional arc with Barry coming to terms with his mother's death was a touching aspect. So, while The Flash had its flaws, it still delivered some super-powered entertainment. Just don't expect it to win any races in the superhero movie marathon!

title: Funny, flashy, and forgettable.
text: The Flash is entertains and at times is both clever and very funny. Ezra Miller proves himself once again a capable actor in the role, this time portraying two Flashes and with good comedic effect. However it also proves the limits both of The Flash character and perhaps Ezra Miller range. The films plot is the long way around the short story, initiated by The Flash's attempt to rewrite history to save his mother's life, and also save his father from incarceration after he is wrongfully convicted of her murder.The Flash has decent pacing, but at time the woeful CGI is so jarring its almost a show stopper. Its too much CGI and also not good CGI, which is where all DC films seem to suffer. When The Flash enters another time line, or strand of the multiverse, it is done well Michael Keating makes an excellent return as a clapped out batman drawn out of retirement. But the Super Girl character and baddie Kryptonians are utterly 2 dimensional.The Flash has a happy ending, but its a tinny ending to a film that already suffers badly from the CGI and a stretched story. Satisfying for non-fans, but probably forgettable for all who see it. For reasons other than Ezra Miller's real life shenanigans I don't except there will be a another Flash movies. This movie probably only proved there was not need even for one.

title: Absolute garbage
text: It is absolutely terrible and centres around a woman-beating one-man-crime-spree and kidnapping child-groomer, who can't act. At all.The story also makes no sense.I get they wanted to do Flashpoint again, but we've seen that story, which was crap and stupid when it was a comic, a half dozen times including relatively recently in the Flash TV show, as it was an entire season of that show.It's a shame that the writing is much worse than a badly and generically written CW TV show.It's also a shame that they put zero thought into the script at all. They wanted time shenanigans and quips and CGI, and that's it.So the idea was bland, because nobody gave a crap about it being any good to start with, and then forgot that when you go back in time that it doesn't effect anything before the point you go back to.Imagine if in Back To The Future, Marty McFly goes back to 1955, and him doing so made Doc be born female decades earlier for some reason. That would be stupid and would mean the writers were stupid, wouldn't it?It's not fun, Miller cannot act, and the CGI looks like crap.Nobody went to see it because it looked terrible, and comes as a part of a string of terrible movies, and the word of mouth is that it's sub-par at best.The reviews are generally favourable, but that's because the only people who went to see it are the sort of people who like this kind of absolutely terrible dreck.I only saw it on the high seas to see if it was bad as I thought it looked, and it took multiple bites at the apple as I kept turning it off and doing something else out of boredom, because there is nothing at all worth watching here.

title: Surprisingly good?
text: I didn't expect too much from this movie. Another superhero movie from one of the biggest movie companies so I thought they will just make something just enough to keep the DC franchise alive and profiting. But it was actually pretty entertaining and exiting. Though I still don't get the timeline thing fully, it had a decent plot. I didn't feel that it was too long or aimlessly taking up screentime. I don't say that The Flash is the best film I've seen but it was worth watching.I recommend this movie to those who want to watch something fun and light but not stupid. Whising you a good time watching The Flash!

title: DC was the original multi verse
text: A proper comic book movie so if this is your medium, it's absolutely brilliant, had it all, Ezra was superb. DC was the first to put out the multi verse - The flash 121. Has DC started their first step towards something that rivals their biggest competitor? Fun is what you want from a movie and this gave it in spades. Keaton, Affleck, Calle all superb. The old same time paradox/alternate world thingy I've have always enjoyed, and have been written so many times, with some classics "it's a wonderful world " that it still works, just written for the time we live in. A must see. How much do you weigh?

title: Not as bad as people say, but also not great
text: Not as bad as I thought it would be. My god does DC love CGI though. It ranged from epic and great to extremely terrible. I could have done without the constant jokes, few of which landed. But, undeniably, I think this movie also had a lot more heart than previous ones. There are good plot beats. Especially the super girl ones. And just plain fun ones, like with Batman.The result is a really weird movie that is kind of hard to rate, since I really liked some things and hated others. I think it overall succeeds at more than it fails, and it feels more comic-y than most super hero films, which I enjoyed - when it stuck those elements. And comparing it to the terrible last few DC films, I think it is objectively better, so yeah, a 6 seems fair.

title: Crazy DC superhero movie...
text: ..that somehow connects most other DC movies. It's so epic to see Michael Keaton back as Batman. He really did steal the show. Imo nobody else can capture the true emotion of Bruce Wayne like Keaton can. Even in the scenes where he's not saying anything,but still showing emotion,gives alot more depth to the character in a way only Keaton can convey that. It's crazy he's even in the same movie as Ben Affleck. Ezra Miller as Flash/Barry Allen gives a crazy performance. It's not perfect by any means but damn I loved how all the different universes connected. It has a perfect balance of action and comedy.40 years after Superman III and the comedic element surely has evolved to blend in with the action better imo. The CGI didn't bother me that much. If only Val Kilmer and Christian Bale also made an appearance than this movie would be really perfect. Definitely gonna watch again,and has put me in a real DC superhero movie kick now.

title: Wish.com version of Dr Strange Multiverse of Madness
text: The first half of the movie was pretty lame. Batman enters the movie and it gets exciting. Batman exits and the movies goes back to being lame. Had Batman been the main character and The Flash a supporting character, this movie would have been 10x better.Not the best DC movie and not the worst, I'd say its somewhere in the middle. Is it worth watching... yes. Is it entertaining... the parts with Batman are. Would I watch it again... No. Overall, the movie is a solid 7.0There were alot of similarities with Dr Strange Multiverse of Madness.A lot of cool cameos, I don't want to add anything to avoid spoilers.

title: Nothing redeeming here.
text: This is not a good movie. That it's failure at the box office had nothing to do with superhero fatigue. It had everything to do with a badly written badly acted film. The only thing anybody might find interesting about it is the fan service but that doesn't begin to carry this film. Ezra Miller acting alongside himself was failure squared. Sasha Calle was rage in a tight bodysuit. Michael Keaton was only there as a call back to a previous era. Even as a Flashpoint homage it didn't work. Studios have got to stop blaming superhero fatigue on their own failures of imagination and providing audiences with garbage. Just like Shazam 2 failed because it was a bad movie, Flash's failures were all about bad writing. Fan service and explosions don't do it for an audience that actually expects to be entertained.

title: A love letter to DC
text: The Flash is unlike anything that has come before. It is a celebration of the Scarlet Speedster as well as the entire DC Universe. The heart, emotion, and storytelling make this one of the best DCEU-era movies to come out.All I can say is that I legitimately laughed through the whole thing, cried twice, and was stunned to silence more than once. Ezra Miller, Sasha Calle, and Michael Keaton deliver outstanding performances in a film that will hit you in the heart and never let go. And here is my favorite thing. It rehabs previous movies. Now, that's a bit of magic.I don't want to spoil ANYTHING.Incredible. Just stunned!!

title: A Tangled Mess with Promising Beginnings
text: "The Flash" (2023) had a promising start, drawing viewers into its world of speed and heroics. However, as the plot unfolded, the film struggled to maintain its momentum, ending up as a tangled mess. One particular disappointment was the lackluster character development of Kara Zor-El, leaving fans wanting more from her storyline. While "The Flash" showcased some exciting action sequences, it ultimately fell into the trap of being just another average movie in DC's lineup.Overall, it earns a modest 6 out of 10 rating. Despite its flaws, dedicated fans of DC may still find some enjoyment in this superhero flick.

title: An emotional rollercoaster with a strong theme and takeaway
text: Given the hype around this film I wasn't expecting it to be such a Flash movie but it was and for the better. It felt like an emotional rollercoaster and was genuinely funny, sad, uplifting, and even unsettling at times. I was not a fan of Ezra Miller's Barry Allen portrayal going into this but I left very impressed. Some of the creative choices worked so well and were very interesting and others I didn't really vibe with as much but I can respect the boldness the creators had in these cases where they really committed to it. The plot was very polished, the exposition didn't feel like exposition, and the action was phenomenal.People and fandom culture in general should take a lot away from this film: that you should let go of the past and look onward to the future because dwelling on it changes nothing.

title: Almost.....
text: I completely understand the hype. With so many recent superhero films and tv shows lacking of the quality that initially made the genre so popular, general low expectations for the most part has led to enough of the audience, over these past few months to come away from this less than disappointedThis is a popcorn flick. It was kinda fun and if the point was to entertain....yeah sure it did the job. The Flash wasn't boring,fairly easy to follow and had its moments with our heroes.Was it a mess....maybe, there was something frantic in the pacing and the complaints levied at the quality and use of CGI are earned. I actually asked myself if the look of it was deliberate , a stylistic choice made due to budget restraints.The portrayel of loss and hopelessness did hit home though not as hard as it could have.Unfortunately the same can be said for the humour, the action sequences, the acting...the use of an end credit scene and cameos that felt out of placeThis wasnt a single movie but the highlights of 2 or 3 loosely held together by what? I dont know much about movies but tell you.What I can tell you though....leave your expectations behind, accept the CGI as is, remember how rare superheroes on screen once were and let yourself forget all the craziness behind the scenes.*Kara and Iris can have my number, address, social media everything and last piece of my favourite fried chicken.

title: Wow: first half is silly DC crap, second half is Very poignant and true
text:
Wow, very weird movie, like it has been written by two completely different teams of writers.The first half is the typical, silly DC crap, with some good action along with idiot characters yapping away (maybe as in reality?) with a silly plot and cockeyed sci-fi trashing of the laws of physics... I almost got up and left the cinema.(If you move into the future or past, the earth moves away from you going around the sun, and the earth is spinning as well, and the solar system is moving around the spinning galaxy, etc etc, so travelling into the past or future while remaining in the "same place" on the earth is mind-bogglingly complex motion.To see this, a youTube search for the video "How Fast Are WE Moving Right Now?" (2 mins 27 seconds) explains it brilliantly.So about half way through all this DC silliness and idiotic plot construction, there is a change in the movie (no spoilers), but suddenly it's a different plot and movie entirely.It becomes an elegy on loss, the past and who we were back then, and how we can "never go home" (philosophy-wise), and trying to go home only messes up your life and the lives of others you love.I cried 3 times holy crap! I never cry in 99.9% of movies.I blame Michael Keaton, one of the two BOAT Batmans. As in the first Batman with him, he brings a bit of human insanity, and gravitas and poignancy to the movie. He makes you actually feel the loss and hope and fear and confusion, and his dialogue brings this home to us. Wow.Michael Keaton, and the actress that plays the Krypton super-girl (Sasha Calle ... Kara Zor-El / Supergirl), and dorky Ezra Miller as The Flash/Barry/Teen Barry become different characters in a different movie. They present a superb, deep dive into things lost forever in the past. WOW.In my own words:The past is gone,
and tomorrow is an illusion.There is only Now.

title: Could have been better !!!
text: I had high hopes for this film when i first heard about it and really really tried to ignore all the negative talk regarding the film, let alone all the stuff regarding Ezra Millar.So to be honest as much as I love ( and I really love the Michael Keaton Batman) he's just not the same in this film (maybe a slightly different reality?) and for me a bit of a let down.I did ,however love Kara's character although I think she was under utilised, I hope she gets her own movie.As for the CGI, yeah !! Not the best, some parts where really shoddy especially when you think its been done a lot better in the past in the X-Men films!! And as for the cameos I'm not sure what that really brought to the film apart from fan service.What I don't understand is that there is so much great source material out there, for example the great Animated film Flash point ,why not literally do this as a live action film??So all in all pretty disappointing and as for the ending...funny but naff and the end credit scene...WHY??

title: Bomb of the Year!
text:
My God what I just saw, the mediocre script, with horrible performances.Now it's the technical part, that damn CGI is too bad and those who complain about the MCU are certainly paying their tongue because it's getting to be even worse for a film that's been in post production for 5 years, incredible something like that kkkk
Not to mention the past that Warner is doing with Mr Miller and the forced and paid marketing for autistic people to praise the film.... In short: everything about this movie is very bad, they managed to do the feat of being worse than Quantumania, the box office size will manage to be worse.Congratulations DC, managed to deliver the worst CBM of the year for the third time!

title: Worth the watch
text: The emotionally charged final scene with Flash and his mother salvages the film, tugging on your heartstrings.While the CGI largely fails to impress, it's Sasha Calle's Supergirl that lights up the screen. Radiant and compelling, Calle offers more depth than Kal-El ever had in 'Man of Steel'. If you can endure the film's slower first half, you'll be rewarded by her stellar performance and undeniable on-screen presence.Matthew Broderick's brief appearance as papa Flash was a delightful touch, and the film's highlights are enriched by such cameos.The film also makes a laudable attempt to weave in various iterations of DC characters, setting the stage for what's to come in the DC Cinematic Universe.While it may not be a masterpiece or entirely true to the Flashpoint narrative, the film serves up a balanced blend of action, coherent storytelling, humor, and emotional depth, making for an overall satisfying experience.

title: Overall I'm just happy I got to see a flash film
text: Where to begin with this movie..It boils down to 4 points:1- Ezra miller. Whatever you may think of they/ them... Ezra's off the camera actions caused consequences to this film and its box office return.But to his credit, he carried the film immensely in a beautiful way.2- no correlation to the dcu. Fans are smart. And we know and knew going in that this film was meant to restart the DCU. And so it left fans wondering well then why watch it?3- more of a Batman film than a flash film:This film was good! Don't get me wrong it's good! And the flack it's taking from fans online is unmerited.But.. most comments will say they enjoyed it more for MK's Batman. Whether you agree or not, the film does win by providing this amazing return.Overall I give it a 6/10.The third hour dragged but the moment in the third act was beautiful.Follow me for more! Pewa4real on the I.g.

title: Flashpoint
text: This has been in production for a long time, and we are finally getting it this year of 2023. I liked The Flash (2023), it was fun, funny, and Ezra Miller was good in the movie, the only thing I would say is that the CGI can be noticeable from time to time. Knowing that the DC universe is being rebooted makes me wish we had more DC movies like this.Despite everything that has happened to Ezra Miller he was incredibly good in the movie; I like how hard Barry Allen is trying to deal with a younger version of himself along with fighting with an alternative Batman, dealing with his mom's death, and getting his speed back which was cool to see for him growing as a character. The younger version of himself was annoying, but that was the point because it was him before he got his powers, also older and younger Barry Allen did work well together.It was cool to see Ben Affleck as Batman working with The Flash in the beginning of the movie, he was cool in the action. The main draw to this movie is the return of Michael Keaton as an alternate version of Batman, who was awesome to see; he was awesome in action scenes, it was cool knowing what it was like in his world, and it was cool seeing his Batman outfit, Batwing, Batcave, and Batmobile. Michael Keaton Batman worked great with older Barry Allen/The Flash and younger Barry Allen/The Flash in helping older Barry Allen fix the timeline, and in action scenes against the main threat.I liked Sasha Calle as Supergirl, and thought she did an excellent job; she was cool in the outfit, and she was cool in the action sequences against General Zod. I also liked the return of Michael Shannon as General Zod, he has more cool fight scenes in this than in the movie Man of Steel (2013). They did a twist on the Superman part in the Flashpoint comic, but I liked it and thought it was done.Having read the Flashpoint comic, I can say they do scenes from the comic either with a twist to it or it will go as it went in the comic. The action sequences were fun to watch, but the CGI was noticeable most of the time, even when you see young Barry Allen you can see the CGI on him sometimes when on screen. The movie does have cool CG visuals when The Flash is reversing time, but there are also appearances of certain cameos that are obviously CGI for a reason but cool to see.I thought The Flash (2023) was a fun DC movie that did an excellent job telling a story like the Flashpoint story in the comics, and Ezra Miller did a fantastic job despite the production issues with the movie. The CGI does stand out, but the effects on The Flash were very cool to watch, especially in those slow-motion scenes. It was also great to see not only Ben Affleck back as Batman for the last time, but Michael Keaton as Batman returning since 1992, but I do recommend watching this movie for The Flash because he was great to watch him evolve as a character and as a hero.

title: Not
text:
Bad, at all. Even though ,all of this super hero films start to blend together)So much intersecting characters and happenings in all the comic books adaptations , that probably I will need to hire a full time helper , just to keep all them in appropriate places)))Anyhow , entertaining, it is. Decent one time watch!600???(((
Bad, at all. Even though ,all of this super hero films start to blend together)So much intersecting characters and happenings in all the comic books adaptations , that probably I will need to hire a full time helper , just to keep all them in appropriate places)))Anyhow , entertaining, it is. Decent one time watch!

title: This is for the haters
text: Just watched this and I have to say, I loved it! Yes the cgi was not the best but let's remember when we enjoyed movies in the early 2000s with the worst cgi and a great story. I think this is the best film to come out of the DC Universe yet and honestly out does anything marvel has released lately. Great storyline, so much thrown in for the nostalgia fans, and with surprise twists everywhere! It was so much fun to watch and I think a lot of you have forgotten that movies are to entertain not just check every bubble on your list. Stop hating on good movies and just appreciate a film for what it is, entertainment.

title: it started off promising.
text: No spoilers. Like with all comicbook movies they rely much in CGI. I would go as far as to say that if you are basing the movie on time travel with younger/older/other versions of characters, there needs to be a better crew behind the computers. There were many moments that felt very joss whedon Justice League rendering /reshots and other times that made me think of Hulk(2003). There was a great story and plenty of space to really explore and work in the characters but the second half just shoots itself in the foot with the yammering on and weak performances to a not at all climactic ending and a no hype post credit scene. At no point did the theatre get all sad, giddy or even a whoohoo. I think i saw one person put their hands up like "yay".

title: Good, bad and the ugly.
text: Let's start with a good things. Michael Keaton, Ben Affleck, Supergirl, some parts of a plot, cameos. There's the bad things: Awful unnecessary cgi. Annoying Ezra Miller, even more annoying than usual. And that's it. It's good and bad movies united. It's seemed good to me. Despite, that I have many reasons to hate it. But of them aren't really connected to the movie. So, my rate is 7. I hope DC will be better next time. You don't have to watch it, I did. It is not that great. But I somehow managed to enjoy it. I thought this will be a reboot showing us new DCU, but it turned out to be less than that.

title: A fitting end to the DCEU
text: After being in development hell, The Flash is finally out and while it definitely isn't the "greatest superhero movie ever made", it is a fitting end to the DCEU. Here are some of the positives and negatives in The Flash.The positives:1. Acting performances. It was refreshing to see Micheal Keaton come back again as Batman. They handled Keaton's Batman decently well, giving a lot of throwbacks and nostalgia. Sasha Calle as Supergirl was also refreshing to see as she too did act decently well on her part. Ezra Miller, despite his controversies, does a decent job at the very least, providing some humour and heart throughout the film.2. The Score. Benjamin did a brilliant job with the score as it really does bring out the effectiveness of the scene.3. Batfleck. Ben Affleck officially says goodbye to the DCEU with The Flash, and although he was a small part of the film, it was truly wonderful to see him one last time as Batman, before we welcome the new one in The Brave And The Bold.4. Direction. Andy Muschetti does a rather compelling and excellent job at this direction, with beautiful cinematography and action.Negatives:1. Third Act. The Third Act felt a bit too rushed compared to the final 2 acts. Supergirl and Micheal Keaton did not have much scope in the last and final act. Micheal Shannon, while his performance in the Flash is great, had nothing much to do with General Zod. Nothing special was given to Zod during this timeline of the multiverse and third act failed to give much scope to Supergirl and Zod.

title: Finally a fun DC movie that (mostly) delivers
text: For anyone wanting more from the mess that has been the DC Cinematic Universe, this is worth checking out.Miller delivers a commanding and surprisingly versatile performance in this epic homage to all things DC. Keaton steals the show, however, as he beautifully takes up the mantle of The Bat once more.It's cameos galore and Easter-egg fodder throughout, but a tight script keeps the entertainment coming. It's directed with love and is refreshingly funny for most of its running time.The final act does become a bit convoluted, but it's wrapped together nicely with a fitting end. If this is the last entry into the canon before the reboot, this was a decent end to what has been a mixed bag of movies from DC (The Batman and Joker excluded).Go for a fun watch and you won't be disappointed.

title: A movie that improves over its runtime with great fan service hiding the bad jokes and CGI
text: Thankfully the DCEU doesn't go out on a low. In fact the finish to Flash is probably the best part.It's impressive the fan service DC were able to work in to this, its worth staying to the end if you're a DC movie fan, trust me. Even Ezra Miller is not insufferable like he was in the whedon Justice League film.So it all sounds good right? Not exactly, the ending although fun in some ways for me waa unsatisfactory... the jokes barely land for more than a whimper (they aren't Thor love and thunder bad though). Also a lot of unnecessary swearing.But the CGI... in the travel scenes and the opening scenes the CGI humans are atrocious. Might as well been watching a toy story film.Shame because with a bit more care this could have been a classic. But the ending made me smile, which is more than I can say for many recent Marvel or Star Wars products.

title: CG wasn't the best
text: Too much CG happening in this movie and not the high quality work. So much red they are using in the CG, especially when he had the flash back all his life. The story line was just alright, was not too interesting or creative. The acting was a little it of awkward and unnatural. They were trying to add in "Famous" actor in the movie as cameo but didn't really help. It would be nice if they gave those actor more scene to make the movie more solid.If I have to choose between DC and Marvel movies.... sorry definitely have to go with Marvel because better quality production. I hope their next movie will be better.

title: Flash is colourful beautiful and heartful.
text: Andy musceitti did the most fantastic job with all the complexities dc had served him.. this movie has action, humour and plot .... Better yet ,it still can make you cry.. it's a shame we didn't get this when dc was fullfledged.. everything would have been different... It honour everything done before... And destroys nothing... Affleck was a blast in every scene he was in... Ezra does so well job , his efforts won't go in appreciated this time .. Keaton delivers... Sasha though short, was the most ferocious Superman seen... Still thepain and love the movie entailed... Thats what got me...i wish everyone gets a chance to see this.. i wish all flash lovers , dc lover , general superhero lovers... Everyone... This is a treat.

title: A Fast-Paced Adventure That Speeds Ahead
text: "The Flash" (2023) takes audiences on a thrilling and fast-paced adventure through the DC Extended Universe. Directed by an incredibly talented filmmaker, the movie successfully captures the essence of the Scarlet Speedster while delivering an entertaining and visually stunning experience.One of the standout aspects of "The Flash" is the performance of the lead actor, who embodies the charming and charismatic Barry Allen. The actor brings a depth of emotion and vulnerability to the character, making him relatable and endearing. His portrayal captures both the lighthearted humor and the underlying determination that defines the iconic superhero.The film's visual effects are nothing short of impressive. The Flash's superhuman speed is beautifully depicted, with stunning slow-motion sequences that showcase his lightning-fast abilities. The CGI is seamless, immersing viewers in the electrifying action scenes and creating an exhilarating sense of speed. The visuals alone make "The Flash" a must-watch for any fan of superhero films.The storyline of "The Flash" is engaging and keeps the audience hooked from start to finish. The time travel element adds complexity and depth to the plot, allowing for unexpected twists and surprises. It delves into the consequences of altering the timeline, exploring themes of identity, choices, and the weight of responsibility. The film strikes a balance between a character-driven narrative and a grand-scale superhero spectacle.The supporting cast in "The Flash" delivers solid performances, enhancing the overall quality of the film. The chemistry between the characters is palpable, and each actor brings their unique touch to their respective roles. The interactions between Barry Allen and his fellow heroes and villains are captivating, adding depth and dimension to the overall story.However, there are a few minor areas where "The Flash" could have been improved. Some aspects of the plot may feel rushed or overly complicated, leaving certain character arcs underdeveloped. Additionally, while the film explores profound themes, it occasionally sacrifices depth for the sake of pacing, which could have been explored further to enrich the storytelling.Overall, "The Flash" (2023) is an exciting and thoroughly enjoyable superhero film that keeps viewers engaged with its high-speed action, engaging storyline, and impressive visual effects. With a charismatic lead performance and a captivating supporting cast, it successfully brings one of DC's most beloved heroes to the big screen. While it has a few minor flaws, its strengths overshadow them, earning it a solid rating of 8/10.

title: Michael Keaton can't save this film
text: I had such high hopes for this film but it was let down by poor writing poor acting from Miller and some of the worst cgi I have ever seen. The opening scene to the movie set the tone with its over the top silliness, I felt like DC were trying to move away the Zack Snyder darker tones but probably went to the other end of the spectrum.Only the nostalgic scenes with Keaton and the links to man of steel had me hooked, But I never had that feeling whilst watching the film where I was rooting for the characters.Also don't bother with the end credits scene it's nothing special after waiting forever for it.

title: An Enjoyable Journey into the World of The Flash
text: I thoroughly enjoyed watching the Flash film. The storytelling was exceptional, with a well-crafted plot and witty dialogue that kept me engaged throughout. Ezra's portrayal of the Flash character was remarkable, effortlessly conveying his charm. His emotional depth and relatability made the character truly captivating, and his interactions with other characters were superbly executed. Additionally, it was a delight to see Michael Keaton return as Batman, presenting an older, weary version of the iconic hero. This made me nostalgic for Tim Burton's previous Batman films and left me yearning to witness his unique take on the character once again.However, the one aspect that I believe everyone can agree on is that the CGI elements in the movie fell short. They felt somewhat outdated and failed to live up to the film's overall quality. Furthermore, I didn't connect much with Supergirl's portrayal, finding it rather dull. The introduction of her character could have been handled in a more compelling manner, as her storyline felt rushed.Despite these minor shortcomings, the Flash was a solid addition to the DCU film lineup. While it may not be the best film in the franchise, it was undeniably enjoyable and served as a successful reintroduction to this new universe of characters.

title: CGI Splendor but barely any new ground is broken for the Flash
text: Quite frankly, it is an enjoyable movie with some humorous quips scattered throughout but fundamentally the story is non-existent and leaves an after taste that really reiterates on the fact that superheroes are movies not just all about fancy visual effects, pop references or "multiverses".It's about the hero and their journey, you would assume the journey would be incredibly important to the protagonist however at times the protagonist doesn't know the importance of why they're going on this journey and thus the whole story collapses under this weight as well under their pre-established character from prior movies. So the story is really poor.The CGI and special effects is really, the only reason you would see this movie. At times it feels like you're watching a comic book come to life, with the same kind of "unrealistic appearance" you would expect if a comic were to actually come to life. It was all really well done in my opinion and I really just wish the movie had better writing.There was also the issue of Ezra, like I said earlier, the story didn't know where it was going and thus there were many times where Ezra's emotions would jump between serious and comical and then there was the problem of capturing two different "Flashes", Ezra simply couldn't pull it off convincingly that both "Flashes" are in fact different versions of themselves, it felt like they were both the same "Flash" despite being entirely different. The whole immature thing is not at all convincing to show a difference between both "Flashes", sure it is humorous to see the "Flash" learn about his powers but that's about it, Ezra's humor stops there and as a result many other actors could have filled the role better and brought more to the table to further the roles of the "Flash".The story is also littered with plot-holes, I mean I don't expect a superhero movie to have perfect writing where everything makes sense, but to completely ignore fundamental points just so that you can force something to happen is really, really poor writing.So in a nutshell, fun movie but terrible for fans of The Flash.

title: FLASH AHHHHH AHHHHH SAVIOUR OF THE UNIVERSE!!
text: If DC don't mind employing potential felons then I recommend John Barrowman as a potential Ezra Miller replacement as at least he has flashing experience.This film sadly isn't doing too well at the box office at the moment and you know what I can understand people avoiding this film as they don't want to support Ezra Miller with all the accusations that have been laid against him. I'll move on quickly from that however I do want to make the point that I find it interesting that although Warner Bros. And DC have been quiet on the accusations they were quick to change the marketing of this film to focus it on the the return of Michael Keatons Batman, I imagine to take peoples mind away from Ezra Miller playing the Flash.That will being said if are able to separate the actor from the character then I highly recommend seeing this film as I thought it was brilliant. That films opens with a well crafted but perhaps slightly underwhelming action sequence but what follows after is one of the best DC films of recent times. The team behind this film have managed to find a way to get around the fact that this flash is already an established character in the DCEU and gives us a memorable Flash origin story. To explain how they do this would venture into spoiler territory however I will say that the decision to put Barry Allen with a past version of himself works excellently. Ironically the two Barry Allen's are how I imagine Ezra Miller is as a person, one side is professional and respectful and the other is obnoxious and narcissistic. To be honest that may be why for me this is his best performance I've seen him give, he really shines in this film which is important as after all he's playing The Flash in a movie called The Flash. It's hard to talk about the plot points of this film without spoiling it however this film trades over the top action for an emotional family driven story and for me it worked really well for The Flash character. After all, he isn't really a strong fighter like Batman or Superman, he's known for his speed and agility. This also helped to keep the film unpredictable and fresh even towards the end but this was at the expensive of a wasted Michael Shannon as Zod however he isn't the real enemy here, time is. There's also a load of fan service here especially for DC fans, if you thought Michael Keaton coming back to play the Batman was going to be the only throwback in this you're very much mistaken and for me it was all throughly enjoyable. Other than Zod being underused my only other criticism would be that that super-girl doesn't really do that much and I don't really know if the film needed her to be in it but Helen Slater did a good job none the less.Overall this may just be my favourite DC film since Wonder Woman and it's one that I think I may find myself coming back to regularly.

title: A good work out in 4DX
text: I have been a fan of DC series since Arrow, but DC films have been really hit and miss. The series have long running story lines that develop a character, while the films (least the ones that stick in the mind) go back to their origins. We all know Batman lost his parents. Here, the Flash figures out one of his greatest powers; time travel and how he can use it to try and correct one of the biggest issues in his life.The annoying part is, that while the TV series has Barry as a grown up CSI, Ezra Miller seems more like lost kid. Give him the long hair and he looks like Alan Rickman, but looks are the only thing. Having Derry Girls Saoirse-Monica Jackson as one of his work colleagues doesn't really make him any more grown up.That does change the tone of the film. It's funny. From the roadside fans at the start, the hospital rescue, through to other scenes along the way, it's enjoyable on a MCU level. OK, the story is hokey, but the real kicker (literally) for me was watching it on a 4DX screen. The speed scenes where awesome, the fight scenes brutal and there is something to be said for flying scenes with wind and swooping.Would I see I see it again at home; unlikely. The main attraction would probably be Michael Keyton reprising his role and all the little cameos (I laughed a bit too loud that the Bills afro cop, Karl Collins plays a lawyer) from other actors listed on here.But if you can see it in 4DX, then do.

title: Like watching a dog in its last days
text: The DCEU is finished. I know it, you know it, we all know it. Unfortunately, audiences are going to have to suffer a little while longer, as Aquaman 2, the movie set to proceed this, represents the final nail in the coffin of no one's favorite cinematic universe. Whether or not the DCU (totally different from the DCEU, I am assured) will meet the same fate, only time will tell. But onto the movie: it's a mess. The CGI is bad. The acting is bad. The humor is bad (there's even a burp joke, because the creative visionaries behind this film believe we're still living in the year 1999). It doesn't matter how much you "turn your mind off" for this one, it's not going to be a rewarding experience. RIP to the DCEU. We hardly knew ya.

title: The Flash is GOOD
text: Have read quite a few reviews, and the majority are hating on the CGI and Ezra Miller.Firstly, the CGI is meant to be that way to simulate the time travel occurring and Ezra Miller does an excellent job as The Flash or whatever version of the Flash he is supposed to be playing.They do an excellent job tying in a variety of characters due to the whole multiple worlds theory and don't try to slam down the viewers throat diversity like many franchises are doing, but do what they can in a meaningful way and in small steps like a non blonde Supergirl or Flash not being completely Caucasian.As an aging DC fan it was great to see Keaton again and the throwback to the fans should keep most content. Storyline has enough heart, action, humor and uniqueness to keep you engaged.In conclusion, people rating this low for CGI are missing the point, and people hating on Ezra due to the headlines you are just feeding into the whole cancel culture ruining the industry. If anything Warner Brothers trying to hide Ezra Miller from publicity to stop the bleeding or canceling Batgirl are going to be their demise for not realizing that everyone has their issues.Good movie and you won't be disappointed if you give it a chance and are a Flash fan in any capacity. However, as a warning I do like the Flash series, which my wife likes to point out is complete crap, so maybe I just have bad taste.

title: Keaton to the rescue!
text: Michael Keaton saved this entire movie!Ezra Miller as the main protagonist doesn't have the stones to carry any big budget movie.And annoyingly enough, this movie has 2 Ezra Miller's in it(!!!) 1 being even more annoying than the other.However, believe it or not, even with Ezra Miller this movie is still a good watch, I actually expected a lot worse! For sure I will be keeping an eye out for the Director who made this movie.Probably better for the Flash movie franchise to write off Ezra & replace him with a much better suitable person - 1 who isn't riddled with mental health problems or at least anyone who isn't accused of child grooming.

title: The Goat
text: I Liked The Movie Very Much . Story , Characters Everyone. Performance Is The Best . Excellent Actions . Emoational. I Liked The Movie Very Much . Michael Keaton Entry As Batman Nostalgia . I Enjoyed The Movie Very Much . Comedy also. No Lag At All . I Am Saying To Go Watch This Movie In Theatres .Frames Was Little Bit Small . IT is Like We Are Watching Through A Tv . Other All Perfect . Acting. Story Another Level . Ben Affleck I Liked His Car And His Batcycle . Michael Keaton Action Scenes . Please Enjoy The Movie .Dont Spoil The Movie . Everything Was Perfect . No Problem. Supergirl Was Nice .

title: Type of film you can watch when...
text: ... you're really bored and/or ill. Seriously, reserve this film for an off day.I was feeling tired and restless the other day so I wanted to watch something easy to distract my mind. I saw this as I was scrolling through HBO Max and to be honest: it's a fun movie. Admittedly, I was also eager to watch it due to the infamously horrendous VFX effects, which did not disappoint. Despite the lead actor's incidents in real life and the production issues, I think it turned out to be a fun flick with Miller putting in a funny and engaged performance. Also, maybe I'm a sucker for time travel films - specifically segments where characters have to deal with the fresh odd situations that they find themselves in - but I think this was done decently with the characters that they had at their disposal. Obviously it feels like it is restrained by its locked casting potential as it would've been a much greater film if the whole Justice League were fully committed. Overall though: flawed but fun.

title: Unfortunate
text: It's too bad Ezra Miller is associated with this film because it was pretty fantastic. I initially refused to see the show because of all his erratic, criminal behavior, but once I considered all the other individuals who worked hard on the film, and my own kid's desire to see the film, we opted to give it a chance and I'm really glad we did. The nostalgia alone was worth seeing the film for but the storyline was awesome as well. If you are a big stickler for CGI you might be a little perturbed, but ultimately it was a cool movie. I highly recommend giving it a shot as well. You won't be disappointed (unless the CGI stuff really bothers you).
