The actor is a child predator but other than that it was something new and exciting done with Xbox 360 visuals. Even Batman looked bad, bring back the man and do his visuals sooooo sooooo dirty. Like how. Do better. Prob why aqua man hasn't been released. Visual effects.

title: Better than its Box Office
text: Like most people, I waited for this movie to come to Max as I did not think it was worthy of spending the money to see it in theaters. While it has problems, its still an enjoyable and fun movie.Barry Allen (Ezra Miller) decided to go back in time to try and save his mother. In doing so, he gets trapped in the past with his younger self (who hasn't received his powers yet). The two of them seek out Bruce Wayne for assistance, but the Bruce Wayne in this timeline is a retired Michael Keaton, not Ben Affleck. The two Barrys convince Bruce to assist them in finding the Superman. When they discover the imprisoned Kryptonian in Siberia, its not Kal-el they find, but Kara-el (Sasha Calle), his cousin. Old Barry also finds out he has unleashed General Zod (Michael Shannon) on Earth again. Together, with a newly empowered young Barry, this new Justice League attempts to thwart Zod while also resetting the timeline.The CGI is awful for a movie that costs $200m (before marketing). I simply do not understand how a movie in this day and age looks so cheesy. Actors are on strike to avoid digital representations of them in the future, but if The Flash is any indication, they don't need to worry. My second issue is with the character of Supergirl (can we still call her that). I enjoyed Ms. Calle's performance as Kara, but she is way underutilized. In the comic on which this movie is based, its Kal-el they find not Kara, but I didn't mind the gender swap. I did mind, the swap if you are just going to waste the character. She contributes almost nothing to the plot and there was some great storyline that could have been explored, but it seemed like the director just wanted to get in more CGI battles. The other issue i had was the idea that two Barry's could defeat an army of Zod's supermen. One Superman kicked the snot out of Barry in Justice League. Yet hundreds of them are easily defeated by...I'm not making this up...kicking them.Having said all of that, the individual parts are better than the whole. I know Miller has a ton of off camera issues, but he has always been my favorite part of the Justice League. His wide-eyed, innocent attitude was a perfect counterbalance to all the gods around him. This Barry is more mature and even he gets annoyed by his younger self. I imagine I would also get upset with my arrogant 20 year old self if I met him...me....today. The byplay and filming of these scenes are excellent and you can't tell its one guy playing two roles in the same scene. The inclusion of Michael Keaton as Bruce Wayne/Batman was a nice nostalgia kick. He still looks menacing and psychotic which was the best part of him being Batman. He looks insane enough to be running around at night dressed like a bat. Sasha Calle looked amazing in the costume and there was some serious potential for a story arc that got wasted. She went from being an isolated prisoner to being human's best hope rather quickly. There was a moment where it seemed like she might turn on the humans (for imprisoning her) but then she sides with them almost at the drop of a hat. Missed opportunity in my opinion.I'm not a huge fan of these multiverse storylines. Seems like it just an excuse to bring back actors or characters and shuffle plots lines when you run out of new ideas. I did enjoy it in Spider-man: No Way Home, and to some extent it was fun in The Flash, but its being overdone. Still, I enjoyed The Flash as a low-tier superhero movie and was not disappointed at all.

title: The Flash 2: A Speeding Spectacle of Superhero Excitement!"
text: The Flash 2" hits the big screen with a lightning bolt of excitement and delivers an electrifying superhero adventure that leaves audiences on the edge of their seats. Directed with flair and finesse, this highly anticipated sequel takes the beloved Scarlet Speedster's story to new heights, exploring the multiverse and diving deep into the complexities of time travel. With a solid script, captivating performances, and stunning visual effects, "The Flash 2" proves to be a worthy successor that will leave fans buzzing with anticipation for more.Picking up where the previous film left off, "The Flash 2" wastes no time in plunging viewers into a whirlwind of action and emotion. Barry Allen, portrayed brilliantly once again by [Actor's Name], is grappling with the consequences of his previous adventures and the weight of his responsibilities. The film beautifully delves into Barry's personal journey, as he struggles to balance his superhero duties with his desire for a normal life. The exploration of Barry's internal conflicts adds depth to his character, allowing the audience to connect with him on a more profound level.The action sequences in "The Flash 2" are nothing short of spectacular. The film showcases the full extent of the Flash's powers, capturing his lightning-fast speed in breathtaking visuals. From the heart-pounding chase scenes through Central City to the mind-bending trips across alternate dimensions, each action set piece is a treat for the eyes. The seamless blend of practical effects and CGI creates a visually stunning experience that immerses the audience in the Flash's world.One of the film's standout aspects is the stellar ensemble cast. [Actor's Name] once again delivers a charismatic and engaging performance as Barry Allen, effortlessly embodying the character's determination and vulnerability. The chemistry among the cast members is palpable, and their interactions feel authentic and natural. The supporting characters, including Iris West (played by [Actor's Name]), receive more screen time and development, enriching the overall narrative and showcasing the strength of their relationships with Barry.The script of "The Flash 2" strikes a balance between heart-pounding action and emotional depth. It tackles complex themes of family, sacrifice, and the consequences of altering the fabric of time. The narrative cleverly weaves together intricate storylines, keeping viewers engaged and guessing until the very end. The exploration of the multiverse and the introduction of new characters add an exciting layer of complexity to the plot, setting the stage for future installments in the franchise.Visually, "The Flash 2" is a feast for the eyes. The cinematography captures the speed and energy of the Flash's movements with dynamic camerawork and clever shot compositions. The vibrant color palette enhances the film's overall aesthetic, creating a visually stunning experience that is both exhilarating and immersive. The visual effects are top-notch, seamlessly integrating the Flash's powers into the action sequences and bringing the multiverse to life with breathtaking detail.While "The Flash 2" is an exhilarating ride from start to finish, it does suffer from a few minor flaws. The pacing, at times, feels rushed, with certain character arcs and subplots not receiving the development they deserve. As a result, some moments of revelation or emotional impact may feel slightly underwhelming. However, these shortcomings are overshadowed by the film's overall strengths and do not detract significantly from the overall enjoyment.In conclusion, "The Flash 2" is an enthralling superhero film that successfully expands the franchise's universe and pushes the boundaries of the genre. With its electrifying action sequences, compelling performances, and visually stunning effects, it is a must-watch for fans of the Scarlet Speedster and superhero enthusiasts alike.

title: I had a total blast to my past with Keaton et al
text: I didn't realize how much I loved Michael Keaton as Batman. The last time I heard him say that line, I am Batman, was on a Saturday Night Live show or something like that. The chills and thrills I got seeing him in that costume again, bringing me back to 31 years old and seeing him in the movies, watching every preview building up to the release date, only for my movie going experience to be ruined by a bunch of talkative inconsiderate moviegoers right behind me. title: The Flash Review
text: The Flash is the first and only movie about the Flash in the DCEU. The main complaint I have is that it really feels like a sequel and this is the first Flash movie. I haven't watched the show with Grant Gustin or Zack Snyder's Justice League yet, so I don't know anything about how they developed Flash and how he handled getting his powers there. It does delve into the multiverse. I prefer the Marvel multiverse movies that came out, of which I'm talking about Quantumania and Across the Spider-Verse. They feel like sequels and are actually sequels, with this one just feeling like one but isn't actually one. That's mainly because it's trying to do the Flashpoint storyline, of which is better to pull off if there's a previous Flash film developing the character.Another complaint is that it kinda revealed a couple things that are meant to be reveals/surprises in the advertising, makes it kinda predictable.For what I find on the better side, it does feel like it does raise the stakes a bit. Barry really shows a conflict of thought and grows as a character. The action is alright, not bad but could be better.

title: Sometimes nostalgia isn't enough
text: This Justice League sequel was, well, about what you would expect: a sequel to a movie/franchise that never earned one. The biggest problem wasn't that the studio (laughably) started a rumor campaign about it being the best superhero movie ever; the biggest problem was that I never cared about the people or the world they were trying to build on. The movie literally riffs off an origin story the audience never saw. From scene one, this was nothing more than a computer animated mess that lacked stakes. There are video game cut scenes that worked better than whatever this was. Whether it aimed for action or humor or something in between, it missed (except for the middle act when the Burton Batman went full Back To The Future...that was funny). The script is bad, the effects are worse, and even nostalgia can't cover over this many problems. I grew up on the Super Friends and Justice League. I spent hours drawing DC Comics. I'm literally the target audience...and this film still completely failed to deliver.

title: Great Movie!! Had fun, love it. Childhood Returned Back!!!!!

title: DC failed once again
text:
DC had the biggest opportunity to revive their horrible movies, but they still haven't figured out how to make a movie. The flash is one of my favorites superhero's. I loved the flash comics and the first 3 seasons of the flash show. This movie was nothing like those two. The writing, the cgi, the characters were all horribly done.Firstly the writing was all over the place. A lot of the scenes were rushed. There was no build up, things were just happening. The movie needed to slow down and build upon these characters. I felt out of touch with Ezra Millers character. They did a poor job of making you feel his emotions. We do not know this Barry DC, introduce us better. Have a more in-depth backstory, stop focusing on Batman and Superman/Supergirl. The flash didn't even seem like the main character, the director seemed to like Batman and Supergirl/Superman more. There is a reason we have source material. Use the comics DC. For christ sake take the first season the flash show and get better actors and have a movie budget. Boom! You have a fantastic movie.The CGI was terrible. There were some scenes where it didn't look bad, but 98% the scenes were god awful. It was a CGI overload. So many colors and things happening. You are often confused what you were really looking at. The time travel art was so confusing, you genuinely could not tell what was going on. DC was shoving colors and motion blur down our throats. Whenever the flash had his suit on, you could tell easily it was cgi.None of the characters were appealing to me.Barry 1 and Barry 2 were not funny and it was hard to take him seriously. He should taking acting lessons from Grant Gustin.Batman was so bland and had 0 character
Supergirl was alright
Iris seemed like a random NPCOverall this movie needed so much work and needed people that actually cares about "The flash". DC you have failed yet again. Genuinely fix yourself.

title: Fix Two Things
text: I don't make it a point to see DC movies. I've never seen "Aquaman," "Wonder Woman," or "The Justice League." I'm not averse to the DCU, I'm just not a huge fan. I chose to watch "The Flash" for no other reason than I wanted to go to the theater. I hadn't been in some time and "The Flash" looked decent enough."The Flash" is not an origin story though it's the first solo film featuring the character. His real name is Barry Allen (Ezra Miller) and he's a spastic young dude who reminds me of a slightly toned down Shia LeBouf.The Flash made a discovery while doing some depression running. He was lamenting the loss of his mother to murder and the loss of his father to prison while running at full speed. In the process he found he could go back in time; which meant he could go back and save his mother.But we all learned from Doc about the space-time continuum, the butterfly effect, and all that jazz. Barry upset the space-time continuum time and again as he tried to get things right.One of the biggest problems with this movie was the CGI. It was CGI heavy in the beginning and it looked terrible. The only other major problem was Ezra Miller as I mentioned before.The time travel aspect of the movie didn't bother me as much as it could. I've seen so many time travel movies with every conceivable method of time travel, that Flash running back in time was no biggie. Have you seen Superman (1978)?The casting also didn't bother me. In fact, it was a positive. There was Michael Keaton, Michael Shannon, Ron Livingston, Jeremy Irons, Ben Affleck, and a cameo by George Clooney. Just fix the CGI and the lead character, then you have a banger of a movie.

title: 3/10 is much better than I expected, but yea this is trash

But if you go see it, drink and count the number of Batmans... plenty of those to go around...Second worst movie I have seen this year, and that is saying something. Stay away.

title: A wonderful ending for the Snyder-verse, loaded with action, heart, and laughs
text: I just finished watching the Flash in the theater with my boys. I thought it was absolutely superb, probably the best DC movie since TDK trilogy, and at least the equal of the first Shazam or WW movies as a functioning, well made film.Some context - I am 45M, grew up with Christopher Reeve Superman and Michael Keaton Batman. Got into the comics after 1989, read religiously through about 2000. Comic collecting fell off after I moved out on my own, but I still read collections on Kindle and have watched nearly all of the movies. I found the Schumacher Batman films absurd and dumb, loved the Nolan films, have no idea why Green Lantern failed (charming performances and a mostly comics accurate story), found MOS and BVS dour and ultraviolent, liked Shazam and WW, think ZSJL is the best of Snyder's efforts because it integrated better character stories and at least a bit of levity. I have watched The Flash of the Arrowverse shows and think it's a great adaptation of the material.So with respect to The Flash movie:-I was engaged by the emotional story, and moved to tears when the emotional finale occurred. The plot itself was clever and well exposited, I never though "Oh, come ON" or "why are they doing this again?"-I was impressed by the attention to detail in recreating the Keaton Batman's manor, props, costumes, and thought Keaton turned in a very good performance.-I thought Sasha Calle was really good as Supergirl, and while I did not really enjoy MOS, thought it was extremely clever and fitting to wrap up the Snyder-verse the way it began.-Ezra Miller, whatever his faults, was very charismatic and emotionally convincing in the role.-I enjoyed the peek at the multiverse, and think it's a wonderful and respectful way to transition from the Snyder-verse - this (or Aquaman 2) will be the last story we see from it, but the world will keep on existing in the larger multiverse.So why is The Flash failing? Is it made just for me, and I don't represent a big enough market? Was the movie just 5 years late to market? Has the DC brand been that damaged by Warner's spasmodic inconsistency? Do moviegoers really care enough about the impending reboot to shun "not main story line" movies? Were Ezra Miller's peccadilloes really enough to sink the film?I'm really just sort of baffled. This was exactly the movie this franchise needed. Fun, full of heart, action packed, true to the comics, loaded with reverence for what's gone before on screen, a fresh start for the future.Honestly I'm kind of astonished WB allowed a movie this good to be made.

title: Typical superhero flick: long, ambitious, rather confusing and bloated with amazing CGI & a stellar cast
text: As a typical modern superhero flick "The Flash" is too long (2hrs 24mins) with ambitious but rather confusing writing (from Christina Hodson) while bloated with stunning CGI visuals (under director Andy Muschietti) & big names (inc cameos from George Clooney, Ben Affleck, Gal Gadot, Jason Momoa, Nicholas Cage, Jeremy Irons, Nikolaj Coster-Waldau & Kiersey Clemons). For a 4th time (but the first as main star) Ezra Miller's the titular speedster, this time traversing time (to save mum's life & dad Ron Livingston's freedom) while encountering himself, Michael Keaton, Sasha Calle & bad guy Michael Shannon. Genre fans will enjoy, but for all others it's a bit too 'much'.

title: Narratively very strong
text: Narratively, this is a very strong film, consistent and supported by good performances, with the clear standout being Ezra Miller, who is as much problematic as an excellent actor.It's a film that makes several references to the past - and even to alternative pasts that never happened and almost happened... in our universe - but it doesn't do it as cheap as Marvel has done before with loads of fan service. Here, it's the purpose that matters above all else, and that is crucial for it to hit the right emotional notes.It has problems in its introductory act, still taking everything too lightly and with humour that doesn't always work - in a style very similar to MCU humour - and it fails to explore anything about its villain (who had already been introduced to us before).Regarding the VFX, I don't share the opinion that they are among the worst ever seen. There's much worse in several Marvel films, including some recent ones. They are bad when the CGI is in motion on the ground and the battles look like a video game. I didn't like it, but it's nothing that isn't commonly seen in most films of this subgenre. I didn't have any issues with the CGI in any other scenes. I don't even understand the criticisms of the CGI in other universes because it was clearly an aesthetic choice (if Cage has that fake face, why doesn't Miller? Because that was clearly the choice when presenting other universes through Flash's eyes).I'm a little sad that this won't continue from here on because it's one of the most promising things to come out of the DC universe and the best thing narratively speaking (not visually), in a live-action multiverse. I would like to see more of Miller in this role and I would like to see more of his relationship with Iris growing. At least we should have more of Sasha Calle's Supergirl, who deserves her opportunity.

title: Best movie 2023
text: Best movie of the year, no doubt. It's hilarious, fun to watch, entertaining, emotional, intriguing.The storyline develops really well, there wasn't a single moment I got bored or distracted. There's so much going on in different places, the movie is never stuck in one thing. You go through all the emotions with this movie.I hadn't laughed running out of breath like I did with some parts of this movie, I hadn't felt so sad in a long time and also so relieved.Ezra really killed it in this movie, it's truly a masterpiece.There are Easter eggs and cameos all around.Sad to see it didn't get the recognition it deserves (at least for now).

title: Fun Movie but what happened to the CGI
text: Flash is a pretty good movie despite the bad press surrounding the star and the DCEU collapse. The first 45 min tends to drag but once the film picks up it becomes very enjoyable. I really liked how the film incorporated Supergirl and Batman, both characters were developed well and added much to the overall story line. The CGI is a major issue, to the point that at times I thought I might be watching a video game cut scene. It was so bad that it really takes u out of the film, a real shame considering how interesting the film becomes. Its worth a watch but brace your self for some bad computer work.

title: Live Action Flashpoint
text: It has FINALLY arrived, after waiting for 8 LONG years the live action movie The Flash has hit the screens.I have to say as an adaptation to flashpoint I really enjoyed the movie, I enjoyed the cameo's when barry went through the speedforce, the movie is very much a love letter to DC fans or the Donnerverse, Burtonverse, Schumacherverse, Snyderverse and every live action comic book hero be it TV and Film for the past and present.Set a year after the events of Zack Snyders Justice League Barry time travels to save his mother from being killed thus by saving her alters things. Its a story about loss, dealing with grief, acceptance and moving on for Barry.Does it reset the DCEU? Not really. Does it lead into James Gunns DCU Universe? Not at all so I am not exactly sure what is going in that department other than its going to be its own universe.Does it open the door to the multiverse? Yes 100% absolutely.

title: Please let the next generation of DC be better
text: Well this was another DC flop. DC just doesn't understand good story building, There are just so many characters that I could just care less about. Any one of them could die and it would mean nothing to me. There is no emotional connection to the characters.You always feel like you are just jumping into the middle of a story. Probably the best DC movie was Wonder Woman because they actually started at the beginning. They made you actually care about the characters.This movie had a few funny moments but besides that was just full of terrible special effects and plot holes. I hope that James Gunn can save this franchise. If blue beetle is a flop then I might just throw in the towel altogether.

title: Why are people canceling this amazing movie?
text: This movie was spot-on and accurate with the comic book, but I guess the cancel culture is awful, so I blame people, not the actors. People do not deserve entertainment! I know how much it costs to make a movie and how many people it takes to make one of these fantastic productions come to life. It is not cheap, and people remember that not many people are going to the movie theater, so being free on Amazon Prime is a good thing. I loved this movie when I screened it; I love Ezra Miller as an actor because he brought a unique character to the movie screen, and I genuinely love the idea they got all the old characters back in this movie. It was nostalgic for me. I have to say, towards the end, when he saw his mom, it made me cry; it hurt me inside because losing a family member was very real to me. Berry Allen had the power of the Multiverse to change everything and realized it is more complicated than that! I bet Cronus taught him a lesson in messing with his time. If you do not know who Cronus is, you must brush up on Greek mythology. Cronus would be considered a celestial in the Marvel Universe, but this is DC; still, Greek mythology is Greek mythology.

title: A surprisingly great superhero movie
text: I avoided this movie because of the horrible behavior of its star, Ezra Miller. But it kept appearing on TV while I was switching channels, so I started watching from the middle. Then I recorded it and watched from the beginning. I have conflicting feelings about saying this, but this is one of the best superhero movies in a long time. It has character development (rare for most superhero movies), action, humor, special effects, touching moments, drama, suspense, and even nostalgia. The screenplay is not simply the all-too-common theme of the bad guy wants to take over the world and the hero has to stop him. The ending, which I won't give away, was more complex than the cliché one where the hero figures out the bad guy's weakness and sends him far away in space and/or time with a hint that he'll return for the sequel.Ezra Miller did a fantastic acting job as two different characters, but from all reports, he needs psychiatric help, and Warner Brothers lost significant revenue because of it. If it weren't for Miller's behavior off screen, I believe this would have been one of the highest grossing superhero movies of all time.

title: Another LGTVHD+ pampering agendas apart from that nothing in it
text:
No matter how many times you read about how awful this thing looks, trust me when I say it's worse than you're imagining. Some of these visual effects are absolutely abysmal, potentially the worst I've seen in a movie of this scale(300 million real budget and mummy movie rock face in scorpion like worse CGI). Main character is in real life a women abuser LGTVHD+ member even far before this film happened and still casted him so many times( if that abuser was a normal guy , they should have get ridden that guy, why pampering a special "type" of gender lobbies) ,,
In story wise we all now it's fictional , but even in fictional mindset story and visual of multiverse doesn't add up , CGI and story maker should watch "what if " series of Marvel and how they handled multiverse atleast....
And flash girlfriend in comics was ginger white girl now series and movies made that as black girl (why racial swap to please some mafia go with original) , I don't know why they inserted Superman's cousin girl in Superman's costume init , and like thor they maked a character (no spoilers who that is )as far drunk in post credit scene (why?) ,,, And main non-binary main actor is very weak in a character of flash..waste of time.

title: Don't listen to the hate
text: The flash was a great film, it really doesn't Deserve the hate it's been getting, it's a fun emotion ride and deserves 100% deserves a watch! You get past the bad cgi for the great story trust me. It's one of the best of the old DCEU and it's sad that we probably won't be getting a sequel or some kind of follow up, please give this film a chance and if your a fan of the flash it's well worth you time, Ezra miller does a great job, don't judge a movie on an actors poor choices in life, it's a fun movie with lots of crazy references to other dc projects you'll see what I mean if you watch it. Give it the love it deserves.

title: So many missed opportunities
text: This is a wasted opportunity. So many neat ideas and character moments wasted on a terrible story and two annoying main Ezras err characters. It has great elements but just when you start to enjoy a scene it's ruined with nonsensical plot, bad humour or annoying character moments. The alternative Batman and Supergirl are neat characters at the core and well played though most character development is ...rough but still easier to just ride with than Flash's main arc which could be so deep but has no real weight nor believable depth. Ezra acts well enough I suppose, but probably has terrible writing.

title: This is the right direction for DC
text: After so many years DC is finally showing improvements, connecting storylines. I really enjoyed the movie. It had a very good story. A lot of nostalgic comic book Batman and little puns here and there unlike Marvel who over do it. I hope DC doesn't overdo it either. It's all around a great movie.This requires minimum of 600 letters so here's it again:After so many years DC is finally showing improvements, connecting storylines. I really enjoyed the movie. It had a very good story. A lot of nostalgic comic book Batman and little puns here and there unlike Marvel who over do it. I hope DC doesn't overdo it either. It's all around a great movie.

title: Keaton saves the day
text: I went to watch the movie with my son only because Michael Keaton returned as Batman.Story plot was a bit weak and the CGI was a bit poor in places but seeing Keaton back as Batman with the Danny Elfman music in the background was worth the ticket price alone.Now I quite liked it to be fair. Was a bit slow in the middle but I wasn't disappointed.I had a nice evening with my son and a bit of escapism. The film is a bit of fun. Don't take it too seriously. Just go and enjoy it.Reviews and opinions are from a personal point of view. See it for yourself and make your own mind up.Keaton is Batman!

title: The Flash (2023) Fanservice but it doesn't work
text: One strategy many movies are using is fanservice. This was seen in No Way Home and it worked in a spectacular way because it was so well done. In The Flash we also have a lot of fanservice, but I don't think it's done as well. The biggest defect of the film is not even this, since the story is boring and the script is often very flawed. We have an interesting direction that creates really cool scenes. However, it's impossible not to be bothered by the CGI, which, even though it really is a creative decision at times, still bothers a lot. The visuals of most of the characters are very bad and this is another negative detail in the visual. The fanservice is cool when Michael Keaton's Batman works, as much as I don't think he was well worked, however, when other characters appear I don't think it works. The Flash is not easy on the eyes for a variety of reasons, but fans of the DC universe will definitely appreciate the references.

title: This One Really grew on Me
text: This is, by far, the best treatment of the multiverse of any superhero movie. This one is funny and exciting, but most of all it is easy to follow and not confusing for the sake of trying to appeal to some psuedo-intellectual. I did not know too much going into this one, and I don't know too much about how it all came together but there are some very fun and jaw dropping moments in this movie that I can not reveal for the risk of being a spoiler. I know Ezra Miller has had his challenges, howler, he is likable in this role and I credit him with some heavy lifting on the acting side. The commercials give away that Michael Keaton is in this one so I am not giving anything away-this is a huge strength of the film. He is delightful, and the references to his time as Batman are terrific. The special effects and fighting are really good. I liked this a lot.

title: Ohhhhh Michael Keaton!
text: DC movies have had a tough time, from the stand alone trilogy of Christian Bale's Batman (Brilliant) the building of DCU movies from Man of Steel... Batman vs Super man than Wonder Woman movies (Brilliant) then Justice League movie (OUCH) we then reach to the 2023 release of 'The Flash' from same leading actor 'Ezra Miller' playing the fast as lighting 'Barry Allen'.When I read up the movie review in my trusted movie magazine it sounded promising and it was!I really enjoyed the movie, I think the plot was really good with Barry's backstory and playing out like the multiverse mash up in MARVEL, Michael Keaton was brilliant as the returning Gotham Knight, like he has never left!Action through out was good, a decent pace movie even from its opening credits a very well made movie, shame the DC movies haven't had the same luster as Marvel as the tone in The Flash is on point.

title: He is the Flash!
text: The new Flash movie, starring Ezra Miller as the titular character, is a thrilling and emotional ride that once again proves the depth of storytelling in DC movies. Miller shines as the fastest man alive, bringing a multi-dimensional performance to the role of Barry Allen. The ending, featuring appearances by Batman and Nicholas Cage as Superman, is especially satisfying and fun to watch.One of the standout aspects of this film is its emotional depth. The story explores complex themes and relationships, and Miller's portrayal of Barry Allen captures the humanity and vulnerability of the character. The film also boasts an impressive cast, with Michael Keaton and Sasha Calle delivering strong performances.Overall, the new Flash movie is a must-see for fans of DC movies and superhero films in general. With its engaging story, talented cast, and emotional depth, it's sure to leave a lasting impression on audiences.

title: Messy, Messy, Messy.
text: TLDR: The Flash is more enjoyable than I thought it would be, with some genuinely fun and heartfelt moments. Unfortunately, it just doesn't work in totality, and the film feels undercooked, to say the least. Everything from the plot to the HORRID visuals and poorly thought out nostalgia bait seem to confirm this. Please let the DCEU die already.The Good:1. Some nice moments. Within The Flash's two and a half hour runtime, I will admit there were some nice moments. The final scene with Barry and his Mom was genuinely sweet and made me want to go hug my own Mom. There are some cool Batman moments and if anything, hearing the classic Danny Elfman score again was nice.2. The weirdness. This is highly personal, but I kind of liked some of the weird, kooky dialog and out-there ideas in this movie. There's a scene in younger Barry's dorm room that I found funny. I'm a sucker for The Flash's powers, they've always been super cool to me and there are some legitimately interesting things done with them.2. The ending (mostly). While the final act of this movie is very bad overall from a visual and creativity standpoint, and while I think this ending was entirely predictable, it's still kind of cool to see one of these movies have a less "we-have-to-punch-the-evil-away" endings.The Bad (hoo, boy):In general, this movie is really ugly. Muted colours, obnoxious blue and orange lightning bolts, and everything looks as if it was shot on a green screen and feels lifeless. Miller looks terrible a lot of the time in his costume and the camera does this weird fish-eye lens thing where it just looks...offputting, that's all I can say. Speaking of Ezra...

title: A good film from DC after a long time
text: Good storyline, good action scenes and one special thing is the jokes. This movie has the best jokes in a comic movie ever They are real jokes not like dumb jokes in Shazam and Deadpool. 😀When Justice League hit theatres in 2017, I'll admit that Ezra Miller's rendition of The Flash wasn't my favourite, but his version grew on me over the years. The DC films in the last ten years have been hit or miss though. You could never tell if a film was going to be good or not. Well, hearing everything that could happen in DC's latest release, The Flash, I had to see it for myself. I'm happy to report that after seeing it and sitting on my thoughts for a couple of days, I can confidently say that this is one of DC's better films in the last 5-10 years and the emotional core packs a great punch.

title: Poor Michael Keaton couldn't make it work on his own.
text: Keaton tried to carry the entire film on his shoulders but just couldn't make it work. 8 of my 4 stars are for Keaton. The other (4) is for the rest of the movie.If this was 2008 and a video game you'd be like "those effects are amazing, the people look so real" but alas this is 2023 and a movie and everyone is an uncanny valley version of a Barbie. The effects are horrid is what I am saying, in case anyone was confused.The plot though, the plot, that was boring and rehashed tired garbage too. The acting, subpar from miller and most everyone else. If you want to see Batfleck watch the trailer, it has 100% of Ben's performance in it. He is not in it one second longer.But stay for after the credits so you can really feel cheated, ripped off and stupid.

title: "Let's Get Nuts"
text: The mere fact Keaton is back as Batman makes this movie awesome. He was absolutely fantastic.Even though the multiverse is the current trend in comic book movies, I am totally a sucker for all these cameos and alternate versions of characters. The inner nerd in me gets all giddy. I would have loved to see Bale, but respect his decision to say no.Even with all the negative press about Ezra, he was fine in the role. Though I picture the younger Barry probably a lot more realistic to his real self. And that being said, he should not play the character going forward.Supergirl was also good and I thought Calle really played the character well.

title: Garbage.
text: This movie is utter trash, it is so bad I can't even come up with words to describe how bad it truly is without being redundant, but I'll try. I don't even have to bring up how disrespectful these cgi "cameos" are because it's self-explanatory. I feel really bad for most involved in this production, and I meant "most" because some of these people needed to be fired for their low-effort work. Which brings me to the effects, as everyone has already stated how bad they are and without hyperbole these are the worst effects I have ever seen in a movie of this budget. For some reason they seemed to have used mostly Photogrammetry for the effects instead of green screen, which would have been much cheaper. I know that they can't use a green screen all of the time, but it still looked better when they could have used it. The Photogrammetry is so bad, it somehow looks worse than the Photogrammetry in Fight Club and The Matrix. As for the plot, it felt shallow and pointless and made me wonder why the whole movie happened to begin with. All in all, if you want to feel miserable for two-and-a-half hours, this movie might just be for you.

title: Ezra Miller deserves a second chance as flash
text: In fact, the film surprised me. I did not expect it to appear at this level. The comedy in the film was wonderful. The action scenes were excellent. The acting was wonderful. In fact, the directing was crazy.Ezra Miller was excellent at representing two different characters in terms of age, temperament, and personality. Really, his performance was amazing. Michael Keaton was great. Also, Supergirl was excellent. The events were fast There was no boredom, but there were some problems with the visual effects. The film dealt with the multiverse was very good.In the end, the film was good, and I hope that this will be a new beginning for the world of DC cinema, and I hope And I hope Ezra Miller completes the role of Flash.

title: Yet another mindnumbing and tedious overuse of nonstop CGI effects, which fail to impress
text: The bad: I NEED solid, true to life characters to enjoy ANY movie, even an action hero blockbuster like The Splash. And there are NONE of those true to life characters to be found.Dont even mention the dialogues, which are cardboard and shallow. Let's even forget about the incomprehensible storyline (writers were still on strike?).Let's talk about the thrill of this movie. Let's talk about the spectacle. THAT's THE reason people flock to these kind of movies right?MORE BAD: there is NO thrill or spectacle. NONE. Seriously. What there are A LOT of are masses of mindnumbing, UNimpressive CGI special effects that bored the heck out of me.If you are a grownup then BEWARE! This movie is only suited for hyperactive gamerkids, who just want to see fast moving picture framerates flash before their eyes. The content does not matter for them...To be avoided like the plague, for any filmloving sane grownup person!

title: The Flash Truly Is The Fastest Man Alive!
text: Worth every penny, and every ounce of waiting. DC's good old Skarley Speedster is back and better than ever! Michael Keaton's Batman and Sasha Calle's Supergirl made this even better as well. I enjoyed this like any DC fan would. I can't wait to see this again.I expected nothing much, and enjoyed everything I witnessed despite a two controversy and came out the theater smiling. I highly recommend this to others who are truly DC Comic fans and are fans of The Flash.As much I enjoyed this movie, a sequel is not necessary. The DCUE ends, the DCU officially begins.I cannot wait to see this again... in a flash!

title: The Greatest Superhero Movie Ever Made
text: Who made this & what is he known for?Andy Muschietti directs the first ever live-action motion picture based upon the infamous character. Muschietti is known for directing the wildly successful It duology. The film is one of the 2 final chapters which began a decade ago with Zack Snyder's Man of Steel. It is the epilogue chapter in the DCEU.Who stars in this?Ezra Miller reprises his role as the titular character with a host of supporting characters which cannot be revealed.What is it about?It is about Barry Allen trying to save his parents.And how was this?What began as a universe which was not well-received by the audience and made lesser(yet successful) numbers compared to the Marvel Cinematic Universe, comes together in a fashion which today's Kevin Feige can only dream of doing.Andy Muschietti's love for the characters, comic books, the DC live-action movies in general, oozes out from the screen and into your mind to blow it out of your wildest imagination. Every second of this movie is pure comic-book awesomeness and for those who have grown up with the superhero movies beginning with the 1978 motion picture, Muschietti provides an entire platter to devour from. The filmmaking is a wondrous combination of heart-stopping action set pieces, breath-taking visual imagery, and intense writing - put together to cater to the fans of all things DC. Not to be mistaken that other crew members do not have enough to do here. Henry Braham's cinematography is scintillating and wonderfully framed. Every moment is a joy to watch while the action is captured in all its glory with sweeping shots and effective lighting. Benjamin Wallfisch provides the score of a lifetime - bringing back all the greatest hits in the superhero roster. John Francis Daley, Jonathan Goldstein and Joby Harold write a story which leaves you gasping for more every time a dialogue is said. For the movie nerds out there - this is the greatest cinematic achievement one can receive in catering to the fans. These guys along with Christina Hodson - who wrote the screenplay, deserve a staggering round of applause to did what they did. Eunice Huthart's stunt coordination is superb! The action set pieces are stupendous and enjoyable in a manner no other DC movie might have done so far.Ezra Miller has put his heart, soul and mind into the character and it shows in every frame. His performance achieves a rare benchmark for the genre and covers the spectrum of every scenario Muschietti places him in. It is a beautiful transformation for a character which was meant to be the comedy relief in the previous films.The Flash is a $200-million superhero movie which is the culmination of so many things across the concept of filmmaking - from studio issues, to actors not getting their due, to being the perfect example that in the hands of the right director and the right set environment, an actor can do wonders. It was impossible to think what could top something like Avengers: Endgame but it happened sooner than later.It is officially the GREATEST SUPERHERO MOVIE EVER MADE.Their Tagline - Worlds Collide.My Tagline - 'Let's get nuts.'THE GREATEST SUPERHERO MOVIE EVER MADE.

title: An Electrifying Experience
text: The flash does not disappoint at all, I walked into the theatre expecting another bad take from DC but this was truely an amazing experience, there are a lot of surprises and cameos in the movie, loved the nostalgia that keaton's batman brought, Sasha Calle's supergirl was a really interesting take, the movie has everything to keep you occupied for those 2 and a half hours, really nice humor and it does not feel forced at all, the jokes will make you laugh for sure. Seeing Ben Affleck as Batman for the last time was sad but also thrilling, the time he got on the screen, he gave his 100% in that performance. One of the best DC movies in my opinion.

title: $220 million worth of garbage.
text: As a huge flash fan myself, I am very disappointed with the train wreck of this movie.Barry Allen is one of the all time greats, but is portrayed on screen by an unhinged child predator. The casting director needs a new job if he thinks that this "person" (or mad goose wizard) is a suitable choice. He has severe mental health issues and desperately needs professional help, not acting gigs. He cannot act and simply grates on your nerves after a very short space of time.Not even Keaton could save this one (though he is solid throughout).The CGI is all over the place and extremely distracting.The story is an unrivalled mess that wastes one of the greatest Flash stories "Flashpoint Paradox".The DCU is dead.

title: Flashes of Greatness
text:
Almost exactly ten years to the day after the rebirth of Kal-El and his incredible start, we Flash-forward to a great and probable final DCEU film.To be fair, there are two more scheduled for release. Blue Beetle and Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom are slated to hit theatres later this year. I can't see it going much further, though, since these lose so much money time and again.And it must be terrible to be the DCEU. It's wildly and enormously better to be part of this team, but people still just flock to the MCU like cattle. There are far greater movies in the DCEU and so many duds in the MCU.I digress. I figured I'd like The Flash prior to seeing it. I had NO IDEA how incredible this movie was. To be fair, it's not perfect - it does go on a tad longer than it should've, some of the CGI was painful and one of the most annoying characters in the entire universe is here. (Hint: it's the stupidly obnoxious 18-year-old who acts like a 9-year-old. NOOO 18-year-old acts this childlike.)I digress again. The Flash wastes NO time getting to the goods - so, no origin story here, thank goodness. I mean, it does take the lead from Tim Burton's original Batman by introducing the character's beginnings later in the story saving room for a nice comic-book action cold open. I don't mind origin stories, however. If it's the character's first movie, so be it. But I like it more when there is just the assumption you know the title character. Especially with the someone named The Flash and that he would be, well, fast.Barry "The Flash" Allen figures out he can be so fast, he can travel through time and wants to save his parents from a tragedy that took his mother's life many years ago. Barry is, of course, told this is a bad idea and can mess up the multi-universe, etc, and...we wouldn't have a movie if he doesn't Flash-on with his plan. Now Barry's must fix this so he can go back to his future.Sucks we have yet ANOTHER multi-universe comic book movie. What is this, the 7th of the last 10 films released in both the MCU and DCEU? Even Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is basically in another realm parallel with our timeline. Mercifully it doesn't dominate the plot and is used seldom enough to be its own movie.This movie was a complete joyride from start to finish. I thought the 1,516 trailers I saw for this spoiled all the cameos. Nope. Brace yourself. Finally, the trailer didn't ruin everything and there are probably 3-4x more AWESOME cameos, some you saw coming. Most are complete and WONDERFUL surprises. And even a few huge laughs out of me for whom they got. And why.I do hope people will give this movie a shot. It's hilarious, action-packed and surprisingly has a TON of heart. I did tear up multiple of times, namely because of the hurt Barry is going through with both what he's done and the loss of his mother. Having lost my own mother, this was really tough to see. Like Ezra Miller or not, he did a phenomenal job with his connection to his mother.For the other role he plays...well, not so much.You really, REALLY, need to be familiar with the ENTIRE DC brand, and not just DCEU. Having known/grown up with DC, since before the original 1978 Superman: The Movie and having watched/familiar with all of the Superman actors over the ages, this is one I picked up almost every Easter Egg. In fact, one guy started talking about the cameos to his group post-film and what they were referencing. I had to go way further with the history and expanded on his lecture about threefold. I know, NEEEEERD. When it comes to Superman...you can call me whatever you like. He will always be my number one.SEE THIS MOVIE. Where people thought Zach Snyder's movies were too dark and Wonder Woman set too far in the past (both of her outings,) this is modern and as light as they come.And this is the Justice League movie we SHOULD'VE gotten.***Final Thoughts: As stated above, I love way more DCEU movies than MCU. Currently, I am a HUGE fan to really liked roughly 60% of the below ranked best to worst DCEU movies. I can only say the same for 33% of all MCU movies. And there are a lot more of those, so they had many more chances to prove themselves...and still comes in second to DCEU.1. Man of Steel (2013)
2. Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (Ultimate Edition, 2016)
3. The Flash (2023)
4. Wonder Woman (2017)
5. The Suicide Squad (2021)
6. Shazam! (2019)
7. Shazam! Fury of the Gods (2023)
8. Black Adam (2022)
9. Birds of Prey and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn (2020)
10. Suicide Squad (Extended Cut, 2016)
11. Zach Snyder's Justice League (2021)
12. Aquaman (2018)
13. Wonder Woman 1984 (2020)
14. Justice League (2017)

title: Keaton is the Key
text: Those not of a certain need to know that, of all the actors to play Batman, Keaton showed the most promise. However, egos in Hollywood being what they are, the producers at the time felt that Keaton, best known for comedy, should have been honored merely to have had a shot. And Keaton himself felt that he had more than delivered (true) and wanted more money. BAM -- that was the end of the Keaton DC franchise. This post-Snyder post-Whedon entry brings to mind the DC "imaginary tales" of the 1960s. However, such is the world of today that the actual DC franchises are themselves are badly damaged by nutty writing and even nuttier personality clashes. Against such a backdrop, an "imaginary tale" is a welcome relief. Under-rated. ((Designated "IMDb Top Reviewer." Please check out my list "167+ Nearly-Perfect Movies (with the occasional Anime or TV miniseries) you can/should see again and again (1932 to the present))

title: Awesome Movie!
text: Great movie for the long DC movie fans. The comedy was on point. I wish the movie was a little more serious but I'll take what I can get from the DCEU. I am not sure what direction WB wants to take the DCUE but I hope it keeps going because I will always be a DC fan. The CGI was not perfect but I appreciate all the cameos they created for this movie. The post credit scene only make sense if Aquaman is still coming out.I do like and enjoy the independent DC films like the Joaquin Joker or the Pattinson Batman so I hope those movies keep coming. I am super excited to see where the DC goes from here.

title: One of the best films I have ever watched!
text: Being a huge DC fan, especially with the comics, films and TV shows, I was so excited for this film and had been waiting for it ever since Ezra Miller's Flash debuted in the Suicide Squad film... and I'm so happy to say that I was not at all disappointed by The Flash! The acting was amazing from Ezra Miller and I loved the performance of Ian Loh as "Baby Barry". I see a lot of people have slandered the CGI, but I think it was perfectly fine and acceptable. The plot was perfect, thrilling and it even made me cry 😂I am disappointed with the lack of trust and chance people are choosing to give this film, as well as the amount of negative reviews. People need to find other things to complain about!Huge credit to the Justice League actors and actresses and to Ezra Miller especially - you did a fantastic job! Hopefully, there will be a sequel to look forward to!Please, please give this film a chance because it's just amazing.

title: Not a DC fan at all but this film is top notch
text: First start out by saying, I am not a DC fan at all but after watching this film, I have to say it Hass to be one of their top five movies. I don't understand what all the negative was about the film. The storyline was decent. The acting was great Michael Keaton obviously stole the whole show and he is the greatest Batman ever. The last handful of movies that DC has put out are nothing short of utter trash with no storyline week plots and horrible CGI. This film, however, redeems sort of them, and it was as good if not better than Batman versus Superman, which in my opinion is probably one of their if not the best film they've come up with.

title: Can't wait to see it again !
text: And that says a lot. A lot of superhero movies have let me down in the last 2 years and except for Snyder's cut of JL in black and white, I'm rarely eager to see a movie a second time. This one does the trick. Yes, the CGI is sometimes questionable but I'm in my 50's and from a time where FX were the word "Kapow" written on the screen. I prefer a solid story to a CGI fest. And The Flash has a good story, just enough humor and a solid cast to make it great entertainment. I had a 21 and a 15 years old with me and we all came out of the theater pleased and smiling. So forget about Miller's latest scandal and just enjoy the ride. Oh, and they get the multiverse right. That's a big plus. Their nod to the past in the final act is moving and creative.

title: Best Super Hero Movie of the Year
text:
I have a lot of trouble with Guardians of the Galaxy and Spider-man through the Spider Verse for the same reason, way, way too over done. I read George Balanchine's autobiography in College. He mentions the hardest part of being creative is to NOT using all your ideas at once. Disney and Marvel could learn a lot from this. I found the Flash just the right amount of done. Include a beautiful Omaj to other versions of the DC universe at the end which only lasted a couple of minutes was a wise decision. I wished they used John
Williams great Superman Music at the appropriate moments. Danny Elfman's Batman music was well used.

title: It's a fantastic movie
text: The fact that more people didn't go see this is criminal... unfortunately so is the lead actor (though Miller's actions may have been the result of mental health issues) This is the BEST DC movie since the Dark Knight Trilogy. Rent it, stream it, whatever, give it a chance. You won't regret it. Without getting too spoilery I do want to warn however that one of the opening action sequences may be a bit rough to watch, especially for those with very young children and dog lovers. It's nothing graphic, it's just a very tense high stakes situatuation. There are some very funny moments and even some cool surprises (despite the best efforts of the trailers)

title: The "Great Reset" of the DCEU
text: "The Flashpoint Paradox", Flash Catastrophic Events which is different from comic book & DC's animated story arcs, the "Great Reset" of the DCEU, and a brilliant introduction to the new Gunn's DCU. Now the Cinematic DC Universe also has endless possibilities and I believe all the dumb newbies will definitely accuse it of copying the MCU's Multiverse concept. The Batkeaton's badass appearance adds a perfect entertaining (if not nostalgia) element to pleased batman fans, and it seems like he doesn't need anyone else to take his role as the Caped Crusader. Flash is a Snyder-verse closing act and an underlined statement that all the DC's ever and "almost" made cinematic universes are exist. People complaining about the bad CGI visual fx, It's not that bad, IMHO. The only thing that doesn't make any sense to me is when young Barry Allen has the same physical appearance with the "real" Barry, while Bruce Wayne is a different person. Adios, Hasta luego, SnyderVerse !

title: Very Fun
text: This is a very fun Flash movie. Despite the trailers showing batman and supergirl this is very much a Flash movie. This is the definition of a popcorn movie, just sit back, relax, and enjoy the movie because you will be non stop entertained with alot of fun surprises and surprisingly some very emotional scenes in this movie. Ezra Miller does a fantastic job at playing 2 different Barry Allen's and you can tell that they are both 2 very different characters. This is by far the best superhero multiverse movie, yes even better then across the spider-vesre. This is a fully complete movie with a beginning, middle, and end. I will infact be rewatching this in theaters because it is just such a fun popcorn movie.

title: A Fast-Paced Adventure Filled with Heart and Multiversal Marvels
text: "The long-awaited Flash movie has finally arrived, and It did not disappoint. The movie is a thrilling and visually stunning journey through the speedster's world. Directed by the talented Andy Muschietti, known for his work on the horror hit "It," this superhero adventure takes viewers on an exhilarating journey through the multiverse, packed with mind-bending action sequences, heartfelt storytelling, and stunning visual effects. From start to finish, the movie delivers an electrifying experience that will satisfy fans and leave them eager for more.Despite all the controversies, Ezra Miller shines once again as Barry Allen, capturing the essence of the Scarlet Speedster with his quirky charm and genuine vulnerability. Miller's portrayal adds depth to the character, allowing audiences to connect with Barry on an emotional level. The exploration of Barry's personal struggles, including his desire to save his mother and the consequences of his time-traveling adventures, add depth and emotional weight to the story.The supporting cast shines in their respective roles, with standout performances from Kiersey Clemons as Iris West and Sasha Calle as Supergirl. Their chemistry with Barry adds an extra layer of warmth and camaraderie to the film. It was great to see Ben Affleck as Batman and Bruce Wayne again (probably for the last time).Calle's performance as Supergirl is a standout, displaying both vulnerability and strength in equal measure. She effortlessly embodies the essence of the character, showcasing Supergirl's unwavering optimism and her fierce dedication to protecting the innocent. Calle's portrayal strikes a balance between relatability and otherworldly power, allowing audiences to connect with her journey on a deep emotional level. Though her screen time may not be as extensive as some fans might hope, she leaves a lasting impact and sets the stage for further exploration of her character in future films.Michael Keaton's return as Batman is a nostalgic treat, and his presence brings a sense of gravitas to the story. The dynamic between Keaton's Batman and Miller's Flash creates a fascinating mentor-student dynamic that fans will surely appreciate. One of the most intriguing aspects of Keaton's reprisal is the way his Batman is seamlessly integrated into the narrative. Despite the time-traveling plot, Keaton's Bruce Wayne feels like a natural progression of the character, a seasoned crime fighter grappling with the consequences of his choices. The older, weathered Batman resonates with a depth that adds a layer of maturity and wisdom to his interactions with the film's titular hero.Visually, the movie is a feast for the eyes. The special effects are spectacular, especially during the high-speed sequences where Barry taps into the Speed Force. The scenes of him racing through different dimensions and altering the fabric of time are breathtaking and showcase the character's incredible powers. The action sequences are adrenaline-pumping and expertly choreographed. The film successfully captures the essence of the character's powers and delivers exhilarating moments that will keep audiences on the edge of their seats. The cinematography and visual style effectively convey a sense of speed and urgency, creating a thrilling experience for the audience.Overall, "The Flash" is a triumph in the superhero genre, successfully blending high-octane action, mind-bending storytelling, and heartfelt character moments. It embraces the spirit of the source material while bringing its own unique flair to the table. Whether you're a die-hard fan of The Flash or simply looking for an adrenaline-pumping cinematic experience, the overall journey of Barry Allen and the grand scale of the multiverse make it a must-watch for fans of The Flash and the broader DC universe.

title: Middle of the road, forgettable
text: The CGi is some of the worst I've ever seen and with this type of budget that is unacceptable. I don't know whether it was because EM wasn't available for reshoots or they ran out of money but it was reminiscent of Mustache Superman.The story was predictable with obvious story beats. The highlight of the movie were the side characters and cameos.There was also a very amusing scene that was a nod to Avi Avard, you'll know what I mean when you see it.Some of the side characters felt very 2D, with the exception of Keaton who stole the show. His theme tune and familiar gadgets and gizmos really do make you feel like you're watching a proper sequel to Batman Returns, until you're suddenly back in Ezra's ultimately pointless story.Don't expect any massive reprocussions from this film as it is massively missable and doesn't really effect anything at all, especially considering the upcoming reboot. The parts that you do feel like may have an effect are disregarded because of the upcoming reboot..

title: Incomprehensibly obnoxious.
text: 9 minutes and 9 seconds. That's how long I lasted before shutting off The Flash. Setting aside Ezra Miller's horrible deeds in the real world, this movie is simply unwatchable. The first scene at the coffee shop had me cringing out of my seat; the bad ADR hurt my brain; and the CGI... everything you've heard about how terrible the VFX are, is 100% true. I've got no idea how this movie was made this badly. Maybe it was a tax write-off, or maybe the director just hates you. Either way, I'm surprised anyone could get through this, because after seeing Flash stuff CGI food down his throat before saving CGI babies in looney tunes situations, I needed to wash my eyes out with bleach.

title: A very great Multiverse film, but not greatest film of all time
text: I'll be very honest, the Flash is an amazing rollercoaster of emotion, heart, comedy, and sadness. The catch for this film having these elements is the horrible, disgusting CGI. I mean, it was very very bad. It makes love and thunder look like The Mona Lisa. Despite the trash CGI, the movie is very entertaining and the story is top notch. The third act is the weakest, but it is complemented by the amazing first and second acts. Ezra Miller put on his best performance as the Flash in this movie. He had range and depth I didn't know he had. Michael Keaton was amazing as always in his grand return as Batman. This movie ticks all the boxes of a great superhero movie and a great movie, but it's by no means the best film of all time.

title: Strong fan service a highlight in another mid-tier DC feature
text: Attempting to get to the big screen since 2018 in various ways, four years on from when its star Ezra Miller was first cast as the famed DC speedster in 2014, the journey to the big screen for Barry Allen/The Flash has been far from an easy one, made all the harder due to the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic and the off-screen controversies of it's lead performer that have often overshadowed other elements of It director Andy Muschietti's attempt to gift Allen a standalone venture that will be worthy of its characters pop culture standing.Arriving in the midst of a significant pivot for the cinematic universe of DC movies now overseen by James Gunn and Peter Safran, The Flash marks what feels like the end of this era of DC comic adaptations (with the equally troubled Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom still yet to come this Xmas) and while its pleasing to report that Muschietti's film offers up some great fan service, throwbacks and fun moments, it's still nothing more than a mildly pleasing blockbuster that is let down by some weak scripting, horrifically bad CGI and a central character that is now hard to judge outside of its actors private life that is far too complicated to delve into via a review such as this.Taking a leaf out of Marvel's feature film playbook (not the first time DC has played catch-up in the medium) and delving headfirst into the Multiverse space, Allen is here looking to rewrite his past only to discover meddling with time creates all type of problems and unforeseen consequences as the powers at be gift us the chance to once more see an iconic figure such as Michael Keaton's Bruce Wayne/Batman or Michael Shannon's General Zod as well as new faces like Sasha Calle's Supergirl appear alongside a double dose of Miller, in what feels like a boardroom not entirely trusting the star power of its title character to carry a film without the extra assistance.Where the story itself takes us offers little in the way of much narrative surprise and The Flash does struggle in making its central premise carry too much emotional weight but after a truly bizarre opening segment that includes, I kid you not, a baby in a microwave, The Flash's dalliances in beloved character spaces and interactions with fan favourites are undeniably enjoyable, particularly evident in a final act that in itself is a bit mid-tier but in a broader fan servicing way is sure to light the internet ablaze.Standing tall amongst all of this is the extremely pleasant return of Keaton's Wayne/Batman, who here showcases age has not wearied him in the slightest, fitting perfectly back into the capped crusaders iconic costume and husky tones, Keaton is having a lot of fun returning to the comic space he helped bring to life many moons ago and weighted against Miller's wildly varied turn as multiple Allen's (ranging from engaging to downright annoying), many will walk away from this outing with their fondest memories relating back to Keaton's turn here.Lacking the charisma, smarts and dazzling spectacle the best of this type of movies have, The Flash can't break the mould of mildly entertaining yet equally forgettable DC features, making it a missed opportunity to create something special, while giving us just enough to suffice.Final Say -Thriving off its throwbacks and homages to what has come before, The Flash is far from a complete failure but also light years away from being the iconic entry its overseers would've been hoping for when it was first contemplated almost a decade ago.2 1/2 therapy dogs out of 5Jordan and Eddie (The Movie Guys)

title: What a movie!
text: Sure, this is a movie for the 40 year olds. It relies heavily on nostalgia but it has it all, humor, action, one liners, throw backs...The CGI could have been a bit better, sure... but sitting there watching the OG Bat as well as numerous other cameos, (I won't spoil but you won't be dissapointed), was just freaking awesome.The story is good and not too complicated but just enough so you don't imediatly know what's going to hapoen but easy enough to follow if you grasp the concept of the multiverse.I cannot believe that this won't be the path for the future movies...I gotta say go see it and see it now. No time to loose.

title: Ahh my coats on fire
text: From the very beginning, it's eye catching and has you on the edge of your seat. The movie is not only hilarious, with one liners for days... but it's heart felt and keeps you guessing. Every time i though I knew what would happen, I didn't and I was tastefully surprised. The movie is 2 and a half hours long, but just like the flash... it goes fast. I would watch it again, like now. Definitely buying it as soon as it is available. It is worth seeing a couple more times in theaters to be completely honest. It's a must see in theaters. Visually stunning, action packed, delicious surprises and I am so happy they didn't change actors.

title: Another DC classic
text: Very well executed. Finally a flash movie that expressed the full potential of the flash superpowers. The flash point paradox with the man of steel universe and the nostalgia of my favorite heroes from the past and present in a complex multiverse made this film very engaging to watch. It had the action, drama, comedy and the thrill. If Your a DC fan you'll love the easter eggs. There wasn't a dull moment. The film captured the essence of who the flash was from his personality to what his focus was and what shaped his character. It did a very good job drawing you into the storyline and keeping you interested waiting for what happens next.

title: Yeah, he's Batman.

title: Great Movie But Misunderstood
text: This movie was absolutely fantastic! Ezra Miller did an excellent job playing three characters which is not an easy feat to accomplish. Despite his off screen problems and yet to be proven allegations, his skilled acting range showed off in dramatic and comedic fashion. Michael Keaton did an excellent job once again but it was nice to see his character have some personality. Sasha Calle was fantastic but under used. Her with drawn personality was great and you really felt for her all throughout the movie. To people who felt this should have ended the DCEU, nope this movie was about BarryAllen!

title: As Close to Epic As You Can Get For a Modern Superhero Movie
text: After all the horrible reviews, I felt compelled to write a review on what I believe was the most underrated movie of the year and maybe the most underrated of the past few years. No need to explain the plot, we all know it is about Flashpoint, and they do it in a brilliant way. The Flash comes in at nearly two and a half hours and it feels like thirty minutes. The pacing is phenomenal and among the best pacing I have witnessed for any superhero movie as of recent. The script is air tight and not one shot of the film feels out of place. Rather than taking the strictly goofy route (like most superhero movies have been doing lately) this film finds the perfect balance of humor and gritty action scenes that should be in every superhero movie. Michael Keaton's Batman steals the show and is somehow even more convincing as Batman at 70 years old than he was in 1989. Every scene Keaton is in is electric and grips the audience in a very unique way. By the time The Flash wraps up, viewers are left with a since of satisfaction due to the ending not being a heart-broken one nor a happy one. With plenty of fun cameos, bright and breezy filmmaking from Andy Muschietti, awesome action scenes, and a perfectly woven story, The Flash is sure to satisfy the craving for everybody's need of another superhero classic.

title: Horrible Casting
text: Miller had no business playing Barry Allen. He was not believable in the role. He was a buffoon who is nothing like Barry Allen. The effects from the TV show were better than in this movie. The only thing that saves it is Michael Keaton. How they displayed the multiverse made no sense and if you blinked you would miss the "cameos" of those who played superheroes in the past. Anyone else in the role could not have done worse. As usual Hollywood wood decided to try and indoctrinate people with "diversity" instead of sticking with the original material. So all in all, the wrong actor to play Barry Allen, poor effects (when a TV show has better effects that says something).

title: Overall a good movie
text: No spoilers here but as a movie or a superhero movie it does pretty well. I'm happy to finally see the flash movie and the story was well written. The only reason I didn't like it was some parts of the movies cgi wasn't really good. It looked pretty goofy here and there. I also with it was more comic accurate with Atlantis at war with the amazons, or even the accurate flashpoint Batman suit. Other than that it was an amazing movie. Me and my father and brother loved watching it and it is most definitely going to be one of the best movies of the year and possibly the best dc movie they have made for individual characters.

title: Disastrous
text: I do not know where to begin. Deciding to role with Ezra Miller after all the allegations, was a mistake. On top of it, James Gunn deciding it was a good movie to role with, was also a mistake. This movie I would have canned and rolled with Batgirl, Black Adam 2, or even Wonder Woman 3. What is going on with the DC Universe? I went into this movie with an open mind and right from the start Ezra Miller is awful, annoying and reminds me of Elliot Page. His character from the Justice League (another horrible movie, shot twice) is amplified in this one. The CGI was overkill. In all honesty, the CW Flash was and has done much better.As I continued to watch, it did not get any better. I got bored with it. There was no depth, no connection, just blah. Different timelines, this character, that character it was just overkill. Like circling The Flash on a chalkboard and throwing anything and everything at it to see if it would stick.I've lost hope for DC. Any movie that comes out is viewed with caution because of how terrible WB has been with it. Sell it off to Marvel and be done with it.Bottom line, highly disappointed. Do not waste your time.

title: Well I don't know why it failed at box office.
