While the special effects may not be polished, it's a serviceable and amusing addition to the growing list of superhero pictures that unfold in multiverses or parallel realities. Barry Allen, an adolescent buffoon with impulse control issues, decides to save his mother's death, creating another timeline with an alternative Barry Allen. He discovers a replacement Batman and Supergirl, replacing Superman. The film is efficient, pacy, and largely enjoyable. "The Flash" is a mixed bag of superhero blockbusters, combining thoughtfulness, cluelessness, challenge, and pandering. It features both good and bad digital FX work, and, like its sincere yet hapless hero, exceeds expectations for competence. However, it often faces challenges and faces-plants into the nearest wall. "The Flash" is a narrative that repeatedly resets and starts again, exploring time, parallel universes, and the possibility of altering "canonical" events or whole dimensions. Despite its thoughtfulness and diverse genres, it suffers from being its own worst enemy. The film also premiered after the release of "Spider-Man: Across the Spiderverse," a high watermark for superhero movies and studio animated features that explores similar concepts in a more innovative way. Ezra Miller stars as Barry Allen, a twentysomething forensic scientist and secret superhero. The film struggles with the impact of his mother's murder and father's wrongful imprisonment. The film's plot is described in detail, but much of it has already been "spoiled" on social media, online forums, trailers, marketing material, and Wikipedia. The review highlights the double bind of discussing the film's meatier parts, as the plot has already been spoiled. "The Flash" has a countervailing tendency that undermines its best self. Instead of repurposing library footage from earlier DC comics, the actors who originally played them have been scanned or rebuilt as vaguely three-dimensional but uncanny grotesques. This process, similar to the process used to reanimate Peter Cushing in "Star Wars: Rogue One" and later serve up unsettling "young Carrie Fisher" in the climax, paving the way for a nearly expressionless "young Mark Hamill" on "The Mandalorian," and de-aged '70s movie stars for various legacy sequels, is trotted out and multiplied ad nauseam here, even though the technology hasn't improved much. The Flash's use of callbacks to other versions of heroes and villains from film and TV serves no other purpose than to burnish Warner Bros' properties and make the audience point to the screen and whisper the names of actors, characters, films, TV shows, and comic books they recognize. The film's principal cast undergoes a zombie CGI treatment in the Chrono-Bowl to visualize alternate realities. Some of these living actors with SAG cards and updated IMDb pages appear faintly demonic, with torsos and hands not anatomically credible. The technology used in the film may have been exploited until quality control disappeared, or it may not be yet there. The use of an animated format raises concerns about the representation of a thing not meant to seem "real." In live-action, the character of "Actor X" becomes creepy and unreal, leading to a broken spell. This is a shame, as "The Flash" is a well-crafted film that warns against a thing while also performing a version of it. Barry, driven by a desire to resurrect the dead, grapples with the ethics and advisability of actions, which the film constantly performs without breaking a sweat.

title: Underdog
text: This film seemed it was going to fail due to behind the scenes issues, however it blew my expectations away I was grinning from start to finish. The cameos were not fanservice and was required for the plot. There was a little bit of questionable CGI but only a little. The final scene was very outlandish but it made me smile, but I understand if it would make some fans leave the cinema. Overall, it is arguably the best movie from the cursed DCEU and was a enjoyable last harrah for the beloved characters. This film deserves the praise and recognition it deserves and it pains me to see that people are willing to let it fail over one of the thousands of people working on this film.

title: ACTION and FUN
text: I didn't expect much when I watched the film, didn't watch trailers and read just a few reviews. So at the end, I was surprised how good this film was!It has anything You need for popcorn cinema: a bunch of action, humour, cameo, cry and laugh and so on. Just sit down, relax and watch the show!Not a film for the family, but for all who like super heroes and time travelling stuff, i.e. Nerds like me.Sometimes it feels like the writers wanted to much and had to shorten the story, but anyway they did a good job. The film could have been 30 min longer, without getting bored.If You don't leave the cinema with a smile on your face then something must be wrong with You!

title: Very disappointed.
text: Me and my wife saw this movie in a very nice theatre in Iceland. We've been watching the Flash on Disney+ for some time now and really like it. We are also fans of DC movies and the Marvel ones too. To say something good about this film is that there were some good jokes and appearances of different actors who was very nice. The main actor, Ezra Miller was on the other hand terrible and annoying from the first minute to the last. I don't know why DC went for this actor who's been arrested many times and is a major troublemaker....which would be ok if he/she isn't just a terrible actor and the voice is also incredibly annoying. Comon DC....get a better actor and have a better plot!

title: Not only one of the best films in the DCEU but also one of the most entertaining superhero films to be released in the past several years
text: "The Flash" is a superhero film serving as the 13th installment in the DC Extended Universe. Directed by Andy Muschietti ("IT: Chapters 1 and 2") and starring Ezra Miller in the title role, it ranks as not only one of the best films in the DCEU but also as one of the most entertaining superhero films to be released in the past several years.Sometime after the events of "Justice League", Barry Allen (Ezra Miller) is working as a forensics investigator while also saving people from danger as his superhero alter-ego "The Flash". When testing out his powers of super fast speed, Barry discovers he is able to travel backwards through time and decides to use this ability to save his mother from dying. Upon accomplishing this task, Barry learns that he has now inadvertently created an alternate timeline with no superheroes, putting the world at risk from the rogue Kryptonian General Zod (Michael Shannon). With no Justice League to assist him, Barry seeks out help from his younger self, an elderly Bruce Wayne/Batman (Michael Keaton), and an imprisoned Kryptonian hero (Sasha Calle) to save the Earth from Zod's wrath.It's hard to believe that it has been ten years since the world was first introduced to the DC Extended Universe, kicking things off with the divisive "Man of Steel". The polarising reception of that film and eventually all of the DCEU's catalogue has kept it far behind the more successful Marvel Cinematic Universe in terms of overall popularity. That's not to say the franchise as a whole is a complete failure, as there are some genuinely solid films in the series as well as some notable performances from its cast. One such character who stands out is The Flash, whose energetic, overly confident personality made him one of the more memorable additions to the DCEU's Justice League. After all this time, The Flash now finally has a chance to shine in his 2023 solo film, which functions as both an excellent character study of the eponymous hero and a wonderful tribute to all the positive aspects of this decade old shared universe.As opposed to a typical origin story, this film gets straight to the point by throwing the audience and its lead character right into the thick of the action. We watch the young Barry Allen race through the city at super speeds to rescue people from a collapsing hospital, using creative and humorous makeshift methods along the way. What hinders Barry's progress is not the task itself but rather his empty stomach, which needs to be full in order for him to perform at maximum capacity. Though this character trait was comically hinted at in "Justice League" (both Whedon and Snyder Cuts), here it is treated more seriously, as the entire fate of some falling newborn babies rests on whether Barry is able to consume a nearby chocolate bar to acquire the necessary energy needed to save them. This is just one example of what the film gets right compared to other DCEU entries and I was impressed at how it was able to balance the humour and dramatic severity without resorting too heavily into either one.Moreover, Barry Allen's characterisation is handled exceptionally well, in not one but two different versions of the same person. The present day Barry is at odds with his double life of working in forensics while also saving lives as The Flash. He is haunted by the death of his mother, as well as the fact that his father is wrongfully imprisoned for allegedly murdering her. All of these problems reach a boiling point when he learns of his ability to fix all these issues by use of time travel. When things go wrong, Barry ends up meeting his past self, whose blatant immaturity makes him a difficult ally to work with. Present Barry is clearly frustrated at Past Barry's behaviour, and it is here the film begins to show the two Barrys as completely separate characters. Like a classic comedy duo, Present Barry essentially acts as the voice of reason to the impulsive Past Barry, allowing for some amusing comic relief scenes that help move the plot forward. But what starts off as a series of humorous situations soon becomes an important battle to save this timeline from destruction, and watching the two Barrys try to work together is a great way to develop each of their characters, with both learning something from each other along the way.Similar to what happened in "Spider-Man: No Way Home", there are certain parts that call back to previous DC films, and not strictly limited to just the contained DCEU library. There is considerable acknowledgment of almost all of the best things about DC in general, ranging from the excitement of watching their superhero movies to contemplating hypothetical scenarios of what could have been. As the film delves even deeper into the DC multiverse, we see plenty of fanservice and easter eggs to spot during our first viewing. Of course, I am not going to spoil anything here so all I will say is that there were a handful of scenes that truly warmed my heart. Most of these moments take place at the climax, but there are also some neat references to other DC media sprinkled throughout the story that should definitely make longtime fans very happy. Best of all, most of it felt like belonged there and wasn't simply shoehorned in to distract the audience from the plot. Even a Marvel fan like myself couldn't help but feel a genuine sense of satisfaction upon seeing some of the surprises that this film has in store for us all.Separating the art from the artist, I think Ezra Miller did a fantastic job playing both versions of Barry Allen/The Flash. Miller manages to successfully strike the perfect balance between the annoyed straight-man Present Barry and the cocky youthful Past Barry, to the point where they each feel like completely independent characters from one another. I found myself caring a great deal about both Barrys and the fates they are respectively aligned to, which provides a superb driving force for the story. It's a huge shame that the actor is embroiled in such disturbing real-world controversies because Miller has a lot of acting talent, all of which is sadly going to waste. Regardless, Miller's depiction of The Flash was well-worthy of the big screen treatment.But the real reason I wanted to see this movie in the first place was to watch Michael Keaton wear his Batman suit one last time, and on that note I was not disappointed. Keaton just so happens to be my personal favourite Batman, so seeing him play the character again for the first time since 1992 was nothing short of surreal. Not only can he still hold his own physically alongside the rest of the younger cast, but Keaton still has that ability to leave an impression on audiences by his presence alone. Even well into his 70s, you can tell Keaton is having the time of his life fighting through hordes of enemies and piloting those signature Bat vehicles the same way he did over 30 years ago. All of this was cleverly punctuated by the film's musical score using the original Danny Elfman theme whenever a scene called for it. If there were ever an appropriate way to pay homage to this beloved incarnation of an iconic hero, then this film does so with a resounding sense of accomplishment.After a decade since its debut, it's kind of sad that the DCEU isn't receiving as much celebratory fanfare as their competitors at Marvel. The inconsistent quality of their films means that some of their best work will likely be brushed under the carpet and forgotten about along with the rest. This is exacerbated by the fact that the entire universe is going to soft-rebooted in a matter of time, which will make these films pretty much null and void. I can only hope that upon viewing "The Flash", others will see that all is not lost and that the franchise is still capable of fantastic things. However, in order for that to happen, all I can do at this point is recommend it to as many people as possible, even if you are only a casual fan of DC.I rate it a solid 9/10.

title: Worlds Collide Going Back to the Future for The Flash
text: We're back in a flash, Streamers! No, literally, this week we were able to see DC Comics/Entertainments, The Flash. Long believed to be called Flashpoint but if you know you know what the movie is going to be about. The fastest man on the planet Barry Allen/The Flash uses his super speed to change the past, but his attempt to save his family creates a world without the superheroes he's come to know, which then forces him to race for his life to save the past and future he knows. Fast and Flash things ensue. Let's see how it goes.This movie is one of those conundrums. It's been made in a DC universe that has underachieved a lot so now it feels like with new management they want the movie to make up for all of their past wrongs. Now, The Flash is a solidly entertaining movie. There are some nice action sequences that are hard-hitting and true to the characters many have come to love. The storyline has a few really touching moments that keep the viewer on a roller coaster of emotions.Like the MCU, this movie is throwing in a bunch of cameos from very recognizable faces but not in a throw away manner, which is slightly cool. The biggest one is not a surprise - good old Bruce Wayne played by Michael Keaton. Keaton along with the others does a valiant effort reprising his almost thirty-year-old role. Anyway, seeing these worlds collide with the Ezra's Flash was interesting and a nice touch even though this version of the Flash seems to fit a bit better with the cornier Mr. Freeze Batman franchise. Nevertheless, this leads to the most annoying parts of the movie. Both versions of Barry/The Flash played by Ezra Miller are a bit too annoying and corny even for the Flash. They definitely should've tapered that writing back to be more like the Grant Gustin Flash. I just wanted to shout out my guy Gustin because my show is ending *cries*. Anyway, the story feels a bit forced rather than organic and when that occurs the movie felt a bit predictable. Even in that, the movie was still watchable, especially once you get to the action sequences, which it does take a while to get to.Ultimately, The Flash isn't the greatest movie, but the way DC operates this feels like a vast improvement. The Flash is one of those movies where you have to see it on the big screen to get the full effect but eventually, you'll be watching this on Sunday afternoons on FX for sure. There is a good amount of action, cameos, corny humor, sentimental moments and etc. That keeps a viewer watching for 2 hours but is it perfect, nope. Grab a big box of popcorn for the Flash.

title: RIP DCEU
text: Terrible CGI, disrespectful to Snyders vision and overstuffed with fan service to those who think Michael Keaton should be the only batman ever.Not a single joke landed throughout and the opening scene which tried desperately to capture the brilliance of quicksilver's scenes in days of future past failed to get anywhere near, which considering there are 9 years between those two films is shocking.I can't believe they're going to let this guy direct the new batman movie.Not sure which version of the film Tom Cruise watched when he announced it was the best comic book film ever! Seriously?!

title: Bolting through Madness
text: I just got out of The Flash (2023) in IMAX and it was great! The first impression of The Flash is that it has some good jokes that I could not resist to laugh. The comedy was good that made it a action-packed, but also a funny DC film. The cinematography and acting was great to seeing The Flash with two Barry Allen's (Ezra Miller), Super-Girl (Sasha Calle), and two Batmans (Ben Afleck/ Michael Keaton) all in action against fighting crime and General Zod (Micheal Shannon) with his army. Kudos to Michael Keaton still playing the role with his great acting in this new addition. I am glad to see what more of The Flash can do in his own movie of what he can do with his powers. Also, this made me more emotional because it involves Allen Barry's family. Director Andres Muschietti made sure that this superhero entry is going to be a memorable one with surprising cameos. It is simply a great addition to the DCU with its cinematography, action, acting, and comedy. I would recommend watching The Flash in theaters because I am going for a second viewing!

title: Not as bad as you think
text:
This is one of the best DC film
For OG Batman fansYou won't regret seeing it.Starting was quite mid
But later when Barry realises that he can actually fix things that's when this movie gets Interesting, A FEW CGI SCENES AREN'T WELL POLISHED(That's because the movie studios push CGI companies on the lease of time)Besides that I enjoyed watching it, it feels more like a new age DC movie with a few OG characters and also a few pop culture refrences that only OG Hollywood fans knows. At a point it also makes fun of Marvel's multiverse theory, but static 'Time doesn't work that way'. It's an entertaining watchVery good for casual viewing.(Climax could've been better)
Don't try to nitpick everyother thing and you'll get a complete entertainment of almost 140 mins(it doesn't feel long/streched)

title: No Henry Cavill
text: Just stop DC, you are continuously screwing things up. Not only writing off Cavill, but way too much CGI and in a really bad way. The whole first scene with Barry and the building. What the actual F! That was so lame...Get back on track with writing and good filming, and for the love of god, get Cavill back will you (saying it, knowing it won't happen bc you have the Guardian Grunt on your team now)The continuous changing of characters and poor chat choices are some what another let down in your department.Get Nolan back in the seat with, let's say Cavills Superman, and that would be a massive start.

title: Disgusting CGI
text: Really? They call this CGI?This movie would win the Oscar for the most primitive, ridiculous CGI! Movies made in the 70's had better CGI than this movie!This was insulting to the audiences that paid money to enjoy a superhero movie!The "2" rating is only for the storyline that had the potential and could have been turned into a good superhero movie!I understand that the makers of the movie have tried to keep the costs down to increase profit, but OMG! There is a limit!!!There are a lot of scenes where the real actor could've been used to make the scene, but NO, NO No, let's save money and be cheap by giving all the CGI's to a 5 year old !

title: Not what I was expecting
text: Pre-release, everyone was touting The Flash as one of the greatest comic book movies of all time. Rave reviews from advanced screenings at Cinemacon, celebrities such as James Gunn, Tom Cruise and Stephen King full of praise for the film.But the truth is it's not even the best superhero movie released this year! That accolade belongs to Across the Spider-Verse. But that doesn't mean it's a bad movie. Not by a long shot! There are problems, for sure. Most notably the CGI, which is rough, to say the least, in a number of scenes.There are plenty of positives, though. The smart script, appropriately fast pacing, creative directing and, perhaps most of all, the humor! The zany, almost Looney Tunes-esque nature of the visual gags was a pleasant surprise, catching me totally off guard. Those gags, which start especially when the younger Barry comes into the fold, prompted a few laugh out loud moments in my theater.Speaking of Barry, the troubled Ezra Miller shows great range playing two wildly different yet strangely similar parts. Michael Keaton brings an unexpected levity to his Batman, while Sasha Calle shows why she's a rising star by bringing remarkable intensity to her Supergirl.To put it plainly, The Flash is not as great as everyone was saying. What it is though is a fun, funny and entertaining adventure that makes 144 minutes fly by. It has not only visually but intrinsically a cartoonish nature, especially evident in its (great!) opening, that reminded me of the amazing Justice League Unlimited and Batman: The Brave and the Bold cartoons.P. S.: Keep your eyes peeled for the more than special cameos, especially if you're a big DC movie history buff like I am. Try to avoid spoilers (I wasn't so lucky), as that will make everything all that more surprising. Stay until the very end for the (only) post credits scene.

title: A huge joke...
text: Within the first five minutes of the film, you will know that you've made a mistake in watching it. By 13 minutes in, you'll be wondering if you should even continue watching.This isn't a serious film, not even close. It is parts slapstick and just plain old stupid parading around as if it were actually comedy. It is no wonder that none of the actors will be sticking around for any further movies in the various franchise films - they don't want to ruin their reputations any further. I really felt bad for Gal's initial reveal and how Ben's Batman was presented at the start.The next issue is that the story is far from original. Sure, that is to be expected with comic book adaptations, but in this instance they're doing an adaptation that was already done better by the TV show.Then, what was worse than the script and story choice - the CGI. This was barely television level, not multimillion-dollar level CGI. I felt like this was all done during COVID and all they could get was the D crew to work on it, not the A or B teams.Sure, the film picks up a bit later on, but by then the damage is done. And it seriously isn't that much of an improvement. You can't take it seriously. The script is crap, the actors just phoned it in because they knew the story was crap and they weren't returning. The visuals and effects were crap...everything was crap.I'm being generous with three stars, but I'm sure the 12 and under crowd loved it. I'm also sure that the studio hired a company to pad the reviews, because this simply isn't a quality movie in any sense of the word.What a sad end to this leg of the franchise, all because DC couldn't pull it together after so many attempts.

title: A FLASHPOINT FOR DC FILMS RUINED BY UGLY CGI
text:
My rating is 8/10
Watched in IMAXSynopsis:
The Flash is DC's latest and highly anticipated film that features Barry Allen/The Flash (played by Ezra Miller) who revisits his past in a wish to fix both the past and present and to search of his childhood that was stripped away from him. This forces our protagonist to also visit the past of other universes and discover his own multiverse journey within his own past journey that he allowed himself into.The film kicks off with a sequence that is simply the weakest in terms of the action and more importantly in terms of the CGI that will leave the audience in a state of boredom towards what's upcoming as well as how visually annoying and ugly it is. However and surprisingly, what followed after is the opposite as the film (and until the end) was able to hold itself in terms of having a very solid story with a bit of drama that increases towards the end.Any action sequence is filmed in a way that will simply keep the audience engaging and entertained. As well as the concept and the way that the film presented the multiverse or travailing in time in terms of how do get to it, what are the consequences of it (both positives and negative ones), and the reason of why our protagonist is forced to discover it is simply very convincing and reasonable and is being presented in THE BEST way comparing to any other film that presented the concept of the "multiverse" and "travel in time" like Spider Man No Way Home (2021) or Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness (2022).All of this is mixed up with heavy drama sequences that will genuinely touch audiences' hearts especially towards the end. Also, mixed with a bit of comedy that is not cheap or cheesy.Towards the end (and for those who watched the film will understand that) there is a sequence that is suppose to be an easy one to comprehend but it was the opposite and that's due to the weak script that it had. It is very complicated (even tho it's shouldn't be) to understand and it is suppose to be the scene that will connect any missing pieces together and connect all the dots together. Despite one particular scene that one character is explaining to another about what is the multiverse and how it works which is a more complected thing. However, the simplicity in explaining it by using some "spaghetti" is what made that scene creative and easy to understand.*Despite whatever Ezra Miller has done outside of acting in terms of crimes, bad reputation, or assaults. Etc. This review will ONLY be discussing Miller's performance within the film itself and THAT IS IT.*
Ezra Miller has successfully proven himself as a phenomenal and perfect actor for the role of Barry Alleen specifically. The film's story was able to discuss two different versions of Barry Allen, an older one, and a younger one, each with more complicated backstories and completely different responsibilities and purposes in life that help to shape their personalities and determine their actions. In that case, the story handled this very well in terms of the sequences and the writing of each one. More importantly, Ezra Millar had a huge role in achieving all of that.Ben Affleck returns yet once again as Batman. However, his presence was barely there as it felt like he was a cameo. On the other hand, Michael Keaton returns as Batman from the 80s Batman films. Meanwhile everyone expected him to appear as a cameo, he surprisingly was not as he appeared in a big portion of the film and had a very enough screen time that made him a supporting actor as well as close of being a lead actor next to Ezra Miller. Keaton was the star of the film. After decades, this man was able to play the role again more than perfectly.The Flash presented SuperGirl for the first time played by Sasha Calle which turned out to be a successful attempt to a certain limit though. The character's presence is great but the character's use in terms of supporting the story, did not add much unfortunately except for the scenes that are related to her own world and where she come from which is specifically towards the ending of the film. Therefore, towards the whole film, there is no enough deep connection that will allow any audience members to create a bond or feel something towards that character. But, Sasha played the role very well and would love to see her step in that role again in future projects.

title: Nice Movie
text: The Flash, directed by Andy Muschietti, centres on Barry Allen (Ezra Miller), who attempts to save his family by travelling back in time. However, when Barry's attempt to modify the past unintentionally changes the future, he finds himself caught in a version of events where General Zod has made a comeback. The only people who can stop him are a retired Batman, a Kryptonian who is locked up, and a different version of himself.The Scarlet Speedster's big-screen solo debut has finally happened, and it's everything I hoped it would be: enjoyable, touching, exciting, and even novel. Although Andy Muschietti has never before helmed a superhero or action film, he certainly understands how to direct a scene. He has the talent, and I can't wait to see what he does next. Because this is the superhero movie I've been most looking forward to all year, my eagerness paid off. The true heart of this film is in Barry's character arc; meeting his younger self forces him to face his loss of his mother and his own maturation at the film's conclusion. Ezra Miller is unquestionably skilled and displayed their acting versatility by playing two versions of the character that have separate personalities from each other, despite all the ongoing controversies that still surround him. Miller's portrayal of this incarnation of the Fastest Man Alive demonstrates once more that the actor is still qualified for the role.Even if this is his final appearance as the Caped Crusader, he definitely reminded me in that powerful opening sequence of how badass he was and still is, so it pains me that we might never have the chance to witness Batfleck kicking arse in his solo movie. If this is actually Michael Keaton's final performance, he will unquestionably leave an imprint on the hearts of both his longtime and new fans. I won't say much more about Sasha Calle's Supergirl because I think she did an excellent job. It's hilarious how rough the film appears for a film with a budget of about $200 million and a lot of CGI. Some scenes are excellent, but others are just hilariously poor. Although a little overwhelming, the third act is shockingly fantastic.The Flash is a large-scale, ambitious time-travel epic that rewards its viewers with surpising cameos. Whether you agree or not, The Flash is among the most effective DCEU films in recent memory.

title: Dire and desperate DC
text: Another disappointment from DC. Too much reliance on (very bad) CGI, weak character development, obvious plotline, and a transparently desperate attempt to homage the past.This movie was not a buzz... it flatlined. The storyline was obvious, alternate timeline characters were annoying, and I felt no emotional connection to the movie whatsoever. The 'multiverse' idea was not cleverly applied; it felt dumb and incoherent.I was hoping this installment could be a good transition to the new phase of the DC universe, but it was far too self-indulgent. It felt like one long, cheap, gimmick; not a finely crafted heroic epic that created pathos for the lead character and would go further to making the Flash into a core DC character.The jokes weren't funny.The homage was too unsubtle; it was uncool.The plot was predictable.The characters weren't realistically developed.The CGI seemed blatant and over-relied upon.There was no real drama or tension.Overall, I felt the movie failed for trying too hard. It lacked any spark of excellence; fading rapidly into mediocrity as the minutes passed. It lacked substance and gravitas; but didn't compensate with effective humor or sentiment. I felt bored, regularly throughout the movie. It created only disinterest.I find it mystifying how DC have failed so many times to produce worthy movies. They have an excellent cast... and awesome source material. Why can't they just get it right on the big screen?

title: Its Hard to Believe They Can Take so Long to Make a Movie so Bad
text: This movie is a disjointed pile of garbage. The positive reviews are clearly from paid schills working for the movie studio, or hopeless fanboys who can't see what's right in front of them.Ezra Miller sucks. That's the only way to explain it. Over acting, chewing up the scenery, I was not able to believe his performance and I usually suspend my disbelief pretty well for these super hero movies.Most of the 'cameos' are just pictures of actors floating by in the time travelling sequences.The dialogue has been infected with that lousy josh whedon-esque rapid fire delivery from a bunch of unknown actors. Hard to follow and it flattens everyones performance into one run on sentence.The one light in this movies is Michael Keaton's performance. He's always a gem and I'm glad he was there because IMDB's rating system forces me to give at least one star.For this mess I'd like to be able to go into negative stars.I pray that James Gunn saves my beloved DC superhero's from the mediocrity that they've currently been dumped into.

title: A Spaghetti Mess
text: All the cameos and nostalgia in the world couldn't save this movie. The gags are to forced, and some of it is really cringey. The film is as broken as the multiverse. There are things that don't add up, big things; and I'm prepared to let a lot of things pass by unchecked in fantasy and sci-fi films.It feels very lazy and not put together well. Don't get me wrong, I loved the idea of it from the trailers, but there is little substance to the film's narrative and the full execution is poor.Is it worth seeing? Barely; and I was really excited to see this. Whether James Gunn and Co taking over the DCU led to it being thrown under the bus, only they will know.

title: Amazingly good
text: Did not expect so much action and such a good story and script. The movie is absolutely stunning and i don't regret those movie tickets at all. Matter of fact, i wish i could rewatch the movie all over again.When this movie becomes public, i'm definitely going to watch it again. I do recommend this movie for everyone and has an amazingly good story and script. Amazing actors too and it really brings back the history of DC's cinematic universe. The special effects are also really good and really makes the movie even better. It's definitely a movie i'll be thinking about days later, trying to understand what happened.

title: Great plot, horrible lead
text: This movie has a great plot, cool cameos, and some great Batman stuff.But everything about Barry sucks. Ezra is a trash person, so that bleeds into my initial thoughts. But Barry is just Disney unlikeable. He's not awkward-but-charming. He comes off more like a super villain origin than a heroes one. Just odd acting and character choices left and right. I didn't even want to pull for him. I just kept calling him a creepy moron under my breath.This plot was fun and the rest of the cast deserved better than this. And the CGI was about on par with Episode 1 of Star Wars. After 9 years of waiting, I'm disappointed.

title: A well made DCEU film
text: I've watched every DCEU project...enjoyed them for the most part except for a select few. This is a really good movie. Not "THE BEST" ever made, but for a film I've waited 9 years for it's worth the wait. Idk why the CGI was off in some scenes..but still worthy of a watch. Catch it on the big screen.Yes..Ezra Miller has a past, I'm not justifying it. However, judging just the performance it's amazing how they played the role of Barry Allen, both the present day and the younger version.Even though it resets the DC timeline...I have questions in regards to the next phase in Gunn/Safran's DC Studios. Only time will tell.For now..even if you never seen a DCEU film, this is worth giving it a chance.

title: Removing the cgi...
text: The film is quite solid, it presents very emotional and exciting moments, Keaton's batman returns like never before, all this and more make this film like a roller coaster of emotions,the soundtrack is wonderful 10/10 it just makes each moment take much more strength and you put yourself in the shoes of Flash,the actors acted very well and it came out very natural ,And now let's talk about the CGI...at times it is quite weak but they are still better than those of the series in recent seasons in my opinion, although they could have been much better and not make silly excuses to say why it looks like that,final grade 8.5/10 well deserved.

title: The potential..
text:
Spoilers....The potential for the flashpoint storyline was obviously ruined. To end the DCEU in this note was awful.. the CGI was not suppose to be this awful but they said it was to cover their tales from the lack of work to go into the film..
The only good thing about the movie was the cameos from people who never made it in their suits to actors who passed away... this film was just awful the whole first half and by the time you made it to the second you just felt so checked out that it didn't matter.Thank you for ruining our chances and childhood dreams to see Batman Beyond because you couldn't make something worth a damn.

title: They chickened out in the desert
text:
The previous Superman movies always have people talking about how many people would have been killed in these city fight between superman and his cousins
So they take the fight to the desert but that makes no sense. Kara sees them fighting in the desert and then goes back to do a science project on the flash and comes back to the desert like 2 days latter and they are still fighting in desert !How are the humans still alive 2 days later And why keep sending people to die in the desert?Just let them fight in the cityMichael Keaton can still fight the Russians obviously so why have him throwing stuff like a weirdo in the kitchen? Just for laughs?I do recommend the movie.

title: Flashes of brilliance
text: Riffs on the age-old tale of wishing to go back in time to right the wrongs of the past; which, I feel, is something everybody can relate to. It's a plot thread that works well to hang all the fan service together and for me it really did work. I mean it's not going to win any awards for legendary cinema, but as a popcorn superhero movie with some cackle-inducing one-liners, surprising emotional moments (well, one in particular that had my eyes welling up), and a lot of nostalgia and DC film-nerd Easter eggs, it is well worth seeing in a cinema.All the performances hit their mark, and just having Michael Keaton back as the main Batman brought a smile to my face. The special-effects are nothing to write home about in 2023, but overall it's a surprisingly heart-felt finale to the Snyder-verse.

title: Perfect way to destroy the only good thing in DC
text:
Where to start...How do you know a movie is DC? Epic music everywhere!The hero sleeps.. Epic music
The hero wakes up... Epic music
The hero gets a cup of coffee... Epic music
Finishes the coffee.... Epic music.Quickly became dull and lost its purpose for me: Elevate the scenes.I know writers are on a strike but to be fair DC never had any. Same story... over... and over... and over...Dialogues are uninspiring. Obviously there to fill the screen. Very simple, very dull. But you didn't come to theaters hear silly teenagers' banter thus this part can be skipped.The only good thing about the movie was one certain cameo. He still got it!One thing that really hurt was... well... probably every DC fan knows by now but for the sake of keeping this review spoiler-free, let's say that they managed to completely and utterly destroy the only good thing remaining on DC.Rest in peace... good memories...

title: Should have named it "Not-the-flash"
text: I mean really, every bit of the story was about anything other than the flash. All the other characters stole the show, and The Flash was a low-level side-kick in his own friggen movie.CG was a HOT MESS. It was all over the place, from a -10 to a +10. It ran the full gambit.Pretty much the entire movie was about Batman and Superman's *already told* movies with a "what if" thrown in... ya know, like the entire series Marvel did named "What if"... that showed a bunch of different timelines.This felt more like a plot-hook to cash in different DC universes with different actors playing the main roles, than it did a Flash movie.

title: Amazing movie let down by poor CGI
text: I loved the absolute crap out of this movie. Loved the plot and the characters the acting was also very well done too. I would've given this movie higher rating if it weren't for the terrible CGI. I know the director said that the CGI was bad on purpose but I can't help but think that 90% of this movie was CGI and half of it wasn't even bad but the half that is bad is just terrible. I'd rather you just not CGI the unnecessary bits at that point since nobody really said they wanted to see "flash's perspective". Also I wanna add that I loved Michael Keaton's performance in this film however I just can't get over how it would've been ground breaking for them to have Thomas Wayne instead of Keaton's batman. Or even Bale's batman. Missed opportunity IMO but oh well. Ezra miller's acting in this movie was also done very well and I can see that he's a really good actor. Sucks that he caused the commotion he did in real life because he's a good flash.

title: Greatest Superhero movie of all time ? Or Granny's peach tea !!
text: Negatives - Very mediocre graphics ... forgettable music .. inconsequential cameos ... a weak looking batman ... a totally wasted Supergirl .. an unclimactic climax and a jumbled ending ...Positives - Sasha Calle as Supergirl and that little heart to heart between Ben Afleck's batman and Ezra Miller's FlashThese were my takeaways from The Flash movie which was dubbed by James Gunn and WB as the greatest superhero movie of all time. In the end it was a big let down with the movie relying heavily on Nostalgia while lacking creativity and any fan connection.Bottom line: DC is dead... Aquaman 2 will bury it ...

title: Let's talk about Trumpets and music design.
text: Movie was overall enjoyable, won't put any multi-verse spoilers in this review, but if you're even slightly aware of the Flash's abilities, nothing comes as a surprise. The humour was a nice bonus, but ultimately nothing can save this movie from awful predictable orchestral sound track that just kills any action. Big Budget movies seem to lack brains and ability to create a coherent experience that should touch all the senses, good visuals, good story, good soundtrack. Silence would have been better than trumpets blasting your face off during each action sequence. The cameos did exactly as expected, made what would have been an okay movie, worse. Best thing about this movie... Keaton? Not exactly, but didnt take anything from it at least. Overall this movie was okay, predictable and could have been a lot better. As it is, I dont enjoy having trumpets and over the top string orchestra blasting at me for 3 hours. If this sounds like fun to you, then so be it.

title: The EZRA MILLER show
text:
It starts with Barry Allen getting late to work and then immediately he is called to action and saves folks.I gotta say , this scene was soo cool and probably one of the best CBM scenes ever made.This movie loosely adapts our beloved FLASHPOINT comic storyline with some major changes and fun fiesta all the way.ANDY handled the movie well with some amazing scenes and heartfelt moments.The ending twist was great and the climax is just top notch work.The flash movie was great
It was fun from start to end 😁
Emotional 😭
Cameo fest 🎆
Cool action scenes
And mostly a great CBMWell worth the hype with some special surprises
Keaton and Affleck were dopeEZRA MILLER carried the entire movie NGL
Hopefully he gets some help and continue playing FLASH.

title: It was... okay??
text: So I finally got around to watching The Flash and I have to say it was kinda fun, the special effects and CGI weren't really the best part of the movie and at times it did take away from the storyline. But, I did find myself enjoying the movie, the storyline is easy to follow as the science involved isn't too hard to understand nor is it completely realistic either. The characters were okay, and the music was fun too. I don't really have a lot to say about this movie, to be honest, I don't think it needed to be 2hr 25mins long because some of the scenes could have been cut down due to being unnecessary.

title: DC Universes.
text: Here there was a blend between the reality portrayed in this film and the media reality of multiple actors playing various DC characters over the history of time based media DC TV shows and films in our real world.All of the actors whom played superman over my lifetime were logically connected by the one story in this film. Same with a few of the Batman's, plus super girl and there may have been a version of a past wonder woman!People are bagging the CGI, but I felt it was streamlined and satisfyingly cartoonish. Cartoons being where all of these character's originated from.Understand that Fay Wray and her King Kong still stand up as a letter from the past to successfully suspend disbelief for some of us. The recent generations have become spoiled and expect every film to out-do every previous films' visual effects. Which is cool when it happens, but not necessary.It's script and characters which propel a good story, and these picky individuals are getting distracted away from what's important, via an unbalanced habit, that is, focusing upon VFX rather than the rest of a films crafts.

title: A great Marvel movie.
text: Yes, I know it is a DC movie, but this is what Marvel's movies used to be for me. A very good story, the right amount of humor mixed with action mixed with drama, likable characters, and a storyline that doesn't make you look at your watch. The story was deep enough that I didn't get bored, but not so deep that it became distracting from the movie itself. The criticisms of the CGI can't be argued, but I would take more frequent movies like this with mediocre CGI over fewer movies with flawless CGI that doesn't change anything besides the aesthetics.I know Miller has his own issues. It is unfortunate that the events that unfolded for him is what was necessary for him to get the help he needed. I don't judge most actors. If I did, I probably wouldn't have anything to watch. Ezra Miller is a wonderful actor who was a huge part in making this movie as good as it is.It's too bad this iteration of the Flash is ending in our timeline. I would have loved to watch another Flash movie or two and see Miller's guest appearances and others as well.

title: Great superhero movie a must watch!
text: I really enjoyed this movie! I would go as far as saying better than 90% of your recent marvel movies!Great special effects and very well put together storyline! The main character was brilliant in his performance as the flash! Seeing the multiverse Batman's , Supergirl and wonder woman was very cool! I don't watch a lot of tv or movies but when I do I like to make it worthwhile. If you're looking for a great fun superhero type movie this is a must watch! I don't write a lot of reviews just wanted to come on here and give credit to a great movie that seemed to get a lot of hate or the respect it deserves.

title: Some element of great that is overshadowed by the bad
text: The Flash is a hero I adore from the comics. It is crazy that it took this long for him to have a live-action movie. Unfortunately, the DCEU Flash movie went through development hell. It had multiple directors leave the project, multiple delays, multiple reshoots, the Ezra controversy, and constant changes in leadership at WB. Despite all these shenanigans, does this movie manage to deliver a great Flash movie?Firstly, they do deliver some strong and emotional moments. It's hard to be angry at Flash for wanting to save his mother and prove his Dad innocent. Seeing Flash cope with the unintended butterfly effects of going back in time and saving his mother, is a great concept. Barry's desperation to save this timeline because his mother still lives is powerful stuff. It has a heartfelt story of grief which I liked. Funny enough, Ezra has great chemistry with himself. Ezra plays the original and new timeline Barry who both interact with each other throughout the movie. I like the contrast between a slightly more mature and serious original Barry compared to the younger whiny new Barry. There are some genuinely funny moments between the two. I am also impressed by how convincingly they made it seem like there were 2 Ezras on set.One of the biggest selling points of this movie is Michael Keaton's return as Batman. It is great seeing him again even though his performance can feel a bit stiff and wooden. I was worried about how they could convince me that a 70-year-old Batman would still be capable of fighting. However, the action scenes with him are awesome and very enjoyable. Ben Affleck also returns as DCEU Batman for 1 last time. He is not in it for long but he is good as well. His action scenes are pretty entertaining and his scene with Barry is a highlight. The music score by Benjamin Wallfisch is wonderful and I love how he incorporates the classic Danny Elfman Batman theme. The greatest part though is Sasha Calle as Supergirl. She is terrific despite not being in it for long. I also think the costume team nailed the Michael Keaton Batsuits and the Supergirl suit as they both look exceptional!Unfortunately, the Ben Affleck Batsuit looks terrible. It is ugly and doesn't even feel like a proper Batsuit. Likewise, the Flash suit just doesn't look great. It looks too polished and very plastic looking. There are scenes where it looks like a guy in a giant red condom rather than a proper superhero suit. On that note, I am very mixed about Ezra Miller as Flash. He was all right in Zack Snyder's Justice League as he was more of a supporting role with a better script. However, his performance in this film comes off as way more obnoxious and annoying. It doesn't help that new timeline Barry is meant to be annoying on purpose but the result is both Barry's are infuriating. He does deliver during the more emotional moments but at other times, not so much.I am also very disappointed in the action scenes with the 'Flash'. While the Batman action is awesome, the action scenes with Flash are just not that satisfying. They are bland to look at, especially when compared to speedster scenes from X-Men and even Avengers. The 3rd act in this movie is a little overwhelming with the amount of things going on. There are some things concerning the multiverse that occurs as well but feels kind of contradictory to the rules set. I also find the ending terrible and contradicts the whole message of the movie. Additionally, they do something in the ending that raises more questions than answers and feels a little dumb if they are rebooting the universe. My major gripe though, is the atrociously bad CGI. A lot of the shots in this film look very ugly thanks to poor CGI. Some scenes look like it is straight out of a video game than a movie. They also use it to recreate people's likeness including dead people and it is disgusting to look at.Overall, what a massive disappointment this ended up being. You can see some element of great in it but it is all overshadowed by the bad. It is sad to see how poor the last couple of entries in the old DCEU are. It makes me more appreciative of James Gunn rebooting the DCEU. We still have 1 proper DCEU movie left with Aquaman 2 but my hopes aren't high.

title: Not Without Flaws, But Still Speeds Ahead: The Flash (2023) Is an Entertaining Watch
text: "The Flash" (2023) manages to be one of the best entries in the DCEU, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. This witty and warm buddy comedy stands out among other DC movies, thanks to its strong lead performance.Although the film follows a predictable time-travel storyline, it still offers solid entertainment throughout. It is refreshing to see a DC movie with a compelling main character, which has often been lacking in previous films."The Flash" is undoubtedly the standout film from the recent collaboration between Warner Bros. And DC. It embraces its love for the comic books that inspired it, resulting in a funny, action-packed, and emotionally resonant experience. Fans of the DC heroes should not miss this opportunity and should rush to see it.While I understand that some may criticize the movie for relying too much on nostalgia without presenting an original or thrilling story, I found it enjoyable and engaging. It does an admirable job of keeping the momentum going despite its lengthy runtime of 2 hours and 25 minutes.Certainly, the film's storyline can become messy due to the inclusion of multiple cameos and a rushed introduction of Sasha Calle as Supergirl. However, I appreciate how it embraces Michael Keaton's iconic portrayal of Batman and channels the same energy with a "let's get nuts" approach.Overall, "The Flash" is a delightful and entertaining superhero movie that successfully captures the essence of its source material. It may not be entirely groundbreaking, but it offers a fun and enjoyable experience for fans and general audiences alike.

title: Horray, and Yuk!
text:
Michael Keaton IS The Batman. Christian Bale may have been good, but Keaton for me is the best, and in this film he just owns it.As for Ezra Miller, well he is part of the yuk! I did not like his character
in Justice league, and this film is made all the worse by the two characters. Maybe it was the writing, but it grated on me.Another Yuk! Was the CGI. Well enough has been said about that on the other reviews. Nice and bright at times, but then when SuperGirl is fighting the Russians, just 1990's BAD.If it had not been for Keaton, then the scoring would be lower.I will not be re-watching.

title: What a waste of money
text: Wow, this CGI massacre of a film really made me question why I go to the movies and pay for half assed congealed messes. But it's ok as every Hollywood actor gets a big paycheck for being in the film for five minutes of work.The Flash is DC's latest entry, who have been on a hot streak just recently with The Batman, Peacemaker and even Black Adam. Being entertaining and fresh. Personally, I would say that they are on top of the food chain within Marvel's recent films. The decision to show The Flash to 'critics' months before it's release was a positive sign that Warner Bros had a hit on their hands.This was the most painful movie experience so far this year, this felt like an early 2000's comic book film. The acting was very over the top, which Ezra Miller's Flash was guilty of doing multiple times. Story wise I was disinterested so much I stopped caring half way through. As for the CGI, my word, $220 million dollars was the budget. What did they spend it on? Seriously, I thought I was watching a fan made film during parts of the movie.My only highlight is most definitely the return of Micheal Keaton's Batman, he did his best for what he was given. This will only satisfy fans who grew up with Keaton's movies in the late 80's.In conclusion, The Flash was a classic example of how you overspend on the cast. There was a mishmash of terrible special effects, a poor script. This emphasises that you should never trust what you read on social media.

title: The movie started with Michael Keaton
text: I really enjoyed this movie as a whole, but I felt like everything lagged on and on until Michael Keaton was on the screen. Such a caliber actor with a natural ability to play a character with so much depth as Batman. Sasha Calle was a badass playing Supergirl. I wish she had more opportunities to play her before now. Ezra Miller plays an okay Flash. He doesn't represent the character from the comics very well, but I know everyone is allowed to have their own interpretation. Sure he has his odd stuff happening personally, but I didn't let that interfere with me wanting to see this movie. I mean, Tom Cruise is the same way yet everyone LOVED his movie last year regardless. All in all, a great enjoyable movie that I think anyone would enjoy..especially when Michael Keaton shows up.

title: Meh
text: Michael Keaton's part was great. He is funny and yet, imposing and powerful as expected. But the rest was just plain meh. How many times do you think the exact same body part jokes are funny? Not very many, and yet they keep going and going. The Flash character is more annoying than endearing. The story and characters are all over the place and actually pretty depressing. The Flash does not come off as a hero in any way. I can't say that I liked this movie very much. The whole thing left me with a bad feeling and I'm glad that I didn't take my kids with me. It's definitely not appropriate for kids or even young teens. It was just plain ok...

title: Not the absolute train wreck I had anticipated
text: Perhaps it was fortunate that my expectations were set very, very low. The story was somewhat engaging, but of course the end result is a half hour too long, as per usual for comic book movies these days, especially in the DC Extended Universe.Ezra Miller in either of his roles is grating. He showed so much promise in We Need To Talk About Kevin (2011). He can be a very good dramatic actor (although he hasn't shown much evidence of that in subsequent roles) but as Flash it's quite clear that he's not a comedic actor.It's fun to see Michael Keaton back in the cowl. I really liked him as Batman back in the day, but he more or less sleepwalks through this movie. Sasha Calle as Supergirl isn't onscreen that long, but the little that she does is fine.For a $200+ million dollar movie the effects are at times astoundingly bad. It's like Warner Brothers could tell they had a dud on their hands, threw up their hands and said "good enough, we're not throwing good money after bad".An OK two and a half hours (although I kept looking at my watch in the second half) but not something I'll bother watching again.

title: Awesome but didn't make me say that
text: I kind of hope that after a movie I am able to think that the movie was awesome but didn't feel like it. I did enjoy the movie experience a lot.I watched it in IMAX. CGI was awesome. Background score almost fits with the scene. Never felt out of place. The story sounds okay in trailer but had awesome execution.The camera movement along with the people was also great. It also had some time travel aspects to understand so from nowhere it felt like a kiddish movie. The Batman was clever as usual.Now that I think about it this is maybe this has one of the best action sequences I have ever seen in a DC movie.It just makes you say wow. I would have given 9 but some scenes felt normal for some reason.A must watch overall though.It's surely above average and clearly worth a greater rating. Do watch it in a good format. You won't regret it.

title: Good th FLASH
text: Hi, it was a good movie, but if the Flash actor was the one who was in the series, it would have been better, the other actors were great, and Flash's costume was very bad, but it had a good story and it was based on a comic, it made it better. I hope DC will do better because It has weakened a lot already, and in the future I will see movies that are great and masterpieces. DC has great characters, but he doesn't use any of them, and if he does, it stinks, but I hope that he will improve to his great days of filming and visual effects. It was not bad, but it could have been better. In my opinion, it was a good movie and it is worth watching once.

title: I wish I had never watched
text: First i want to start like this the movie was not what i expected at all trailer is good but not movie so most of the characters are not even included and the movie is super boring waste of time other DC movies were much more meaningful and quality only the batman scenes were good going back in time and two flash characters is so illogical maybe most of you think like me or vice versa it gets very boring in the middle minutes and I had to pass my score will be low anyway, the score of this movie will drop on imdb black adam was more beautiful than that, more visual effects were used in this movie In short, I did not like.

title: a good "The Flash" movie
text: This movie, as a "flash" movie is pretty good. It surprised me besides the controversies with the main actor. Which, one is annoying enough, now add two of him in one movie, where one of them is one purpose more annoying. The "other" batmen added a bit change to the movie, and this kind of movies where time travel and alternative universes are a thing.Also, the fact that they didn't make supergirl a merry sue is a big score for today's movies. They learn that the planet needs superman, no matter what.Considering the changes in the timeline, I am curious to know where "the flash" will go in the future.The special effects and CGI is a bit strange. Not necessary bad as some other big movies in the last years, but just strange. Also, why didn't they bring the real actors instead of CGIing them in the movie?!But a very good movie for superhero fans.

title: Some bad CGI, but very entertaining
text: Although it had many flaws, and had a lots of bad CGI at many places, especially when both Barry Allens are in scene. But the movie turned out to be surprisingly good. There were some stereotypical tropes and cliches of a super hero movie, but the idea in the movie seemed very original. The movie has been bashed due to all the bad publicity around Ezra Miller, but the story is quite refreshing.I liked the Keaton Batman. And i also liked the refreshed idea of multiverse and how things work in a multiverse.Things i did not like were the CGI at many places, and the Supergirl.Overall a solid 8 for me.

title: When good writers go lazy
text: Not long ago I wrote about how Across the Spider Verse stood out among other comics by defying the fatalistic approach adopted by most comics. Come and see this movie and you'll know exactly what I was complaining about.I liked it. It had great characters, and great acting (one is the result of the other). I mean - I loved Ezra Miller whenever I saw him/them on screen. Sasha Calle is giving a great debut performance and Michael Keaton finally gets to be a real Batman. If only Tim Burton gave him a real chance to act back in the days. That means the writers of this movie know their job. Only problem is, it seems to me like they spent too much energy on writing the characters and didn't have enough left in their tanks when they reached the plot.I'll admit, the entire idea of time loops has been milked by sci-fi to the bone. So, going there was doomed from the start if you ask me, even with all the nice Back to the Future jokes. But Back to the Future said - your destiny is yours to determine, while this one goes back to the lazy old fatalistic cliche. And then, they commit an even bigger sin in my personal book by allowing their heroes to reach a literal dead end. I said it before: in the world of comics if a superhero has to die - someone wrote it wrong and chose the easy way out.This should've been a real great movie, but it fell short when it really counted. For me, that's a pity.

title: What did I just watch?
text: 6 directors, over 220 mill, and a real life criminal, and this movie was abysmal in every way!The only thing I liked was Michael Keaton, that's it!The origin of the Flash made zero sense, and his powers either.Ok, the kid can run fast, but how does it make sense that he can vibrate through a solid object like a wall, or a door, holding people or physical objects lol, dumb!Doesn't make any sense at all.The whole "multiverse" idea stolen from Marvel, gee, that's original lol!The actor who played the flash was annoying, and the actress who played Super Girl was not very good.No way this gets a sequel with a new lead, we don't need it. Save your money and make a better movie!

title: Funny and entertaining
text: Even for someone like me who watched the entire Flash Tv series, this was very entertaining.Many LOL moments I could feel in the theatre.Micheal Keaton was brilliant and Sasha is cute and her expressions are fantastic.Ezra Miller fits perfectly for the weird and quirky personality. His acting has improved a lot compare to his previous outings in DCEU. Stark difference between the dual roles.Visual effects in some scenes could have been better. But overall it is good. Would have been fantastic if the movie was in 3D.Don't listen to trash talk around because of Ezra Miller. Its just fun to watch and I enjoyed it.

title: Strange and confused
text: This movie had been plagued by media storms and controversy and ultimately had a huge weight on its shoulders. It came no where close to being the blockbuster from DC fans were waiting for and instead was just bad. The plot is pretty straightforward and not particularly difficult to do but still the movie disappoints. The film looks bad with the CGI looking unfinished in most parts and there is not much interesting happening on screen to distract from how ugly certain scenes are. Disappointed and not sure how this was meant to usher in a new era for DC. The same storyline has been executed better through the tv show.

title: I prefer the Eric Stoltz version
text: Honestly, I wasn't expecting much going into this, but (accusations aside) I didn't mind Ezra Miller in the Justice League movies, so I had hopes it would at least be entertaining. Instead I found myself bored after 30 minutes of the movie, leaving another 2 hours of mind numbingly boring nothingness left to watch.The film's one saving grace, was seeing Michael Keaton don the batsuit one last(?) time accompanied by Danny Elfman's classic Batman theme, but even this was not enough to save the film.The pacing was all over the place, the character development (especially of Supergirl) was practically non-existent and most importantly, Ezra Miller was just not up to the task leaning more towards annoying than anything else. The only moments of any real emotion, were those featuring Barry's mum and soley because of her ability as an actor alone.The film was also massively hindered by the subpar CGI, which was so jarring it took you right out of the movie (Christopher Reeve deserved better). It was like Superman's moustache, but everywhere!!I don't hold out much hope for the new DCU if James Gunn thinks this film is soooo amazing that not only does he praise it at every opportunity, but he then hires the film's, clearly out of his depth, director to helm the first Batman movie of his new superhero world. I just hope to God they manage to surprise me with something truly entertaining, but at this point it may be too late in the game for anyone to care about yet another superhero movie.

title: ENTERTAINING
text:
Finally a win for DC fans to enjoy in theaters, Best Time Traveling movie of recent times.Andy Muschietti didn't disappoint the fans, by giving a movie which will be remembered for ages.Movie is Emotional and filled with amazing action & fan service scenes.Comedy & humor scenes will make laugh you out loud throughout.Loved all the Spead Force & phasing scenes. All Batman action sequences was breathtaking.Ezra Miller performance was amazing, you won't feel that same actor is playing two differnet persons.Loved all the cameos, it elevates the movie when it slows down for a bit
CGI of characters shown in speed force is very poor.

title: How you should work with fanservice and multiverse
text: Well, a couple words to say... First of all: Flash is a good fanservice movie, but kinda spoiled by bad graphics. Assuming that it was in a producrion hell, it is a big surprise that we got this work, yes, quite standard, but full of respect and love to DC and it's films and fans. If you think something like 6/10(assuming if this movie have ever had good graphics) isn't enough(for blockbuster), you just check my ratings, you will be terrified about other movie ratings, telling ya. Ezra's acting keeps us entertained during the whole movie, this is yeat another thing worth mentioning. The best part of this film is though it is quite light and undemanding it constantly shows you something that makes your sad face create and keep broad smile. Gosh, it was the first time in my 18!! Movies and series where i had fun! P. S. Are we really done here? After all of this? No more Man of Steel, no more Cavil? No more this Flash, that was drawing attention even in 2017 JL and blasts now? No more Affleck? No more best Bats? No more Dawn of Justice UE development(cause it os really unrivaled among the best comics movies and it is in reality a cinematographic masterpiece) Though i disliked ZS JL, i think we can surely give a shot to a guy that filmed Dawn of Justice. Yeah, i think that Wonder Woman movies are disgusting, that Aquaman's only place in the trash, but for example first SS(as well as Birds of Prey) was kinda average movie, that somehow was disliked by the audience, the second one was kinda entertaining. First Shazam was not that bad, though failed in the end, Black Adam would not be that bad if not the ending. Man of steel was OK the visual adventure. So it is something that we could work with, right? Cut worst parts, or remake them? It would be so sad, to end this after such a good example how through all the difficulties you can combine parts, actors, approaches and universes so different in a good film.

title: Lots of people didn't like the movie, but I absolutely loved it!
text: The CGI might not have been Transformers level, but it was still good, I don't understand why people are the movie so much.I absolutely loved the acting of Ezra Miller. I've heard shady stuff about him so I didn't know what to expect, but his acting was amazing, considering he was playing two very different people at the same time that he made have an amazing chemistry. With himself, but that was very cool by itself.Through out the whole movie I was laughing so much, which is rare for me. Maybe the movie was a bit weird and chaotic at times, but I absolutely loved it, and would probably rewatch again.

title: Great Flash Movie getting a BAD RAP
text: "The Flash" was the very first comic book I got when I was about 6 years old, in 1969. The Flash has always been my favorite. This movie IS NOWHERE NEAR as horrific as the reviews on social media. Let's be clear, Ezra Miller's "external" antic's do NOT help this film. HOWEVER, the film itself is a solid comic book film, he does a good job as Barry Allen. All the hype about Michael Keaton is overblown, he has a small part, a lot more than a cameo, and he does a great job. To this day I have no idea why they just didn't allow Grant Gustin to go ahead and play this movie version, on the TV Series he has done a fantastic job, and I think he would of done well in this film. I base my reviews on, will you be wasting your time, IF you like The Flash, this move is worth your time, don't listen to the "hater crowd". I have loved The Flash twice as long as a lot of these "so called" experts been alive. This movie is about "The Flash" and you will enjoy it.

title: What movie did you watch?
text: The reviews and ratings can't be for the same film I watched. This is easily one of the worst films in the last decade. The acting is meh, the character they made the Flash is pathetic, the effects aren't up to video game cut scene quality. Frankly, the only worse film I have seen lately is... well, most of the rest of the DCU. This is just sad. The multiverse concept is not thought out, explained, or even coherent. The closest they come to a saving grace is Keaton, and he spends so much time as a poorly animated rag doll that even he can't help the film.Is this what movies have been reduced to? Is this the level of incoherent schlock we have to look forward to? And worse, have all of you lowered your taste to the point that this earns stars from you? Pathetic.

title: Could've been good, but Ezra miller ruined it.
text:
I'll start off by saying that I've been using imdb for 12+ years but never bothered to make an account or review anything. This movie made me do that, for a not so good reason.The first 20 minutes in this movie are cringe inducing. From the attempted comedy (which it miserably fails at) to the atrocious CGI, to the competition about who can be most annoying person in the movie. Ezra Miller is not a good actor, nor is he anything close to funny. He literally spends the movie figuring out new ways on how to be even more annoying than the previous moments.Once Michael Keaton and Sasha Calle finally get introduced the movie picks up somewhat, but that's like an hour in. I almost shut the movie off several times before this. It's no way near as interesting as I thought it would be, and it was more of a how-long-can-you-take-the-cringe fest throughout this movie.Positives:
+ Michael Keaton, he's good in virtually anything you put him in, the same was the case here.+ Sasha Calle, she was a good supergirl. (I was sceptical from the trailers but she can at least act, unlike certain others in this movie)
+ Some decent action and fight scenes.That's about it.Negatives: Oh boy, where do I start....
I could go on and rant some more, but it's kind of pointless. If you watch this movie, turn your brain off and try to not use logic because it will just make you mad.

title: While I didn't hate this as much as some it was certainly far from great.
text: As someone who's seen almost every episode of the CW Flash show I wanted to like this so bad, but terrible comedy, a plot that didn't even seem to know where it was going, awful writing, and some of the worst CGI in film history made it pretty much impossible to like.The first 15 minutes were awful and luckily it was uphill from there... Just not very uphill. The middle section seemed like it went on for hours, and most of it could've been cut without losing much of anything important. The ending went on for too long and didn't focus enough on the stuff that mattered. The grocery store scene at the end was probably the best part although it still had Ezra Miller so I couldn't fully appreciate it having to see his face. The entire part with the multiverse collapsing was so out of place and every cameo was thrown in for no reason.Ezra Miller (ignoring how he is IRL) gives an annoying and basic performance(s), and honestly this would've been better played by almost any other actor. Michael Keaton was one of my favorite parts of this, but even his performance is far from his best.The writing, while okay at times, is extremely cheesy and poorly done. The direction is bland and boring. Worst of all, the CGI. Despite what Andy Muschietti may say, the CGI, not in certain parts, but throughout the entire movie was unforgivable. Starting awfully with the CGI babies and staying at that level of horrible for the rest of the film with few moments that looked even okay by VFX standards.Overall The Flash is one giant convoluted mess with a few moments of redemption, mostly ruined by Ezra Millers existence.

title: Beat DC fill outside of Nolan's trilogy
text: I went into this apprehensive - and with lots of reasons to doubt Ezra's casting, very very problematic actor, however despite that - they are an incredible Flash and really give the character and role justice. Highly entertaining film - with some of the most incredible visuals seen in recent films. The cameos are incredible, and the sense of humour is spot on - and not over used. I enjoyed every single moment - and really loved the action packed, story driven but yet emotional story. DC films can be very hit and miss - but this is a very. Very valid entry and a film that I'm already looking forward to rewatching. This is the direction DC needs to take , here's hoping.

title: Unrealistic?
text: The first scene at the start of the film is so unrealistic, phenomenally unrealistic. Nevertheless I plow on with disgust & try to forget that scene.What's with DC and the ABOMINATION use of CGI effects? Mind blown at how terrible the use of CGI is, like you can see how cheap and dated it is, it's worse than the original Justice League film (2017).Nevertheless, Millers acting is average if even that, whereas the storyline is very far fetched, to the point I lost interest but no I was committed & had already watched a hour of the film and was determined to finish it.So my verdict is that this is a very 'unrealistic film'. Have I said that already?

title: Spectacular Nostalgia with brilliant execution
text:
NO SPOILER REVIEW:
It's something very fresh coming from DC, PHENOMENAL movie.Time dilation, hour glass theory and all the time related references showed nicely, from the first scene the action and VFX hooked you into the movie.@SashaCalle was brilliant so as Ezra Miller, it was a treat to see Ben Affleck again as Batman.There are many awww and jaw dropping moments which adds 1 extra mark into it, it's solid 7 + extra 1 for all the things which you're gonna witness.@muschismes did a decent job.And seeing Keaton on big screen as Batman was a nostalgic ride, he still has Batman in him.

title: Cringe Garbage On Steroids
text: One of the worst superhero movies ever to mar silver screen. Everything about this movie just screams CRINGE!! Let's face it, Marvel and Disney have hit rock-bottom here. When you start copying and pulling from past movies like Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure, and Back To The Future, it just lets everyone know that you don't have a creative thought in your arsenal any longer. Who will Marvel and Disney steal from next? Will it be the Brady Bunch? Maybe The Monkees? Will they steal the plot from Ishtar? Or maybe even Throw Mama From The Train? Better yet, just Throw This Movie Into The Trash.
