title: The Start of DC Multiverse
text: A compelling and well-executed storyline, strong character arc and development for the main character, as well as supporting characters. I enjoyed the growth, complexity, and relatability in the characters that DC present. The Flash's superhuman speed and time-manipulation abilities, visually stunning and well-executed special effects were greatly portrayed his powers effectively.You will feel travel back in time to old DC universe. This movie is also the start of DC multiverse. Looking forward to what happened next to DC movies.Even though I know that this movie had some flaws with the controversial actors DC still present this movie well. This movie definitely 100% worth your time.

2024-012(3/22/2024)
This is the kind of comic book movie I always wanted to see. The use of the multiverse setting is seamless and very watchable. It makes me very sad that the DCEU has ended, just because of that. I'd like a sequel to be made in the same way as the Snyder Cut. (I really want to see Wonder Woman 3 too btw.) The situation where a massive disaster is caused by the sheer desire to see one's mother would probably only resonate with those who have lost their mother or a loved one. I personally really liked the interactions between the slightly different personalities of Barry(am I spelling the name right?) and Barry from different timelines, so I found it enjoyable.

title: A Fantastic Superheroes Team-Up Movie About Accepting the Past
text: The Flash is almost everything a superhero movie fan could ask for; it offers a wonderful mix of emotional connection, dramatic family themes, stunning action sequences, top-notch performances and a smooth pacing that manages to keep up with the character. When you really think the details that stand behind, all of the narratives within the DC superhero and origin story movies have true potential, and it doesn't matter whether they're labeled as comedies or dramas, or related to DC or Marvel comics. But it feels so rare to see these concepts executed to their fullest, The Flash being an example.When Barry Allen decides to use his super speed to travel back in time and change his unfortunate childhood, his attempt to prevent his mother's death and ultimately save his family traps him in an alternate world without superheroes, forcing him to confront his past and save the future. Although extremely entertaining and paced like lightning, there is no doubt that this movie is far from perfection. Some of the CGI work will really bother the critics and audiences who pay attention to special details in the effects. In addition, some will find it bothersome that characters like Batman, Supergirl and a Barry Allen from an alternate universe get to take up a lot of elements in the Flash's story.To save discussing the film's strengths after the criticisms so we can leave off on a positive note however, the chunks of runtime in which we spend time around the other superheroes all feel like they fit neatly into the story. Batman, Supergirl and an alternate universe's Barry Allen each have necessary roles to play in the story, without feeling forced or overshadowing the main character's story. The performances are also magnetic from beginning to end. Despite the controversies and trouble he's been involved in during the past few years, Ezra Miller is very good in both his struggling role as Barry and his annoying alternate-universe role as the same person but with a completely different life.It's also an absolute blast to see Michael Keaton back as the Batman in this day and age, and Sasha Calle is also pretty good inhabiting Supergirl, although she doesn't have as much of a role in the movie as the Batman. What's equally as impressive as the talents in front of the camera is Andy Muschietti's exquisite work behind the camera. His direction is pretty much spotless in this movie, which makes the sometimes-poor CGI forgivable. And the action throughout The Flash deserves it's own discussion, it's just so exciting and fun to watch at the cinemas. Despite its cons, this is a big-deal cinema movie that will deserve its popularity, and we need to see more superhero movies that have enjoyable, well-crafted elements other than humour.If you liked this review, check out the full review and other reviews at aussieboyreviews.

title: Awful plot, awful Ezra, awful CGI.
text: To begin with, Ezra Miller can not carry a movie like this. I don't know what it is about him, but it's something about taking things way to far and not being consistent. Especially his portrayal of his characters younger self, who seemed to constantly shift from a dumb teenager to an extremely annoying little child. Considering how Ezra Miller acts outside of movies, i imagined his younger self was just Ezra being real life Ezra.The plot is embarrassingly generic and we've seen it SO many times before, even in recent DC/Marvel productions. Time travel -> butterfly effect -> multiverse. Whoever wrote this and whoever gave it an okay need to go out and touch some grass for a while or forever, because they're obviously creatively bankrupt.The CGI... Oh, the CGI. Man. There were some decent CGI in there, but generally it was just awful. Uncanny valley galore.The only part that i actually did like was Michael Keaton, but the rest of the fan service just felt forced and uncomfortable.I believe i chuckled two times at some jokes, so thanks for that tho.

title: The Thrash
text:
It is really hard to define such a ridiculous and highly idiotic movie like this one.CGI IS HORRIBLE: CHECK
STORY IS EVEN MORE HORRIBLE: CHECK
THE ACTOR WHO PLAYS THE FLASH IS TERRIBLY ANNOYING (WITH A EVEN MORE ANNOYING NASAL VOICE) : CHECK

I can only imagine how people pay to watch these utterly garbage movies. Seriously?The worst super hero movie I've watched (51 mins) in my life.Go see for yourself.

title: Masterpiece
text: Before Justice League DC was literally on surviving mode and the film makers just wanted to keep alive DC by making anything but now they get into the serious job and they took inspiration from marvel team how to make a masterpiece and this movie has surpassed the level of all previous DC movies. In all perspective "The Flash" has proved to be a masterpiece and we the audience literally didn't want to bound within the Marvel world where the things has really got slower and boring after thanos elimination. Now we can expect more masterpiece from DC just like Marvel did. Hats off to the maker of this Movie. Superb.

title: It'll split viewers down the middle, when it really shouldn't.
text: Just go and see it.Patterns emerging where people will leave negative to average ratings and go and praise movies like Thor: Love and Thunder.Miller's off-camera antics have definitely impacted the film's potential box-office sales, but the movie is good. If what The Dark Knight is to DC is what Winter Soldier is to Marvel, then The Flash is definitely DC's Iron Man - a new beginning.CGI can be a little rocky at times, but really enjoyed the story.Keaton was made to play Batman, which oddly enough, was a controversial casting choice under the direction of Tim Burton. Fast forward to present day, and it still amazes that the one person no one thought could ever play Batman, is still the benchmark for the character.Miller finally gets The Flash film years in the making, while audiences finally get a chance at DC nostalgia.Really enjoyed Supergirl and the light humor. And Ben Affleck back in the suit makes for a great time.

title: Could have been great if mcu hadnt done it first.
text: Coming from a dir hard dc fan, and snider fan. I absolutely loved this movie. Story is good . Emotionally , comically and action wise its balanced . Fan service was great. Some ssurprising cameos and easter eggs. But this could have been great if mcu had not done this first. They've done the multiverse thing in multiple movies recently (nwh and spiderverse) and all the fans were expecting it from flash so it was not that surprising. Production quality was not that great in my opinion . Cgi was somewhat bad actually . Main villain did noy get enough screentime. The ending was quite great. Im gonna bet any guy with loving mom would cry at the end. I did.So overall this movie did not disappoint. It paved way nicely to the new era of dcu. Hope this time it will be better.

title: If you enjoyed the tv show... this is nothing like it.
text: The TV show received widespread acclaim for its engaging storytelling, character development over the years. It built a dedicated fan base and was praised for its faithful portrayal of the Scarlet Speedster's adventures.But the movie is a real "hot mess" at so many levels. Why present the main character as an ADHD on the verge of autism, when it has nothing to do with the TV show?Flash falls tragically short of its potential. From the outset, the superhero premise shows promise, but unfortunately, it fails to deliver a cohesive and engaging storyline. The plot is convoluted and poorly paced, leaving the audience confused and disinterested.

title: Very bad movie

title: The Absolute worst DC movie i've ever seen

title: My Eyes Hurt From the CGI So Much That I Remembered All of Ezra Miller's Crimes
text: I'm sorry, but if your superhero movie is relied heavily on CGI for like 85% of the movie and most (noticeable) of them are humans, I expect the CGI to be at least somewhat negligible. This was just plain awful. How is the director not embarrassed to have released this atrocious-looking movie? And not only that, why do they have to slow-motion on every single terrible CG scene? Are they that proud of this abomination that they intentionally keep showing it in slow-motion?Even if this movie had the best plot and acting ever, the CGI still would've made me rate it lower. Live-action movies are supposed to have real human actors interacting with each other and things to look realistic. But this? This is just on a whole new level. I don't think I've ever seen a movie with much CGI and it being this horrible. Even Quantumania which looked like Sharkboy and Lavagirl, still looked more realistic and practical than this. Like I understand there are two Ezras here, but they seriously couldn't have a stand-in and then digitally put Ezra's face on him? They really had to make up a whole CGI monstrosity for him and every scene in the movie? They even replay scenes that happened at the beginning of the movie, but they have reconstructed the whole scene with CGI and it looks horrible. I understand that they need to make a 3D version of it for the 360s, but honestly, if they just composited the real scene, I bet it would've still looked better.Moving on from the CGI, which I could rant about all day, the movie itself is not that horrible but not good either. It's entertaining enough but it's still meh. It's not the worst superhero movie of the year and it's definitely not the worst DC movie of the year.The plot is loosely based on the Flashpoint comic, which I have only seen the animated movie of. But the movie is more focused on throwing in cameos after cameos, which some particular ones have CGI worse than video games from 8 years ago.The movie actually starts pretty well but becomes nonsensical by the minute, and there should be a feeling of progression from the second act, but by the end, you realize that it was all just a bunch of cameo fest to pad the runtime, nothing of a value was added to the plot.They say a hero is only as good as his villain. Well, I looked and I could not find a villain. Unless they mean the one that comes at the end of the movie. If we consider Zod as the villain, he doesn't even show up for like 1:50:00 hours into the movie. Even Thanos in Endgame had some scenes before showing up for the final battle.They literally have one of the most complex and interesting comic book storylines at hand and they decide to not include even half of its interesting aspects into it. Thomas Wayne who is a hundred times more interesting than an old actor's nostalgia bait cameo? Nah, who cares about interesting characters. Wonder Woman and Aquaman who have the potential to be evil in the new timeline to raise the stakes higher? Nah, just throw them in for a minute or two as cameos, can't afford them for the full movie and can't afford good writers to implement them into the story. So this is really disappointing aspect of the storytelling of this.Then we have the characters, and even Flash himself has a really bare-bones characterization, and as much as Ezra Miller tries hard to act really well, you as the audience don't really get emotionally attached to his character. So there aren't really emotional attachments here and it's like "eh", except for some scenes with his mother. So it's no wonder that you don't care about Bruce Wayne or Supergirl either. Supergirl's character especially is handled really disappointingly and is basically just there to fight ad nothing more. I don't know how this movie manages to be 2:24 hours and have near to zero characterization for the supporting cast.It makes sense for the filmmakers here to have Michael Keaton's Batman in this story. But he just basically does everything Thomas Wayne did in Flashpoint minus all his interesting characterization and his stake and motive in helping Barry.The middle and the end of the movie are just pure nonsense and horrible CGI scene after horrible CGI scene with terrible cameos just for the sake of cameos that it gets exhausting by the end. It's like they decided they wanted to have all of these cameos first and then they said "hmm, let's check Flashpoint and see how we can construct a plot around these cameos".Now I've ranted a lot about the negatives, but I didn't hate hate this movie, I just didn't care for it that much.Some things I liked are firstly that I thought it was a decent idea that they decided to show Flash's origin story through the second Barry instead of the main Barry.Some scenes and lines were actually funny too, though some were really cringey and Barry was written as a 12-year-old instead of an 18-year-old. I also have to say that a movie making you laugh occasionally doesn't mean it's good.I also liked that they didn't really hold back from showing the different powers Barry has and how powerful he truly is.I also like bits and pieces of the story but it's all taken from Flashpoint anyway and they just reminded me of a way better Flash movie called Justice League: The Flashpoint Paradox. I should go rewatch that to remember how good the story actually is.I liked some Batman action scenes too but I already forgot about all of them anyway.But I guess that's all the compliments I can give to it.The movie is also one of the worst and most pointless post-credit scenes I've ever seen that could rival some of the worst of MCU's. Even MCU ones have some point to them or they tease the next movie. This was just another excuse to have a cameo, as if this movie needed more.The movie also has nothing to say or change about the current DCEU timelines and it's just confusing how they're gonna move forward with the new movies. Not having this movie really reset the universe makes it more pointless to watch since it can barely stand on its own. Though I guess that weird ending scene with the tooth thing is vaguely referring to a reset, but it's not clear.In conclusion, the problems are:Overall, the movie is just mediocre and forgettable, it's not super terrible but it's not good either. The only thing saving this movie is that the story, or at least some parts of it is based on Flashpoint. But it's still a decent watch otherwise.

title: Trite. Predictable.
text: In an alternate reality, where this would have released before every other superhero movie set in multiverse / based upon time travel and altering the past wrongs, it could have been a Bonafide blockbuster.It comes across as boring and trite because the viewer has seen the same, with a different set of superheroes, many times in the recent past.Ezra Miller is earnest and quite likeable as Flash. Keaton tries to recreate Batman magic of the 90s and fails as the script doesn't give him anything to work upon, besides the rousing BGM from the 1989 Batman.To think that the bosses at DC saw this as their sure shot at box office / critical response glory is hilarious. This earned what it was supposed to. Don't think it is going to spawn any sequel.

title: The story and the actors are great! The movie is nearly ruined by awful CGI !
text: While the story is fantastic and the actors give great performances, the movie is nearly ruined by awful CGI effects.The plot follows Barry Allen as he gains super-speed powers and becomes The Flash. The story is exciting, full of twists, and strikes a perfect tone of fun and heart. Ezra Miller and the rest of the cast are perfectly cast in their roles. Miller brings a charming awkwardness to Barry Allen that wins you over. The other actors also deliver emotive and funny performances.However, the CGI in this movie is shockingly bad. The Flash's super-speed runs and action sequences look incredibly fake and cartoonish. Some scenes are downright cringeworthy. The visual effects fail to make The Flash's powers feel believable or cool. For a superhero film where the lead character's main power is super-speed, this is a massive flaw.If you can look past the terrible CGI, The Flash has the makings of a great superhero film. The story and characters do justice to the comics. But the CGI nearly spoils the whole movie and taints the experience. With a blockbuster budget, there's no excuse for such poor visual effects. I would rate it 3 out of 5 stars. If they had only spent more time polishing the CGI, this could have been a 5-star film.

title: Some is really fun...
text: A lot of this movie is super fun... the idea of tying in so many movies is amazing.... But you can't outrun (pun intended) the fact that it takes a long time to get to the fun parts, and that Ezra Millers depiction of the flash is incredibly annoying.... Where Peter Parker is a character you can connect with and sympathize with, The Flash in this movie is irritating and unlikable... which really ruins soooooo much of what should be an awesome flick.I get that people think this movie did poorly because if Miller, but the fact is.... Unfortunately people don't care... it's more that his portrayal is just brutally annoying.... Most other things in this movie were fun.

title: Hmmm. Love the effort
text: This movie, while demonstrating efforts in production, unfortunately falls short of delivering a truly satisfying experience. The film exhibits strong technical aspects, with impressive visuals, well-crafted sets, and commendable special effects. However, it struggles to overcome its flaws in storytelling, character development, and overall execution.Visually, the movie is captivating. The use of CGI and visual effects creates stunning landscapes and mesmerizing action sequences that immerse the audience in the film's world. The attention to detail in the production design adds authenticity to the setting, providing a visually pleasing experience.The cast, comprising talented actors, delivers earnest performances. Despite their efforts, the characters lack depth and fail to elicit a strong emotional connection with the audience. The lead protagonist, in particular, lacks a compelling arc, leaving viewers disengaged from their journey.The film's storytelling is where it falters the most. The plot struggles to find coherence, jumping between various subplots without a seamless flow. As a result, the pacing feels uneven, and certain moments drag on without significant impact. The lack of clarity in character motivations and key plot points makes it challenging for viewers to invest in the story.The movie introduces intriguing supporting characters, but their potential remains largely untapped due to limited screen time and underdeveloped arcs. As a result, their contributions to the narrative feel superficial and fail to leave a lasting impression.The dialogue, though delivered competently, lacks the necessary depth to elevate the film's emotional moments. Attempts at humor fall flat, and the exchanges between characters often feel clichéd and uninspired.While the film touches on profound themes, it does so in a superficial manner, failing to explore them in depth and leaving the audience craving a more meaningful exploration of the central ideas.In conclusion, this movie showcases effort in production and features impressive visual elements, but it fails to deliver a cohesive and engaging narrative. Despite the dedication of the cast, the characters lack depth, and the storytelling struggles to find coherence. While it may appeal to some for its technical achievements, it ultimately falls short of being a truly captivating and impactful cinematic experience.

title: 5lbs of fan service in a 10lbs bag.
text: Cheesy, as camp as Adam West, somehow worse vfx than superman's moustache and more holes than wrought iron. Despite its attempt to kill the super hero genre, it was actually enjoyable.If the visual effects were even on par with the TV version of Flash, it might have rated an extra star. Seriously, I've seen fan created features on YouTube with more believable CGI.Best advice, don't watch it all in a single sitting. Break it up to save throwing things at your screen and realising that you won't be getting that 2hours and 24minutes back. Oh and for the love of all things sacred, don't watch it in 4k.

title: Some fun but mostly absolutely awful
text: The main problem in this is Ezra Miller. They're awful. Truly absolutely awful performance in every scene they're in.Michael Keaton isn't bad, but there's no justification for him to be there beyond fan service.Setting the movie around the events of another awful movie was a strange choice and it didn't manage to make it high stakes at all.The CGI is really bad at parts. 90s PS1 era bad.Hilariously I would say this is one of the better DCEU movies, it's almost amazing how they've managed to avoid good film making at every step of this universe.Hopefully this is last we see of Ezra Miller in any capacity. They have no place in front of a camera.

title: For the love of everything holy, cast someone who knows how to run
text:
Flailing, I mean running.Why do studios insist on casting people who have never run or even jogged in their life to play The Flash. Of all the superheroes, The Flash is the one that needs to be played by someone who's actually athletic. Why does he move in slow motion while sliding all over the place? In like every scene their is no motion blur effect making it appear like his arms and legs are moving extremely fast. The Incredibles and Eternals did it best. They make the fast characters feel fast. If The Flash ran like Extra Miller does in this movie he'd be the weakest superhero ever, like the running is worse than Twilight was. I literally can't get past it, it ruined the entire movie. Plus Ezra Miller is a horrible person who has always had the most annoying voice. I've hated him long before he went crazy, but even ignoring that the movie was a joke.Comedy?The film tries to be funny, or at least I think that was the goal because it didn't land at all. The first 10 minutes of the movie is about him being hungry. Idk when that trope became a staple of Flash, but it stupid and not even funny. Why would it funny? One of the most powerful superheroes in DC will die if he doesn't eat a Snickers. That's the stupidest thing I've ever heard. Numerous scenes feel like TikTok level comedy.Visual Effects:
The visual effects weren't good. If the story is good, bad effects can be overlooked, but the writing wasn't good either. The effects aren't the worst ever, but it feels like videogame or CW level effects in many scenes. Characters are also usually associated with a color so its easy to recognize, but the effects colors change multiple times. I don't know if it was meant to mean something, or just an artistic decision. Also a weird visual mistake is why is young Barry taller then current Barry?Final Conclusion:
I can't go on, I'm getting too mad. The Flash was my favorite character as a kid and they turned him into a movie that feels like it was made for Kids YouTube. Only watch this if you have absolutely nothing else to do or watch.I'm still mad about the running. Just put him on a treadmill turned way up in front of a green screen. It could be so simple. Please.

title: Not happy
text: The only good thing about this entire movie was to Michael Keaton as Batman once again.The premise of the movie is exactly what the CW series was about. Barry tries to save his mom from dying and screws up the time line. This has been done multiple times and now in its first motion picture. Waste of time.When are we actually going to see something original when it comes to characters that aren't top notch.Oh and don't get me started with Kara, Superman's cousin. She reminds me of the talentless girl from the Twighlight movies, Kristen Stewart.What was DC and Warner Bros thinking when they made this movie?

title: Other than special effect?
text: If one wasn't concerned whether the special effects were good or bad, it is entertaining enough for teenage boys and youth. But the movie seems to have simply too much thrown in to make for a really good movie. It really becomes mindless entertainment with a very simple plot. If one goes back in time, it doesn't mean when one exits, one will return to the same temporal universe. And if that wasn't made clear enough, in the last act with the clashing of different parallel universes, that was drummed in. The younger Barry Allen character sometimes became annoying, but it never was stated his age anyway, so it may have fit with his age. Sure there were some fun spots, but also some boring ones.

title: Saved Grant Gustin's career
text: I always thought that the role should go to Grant as (1) he is such a great actor and (2) I hate the whiny Ezra but this movie made me change my mind.The first few DC movies were so dark and humorless compared to Marvel and I guess they decided to put a bit more humor into theirs too. Witness the light moments in Aquaman and such.Then comes the Flash movie. It was basically an attempt to mix spoofs and sitcoms. The writers turned in bits and pieces of a script and the studio basically said: Ok, all these scraps look good, so let's take em all and turn them into a movie.This was so, so painful to watch. It's not that there were plot holes, but more a case of you need to find a deep enough hole into which to throw the whole thing.

title: Flash ending makes no sense
text: Technically the 2nd flash wouldn't exist. He exists beascuse Barry Allen (the flash) was pushed out of the chrono ball by the purple being witch turned out to be the 2nd flash altho he was created beascuse he pushed Barry Allen out so if he was never pushed he would never exist but he exists because he made himself exist. So I think it should have another ending like his mom is the villan or batman is evil. Wonder woman should be in the movie more she's there for like 40 seconds. Other than that the move was good, just a bit confusing. Anyone else noticed that flash 2 shouldn't exist? Or is it just me.

title: I think both the DCU and the MCU need some time to rest.
text: The Flash.. oh boy..I went into this film with really low expectations, and there are honestly very few positives here. I had seen everything at the moment, I wanted something fun , something I could turn my brain off for two hours. This movie though, I was not happy. I felt ashamed for the writers , ashamed for Warner and how did Jim Gunn approve this?The visuals are disappointing. For a film that cost over 200 Million to produce, it felt like a Saturday morning kid's production. The actor who portrayed Barry and his younger self, are the worst casted characters I can recall recently. Young Barry is so annoying, but for some reason the producers choose to put him in 2/3 of this.The film starts off well, felt similar to Ant Man, but almost right away goes to this odd time travel plot to save Mom. Others have said the same thing, Michael Keaton was the only good save for this film. The only thing I thought as I watched this, how could an exec think this was ok to be released? Why does Warner have story problems on all DC projects of late? Like my title stated, I think both Disney and Warner need to put their superhero stories on hold for a couple years.This is a hard pass.

title: The worst superhero movie that I saw
text: Not good movie it shows again that DC is really below Marvel and farnnnn!The special effects are poorly done, absolutely unpleasant to look at, and they use close-up angles as if they weren't going to notice that it's 3-D. Pfff, they haven't understood technology, it's more like video game shots than film shots, their direct designers have a good handle on it compared to VFX, where it goes unnoticed...What holds the film together, perhaps, is the character's general story, which is quite nice, where we learn about a terrible trauma, and it revolves around that, but it's not grandiose either...You can see that they're trying to copy Marvel a lot, but .... they're not up to the task, especially in this film, which really isn't that great.But I'm glad Michael Keaton is back !!!!So if you have to choose between Fast & Furious and this, I think the choice is quickly made!

title: Struggling to get through it all
text: I came in with low expectations but oof, I am not enjoying this movie. I'm writing this review before even finishing because I'm half way through and I can't like this character at all.1) Ezra Miller had been dead to me following his multiple egregious accusations. 2) They really dumbed down Barry Allen so much in this telling of The Flash. The attempted jokes and one-liners are not landing at all and to complete this entire movie is going to be a chore. I'm only still watching to see Keaton in action, let's see if he can save the day and my viewing experience but he is unlikely to be enough.

title: Disappointing
text: Firstly, I thought that the movie would be interesting to watch as it was deemed to be a proper live action Flash movie but after watching the movie, I am totally disappointed. The story was okay, the screenplay was below average, the direction was bad, the performances were above average, the CGI was bad; it's hard for me to find out something good in this movie. It felt like the studio joined the leftover scenes from previous movies and added some cartoonish CGI to it. Its sad to see that Warner Bros is continuously failing to give us good DC movie.Overall, I will say that you should skip it.

title: A 'B Grade' Film
text: In the old days, when hand held camera work was considered unartistic and for students who could not afford a proper camera, there were 'B grade' films. Basically films made without a budget, which may or may not have had any editing, a decent script or a proper camera crew. This film is rubbish, brings nothing new to the screen and after SO MANY Marvel films...this is just plain boring. The actors appear to be ok, but the film has been badly done...the costumes are average, the lighting is average, the script is poor, the plot is non-existent and there really is no point in bothering unless you REALLY HAVE NOTHING ELSE TO DO.

title: Long, slow, dull
text: The bad: Watching manic Ezra Miller act with manic Ezra Miller gets old. Fast. The editing doesn't help because the pauses are just a bit too long to make the conversations flow. But even before hand, the character didn't feel right. They turned the Flash into, well, an idiot. We get it: he's always hungry. We don't need 20 minutes of the same joke about him needing food. Or that he's the member of the Justice League who is cleaning up the messes of Batman. Funny? Sure. For a moment. But it drags.The good: Once Michael Keaton enters the movie it moves. The filmmakers and Miller should have studied Michael Keaton acting with Michael Keaton works (Multiplicity) because he's a comedic actor. The man is just fun to watch. Thankfully he's in the film for the remainder.More bad: the fight scenes. The filmmakers are trying to pull a page from Waititi's Thor. But it doesn't work when you try to have two Flashes who have known each other for a day working in perfect synch. It's forced. And dull.Further bad: Zod. Completely support what they were trying to do. But they failed bc Zod is a one note character who was even dull in Man of Steel. His return should have caused us to care about the destruction of the world. We don't. But this isn't because of Zod. This is because the filmmakers take so much time on attempting to draw humor from two Millers that they fail to bring a human connection to the audience to make us care if anyone survives.I literally cared about the dog in the beginning more than anyone else.If they cut 45 minutes of the movie, maybe it would have worked. But at 2.5 hours? Not at all.This was far from the 'best superhero movie made yet' and people claimed. It's far from even a competent movie at all.

title: A Disappointing Entry in the DC Universe
text: "The Flash" (2023) falls short of expectations, ranking among the weaker entries in the DC movie lineup. The film suffers from several shortcomings, including lackluster acting, unconvincing costumes, and noticeable instances of artificiality.One of the glaring issues lies in the acting performances. While Ezra Miller tries to infuse energy and charm into the role of Barry Allen, his portrayal falls flat at times. The delivery feels forced, and the emotional depth often fails to resonate, leaving the character feeling one-dimensional. The supporting cast doesn't fare much better, with underdeveloped characters and performances that fail to leave a lasting impression.Another drawback is the quality of the costumes. While superhero films often rely on elaborate costumes to bring characters to life, "The Flash" disappoints in this aspect. The costumes appear cheap and unrealistic, lacking the detail and craftsmanship expected from a big-budget production. This detracts from the immersion and diminishes the impact of the superhero's iconic appearance.Furthermore, the film struggles with its visual effects. While some sequences showcase impressive CGI, there are instances where the artificiality becomes glaringly apparent. The lack of seamless integration between live-action and CGI elements further emphasizes the film's shortcomings in this regard, undermining the overall believability of the world and its characters.Despite these flaws, "The Flash" attempts to maintain an engaging plot. However, it stumbles due to convoluted storytelling and a lack of clear narrative focus. The script fails to deliver a cohesive and captivating storyline, leaving viewers confused and disengaged at times.In conclusion, "The Flash" (2023) is not the best offering from the DC Universe. The film suffers from subpar acting performances, unconvincing costumes, and noticeable instances of artificiality in its visual effects. While it tries to deliver an engaging plot, it falls short due to convoluted storytelling. Fans of the character may find moments to appreciate, but overall, it fails to meet the expectations set by its predecessors.

title: Flash will have to run back time literally to fix this one
text: The CGI looked like was done by couple of teenagers going to graphics school and did a weekend project on how a DC movie can look like. It's good for them for being done in just two days but it's really bad for us DC fans. I think this will be a one nail in the DCEU coffin in the near future. I thought I have seen worst CGI in Justice league. But this one just took number 1 place for the worst cgi in a movie. It does not look like a multi million $ budget movie at all. I wonder how DCEU always get the CGI part so bad. Did marvel hire all the good designers or what? Most of the time I wondered if I was watching a pre screen release where they still did not finish the CGI. I hope theres a finished "snyder cut" of this one too.

title: Never forget this name: John Wesley Shipp the first Flash.
text: During the 90's I saw the live action TV series based on the DC character The Flash. Years later, well into my prime, I'm seeing this 2023 version of the Flash for the first time. Stated that I'm not an Ezra Miller fan. I don't know how or why a person who has no theater experience of 15 years is chosen for a lead role. John Wesley Shipp was the best Flash. He should have reprised his role.This movie is about alternate time-lines. There is no plot. Just blind nonsensical CGI action. With a multi superhero cast, you shouldn't expect a coherent plot. In fact, Hollywood has lost the plot entirely. They should really stop making movies altogether as there are no talented actors to be found these days, let alone action heroes the likes of Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone, Jean Claude Van Damme, Chuck Norris etc., etc. These new generation of actors don't have any screen presence or skill and are just lucky to be at the right time and place to just sneak the role.Brief plot: due to a traumatic childhood incident that Barry witnessed his mother lose her life, The Flash in a burst of anger tries to undo this by traveling back in time. But this has serious repercussions and he will find out why. This is similar to the Back To Future trilogy of films where Marty tries to undo the harm he has done. The only difference between these movies is the superhero element. Back To The Future didn't boast any superheroes but was an enjoyable and exciting watch.It is good to see my childhood Batman actor Michael Keaton(Pacific Heights 1990, One Good Cop 1991, Desperate Measures 1998) reprise his role again.Verdict: if you've got time to spare than this is an average movie to sit through, just about worth one's time.More superhero themed movies: Condorman 1981, Misfits of Science 1985, Masters Of The Universe 1987, The Meteor Man 1993, Blankman 1994, Steel 1997. I have seen all of these movies and recommend them if you haven't seen them already.

title: Not a big fan of multiverses anymore; expecting more from Gunn's DCU! [+54%]
text: The Flash, once considered to be the DC entry that'd revive (or reset) the whole franchise, turns out to be an okayish affair. Of course, this was mostly written and shot during the pandemic with multiple changes in creative direction, post-production delays, and the whole Miller controversy. The end product features yet another multiverse setting, with Allen's decision to save his mother creating an alternate timeline where some Justice League members do not exist (or are different from the ones we've known). The 18-year-old version of Miller is designed to be a complete goofball, and it feels a bit overdone in the film. The CGI also leaves much to be desired; it's a mixed bag - some scenes look terrific whereas some look downright terrible - you'll know which ones if you've seen the film (why did they do Superman dirty?).The idea to bring back Michael Keaton's Batman in a more prominent role (as compared to Batfleck) is one of the better creative decisions the film has taken. The Supergirl angle didn't do much for me, as its overall impact was left wanting. But the worst is reserved for the film's final act. The script meanders, considers various possibilities, and settles for the tamest one. This has been the case with most of Christina Hodson's scripts; they always lose steam when it gets close to the finale (be it Bumblebee or Birds of Prey). I hope future comicbook films also discard the "change-your-past-using-time-travel" trope.

title: Oof!
text: I see the potential. I enjoyed some of the cameos and call-backs. But what the "Call of Duty" is going on with the VFX? I will steer clear of spoilers, but visually this movie hurts. Story is muddled, I'll chalk that up to post and edit. I only gave a 5 out of respect (and maybe pity) for those that thought this film would own the summer box office. Which it hasn't and won't. Tragic.I can't even blame Ezra Miller. Their performance was fine. This film would have benefited from more practical effects and a simpler story. It was too busy and the result is muddy with no polish.This film might deserve a director's cut or fan edit, but that's provided WB isn't fragmented and auctioned off piecemeal to pay off the creditors.Anyone have a workprint of "Batgirl" kicking around?

title: An story that could've been great
text: Flash point paradox is a great story. I recommend watching the DC animated movie or reading the comics since this movie really didn't do it Justice. It was still okay overall and you could see where they were going. It just needed more life, less CGI, and maybe just a better overall direction that didn't try to rely on flashy gimmicks and really bad jokes. I really dislike the portrayal of Flash in DC movies as they lean in to to much of the negative traits of the flash, but Ezra did play the character well enough. I found this Reddit post that describes Barry Allen in my opinion the best:"To me Barry is intelligent, dorky, a bit on the shy side, and very optimistic about the motivations and potential of the people around him, even his enemies. He's always quick with a dad joke or a flash fact. A large part of the original conceit of Barry was to make him an educational hero to appeal to the comics code authority so the flash facts were very important and form a core part of his character now-Barry's coolest speed feats are things he figured out how to do via his knowledge of physics and chemistry, as opposed to Wally's more fantastical feats. On the flip side, he suffers from a lot of internally focused anxiety that can prevent him from extending the patience and understanding he has for other people back towards himself, so he tends to beat himself up for any mistakes (real or imagined) and it gives him unmanageable expectations he can't always live up to and can stop him for reaching out for help when he needs it. To me Barry is intelligent, dorky, a bit on the shy side, and very optimistic about the motivations and potential of the people around him, even his enemies."I saw attempts at most of these traits, but the lack of a more optimistic and upbeat Barry with actual jokes that stuck made the Flash bland and boring. You could replace the Flash with any random and nobody would care since the story is still okay. Well that's basically the movie the Flash summed up in a nutshell. Okay superhero story. Worth a watch if you're bored.

title: I wanted to like this and it's not all bad but...
text: Stop with this multiverse stuff, have you learned nothing from Marvel!? The multiverse is not winning fans, it's too over complicated and I am sick to the back teeth of schlocy CGI, we may as well be watching the cartoons (that are better than the movies). Matt Reeves has the right idea, ditch everyone else and just let him make the movies!Rant over, I actually found the movie quite enjoyable in parts and I loved the ending. Seeing all the different characters was great to be fair and some of the action sequences are spot on, still too over reliant on CGI again.Ezra Miller is a good flash and he showed promise in a number of areas, just a shame he's a bit of a fool in real life.Overall 5 out of ten isn't bad and I was expecting a lot worse, could have been 30 minutes shorter too.Would I watch it again? Probably but not for a while.

title: The Flash is a supporting role in his own movie.
text: There were moments in this film that excited us, unfortunately, they were scenes with "other" heroes in them. Most notably, Michael Keaton's Batman from the 80's puts on a much better show than Ezra Miller's 'Flash', and his younger, dumber self. The pair of time-traveling twins were so loopy, and neurotic, the overall feel when they were on screen was that of a Saturday morning cartoon. When any of the "other" heroes got screentime, it was as if the movie completely changed tone, and we all started paying attention again. DC needs to quit trying to copy the success of GOTG, (mixing humor and drama)... They're not good at it, and it really screws up the feel of their movies. Overall however, we do recommend the film, just keep your expectations on the low side... Think: "One step down from the theatrical version of Justice League".

title: They found a way to change actors in the future
text: So the actors that you knew playing Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman for sure they will be replaced in any next DCU...I think "The Flash" was made for this to happen.Now, the movie itself, some fun moment, many thing I did not like, like the representation of the "intersection" when the flash was in its bubble, does not make any sense.CGIs some are fair, a lot are from a series z category, especially the faces they looked like they were draw half 2D, half 3D.In the end I am very mitigated about the purpose of this movie, hals good, half bad and I did not like the end at all, it opens the door to anything even the worse like changing the main good actors we have to use.

title: Lower Rating Is For Disgusting Factor
text: This movie could have been so much better, but they ruined it by adding such disgusting stuff to Barry's character. I mean, how childish and immature can you make an alternate Barry? And how much of Barry throwing up did they have to show in such vivid detail? That might appeal to a much younger audience, but I highly doubt that those things would appeal to anyone else. The story also seemed to just plod along, without much excitement...although there were a few action scenes that were good. Unfortunately, the overall package failed to deliver what I was expecting. This seemed to be more on par with an episode of The Flash series. They definitely need better writers. Such a pity.

title: A Few Years Too Late
text: The Flash" had moments that I enjoyed, but mostly had moments that were just fine. I didn't leave the theater disgusted by the CGI, but I also didn't leave the theater energized because of all the cameos. The dual Barry stuff worked, the plot itself is pretty good, and I thought that Ezra Miller did a pretty good acting job.With the reset in the DCEU, this movie just felt pointless. In a world that we have "No Way Home", the cameos in this movie seem a few years too late.Best Character: Alternate Barry.Best Quote: "Not every problem has a solution, Barry." - Barry.Best Scene: The Top Shelf.Best Piece of Score: "I Loved You First".

title: Poor CGI mixed with an Underwhelming Story makes for a Truly Disappointing Watch
text: The 13th installment in the DCEU, The Flash is here and it is disappointing. The story like any other contemporary superhero movie is filled with humour and lots of action. It tries to balance the dark and dramatic moments along with the comedy but is largely unsuccessful which results in this movie suffering from a vast array of tonal inconsistencies. The humour felt a little too much at times. Not to mention the movie drags on for too long thanks to some problems with the screenplay and the wildly uneven pacing.Ezra Miller's performance was okay. He might be overacting at times but overall he does an okay job. It's Michael Keaton as Batman who steals every scene he's in making the movie somewhat interesting.The direction, however, is quite amazing. The different use of angles and lenses felt really interesting to watch. The score is perfect and knows how to deal with the story while still having the sense of nostalgia.Now being a superhero movie it has extensive use of CGI and oh boy was it not good. Half of it was extremely terrible. It all looked so incredibly fake and cartoony that it took out of the movie more than once. This was easily one of the worst uses of CGI I've ever seen in any superhero movie.Overall, the cast does a decent job and the direction and score is really good but all of it can't makeup for the poor CGI quality and the screenplay which drags the movie down.

title: A multidimensional disaster
text: Trying to be the DC's no way home. This movie left dc no way home into the minds of people.This was DC's attempt to show how the past movies were all in other universes that are in a single omniverse.The concept itself isn't bad but the execution and the cgi of this movie holds it back (well that is an understatement). The cgi when flash time travels or multiverse jumps or whatever is very confusing and the whole plot of flash trying to save his mother and then ending up in a different universe but he still believes he can save his mother in his universe and the other flash believing he knows how transcends the border of even movie sense and make this movie a wasted effor with what otherwise in the trailer seemed a good movie but that's all the trailer and movie are trying to do, ride on the hype of noistalgia and the acting of those former movie stars and it does not work.All in all this movie won't effect DC very much because they have a lot of bad attempts under their belt and this movie does not wander a watch as you won't miss anything if you don't watch this disaster.

title: one question...
text: During the last few years, we have unfortunately moved away from the ideal cinema, not only in one field but in all fields. Like many children and teenagers, I was in love with superheroes and their worlds, and when I got older, I expected that the cinema, using its facilities, would be able to provide me with eye-catching movies along with humanitarian and anti-war content. Cinema taught me how beautiful the world can be through its superheroes! Unfortunately, they were not able to present an impressive work in terms of special effects, nor were they able to say important things in terms of content. Suffering from clichés and parallel worlds and... getting away from the original. I have only one question: Where is that eye-catching matrix full of content that was made with facilities 20 years ago?!!

title: Funny, but so immaturely written with dismal CGI
text: So, I know that hundreds of millions of dollars were spent on this film. How the CGI ended up so bad is beyond me. I swear the stuff I watched in the early 2000s was better. I don't understand how can spend so much and deliver so little. Now the story premise wasn't that bad, and it really did have some funny moments. This was quickly spoiled by over doing the comedy to the point where is started to get annoying. Naked jokes are funny once, dick jokes, the same. Repeating the same joke is really a sign of poor writing and a lack of mature imagination. It's sad.Additionally, I'm not sure why the director felt that 18 year-old Flash needed to act like a four year-old. Eating like a toddler, food all over his face, jumping on he bed like his first sleepover. It was pathetic and embarrassing for the lead, frankly. I wanted to give this a higher rating, but the dumbing down and lazy directing, just makes it impossible to rate it above a 4.The Marvel Universe it becoming a daycare center.

title: A MIND BOGGLING MESS WITH A PLOT HALF WAY THROUGH FILM
text:
If special effects is what you like give The Flash 9.0
Other than that the film is an overly long production that depends on the viewer never having seen a DC super hero movie.The plot is non existent for half the film, the time being consumed by introducing various characters from the DC universe.And even when there is a definite story, anyone who has seen other DC universe super hero films would know the plot to be impossible.Eventually to flush out the thin storyline, the producers thrown in brief guest appearances by most DC superheros.The time slipping trick is so crude and confusing, I just made it to the end wondering why I spent nearlt three hours on this turkey.

title: CGI so bad that it's distracting
text: $200m budget and yet the CGI is horrific. Literally some of the worst that you'll see in a recent super hero flick. It's almost incomprehensible how any of it was approved and allowed into a major motion picture. It's hard to take anything else seriously because as soon as there is any action sequence, you're immediately exposed to horribly fake looking people and stiff animations. One can only assume the artists involved were under crazy time constraints to get shots finished. Honestly - it sucks to make an entire review on hat harps on about visual effects, but it seriously affects the entire experience! Anyway, thank god for Michael Keaton. Otherwise, epic fail.

title: low tier superhero movie
text: Lost all desire to watch the film 30 minutes in, and think principle is the only reason I watched it. It was like a kids movie with kids' humor but some bloody and dark scenes. An action packed movie without logic, intriguing aspects or any type of thinking. A generic layout of Barry Allen as a socially awkward researcher trying to get together with this girl he likes and saving the world. The plot gets a little interesting when time travel and alternative time lines are introduced, but somehow it becomes unexciting. Maybe because of the mess that is created, all the illogical decisions or the bad CGI. All and all it feels like a typical dc or marvel movie with some bad humor but at the same time an appealing universe.

title: Hard on the Outside and soft in the middle.....
text: OK going into this I was accompanying a Flash series fan, while I was looking forward to something new and a bit of fun, not having watched any of the series.The first portion of the film was mildly entertaining and they set up the introduction to the multiverse, and how they portrayed the portal was a unique artistic approach - with almost all of the super person movie bases having a multiverse of some sort at least this had a unique portal to display.That being said...enter stage two of the movie where our superhero has travelled in time through the portal to one of the other universes. Introduce a dolt like putz of a former self right out of Bill and Ted's and slog along babysitting this character at a kindergarten level and the movie breaks new ground in boredom. Finding what snacks we had left was beating out the movie for attention and my thought was I could cut out 45-60 minutes out of this film. The intelligence level here was nearly insulting. I found out that my friend who is a big fan actually fell asleep.Snacks depleted we moved into the third portion of the film and back to action, although I seemed to have lost any attachment to the characters by that point...at least the portrayal of the portal again was interesting and there was some (seemingly pointless) action taking place. I wont give a spoiler but the end message has been done a million times before.Holding my tongue I asked my friend what they thought...."Bad" was the reply.... I said I agree...thought it might just be me.I wont recommend this one.

title: I need more Warner Bros
text: Flash 2023Flash 2023, the latest installment in the DC Comics cinematic universe, falls short of the expectations set by its predecessors. Despite promising potential, the film struggles with weak character development, unnecessary scenes, and a messy time travel theory, leaving viewers with a sense of disappointment.One of the major flaws of Flash 2023 lies in its inability to properly establish and build its characters. While the film features beloved characters from the D Comics universe, their development feels rushed and superficial. The audience is left craving deeper connections and a better understanding of their motivations and personal growth.Furthermore, the inclusion of numerous unnecessary scenes detracts from the film's overall cohesion. These superfluous moments not only disrupt the pacing but also add little value to the story, leaving viewers questioning their relevance and contribution to the plot.One of the most glaring issues with Flash 2023 is its mishandling of the time travel theory. Time travel can be a complex concept to execute effectively, and unfortunately, the film fails to provide a coherent and well-established framework. This lack of clarity results in confusing plot holes and inconsistencies that hinder the audience's ability to fully engage with the story.The shortcomings of Flash 2023 highlight the need for Warner Brothers to exercise greater caution and meticulousness when bringing D Comics to the big screen. Thorough script development and attention to detail are paramount in ensuring a satisfying cinematic experience for both fans and general audiences.In conclusion, Flash 2023 falls short of its potential, with weak character development, unnecessary scenes, and a muddled time travel theory. While it's disappointing to see these missteps, it serves as a reminder that Warner Brothers should carefully consider the execution of their DC Comics adaptations in order to deliver more consistent and fulfilling films in the future.

title: Actually Thought-Provoking.
text: Yes, this is a summer action film, but the story is actually kind of deep. It revolves around a question I've often posed to myself and others, "What would I be like if I didn't go through the struggles I did?" This movie gives an answer. I always figured, you know, I've been through some horrible stuff, but I have an idea of what I might have become without those experiences, and I don't like it. Pain and suffering gives us a perspective that helps us see our circumstances with more brevity, unless we let that pain destroy and consume us. Yes, that is what this film is really about, I found myself very happy while watching this that a mainstream action film dared to explore such themes.It is a fun movie, I have seen it twice and I enjoyed it equally both times. It was unfairly panned, the fact is, people or rather critics are fatigued by comic book movies, and I don't blame them. I won't watch anything put out by Disney/Marvel, so that leaves me with DC, and overall, I think their movies are far better because they are by and large fun movies. When I go to see a superhero film, I want a fun film. I was never a huge fan of the "Dark Knight" and I enjoy "Batman & Robin", so that should tell you something. I think comic book films are best when they understand how silly they are. The Flash does.The acting is by and large good, the script is still kind of by the numbers, but again explores some pretty deep themes which really sets it apart. It was extremely fun seeing Michael Keaton back, he is my favorite Batman, and personally, I just want a new Batman movie with him, don't care how old he is. I enjoyed the other surprises, that I won't ruin. I loved the running jokes revolving around pop culture, those were a lot of fun. Again it's just a fun movie with some deeper themes underlying it that it knows how to explore. I don't think the CGI was bad, I've seen worse in Marvel movies. So....Overall, if you like your comic book movies fun, but with a bit of pathos, you will enjoy The Flash.

title: Review: "The Flash" (2023)
text: With the cinematic world constantly evolving, fans eagerly anticipated the release of "The Flash" (2023), with hopes that it would bring a fresh take on the beloved speedster. The DC universe, rife with compelling characters and intricate storylines, often sparks fierce debates about character interpretations, and "The Flash" was no exception.Perhaps the most polarizing element of the movie was the portrayal of The Flash himself. To say the character was 'annoying' would be an understatement. Every quip, every expression, every gesture seemed calculated to irk the audience. There's an argument to be made about characters needing flaws and nuances to be relatable and human, but in this case, it felt like an overload, making the film a laborious experience for many.One might wonder, was it necessary to make The Flash this irritating? On one hand, it could be a bold choice to highlight Barry Allen's struggle with his newfound powers, his insecurities, or his efforts to fit into the superhero community. Painting him as an outcast or as someone trying too hard to be accepted can be an interesting take, providing depth and layers to a character often seen simply as the 'fast guy'.However, a line must be drawn between complexity and vexation. While the filmmakers might have aimed for a more humanized, imperfect Barry Allen, the result was an over-the-top annoyance that overshadowed the character's redeeming qualities. For many viewers, it became almost impossible to finish the movie due to this excessive portrayal.In conclusion, while "The Flash" (2023) had its moments and will undoubtedly have its supporters, the overwhelming sentiment is that the portrayal of its titular character detracted more than it added. In the future, filmmakers should remember that while it's essential to make characters relatable and flawed, they mustn't alienate their core audience in the process.

title: Well executed attempt to fix the contentious Justice League tone
text: Full disclosure: I have not watched the Flash streaming series with Ezra Miller. I have watched all the previous movies that are attached to this movie's slice(s) of the DC Universe. So I won't have any opinion on how this connects to the series. :)I think, this movie felt like a good jolt, to get the franchise on track towards something a bit less serious and dark than what we have seen in the Justice League movies. A super hero that doesn't take himself too serious, even though his origin story is quite tragic. Michael Keaton is also doing a great job reprising his role from the '90s.I am sure the plot hole hunters on YouTube will have a field day with this story, as any story written around time travelling will have big problems keeping the ends tied up. The whole concept is after all chronically flawed in itself. I do think they managed to keep the story from falling as much apart as the Multiverse in that other franchise is at the moment.Only gripes I have with this movie is that Ezra Miller do tend to overact the loud teenager a bit. It can get a bit much in some dialogues with that other teenager. The end credit scene, funny as it was, might also be a bit illogical to put in there. It puts them in a trajectory that could make the stakes as low as they are in the Marvel Universe these days. But overall, I think this might be a movie pointing DC in the right direction for their next few movies in the franchise.

title: There is a LOT going on here
text: Firstly, the anticipation was rewarded. We were presented with not one but two versions of Flash and Batman, alongside a plethora of Kryptonians - all of this in addition to a few other surprises that I won't disclose here, sticking strictly to what was revealed in the trailers. The new characters left a memorable impression, while the established ones held their ground and kicked some serious butt.The movie was so densely packed with action and storyline that I found myself halfway through, realizing that multiple viewings would be essential. The soundtrack was adventurous and perfectly matched the tone of the film.However, the movie wasn't without its flaws. In my opinion, it leaned too heavily on humor, and the quality of the CGI in a specific location felt subpar. While this seemed to be an artistic choice, it still appeared peculiar.To conclude, I am eagerly awaiting the next chapter in the DC Universe, excited to see what they have in store for us.

title: It entertains, but where was the great film we were promised?
text: Despite being one of the fastest traveling superheroes in the medium of comic books, it has taken a very long time for The Flash to receive the big screen treatment. Attempts to bring the character to the cinema go as far back as the late 1980's, but while some approaches almost came to be ultimately it was not meant to be. We might've seen a movie earlier in the last decade if Warner Bros. Didn't drop the ball as hard as they did with their attempt at a DC Cinematic Universe and mishandled Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice and Justice League and made a mess out of everything, but finally in 2020 things started coming together and cameras started rolling in 2021. It was looking smooth but change in management at Warner Bros. Led to serious retooling of the plot that resulted in extensive reshoots and different endings. As a result, the budget became ridiculously bigger, and to make matters worse its star became a source of much controversy with many wondering if they would recast to make sure it had more commercial appeal, but too much was already spent on the production.People were unsure if the movie would be any good, but surprisingly several key figures in the entertainment industry from Tom Cruise to Stephen King showered the film with praise after seeing a version of it and encouraged everyone to get their tickets as soon as possible. Having seen the movie, I have to wonder if they saw an early cut because what has been released in theatres, I would say it is...Just fine. However, nothing to write home about.This film is a loose attempt at the Flashpoint storyline that ironically also reset the DC Universe, only it is a bit more complicated, lighter in tone, and does away with some key elements from the comic book that would've served the movie better. While there are some pretty solid dramatic moments here and there, it largely plays out as a comedy, and even though most of the jokes work there are a number that do not. Most of the humor comes from the younger version of Barry Allen from the new timeline The Flash has created by going into the past, and Ezra Miller overdoes the silliness to a point where the character's intended annoyance is taken to an irritating level. Miller still does fine as The Flash, even though it is still a more Wally West version of the character than Barry Allen.Michael Keaton, Ben Affleck, and Sasha Calle are all great in what time they have, they make the most of what they can do and you do wish there would've been more time spent with them. Seeing Michael Shannon and Antje Traue back as Zod and Faora was also a plus.There is some pretty fun spectacle and engaging action set pieces, but the storytelling is largely pretty sloppy and various plot threads do not end very satisfyingly. A lot of the "wow" factor tends to be lost in the very poorly rendered CGI, which honestly feels like you are watching a cinematic from a PlayStation 2 video game.In the end, The Flash (2023) is a "coulda, woulda, shoulda" type of motion picture, some joy can be had with it but most likely you will come out not feeling disappointed in some way. It is a shame, because The Flash is a great character that has many exciting stories to pull from for a movie, and in 2023 the money and effects are there for something fantastic.

title: this doesn't show much overall improvement
text: Destroying Cinematic Entries Unequivocally (cough, cough), the DCEU is at it again, this time chronicling lightning fast superhero and unofficial Justice League janitor The Flash. At the outset, some prolonged and needlessly pretentious action scenes with poor special effects set the tone early for what turns out to be quite an uneven showing. Barry Allen's a lonely, broken forensic investigator trying to relive his past, but his inability to let go and his attempt to try and undo history leads to catastrophic results when he--quite literally--breaks the universe into alternative timelines. The dilemma is now whether he and his younger, less mature self can clean up the multiverse mess that he's made. Given the amount of fan service and characters that occupy the run time, it's curious as to whether or not this can be viewed as an actual Flash movie; Miller holds their own but the dual role does make them half engaging and half annoying, but after so many years it's a pleasure to see Michael Keaton once again don the cape and cowl, just too bad he wasn't given a better movie in which to make his Batman return. Multiverses, variants, frequent attempts at humor, callbacks, thunderous action scenes...they're all thrown at you but nothing really sticks, not to mention Marvel already played this card (Spider-Man: No Way Home anyone?) in superior fashion. How many DC duds have to be produced before they realize they're doing it all wrong? **

title: Barry travels back in time, to a spaghetti bowl of different timelines and universes.
text: For some reason I thought this movie had received a negative reception and was prepared for it not to be very good. Well, I was mistaken, I found it thoroughly enjoyable, with some novel ideas about time travel. I watched it at home on BluRay, my wife watched the first half then left, she isn't much of a Superhero fan.Ezra Miller is Barry Allen, aka The Flash. As the movie starts there is havoc in the city, Barry goes to a shop for his usual breakfast, a sandwich loaded with calories for the high energy he needs, PB, raisins, honey, bananas, and maybe a few other things. He needs it quick so he can spring into action but the usual waitress is absent that day and the guy replacing her is slow. So he has to forego that and spring into action. Interesting start to the movie to show how his super fast speed needs additional energy. Most movies and TV shows just skip that point.Anyway as the story moves along Barry experiments with backwards running to travel into the past, to a few minutes earlier, or a day earlier. He decides to try to return to his childhood and correct the incident that led to his mother's death and his dad's false imprisonment. But everything gets scrambled and, in a session with Bruce Wayne (Michael Keaton) he learns that alternate time lines aren't really parallel, they get scrambled like a bowl of cooked spaghetti. (At least in this movie!)Anyway all this leads to a number of complications, The Flash, Batman, and Supergirl end up in a fierce battle with Zod. In that scenario there are two Flashes, Barry Allen at two different ages.The whole story gets very complicated but is written well and all makes sense, if you pay attention.

title: Emotional Core and Nothing Else
text: The Flash is the latest instalment in DC's ever-troubled movie franchise. While the film has its heart in the right place, it falls short with lacklustre (bordering on laughable) CGI, forced jokes, a significantly smaller scale compared to the comics, and various other shortcomings. Despite several years of development, The Flash feels rushed and fails to deliver on its potential.The main plot revolves around Barry (played by Ezra Miller) going back in time to save his mother, a decision he couldn't make when he was younger. As expected, altering the past comes with consequences, especially when time travel is involved. Things take a turn for the worse, leading to a new dimension where Superman is absent, but Supergirl (Sasha Calle) takes on the mantle. Batman is portrayed by Michael Keaton, reprising his role from the past, and the Justice League is nowhere to be found. The film now features a revamped team of two speedsters, a Kryptonian, and a different version of Batman.Ezra Miller's portrayal of The Flash has been a wild card pick from the beginning, depicting a young Barry struggling to master his powers and find friendship along the way, which isn't easy. In this film, he has grown significantly, especially when he encounters the second Barry, who hasn't faced the same struggles. We witness how much he has matured. While no one can replace Henry Cavill as Superman, introducing Supergirl is a different story. Sasha Calle brings raw emotion, stoicism, and a no-nonsense attitude to her portrayal. Michael Keaton, reprising his role as Batman, slips back into the character effortlessly, as if he never stopped playing the Dark Knight. His revamped suit, new technology tricks, and seasoned experience make him a formidable and successful protector of Gotham.The Flash suffers from egregious CGI, severely hampering the overall experience. While it's usually better to have no CGI at all for grounded heroes, those with even minimal powers require proper CGI execution. With the film's extensive development time and a budget of around $220 million, there's no excuse for such subpar visual effects. The Flash becomes the latest addition to DC's franchise blunders. One can only hope that under the direction of James Gunn, future DC films will be crafted with more care and a genuine appreciation for the original comics, featuring a broader array of characters, rather than barely a handful.
